content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												I played 20 hours in my first weekend with this game. So, it's safe to say that I'm enjoying myself.The turn-based combat is fun, challenging, balanced, and only iron-man style saved games. The artwork and world are warhammer of course, so no problems there. The rpg elements and the numbers behind them are all out in the open, and the options for customization and skills are varied, but not too overwhelming.Your soldiers can receive permanent injuries from being knocked out in combat, which comes with visual changes like scars, lost eyes, peg-legs, etc...The style of any given type of weapon is customized to not only the faction, but also the type of unit within the faction (e.g. 'helmet' not only looks different for, say, sisters of sigmar vs mercenaries, but also for hero champions vs henchmen warriors within mercenaries).There's some recycling of map assets, but there are enough different layouts, orientations, and starting points that you don't really mind, and the story missions add some interesting variety on top of the standard 'route the enemy while collecting wyrdstones'. Also, the reason you can't collect all of the wyrdstones after the battle is that a) you auto collect some and b) lore-wise your soldiers are withdrawing from a dangerous area after some of them were wounded, so they don't have time to scour the whole place (the more are alive after the battle, the more stones you get). Although, I will admit that it is an imperfect solution.I find that the UI in battle is pretty intuitive, and usable with only a few buttons, but i see that others have criticized it. to each his own i guess.Some cons:a little too much waiting for animations and two clicks where one should do. Also, sometimes I wish I could get one unit past another in a doorway, hallway or some other narrow space.Some of the 'impressive' units are kind of lame. I don't really like the artwork on the ogre, for instance.I'm not really sure what it is all building towards, and sometimes it seems like the story missions are too few and far between as compared with the normal missions.face textures can be pretty bad, especially the youngblood mercenary, who has a 'punchable' facetoo often i have like a 95% hit chance that misses twice in a row, what is that a 0.25% chance of happening?theres this animation of throwing both arms back and opening the mouth in a silent scream that happens with almost every action or stance change that feels like a placeholder that should have been replacedi wish i could move/deploy units from the overhead map modehard to tell topographic info from the overhead mapthe ai is fairly easy to beat once you figure them out, although i only choose the 'normal' difficulty missionshaven't found much of a good use for the warlocksome tedious, minute upgrading after each battle, and some skills and traits that seem worthlesssometimes RNG is annoying, but that goes with the territoryall of my guys are waiting on me getting enough money for their skill upgrades, which isn't going to happen. I have a dozen guys, each with a few skill points to spend by now, but it costs either 100 or 200 gp to buy each one, and after paying upkeep, medical, recruitment, and equipment costs, i can afford to buy like one skill for one warrior every wrydstone shipment request period (like every 10 game days, during which I'll probably do 5 missions, or like 3 hours of gameplay about)repetitive loading screen messagesA lot of these cons are the sort of number tweaking or minor adjustment type things that could be done in a single patch (e.g. fix RNG percent chances, drastically lower skills gold costs, speed up or get rid of some animations, write more loading screen quotes, make some better face textures, allow deployment from tactical map, etc...), and I'd like to hope that they will be fixed in an upcoming update, although I have no idea about that.The comparisons to XCOM are inevitable, and generally unfavorable to Mordheim judging by the other reviews, but for what it's worth I played XCOM 2 for a couple hours before getting a bit bored/frustrated and moving on (temporarily, I'll give it another try later), but I played 20 hours basically straight of Mordheim the first weekend I fired it up, so take from that what you will.This is one of those games that is flawed, but very fun and keeps me coming back, like mount and blade, rome total war, and men of war (i don't mean that it's like those mechanically, of course)

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11
												As I dig this wyrd tick from my skin with the tip of my rusty dagger, I ponder why I traveled to Mordheim in the first place...nearly everyone I traveled with to this blasted city has died or disappeared. The weather is nearly as tempermental as the food and I've faced horrors I never wish to speak of or think of again.It seems whenever we strike a find of wyrsdstone or long lost gear, we lose someone to some thing. It is completely unfair...We hired an ogre once, Four-Tooth Tubbygut. We thought things would ge easier...we were wrong. The blasted bellower just attracted worse things. I remember that day well, I lost an eye and Heinrech...lost his life and let me tell you, losing a man while you're staring down the blood red, dead, eyes of a vampire is something you quickly won't forget.Sure, Ace McTwirlystache may make a shot that cripples one of those vile mutants allowing you and the gang to cease its diabolical existence but those moments seem to be so few and far inbetween. Everytime I look up to our leader Maximillion I realize it's Hubert Steinbor-...no wait it's Von Drakham, no wait it's someone fresh.Ha! Fresh blood in Mordheim, the only constant...again I ask myself why I first agreed to sign up for this damned company. Gold? Glory? Riches?Now that I think about it...I remember exactly why I signed up for this.*Thus ends the ramblings of Emrich the peg legged, one eyed, one armed wyrdstone gatherer*To the point. This is a brutal game. It is unforgiving and the odds are stacked against you. I would say this is less of a "RNG game" than it is a "how you adjust and react to a problematic situations". I say this simply because you will be faced with many rough situations.It's similar to Valkyria Chronicles with movement and the actions use a action point system in a sense as well. Many who jump into the game never come back because it's tough, it has a steep learning curve but just remember the Warband is what matters.Do not get attached to characters. They. Will. Die. They will get maimed and nigh useless. You will be forced into making decisions where their is no "good" outcome but "which is less worse".The warbands, and their are 6, play differently and have a different feel. Weapons balance is wonderful because a daggr can be just as useful, if not more so, than a halbred. A bow better than a handgun, it is up to you to figure out when it is best to use a certain weapon as well as how to build a character around a certain weapon. This game requires you to laugh when things go bad and to learn so you lower the chance of making the same mistake again (because honestly you will make that same mistake again).The story missions, which each warband has their own, are tough and should be tackled after you spend a decent amount of time learning the basics and gearing your warband out. They aren't amazingly done and honestly, they can be quite frustrating but they do break up the normal gameplay of warband fights and wyrdstone hunting.The AI is adequate and even though they do one of the largest pet peeves I have with video games (artificial difficulty by giving the AI stat buffs, depending upon the difficulty) it's fun. The AI matches its warband to yours, so if you bring a big guy they do, if you don't they don't. This way you can't rest on your heels with an all decked out warband, the opposing warband will always be a threat.Ultimately, the game has some flaws but I believe it is a game worth playing for a certain type of gamer. One that tackles a challenge expecting to learn something. Those who go in as an underdog who appreciates when they make a 30% hit 2 times in a row. Those willing to take chances for a big payout, at the cost of possibly suffering complete failure.As with most games, I recommend getting it on sale.

												A truly immersive game that will get you attached to your warband quibbles and injuries included any and all commanders will get a true sence of responsibility for their troops not wanting to put them into a no win situation. good AI that will predict your move and will try to outwit or flank your warband.A must have game in my library that I look forward to playing more and more and more 10 / 10, (especially when dwarves are added).Good customisation options for warbands, variety of weapons and tactics, good range of skills. content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												Mordheim is pretty impressive I have to say. A wonderful turn based strategy game, where you build up a warband of adventurers. Taking to the streets of this doomed city in pursuit of the ultimate treasure; Wyrdstones. A mystical magical element that is somewhat of a byproduct from a cataclysmic event. A bit like Aspertame being pooped from E.coli. That sort of thing.As a paper and pencil RPGer (in my youth) and having to deal with stats upon stats. This is a veritable wet dream of numbers and calculations. All required just to make sure you don't trip up over your boot laces while swinging heavy chunks of sharpened (or just blatantly heavy), metal around. Usually in the direction of something nasty. And there are plenty of bad guys to go around. Though this is a Warhammer based game, so who is good and who is bad is usually down to how many different shades of grey you are willing to tolerate. Each of the four factions (plus some more available as DLC), have their own agendas and each will be pitted against you one at a time as you rummage through the ruined city, seeking your fortune and glory. But beware, Mordheim is not an easy game. It is no doubt as harsh as it's tabletop counterpart and just as unforgiving. I  started my first campaign with the Sisters of Sigmar. A sect of violent battle NUNS with big hammers and even bigger thighs. And by the end of the second mission, three out of my five starting units had been hospitalised. My Hero unit had been laid up with internal bleeding. Then I had one lesser unit down with a shattered jaw. Good thing she wasn't a magic user, as she won't be uttering any incantations any time soon, if ever. And finally one poor lass got her leg chopped off and is now hobbling around with a broomstick shoved where only an orthopaedic surgeon would dare to go. And that was just the first TWO days (gametime), of their campaign. However, a few hours of gametime later. My nearly dead one-legged zealot (Oussia"Peggy"Praseck), has grown to be become one of my strongest units. And can dodge around on her up ended broomstick, faster than any other unit in the field. Like some sort of crazed holy paralympic ninja.... With a hammer !I didn't hold out much hope for a successful outcome during the first few hours. It all seemed so hopeless and against all the odds, yet I had a total blast with it. and stuck with it.  The strategy elements are functional enough and it's about as near to any tabletop simulation that as you can get. And although excessively tough on beginners. Once you have some gear and more warriors to field. The more smoothed out and even, the gameplay structure becomes. The background simulation is completely RNG based and as a result you have to prepare yourself for a beating. Though to be fair, the game does warn you regularly that it's more about how you cope with one atrocious situation after another. As opposed to being a total wargod and beating everything, all the time. Winning is a luxury and Mordheim reminds you of this constantly. With the high price of blood, sweat and tears that it takes, just to get the smallest of victories. However, if you are patient, keep your squad together and play smart. There is quite a bit that you can do to lessen the impact of injuries and fatalities. Neither of which are an absolute certainty, should any of your team come a cropper and be knocked out of the game. You can get lucky and have some just walk away from the ordeal with minor cuts and bruises. Again, this will be randomly decided at the end of the match. And is something you will be hoping for, considering the alternatives (Broken bones, severed limbs, amnesia or even permanent brain damage etc..). Which will result in that particular unit being forever handicapped in some way. Sometimes to the point of being rendered completely useless. But it's OK. Should this happen, you can always fire your crippled units as any decent humanitarian commander would.It could do with a little more "oomph" in the graphics department (Though I did come to this straight from playing DOOM. Which as you may or may not know, is glorious to look at. Even if the game itself is a bit rubbish). So Mordheim may appear to lack a bit of polish on that front, but it looks well enough and does feature some well designed characters / monsters. Other than that, it's just a really good game. With stacks of options and an excellent selection of customisation for each individual unit. If turn based strategy is your thing. And you want a challenging TBRPG that would give even The Darkest Dungeon a run for its money in toughness. You won't go far wrong with this one.Brilliant 8/10

content:
Posted: February 2
												Replaced Incubation (classic squad based strategy game) as my all time favourite game. I love the genre and really don't get why people bemoan the AI and difficulty so much. I read one review talking about how the only tactic is hiding in shadows which is utter rubbish. My standard is just to front up with a few tanks (parry and dodge so i can allow for the annoying wars that cant be parried) and hit them hard from distance too. All whilst one of my quick moving guys runs round and grabs all the goodies. Take advantages of the flaws like climbing up to a surface with a ranged char and standing on the only way up and enjoy picking off the AI warband with your pea shooters.Brilliant game and now i can't wait for the fact they are due to release a necromunda game.ps is it just me or is it actually good to be punished for your mistakes rather than mollycoddled so much. I love berating myself when wrong and just enjoy relaxing with a nice glass of port watching a well thought out strategy play out the way you intended

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												Very much a positive surprise. While I knew I liked the concept (I was a big fan of Necromunda back in the days), a smattering of bad reviews seemed to indicate that there was little strategy involved, and it was all based on luck. I should have known better. Ofcourse there is randomness, but there are almost always options, and as in many of the best strategy games it is a matter of adapting to bad luck and equally important to be ready to exploit good fortune.However, if you cannot cope with permanent loss of virtual people and goods, this is probably not a game for you. For me though, the higher the stakes the more I enjoy the game.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												I love Mordheim but this i'm not so sure.I was SUPER excited for this when I first heard of the computer re imagining!Eh but where to even start...  Well first thing the C64 tape deck like load times are slightly annoying but I can for the most part ignore this IF the game was worth playing in its current state.Looks and plays really neat once you are in game, the viewpoint when its the opponents turn is a little odd but not sure how this could be changed and sometimes I feel it is a little disorientating switching guys in 3rd person but only minor.Glad to see that ranged attacks have been tuned down as when I first played this at launch it was VERY strong.Not sure why the devs have gone with the obscene Health totals instead of models having a wound total? Changes things a lot as in the final tutorial mission the Plaguebearer has 350hp from memeory and my guys on a successful hit are only doing 20ish dmg? Makes no sense to me why life totals are so high and i'm sure this is how its staying at release. I would like to see a more faithful alternate system/mode so it is more like the TT version with dice rolls and normal wounds, somewhat like Bloodbowl having traditional mode and weird blitz mode that nobody plays.Only play single player if you love screaming at the screen and cursing RnG.

												First of all let me say that I am not familiar with the lore or Warhammer at all, really.With that knowledge I enjoyed the game but it has some very large issues which makes you want to uninstall it or smash it frequently. These include the random nature of it (95% chance to hit and I miss three times? Not DODGED, flat out missed). The bull♥♥♥♥♥♥actions the computer takes (I am in Ambush stance, the computer moves a guy perfectly along my threat area just enough to get behind me and hit my weak guy I was protecting with the ambush). Various other things like not being able to climb a ladder because one of your guys is too close to it, which I mean he is 5 meters away but I cannot takes within his aura. This includes looting, climbing, etc. I have put a lot of time into this game and about 40% of the time I hate and the other 60% I enjoy it. My absolute largest complaints are the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t "balance" the game does. No matter the difficulty the computer always has a stat advantage just because it's the computer. Not to mention the computer matches your own loadout. I bring three heros? They bring three Heros. I bring a leader, an impression and nothing else, they do the same thing. Rather than code some thought process into it the game just copies you.

												This is a first impressions view point, I'll update as I play further.This game is awesome! It's like vermintide and xcom had a baby. An evil festering baby! Its the only strategy game like this I've ever seen with WSAD movement controls which guarantees you can put your characters where you want them and wont have any of those OH #$%^ moments like you do in Xcom when you think you click behind that cover and your character instead jumps on the roof and dies!The rich lore of Warhammer is here in all of its immersive goodness. Currently with 4 factions, several different unit types for each and an arsenal of weaponry.A campaign that has some rogue like tendencies. IE once you unlock certain progressions the bonus applies to all of your armies from there on.My only complaint so far is that the % attack chances seem to be off. An enemy can frequently dodge repeated 70+ % attacks which can make for a rather frustrating experience when that easy minion you'd planned to finish off and then turn to assist your other unit becomes a complete route instead.That being said the game is new and I expect that one complaint to be rectified soon.I've included almost 2 hours of stream footage of the battles for those needing a bit more info before making a purchase. All in all a solid game!

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												The reason I would not recommend this game is because of the random number generator the game uses for the various tasks your characters perform.  I am not sure if others have had the problems I have, but at least for me, during each and every mission there would be streaks of terrible luck.  There would be six to seven tests in a row where the "80%" or higher chances would fail.  This was not an occasional thing, this was an every mission thing, and almost always took me from having the edge in a mission to either just succeeding or failing miserably.  I played dozens of missions, and these streaks would pop up in every single one.  In addition, though I always equipped my leader with the best parrying weapon and shield combo I could find, I did not make a single parry test the entire time I played, despite there being a "50%" or higher chance to block... and again, I will state that I played dozens of missions, each of which my leader would be hit multiple times while attempting to block.  I do not mind difficult games, I enjoy a challenge, but this did not feel like a challenge.  This was me being (rightfully) punished for tiny mistakes I made, but then being screwed over by the random number generator when I was doing everything right.  I would make tactically sound decisions only to have them blow up in my face- not just occasionally, but EVERY. SINGLE. MISSION. I. PLAYED.  Again, I am not sure if others have this problem as well, but from my experience this game needs either a re-work of their random number generator or a more realistic statement of the odds on a given action.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								UPDATED REVIEW:In spite of my initial review of the game being rather negative, especially with regard to the random number generator and other random aspects of the game, I have to say that the game kept me playing.  I've been playing the last couple of days, steadily working through a new campaign, and I am absolutely loving the game now.One thing that isn't very apparent when you start out is the fact that, in the early stages of the campaign, the game is brutal.  This is largely because your warriors don't have any skills, gear, or money to acquire new gear.  Similar to other campaign-oriented tactical games, like Darkest Dungeon, X-Com, Blood Bowl, etc., if you persevere with the "darwinian" nature of the early game--and simply understand that warriors will die--the game eventually 'opens up' as the warriors that do survive slowly acquire the skills and gear necessary to become even better.  As additional hero/warrior slots and types unlock, and the money starts flowing, things get better and better.The RNG can still be frustrating at times (most tactics games are like this), but as your warriors become more skilled and powerful, the chances for really bad streaks of 'bad luck' tend to be mitigated somewhat.  More than anything, with the right gear and/or stat increases, your warriors don't seem quite as fragile.At this point, if I could change anything about the game, I'd perhaps add a little more information to the in-game tutorial.  While it goes through the motions of showing you a handful of common things you can do, it doesn't really expalin why you would want to do said things.  For example, learning how to disengage from battles and drawing the enemy into ambushes is extremely important, especially in the early part of the campaign, when your warriors are weak and can't trade blows for very long without being knocked out of combat.  Keeping your warriors 'alive' is also vitally important, as rout tests are based on the morale/number of warriors you have on the field of battle.  Therefore, if you have a deeply wounded warrior, sometimes its best to run him back to your cart (or some other safe area), and just let him sit out the remainder of the battle (instead of being knocked out).The other thing that the tutorial doesn't really explain very well is the smuggler's den.  This part of the campaign game is extremely important, as it funds pretty much everything you do wtih your warband.  Without a fundamental understanding of how the smuggler's den works, you simply won't have the gold necessary to buy additional heroes/warriors, or pay for training, treatment, wages/pay, scouts, etc.All in all, I'm having  a lot of fun with the game now.  The initial hurdle of getting through the first few battles, and coming to grips with how each of the game's campaign systems work may have taken more than a few hours, but I have to say now that the game is really fun.  ORIGINAL REVIEW:This game has a lot of potential, and I like a lot of what I am seeing--however, that said, I can't find myself recommending this game (yet) for one simple reason:  The hideously random nature of the game is just too ridiculous.  Now, don't get me wrong, I'm not just saying this in a "kneejerk" kind of way.  I understand perception bias (that sense that you're ALWAYS getting bad dice/percentage rolls, when you really aren't), and I can appreciate the fact that the game is difficult (sometimes brutally so).  Having played many games in which the RNG is a major factor to your success, I am well aware that streaks of good and/or bad luck happen.   But the RNG is just the tip of the iceberg, and when combined with all of the other randam "elements" of the game, it just makes for an extremely frustrating experience.When you're not getting a string of bad rolls (say, five or six 75%-83% success failures in a row ... while the enemy team seems to never miss), you have to deal with unlucky positioning and/or creature spawns as you move your team around the map.  Because all movement is turn-oriented, and based on an initiative order, you're commited to your movements when you have no idea what's around the next corner.  In a general sense, this is fine, as it's all part of city-fighting.  But frustration sets in quickly when nearly every other mission spawns neutral creatures (like horrors, daemonettes, etc.) that utterly rip your team apart.  You make one unlucky move, and *bam* two of your warriors are dead.  You can't disengage.  You can't flee.  You're just dead.  And these aren't even "Hard" or "Brutal" missions--this is on "Normal". I played one mission where a daemonette murdered nearly the whole enemy team (they had two members left) as I strategically outlanked both the enemy team and the daemonette, while I raided their wagon.  Pretty cool.  But even with only two members left, the enemy team would not route.  And then the daemonette, apparently wanting to "share the wealth", ran all the way across the map to where the rest of my team was, and proceeded to murder one of my warriors.  After which, my team suddenly routed, even though I still had my leader and one more member than the enemy.  I instantly lost the mission.  While it was kind of 'interesting' and cool that I could "play" the daemonette to kill the enemy team, in the end, the totally "artificial" way in which the daemonette just ran across the map to murder my team and randomly cause a route was highly annoying.  Which leads me to my next issue:  routing.Routing seems completely random.  I can kill the enemy leader and half their team, and nothing happens.  But if my leader gats taken out, it's almost a certainty that my team will be instantly routed.  Route tests seem to happen without any kind of discernible indicator, too, besides some text.  One turn, everything is fine-and the next you simply lose.  LoL.  The concept behind being defeated by route testing is fine, but the implementation is poor and rather unsatisfying from a gaming perpective.  Which just about sums up the entire experience of this game.On its own, the RNG is fine.  In other games, like Blood Bowl, or Talisman, it's an integrated part of the gameplay--because you can either strategize around the randomness, or the game is simply driven by the randomness and centered more on making choices.  Mordheim is neither:  you can't strategize many outcomes because positioning, encountering and randomly spawed creatures of ridiculous strength ruin any "game plan" you might have; and at many times the combat does seem very driven by the randomness while not providing anything even resembling an interesting choice to make.  More often than not, you have to just sit there, selecting the same thing you've selected for the last three rounds, while you slowly watch your team get ripped apart by unlucky circumstances and dice rolls.I really want to like this game, but it just really seems to be missing something.  The only feeling I have while playing this game is one of intense frustration.  Which is really strange, because I absolutely love randomness and replayability in games.  Mordheim just doesn't have the right "mix' or synergy yet between randomness and game mechanics, and it's for this reason that I simply cannot recommend this game at this time.  That is not to say, however, that, in the future, this game will not be good.  As of now, the game is still in early access and many of the balancing and/or frustrating aspects of the game may still be tweaked.

												Casual gamers go home!Pro: Your desicions, goood or bad, REALLY affect your characters and game.Genuine feeling of accomplishment on victory.Con: No matter how good you are RNG can set you back hours, even days.High # of design choices neither smart nor fun. read: BATTLE LOOT BROKEN.TLDR;So much to love about this game. Dig in!

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								I typically play grand strategy titles but picked this up on a whim. I am glad I did. The game strikes a very good balance between challenge vs. playability, emersion, risk vs. reward, progression, etc.. I absolutely love the 3rd person point of view and feel of the game play. It gives you the illusion of playing out a mini adventure, each time you start a new mission. There are quite a few naysayers out there who exclaim that the game is too hard or unfair. This is a thinking man's game. You must plan out your actions carefully and execute. Do I risk splitting up to gather more reward or play it safe so that I have strength in numbers? If you like a challenging game that affords you the opportunity to imagine yourself as the leader of a small band of brothers (or rats, sisters, etc..) and enjoy advancement and progression, you will like this title. I am not crazy about the Warhammer universe, but the gameplay has me addicted...there is always one more thing I want to do before putting the game down...good mix of tactical play, overall strategy in mission deployment, warband management, etc..ProsImmersive Gameplay: You identify with your merry band of warriorsNail biting: Many missions will come right down to the wireChallenging Gameplay: Rewarding to those that want a challenge. Feeling of accomplishment. You earned your victory!Varied Maps and Mission set Ups: Every mission will be a bit different than the one before.Point of View: Refreshing 3rd person perspective that plays out before your eyes. It doesnt seem turned base...you are almost watching an action movie.Fog of War: What's in that house across the street? Should I risk going in and getting cornered? What about that treasure chest that's in there?Customization: Moderate character customization options. rename and tailor the look of your warband.Pick and Choose: though not really a sandbox game, you have some flexibility in picking the missions you want to play.Fun: I just enjoy playing the game. I cant put it down.ConsIron Man: No combat saves. For me, this adds to the game tension (risk vs. reward) so is not an negative, but the game is unforgiving. You will live with your mistakes (or die by them).Finesse Required: You must learn the tactics and how to play the game to get good at it. (Hint: Stay together!)Luck: There are some situations that amount to dumb luck (good and bad) that no amount of tactics will overcome. This hasn't occurred too often, but it does happen.Customization Options: what is available is good but wish there was more.Repetitive Missions: though I have not tired of the missions, they are similar in scope and style, save for the four story missions. Could become "grindy" for some.Review based on the solo campaign. I have not played the mulitplayer portion of the game.

content:

Early Access Review
								Let me start by saying that I bought this game a week ago, and I now have over 35h played; says a lot!If you are looking for a punishing (hardcore) turn based strategy game with Warhammer setting & lore, chances are you might love this game!There is a small learning curve (however tutorials will greatly help if you take the time to go through them) and controls & mechanics may take a few hours to master, but once you do, the game really becomes fun & immersive!Basically you create a Warband, customize it (for each member you get to choose its weapons, armors, skill points / attributes, spells, etc...) and then fight skirmishes against the AI or players. Shall you emerge victorious from a mission, you'll accumulate xp & loot/gear; however if a soldier falls in battle, he may become permantly injured (suffer from stats reduction).If you take the time to get inot the game, you will get attached to your warband, curse at your monitor when your captain/hero takes a few big hits, and celebrate when you finally overcome the enemy and see him routing.For a long time I have been looking for a PC port of Warhammer tabletop games, and it's finally here! I started playing Mordheim in October 2015 (early release), and I can say that at this point the game is quite polished. Sure, there's is room for improvement, but overall the game is definetly enjoyable in its current state.I cannot wait for offical release, and am keeping my fingers crossed for the addition of new factions. Would definetly love to see some greenskins (orcs & goblins), elves (dark, wood, or high elves) and dwarves!While I acknowledge this game may not be for everyone (its a turn based strategy game), personally I must admit that I've been having a blast! Hoping to see you on the battlefield, and looking forward sending your warband to the hospital xDMy score: 9.5/10Bull

content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								In 1999 I was 14 and very much an impressionable nerd. My friends were interested in Warhammer Fantasy and one of them got the 3rd Edition 40k starter box. I had a look at his White Dwarf magazines and Mordheim jumped out to me. A role playing games based on end-time conspiracy theory set in the WHFB universe. Of course in 1999 we had the whole year 2000 prophesy nuts going beserk.My first warband was the Cult of the Possessed, followed by the Witch Hunters. My friends played Skaven, Undead and Orcs, the last of which was released in White Dwarf magazine. My friend who played Skaven let his brother use the mercs from the starter box, and my own brother got the starter box and used mercs as well. On top of this, the table-top club we went to had about half a dozen guys also buy the starter box. In up, we had at least 12 people playing all different warbands every weekend for about 3 years.Around 2003, I moved away from my home town and stopped table-top gaming for a while. I picked it up again however in 2009 and started playing Mordheim again until 2011. Life was a lot faster and I couldn't play as much as I used to. When I heard about this game coming out, I immediately jumped on board the band wagon because of my teenage passion for it and rekindling the fires of my youth.Now for the game itself.I feel that the game could use a little spit and polish to improve a few graphical and sound issues (as well as some dodgy camera angles), but overall this game captures the feeling of playing the tabletop game. The music and visuals are incredibly atmospheric and the turn based nature of the game works well as a translation of the table-top to the PC. Would I change any gameplay elements? Not really. The only real thing i'd like to see added is the ability to play a multiplayer campaign against friends or with jump-in games to mix things up a little bit.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
Product received for free
												I've tested it during 3 day free trial.TLDR: Good idea for a game, balanced mechanics, but with some frustrating little inconsistancies, bugs, and too little content per race. Try it, for a few warband levels, if you like it, buy it, if not, you probably won't like it in the future.Pros:+ tutorial explains the basics, however there are some rare situations, when I find myself wondering what will happen if XYZ... and those situations are unexplained...+ combat mechanics are good, well balanced (except 2x1H weapons:( - they should change that for sure), charge, ambush, dodge, parry stances are all OK, however they should add a contant reminder for begginers, what costs what, so you can plan ahead, instead I've found myself lacking 1 movement or attack point, that could be spared if I knew it beforehand...+ looting, equipement and RPG elements for every one single unit is very good, XP gains are slow, but not too slow. you get points to distribute, when you get each 1/4 of a level.+ each of the unit, have many stats, that are clearly explained, so you know what you must do, to get better at what you want.+ game offers a decent challange regarding difficulty... some missions are harder, some easier, some you can win without losing a single unit+ good number of maps (12 i think is the number now), that have numerous types of deployment rules, with random wyrmstone gems and chests to scavenge for. Also i think there are seperate maps for campaign special quests but im not sure. also the side quests, are quite interesting and valuableCons:- you cannot change armor/weapon proficientcies for any unit, so if you want to make an archer from a meelee fighter, you can't... also you can't for example use hammers for warrior that uses maces. so you're stuck with those weapons that devs set up for this specific unit.- there are for every faction only: 1 leader, 3 hero units, 2 henchmans, and 1 giant unit (counts as 2) to choose from... so it lacks diversity in regards to units (not factions). At one time, you can only have 10 units on the battlefield, and thats a good number, not too high, not to low.- skills are too expensive, so for the first 20~ games, youre stuck with generic units, even if you got ability points to spend. you will lack money, or you will not want to waste precious warrior in next few battles, to instead learn a new skill in X days.- equipement picked up, and then dropped by your dying unit, dissapears after winning game, unless you pick it up, by some other unit... wich is quite annoying. also you only get a very small percentage of whole loot on the map, after winning, so sometimes you find yourself stalling, and scavenging instead of killing the enemy right away.- some sidequests in campaign are very hard to do, and others are very prefered. you always get 2XP plus additional 3XP for sidequests, where for a win, you get only 2XP. so a mission without a completed sidequest is worth 1/2 of the other one... again you sometimes have to stall to get the side objective done- there are some UI issues, that should be handled... it feels like a console game with control scheme and hints. however there should be some options added that would help to orientate, for example: overhead unit icons, and maybe custom icons for each unit... also scavenge and wyrmstone sites are marked on map, but when its inside a 3 story building, you must run thru whole of it, to find it. mark it clearly OR just disable those markings, and add more of those points to collect, so you must find it yourself, but its easier. also only recently I've found out how to check, wich specific unit is in the initiative queue next (shift and then E/Q)- shop pricing is quite strange... warband lvl 1, can only buy white basic items (swords, shields, bows, clothing etc), for about 10 gold. but there are also rare enchantments available for 300 gold +. they shouldn't be available for lvl1 warband, or they should add some small enchantments for low lvl warbands.- you cannot skip nor speed up the animations- there are some combat inconsistancies... for example: enemy charged my unit on stairs, he attacked me, but I couldn't attack him back (I couldn't move becouse of being engaged in combat with another unit)... example 2: I could charge at enemy, so i did. but my character got stuck, and run for few seconds into a wall, then stopped at this place and I couldn't attack the enemy, so i was forced to end my turn. example 3: archers are engaging meelee characters, so if you attack an archer, you must disengage to move, even though they cannot attack you, and they have no attacks of opportunity... ALSO example 4: stunned enemies also keep you engaged in combat, so you cannot move away... wich is stupid in my opinion. there are some strange movement inconsistancies, for example, if an ally unit, climbs the wall, and ends their movement there, you cannot climb it with any other unit, even if you could move after that climbing. tutorial says, that sphere of influence around your character, lets you run though it, but you cannot stop your movement there, and thats true, but only on flat. next: ambushing near corners: when you setup an ambush stance very close to a corner, and enemy will enter your sphere of influence, before your unit sees it, the ambush doesn't trigger. and when you setup an ambush stance on a climbing spot, the enemy can climb, but it wont trigger the ambush (again because he entered sphere of influence before your units sight... ) PS: you cannot ambush enemies from above:(offtopic... things I would like to see: ambushing from above / below, more items (random item generation?), horseback riders, flying units, maybe some mortars or other artillery types, traps that you can place on the ground, more casters and spells, 'pets' or other uncontrollable small monters or animals that fight alongside, movement abilities (grappling hook, magical bridges, etc), other gamemodes: CTF?, defender/attacker?, 2v2 games?, coop campaign?

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												This game makes me do something that I haven't done in a long time. Shake my fists in fury at the screen and shout at it like a child "The Game Is Cheating!". In all honesty though every time I think I am getting ahead in the game on campaign mode I just get smacked down, by either my scouts failing to see an enemy warband leading to my guys getting ambushed, or just not being able to land a strike on certain opponents. It is infuriating but also fun, A diabolical mixture that these folks at Rogue factor have put together, that shreds my patience while making me want more of the short lived thrill when I overcome some ridiculously  stacked odds. I definitely recommend getting this game and familiarizing yourself with it. I have played this game for a decent amount of time and still enjoy it. The only things that would make it better for the time being would be some sort of supported multiplayer search, and some more TLC from the Devs. Over all a fun and somewhat time consuming game.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Firstly, I only own this game. I have been a fan of Mordheim from the TT days. When I read on Rock Paper Stone that Mordheim was about to be turned into a PC game, I instantly upgraded my rig, and created a Steam account.I purchased and have not looked back since. I joined the community {basically The Gentlmen of Mordheim} and participated in this EA - there have been issues, desyncing and invisible blocking and the attacking through walls etc.That said this game is REMARKABLE the translation from  TT is not faithful or prefect, but what Rogue Factor has given us is a beautifully rendered visual experience, accompained at times with sublime gameplay. Let's pause a minute and discuss the visuals. The City itself really captures the menace and threat of all the literature I have read about Mordheim. The streets are barren and forboding. The architecture exactly how I imagined it should be. The skies are dark and full of ominous promise. The whole vista is a sight to behold. I can't wait to see the finished article.The modelling is exquisite - the Skaven have been captured magnificantly, not only the detailing but also the character. RF's Skaven are simply a work of art, easily imo unstriping the attempts at Rattyness that Vermintide is showing us.Watching a rat socerer cast a mist is a joy to behold. Or the way they run, with their arms out to the side, clutching a pair of Warplocks and their cloaks flaring out is WONDERFUL!The way the Sisters raise a Sigmarite to the heavens when invoking a blessing is spot on!I could go on and on...All of the Warbands look fantastic - RF should win an award for their creativity and sheer brilliance!The gameplay can be riveting - so many tactical choices to be made. Placing a unit in front of a trap and waiting for an opponent to attempt a charge, and getting stopped by the trap is a particular fav of mine.Setting up a sheildwall and halting an enemy in it's tracks and then using ranged to slowly dismantle the enemies ranks, is another joy.Now with Progression this game has reached new heights. Apart form all the incredible management options the Hideout now affords us - the arrival of progression makes the choices of where to put the points even more important. The injury system really injects, tension and drama - I have two rats with only one arm each!! I could go on and on - but this game is a MUST HAVE for any fans tactical/turn-based strategy games.ROGUE FACTOR BE PROUD VERY PROUD!!!BUY-BUY YES-YES!!!!!10 out of 10 and it isn't even finished!!!!

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												A genius conversion of tabletop game Mordheim. What else to say. for GW outsider.... X-COM, man, with wyrdstone harvesting - if you love it, buy this without hesitation. It has it own set of rules but basically same turn based system with initiative, strategy, various classes and weapons. Technical point - it gets tweaks, patches, new content and so far has very reasonable DLC policy ... quite unseen nowadays. + Great classic turn based RPG elements+ Narrating, story, misions for all four warbands+ Graphic and technical processing+ Steady learning curve, very unforgiving dificulty when you just start+ Mutation chaos events, injury and permament injuries system. Loosing an eye wil affect your hero both graphically and for stats and issues like hit rating. Quite like this! Crack their heads to force stupidity checks!+ Rout system+- RNG- AI is stupid, really. The high dificulty is just made plainly by higher stats, numbers, sheer advances of their weapons and armor. Still, it's still on ok level but if you got two brain cells, you will eventually beat it... guess this game makes sense more for multiplayer :)- No option to change dificulty. Prepare for hard ride especially in the beginning!- Tutorial is rather confusing, mix of level playing and just texts with pictures. Had to elaborate myself the veteran perk system issue ...- Unlimited enemy reinforcements in story misions. If you loose some precious turns, you will get swarmed (especially if your party is not proper prepared)9/10  I claim to be affected by my love to warhammer world so deduct at least two point if you are not :)

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												My only complaint is that the success estimates for attack/dodge/parry are not accurate. I'm not harping on the random number generator -what I'm saying is that it's obvious the estimates do not take all modifiers for both parties into account. It's common in Mordheim to miss 5-6 times in a row with a 90% hit chance, or to get smacked 3-4 times in a row by an Impressive even though you're in dodge stance with 95% dodge rate. The odds of these bad runs happening should be one in a hundred, one in a thousand, or worse. But you will see one or two each skirmish at higher level play. It's quite frustrating.Other than that, the game is fantastic. Check out Valkyria Chronicles if you're looking for similar mechanics wrapped up in JRPG window dressing.

												I have very fond memories playing the original tabletop version of Mordheim, so I was a bit nervous when I first tried out this adaptation. However, after a bit of a learning curve, I can say that it holds very true to the original and is a blast to play. Let's be clear - this game is brutal. There is no, "oops, I'll just reload a that save point" here. But that is something I love about it - you have to live with what happens to your warband, and a a story develops to explain the various skills and ailments of your members. This is something very unique to this game.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												This is not an easy game. Not a casual game. If you thought the likes of Xenonauts or other micro-management games caused you anxiety and a sense of overwhelmedness, this just ups the quotient. There is no hand-holding in this game. In fact, the tutorials are just as likely to end with you defeated as with a victory. Which is a good thing. It confirms to you just how unforgiving it will be when you actually engage the gameplay. Everything you do is tracked from the word go - the only semi-casual element would be the skirmish mode where you can play free of consequence to your warband. Otherwise, all actions and consequences follow you from the git-go.This is a tough game to recommend. Am I happy to play it? yes. does it feel fun? yes. was it easy to crack the ice that surrounds it like a diamond shell? no. But get that crack and it begins to spread and reveal the gem I hope to continue to find it to be.And while I know this dates me as the less-than-young man I am, a game like this truly makes me pine for the days of game manuals that were hundreds of pages long. A nice heavy book to occupy your mind and time AWAY from the screen and equip you with the tools and skills you will most benefit from when you set to playing.  Just an observation, but I do miss those days.A few more missions in and I must say this is just incredible. The damage/reward system is very crucial to optimizing your experience. upgrading is not easy to come by, but so very pivotal when you have the chance. And the RPG elements of equipment management also lend a very fine touch of color to this fantastic tactical strategy gem.  major thumbs up

number of helpful: 22 of 40 people (55%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Only pick this up on sale. I really enjoy the basic gameplay but am dissapointed by the severe lack of customization options, ugly character models, and poor animations. Considering the turn based nature and lack of action oriented gameplay it should be rather easy to create nice pre-canned animations, but instead they remind of an mmo decades past. Minimal effort put in. The animations for ranged attacks are the worst of the bunch because they don't pitch up or down. For the price they normally ask for this product and considering when this was released I expect much better. Edit: It is also worth mentioning that the graphics advertised are not what I have actually experienced despite system specs which can handle the game twice over and having all settings at maximum the game looks quite poor and more like a 2009 release. This may be due to the fact that I have AMD and apparently this game has trouble with AMD. So beware of that if you too have an AMD card. Highly frustrating not being able to enjoy the graphics. The DLC is a complete ripoff and incredibly lazy in it's implimentation. They could not even be bothered to create one faction specific unit for each faction so two of the four are shared between factions. The new Witch Hunters faction is incredibly ugly, their primary units are so despressing to look at, yet if they could be customized to a greater extent this could perhaps be forgiven, but it seems this newest faction has even fewer customization options than the others. Hope you like having anorexic, half naked, self-flagellation obsessed old men as the backbone of your fighting force! I get that it's cannon, but the execution is quite poor. It's the lack of variation in appearence and the fact that the vision the developers had far exceeds religious flagellation and takes a turn into chaos level self mutilation. It's overdone. Also there's no hounds... no ♥♥♥♥ing hounds.Edit: The dlc is even worse than I initially thought because any army of order can use the human dlc heroes and any army of destruction can use the skaven and chaos dlc heroes. The joy of a game like this is the asymetric balance, letting units move from one warband to another kills that and it really makes me never want to take part in pvp. So despite owning these special units I never use them because it cheapens the experience and breaks immersion. Why they could not develop one special unit for each warband and release it as one character pack is beyond me, but if many more units are added in this way you'll start seeing primarily mercenary warbands in pvp that have little connection to their actual warband. Already too many wolf priest builds going around as it is. Really really bad design choice on part of the developers. Asymetric balance is key in a game like this and every deviation from it will kill the experience a little more. The gameplay itself is pretty fun and does a decent job capturing the feel of a tabletop game for the most part. Unfortunately it's bogged down by a grind oriented campaign that has you doing the same thing over and over and over. There are a few different scenarios, but that merely changes how you deploy, not the objective which is to eliminate or route the opposing team. Story missions change it up a bit, but not enough to make it feel fresh. And while there is a pvp component that ought to be fun, it's just more of the same. It lacks the fun social element of a tabletop experience. Also playing the pvp mode that enables injuries and looting is a huge risk considering the intensive grind that goes into getting decent units, and the safe mode is without risk or reason to play, though you may learn a trick or two. I like the hardcore element, but leveling up is far too arduous. I think the most frustrating element is that you can rarely complete secondary objectives for their xp boost because the enemy team routes and essentially ends the round. Thus any unclaimed salvage, unclaimed loot, and unclaimed wyrdstone dissapears. Sure you get a few bones for a victory, but it's pitance in comparison. Furthermore this makes no sense. If they ran away, why not let me get everything? What's stopping me? Why make me game the system and spend three hours emptying a map only to realize that doing so is insane and a total bore. Fixing this issue alone might go a long way towards making the game feel less like a grind. The game needs some fresh ideas and a strong multiplayer component if it wants to have any real staying power, right now it's one of those titles you buy on sale, play for a week or two and then forget about. It's a real shame too because this game does have potential. The underlying mechanics are sound for the most part, but everything built off of them needs to be reconsidered. Bottom line: If you are interested in this title and enjoy turn based gameplay then snag it next time it drops below $20. However you'll most likely regret spending anything more than that.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												This game is really fun, and extremely enjoyable. However, expect to get frustrated and absolutely hate this game at times. That said, you might find yourself lucky and absolutely adore this game. The reason why I wrote the love/hate mix is because although this game is a lot of fun, at the start you'll struggle. Then again maybe you won't. You'll experience bugs from time to time, some minor, others major. For example, there's no timer at the moment, or at least there's no timer that I'm aware of. So if the enemy bugs during their phase, you'll find yourself stuck in the game "waiting for your opponent" and you'll be stuck waiting for the B'stard forever untill you decide to leave. Now, you can't leave without taking punishment as if you lost. This happened to me, one of my Warband *party* died, and the other lost his arm (he was my archer!). So because of this bug, a bug which I experienced when I had only just started a game, two of my warband were seriously hurt/killed. Bummer I know.I haven't had any problems with bugs for a while now, but I'm sure they're waiting for me. I'm also finding the right pace to play at for me. When I first started playing I died a lot, I'd make and break warbands because the game frustrated me. But then I started to think more, plan more. I haven't lost in a while now, sure a few lost hands and broken feet but you can't expect to come out of each game without a scratch.This game was hard, is hard, but I'm slowly getting better, stronger, and I'm having much more fun. You might follow this pattern, you might not.9/10 I would tell my friends to buy this game, but I wouldn't tell that one friend (we all know one) who would tear out his computer and throw it out of a window. Be patient and you will enjoy this game!

												Game has been steadily improving with updates.Sigmarite Greathammer is a nice addition, would be nice if it had a unique model and texture though because it currently looks exactly the same as the regular Greathammer.It's nice that they added a new war band and new units as DLC, and I hope they add yet more in future.I would really like to see a Night Goblin war band with Squigs and Loons, and a Chaos Demons war band that actually lets you field the demon units in the game. I want to field a Daemonette :P the model is reeeealy nice.It's way more optimized and stable than it was.There are still long pauses during the AI turn while you wait for the enemy units to move around the map. It would be really nice if they could figure out a way to speed up enemy movement when you cant see the units anyway, this game has allot of downtime when your not really playing, just waiting.It's hard to find good srpg's, and this one is actually not too shabby.Good lore, good atmosphere, plenty of grimdark, and nice music thats appropriate to the game.For all it's flaws this game is getting better, and I hope the developer continues to improve it and add to it. It already has a special place in my heart as there is nothing else quite like this out there.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												You know a game is good when it keeps you playing for long. That is certainly the case with this game.The movement is clunky, you sometimes get lag when you attack enemies, your actions and enemy actions take long to perform and you miss so much that the battle lasts at least 1.5 times longer. The sub-objectives in various missions can't be completed fully because the enemy either runs out of units, you miss a lot or you don't have enough SP to get all the resources, When you pick up some of the resources your units run out of space very quickly and the only way to get more is to go back and forth between scavenging locations and your treasure chest.You typically get to do one or two actions per turn on one unit at a time (for example, on low SP unit you attack and then use a stance). It starts to feel monotous after a while.I'd enjoy the game more if the tutorial explained things in more detail and if you could do more in battle each turn.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												This game certainly won't be for everyone, that much I can say.It's difficult and unforgiving.  You will get frustrated.  You will also get excited, scared, anxious...it's the type of game that causes tension because you know a mistake, or just some bad luck, could erase one of your party members permanently.  You know, that guy you're real proud of that's been kicking♥♥♥♥♥and taking names?  Yeah he's dead now.  Or maybe he just lost an eye if you're lucky and his stats are crippled in some way.You never really feel safe in this game.  Every time you venture out, even to missions you feel "good" about, bad things could happen if you don't pay attention.  If you get impatient, push a little to far, or if you just have a run of bad luck.But that's what makes the game great, because everytime you go out and come back alive you feel like you've achieved something.  Even the "junk" weapons you bring back are, at least for me in early game, a boon.Truth be told, I still haven't even completed the first story mission.  I have a warband (party) put together that I've been playing with for a good five hours, and I'm not 100% sure what to expect...so starting that mission might be pushing the reset button.  Or it might be glorious.Guess I'll go find out.

												This is a great conversion of the tabletop game - not exactly the same, but it captures the look and feel of Mordheim incredibly well.  The battles are intense and deadly, the environment hostile (sometimes frustratingly hostile - forget that at your peril - perfect for Mordheim).  The warband customisation is very satisfying - you can easily spend as long tweaking your warband as you spend fighting battles (just like the tabletop game).If you know and love the tabletop game you should love this game too.  If you do not know the tabletop game, it is good enough to stand on its own merits.While the game feels complete, there is plenty of scope for the addition of other warbands and individual heroes - bring on the Undead and especially the Witch Hunters!

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												Great Strategy game where you get to manage your own squad of warriors. Good amount of story telling in their journey. They can get injured and lose limbs, eyes, and more. If you like xcom then I'd definitely give this a shot!I would like to see some more weapons and gear, the current selection is a bit limited. Some may find the game play repetitive, but I personally love it.Would love to be able to equip battle scarred warriors with things like hooks and eye patches.The RNG may make you rage, but ultimately a clever leader will regularly bring their war band to victory. Yes you will lose people, sometimes for stupid reasons that you couldn't control, but such is war.I see some people hating on the game for RNG. Personally I like the challenge and honestly it's not a super hard game I win like 90% of the time and only lose people every 7 missions if that. Yes I do rage at the skaven when they triple dodge my swings but I get them in the end. I will say this, if you're looking for a walk in the park game where you can just beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of enemies this is not that game.I will levy one bit of criticism against a particular RNG element in the game.The smite or "magic kill debuff" is really unecessary. In the game using any spell has a chance of giving your spellcaster one of a variety of debuffs or negative actions. Some examples are:-turn ends immediately-reduced accuracy for a couple turns-other stat debuffs like hit chanceOne of these negative actions in response to ANY spell cast could be a smite which deals 9999 damage to the caster and thus insta kills them. This can happen to your casters or the NPC team casters and I've seen both. Ultimately it's too strong a penalty and I think it stronglty discourages using casters. The other debuffs are one thing, but the insta kill is too much. Why have a caster when you could just recruit another melee hero who has no chance of dying on an arbitrary action? It already takes a ton of money just to teach them spells so why bother?This is the games biggest weakness in my opinion and I wish they would remove it. Even when it happens to the opposing team it's usually not a big enough deal that it changes the tide of battle and if that is the point of it, an RNG mechanic that can change the tide of battle, it can be done in a lot of other more interesting ways.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												Quite a nice tackle on one of the gems of the pre MMORPG offline gaming epicness.What I expected: A somewhat DoW2 influenced brawling game looslely tied together by the mordheim theme.What´s actually in the game: A careful adaption of the tabletop game. The one thing that I imagined beeing a flaw in gameplay was the Action point system, since I´m quite a diehard fan of the tabletop I feared that it wont "feel"like mordheim. Boy was I wrong :DShort explaination: Your fighters can use their AP to move arround, reclaim AP´s by simply going back the path you used. So you are able position them tactically and set up traps, find nice sniping spots... But be careful of the chaotic infestations on the ground, walls and in corners, they will interrupt your movement if a charater gets too close and set´s it off. This will end a movement substep, and a char cant reclaim the AP´s he used till he hit the trap.The experince system is a bit different, as well as the attributes. It´s heavily influenced by the Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay system and it works really great!The procedural map generator is really cool, and the campaign special scneraios bring a lot of flavour with them, and you´re able to field the dramatis personae of your warband to the skirmish.resumé - If you like turn based tactical games you really should consinder the game, even if you haven´t got a tabletop background. If you like the Warhammer Universe and especially the Mordheim theme, it´s almost a must buy.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Mordheim: City of the Damned is a turn-based, squad-level tactical game set in the devastated city of Mordheim. You begin by choosing a warband - the current choices include four different warbands with (what is currently) a basic variety of units, spells, and abilities. You manage what units from your warband you will take into combat within Mordheim. Some are more capable than others overall (heroes) and their inherent unit statistics vary leading to variety in capability - in other words, units with higher agility have higher dodge and hit chances, higher toughness means shrugging off damage, intelligence affects spell-casting, so on. The unit statistics can be viewed from your warband management screen, along with equipped weapons, armor, abilities. Currently you can only change armor and weapons (from some basic choices with differences in combat effects) and swap out your warband units. The plan is for your units to gain experience as the game's development progresses, thus making your units more powerful (and mitigating some of the RNG effects). Most units can currently carry two sets of weapons for tactical variety. Weapons such as swords allow the user to parry while halberds hit hard but suffer an accuracy penalty. Some weapons apply debuffs when they hit enemies (poison blades, warplock pistols, etc.) that can stack and ruin someone's day.Each unit has two types of points - blue points for movement actions and red points for offensive actions. Blue points allow your units to move, climb walls, jump down ledges, reload ranged weapons, flee from opponents, swap weapon sets etc. Red points allow you to attack, cast spells, etc. Some actions require combinations of both (for example, safely disengaging from an enemy without provoking an attack of opportunity requires the use of both types of points, or taking full aim with a ranged weapon).The turn order for units is displayed at the top of the screen but since units of the same type utilize the same icon the information provided isn't as useful as expected. Turn order is determined through initiative based on unit statistics. You can also zoom out from a unit by pressing the LALT key, giving you an overview of where your units are currently stationed, any visible enemy units and previous known locations of currently out-of-sight enemies (marked with a ?). This is extremely useful as Mordheim's devastated and maze-like city streets can be difficult to navigate otherwise.Action success is percent-based, so you can clearly see your chances prior to performing any action. This is of course where RNG effects can be extremely frustrating, but again, once experience gains are implemented stronger units should help mitigate this. Like a lot of turn-based tactical games with these mechanics risk management is an extremely important aspect of the battlefield.There are lootable points on the battlefield and dead enemy soldiers will sometimes drop 'special' weapons (in other words weapons with different statistics, or essentially 'magic' weapons). You can't permanently keep them in your inventory at present but in the future this should impart a sense of unit progression and reward the player for succesfully defeating opponents.Graphically the game is well-done - on the highest settings the game is crisp, runs smoothly and has nice effects. The music is suitably dark considering the setting and lends an appropriate 'doomed' quality to the atmosphere. Those who don't enjoy the Warhammer universe's grimdark grimdarkness might have to overlook these items to enjoy the gameplay.There's quite a bit more to be done in Mordheim. I personally am looking forward to unit progression and the loot system. As it stands the game provides you with one-off skirmishes between warbands to give you a taste of the game's combat and gameplay. If you love games such as X-COM, Xenonauts, UFO: Afterseries, or essentially any squad-level turn-based game you'll definitely enjoy this. Keep an eye on it - if they don't fug it up this could be great.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												As a avid player of the tabletop mordheim and a player of Games workshops other games (Warhammer, W40k ect.) I find this game is a true homage to one of it's first true tabletop experiences, without (Well mostly) the obsessive power creeping that has come from it's latest instalments of tabletop games Setting Mordheim, as the name is stated, is played in the once great imperial city which is now just empty corridors and frigtening manisfestations of chaotic energy. And Mordheim the video game doesn't dissapoint. The city itself is well presented and offers the true tabletop experience, baring a few things that tabletop players are farmiliar with such as a birds eye view of the battlefield and no fog of War.In a way this makes the game feel more like a discovering city fight than the all omnipotence view we as tabletop players come to expect, that is there are no way of knowing where your oponent is unless you take the energy to find them. I was genuenly surprised when my character walked out of a door to suddenly come face to face with a Rat Ogre. Boy did that make me a bit paranoid for open doorways and back alleys.Overall The setting is what you would expect from this game, it hits the spot with not only a pinpoint nail, but also the flying hammer behind it. Gameplay Let it be known that the games i enjoy all have one thing in common, and that is not how pretty or how vibrant the world is, I am not a gamer who thinks of such trivial things so zealosly. Instead i find that the games i enjoy all have mechanics that are both easy to pick up and hard to master.Mordheim is no different, it's mechanics very farmiliar to my knowledge of the tabletop game, with a few good exceptions. The Combat sequences do feel like they have that tabletop feel to them (Such as the no guarantee of doing a stance such as dodge or Parry), this is a good thing. It shows that the developers reseached their source material well. However I did notice other things in game which vary way differently than their tabletop Counterpart. These features were noticeably different and feel more on the side of a computer game than a tabletop. And result in things that are rather alienating compared to it's tabletop counterpart (Which is a suggestion of you shouldn't believe everything that is being portraiyed in this game as it's tabletop counterpart) other than the few things that felt like they didn't feel right I had no quams with the system as it was hitting pretty close to home Extra Features Mordheim doesn't really feel like mordheim until you add the one core component from it's tabletop edition into the game, if it didn't have this it would just feel like a city fight of Warhammer Fantasy, and i would say as a person who has playedc both, they are SOO not the sameInstead the introduction of the persistant warbands and the campaign system trully make this a very well made recreation of the tabletop game and make every fight and every warband that much more investing to the player. It's not a simple matter of making a dream warband and proceeding to curb stomp every opponent out there but rather seeing your characters become the warriors they are from every bloody battle you encounter. You as a player pour your time and effort to make your characters an extension of yourself, which makes it all the more harder when those same characters lose vital parts of themselves or even perish from your roster permanently.Mordheim the tabletop game was unforgiving to it's players and made them that much more invested in the survival or their warband, Mordheim the PC game delivers the same hit, time after time. Verdict Overall, I feel  that this game is truly a great extension of it's tabletop counterpart and it makes due of it's promise to give you that genuine tabletop experience. If you are a veteran of the tabletop game i would highly invest in this. For those who haven't played a tabletop game i would suggest you try this out. The concepts and mechanics can help you get through the trial stages of learning this remarkable and addictive game.9/10

My 10 lvl  Skaven warband, which after God knows how many missions still was injury free and was finally all geared up in purple got wiped out. Every warrior got some horrendous injury and some equipment got lost. Starting the turn surrounded, on deadly difficulty and watching all of your most valuable warriors getting gangbanged isn't fun at all. I like the challenge, but this is just unreasonable and broken.Still recommend this game as had much fun until now. However, not sure if I will ever launch it again at this point.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								As was the case with The Long Dark, Mordheim: City of the Damned is in early access and will be reviewed as such. At a later date (when the game is officially released) we will come back and update our review of it. The score we will give at the end of this review is the score for the game as it is right now. And, on that note, let’s get rocking.I – Story [8/10]Mordheim: City of the Damned is a turn-based strategy game (with some RPG elements mixed in) from Rogue Factor. It is a digital adaptation of the tabletop game Mordheim from Games Workshop. Set in the city of Mordheim (part of the amazing world of Warhammer) a comet has crashed and turned the whole city into a horrific battleground for bands of mercenaries from across the land. The prize? Fragments of Wyrdstone that came from the comet and that are scattered throughout the city.It’s not the most intriguing of stories (and, let’s face it, this was originally a tabletop game), but I rather liked it. Not to mention the gorgeously morbid setting in an absolutely immersing universe.II – UI [5/10]There were very few things I didn’t like about the user interface as it sits now. Accessing individual unit stats and action menus is easy as can be, but (again, this is still in early access and will hopefully change) the lack of functionality in the tactical overview map is disappointing. It is often times hard to plot out your strategy on the overview map and then attempt to put it into action in real time. A minimap would definitely alleviate this problem to an extent, but increased functionality of the overview map should definitely find its way into a future update of the game.The really troublesome thing about the user interface is the incredibly awful camera angles during your opponent’s turn. I can’t stress enough how annoying the camera angles are during action phases that are not yours. Sometimes you’ll be looking at a unit in a completely different area of the map that has nothing to do with what is currently happening and that is if you get lucky. More often than not, you’ll be looking at some scenery. While that isn’t necessarily a bad thing in and of itself (the environment is fascinating), it gets obnoxious in a hurry.As far as actual action animations go, the camera angles need some work, but the animations themselves are pretty nice.III – Gameplay [10/10]I love the gameplay in M:CotD. I’m a newcomer to the Warhammer universe for the most part, especially the fantasy side of it, but M:CotD is genuinely fun.There are currently two modes of play. The first mode, “Battleground Only”, is essentially a deathmatch. The object of this mode is to either kill all of the enemy’s units or cause them to rout, effectively forfeiting the skirmish. This (alongside the tutorials) is a good way to become familiar with the mechanics of gameplay.The second mode of play is “Extra Objectives”. In this mode you can win the skirmish in the same way you can win a “Battleground Only” match or by being the first to complete a secondary objective. There are three secondary objectives: “Marked For Death”, “Crush Their Will”, and “Wyrdstone Rush”. To complete “Marked For Death” you will need to kill specific units of the enemy’s warband and collect their belongings as proof. To complete “Crush Their Will” you will need to steal the Idol of the enemy’s warband and stash it in your chest. To complete “Wyrdstone Rush” you will need to gather a certain percentage of all the Wyrdstone on the map. Also, your team and the enemy team could have different secondary objectives or you could have the same one. It keeps things interesting.You also have the ability to alter the roster of your warband. Other things you can manage is what equipment certain units have and how their skills are being developed. You gain experience the more you play with your chosen faction. IV – Content [7/10]For M:CotD to be in early access, it has a fair amount of content already. There are four playable factions to chose from currently (Empire Mercenaries, the Cult of the Possessed, the Sisters of Sigmar, and the Skaven Clan Eshin), four playable maps, a good diversity of units for each faction, and a good smattering of items to equip your warband with. As it is now, is there enough content to justify the price tag? Probably not. At least, not quite yet. There is still more than enough to keep you going for a good long while though.V – Visual [10/10]Now we’re coming to the aspects in which M:CotD really shines the brightest. The graphics are beautiful; both character models and the landscape. Everything is dark and gloomy and the atmosphere is to die for. Every unit is intricately detailed and wonderfully animated. The environment may be the best part about M:CotD. It might be Hell on earth, but it is an unforgettable place to visit.VI – Audio [10/10]We have now reached what I consider to be the greatest part about M:CotD: the music. The music in this game is perfect. It really sets the feel for every single battle and incursion into the cursed city. Not only this, but the sound effects are incredibly well done. As far as sights and sounds go, Mordheim should be your next tourist destination.VII – Overall [8.3/10]Overall, Mordheim: City of the Damned is off to a great start. This one has serious potential and I cannot wait to see where it ends up in terms of it’s completion.
