Early Access Review
								At the time of this review I've only got about 14 hours of play time with it and it is in early access.  This game in general is pretty awesome, and the development team keeps updating it.  What more could you ask for from an organization?If you enjoy a turn based strategy game that actually requires you put more than 2 seconds of thought into what you are about to do, and you don't mind playing it while in Early Access, then this game is absolutely for you right now.  Pros:I enjoy the amount of customization that goes into preping your warband.  I like the fact that I can select a style of weapon or type of armor, and I can cutomize those items by putting runes in them.I like that I can chose which skills I'm going to use based on how I spent my attribute points.  The development team listens to the customer base, and actively pushes out patches.  This alone is just awesome!Cons:  At this time I can't say they have any.  How is that possible right, all games have faults?  If you re-read my last pro comment, it speaks volumes as to why I can't say this game in its early access state has a con right now.   If the game was in it's final state, and the development team wasn't actively engaged in making the game better, then this review would have some cons.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												Not a bad game. Might even call it very good if it weren't for my main issue with it (explained below). I wouldn't even call it as rough as others say. Sure the looting is harsh, since the percentage that you get of what you couldn't pick up is low, random and based off the number of standing warriors. Your units also tend to die fairly often. Which, frankly, them actually dying isn't so prevalent as others make it sound. It's not exactly a bad thing for what this style of game tends to aim for in having losses mean something. It's also something you're warned of fairly well up front. Makes the reward sweeter in the end.The atmosphere is nice. Graphics are decent. Models are very nice. Animations are just a tad stiff in some instances. Sounds are pretty good (unlike other players, I did like the narrator). Music does overpower dialogue in most instances, so be ready to turn that down. The overall feel is kind of like a mix between Nosgoth and Xcom. Good number of skill choices and customization options. Mechanics overall aren't unenjoyable either. Being able to customize your individual warriors was also a nice touch.However, I don't appreciate how you are massively penalized just because of a 2 (or more) units vs 1 fight. Already at a disadvantage (or not...see further down) due to numbers, then the mechanics say you essentially lose by proxy when it saps all of your move and action points from being pinned between two (again, or more) enemies. Your unit is forced to stand there.Oh, I'm sorry, I should mention that there are units who are immune (very few) and a slim chance of passing the check. Which allows you one turn worth of retaliation in an already unbalanced fight? Yeah no. I'm sorry, that's too cheap for me. Games can be made hard without saying you lose, in a situation where you should be able to have the chance to turn things around.Fear and terror checks from some units and abilities that actually make logical sense? Sure. I actually find that appealing as well as an additive to the more intimidating units, and I think it should actually be more apt to initiate a flee scenario. This particular mechanic is far too broad and encompassing of nearly every combat scenario, though. Why do I say this? Because even if you have allies standing 10 ft away, even if you overall outnumber the enemy in a group fight, if there's an enemy between your unit and them? Then this mechanic apparently says you're 'alone'. Yes, in a 2v2, 3v2, 3v3, 4v4 or other combination mob fight, you can have units tagged as alone and unable to do anything other than sit there and take it.I played two warbands, tested, and tried to prove this wrong, but it happened almost every time. I'm sure this could be exploited and I did do so once or twice. To me, though, it still feels cheap. I prefer to win by skill use and the chaos of the RNG rather than something that I, frankly, put on the same scale as a game breaking glitch.For that reason, I don't and can't recommend this game. Is it awesome? It doesn't rate as great as some other far more pricey titles. I also don't regret playing it for free. I have enjoyed getting into it and tried my best to overlook this issue. If I'd paid money, though, I'd be asking for a refund. So past the promo it's likely coming off my computer. Hopefully others have better luck with it. Cheers.

												Is it a good game? Depends what your looking for.If you looking for cassual, turnbased strategy game this isn't it.If your looking for gritty, unforgiving game that cuts of your head and takes dump in your windpipe this is it.Game itself is far from flawless, many places its clunky, tutorials are wanting, and some obvious mechanics and information is obscure at best. The maps, and gameplay can get repetitive too, would have liked to see alot more customisation options for the warriors, alot more maps and alot more variation in armor and weapon skins. Also more diffrent scenarios would not go amiss, instead just routing your opponent... as only starting positions and conditions change.The story campaing is atmospheric as is the game as whole. Also the fact that the game MAKES you learn stuff to be successfull instead of patting your head even when in defeat for "giving your best", instead of everything you got. Constant strategic aye and positioning is needed to win even the most "normal" missions... that is unless enemies bug in walls, carts etc. and you can just pick em off at range. Difficulty really is unforgiving as losing a key member of a team will hurt early and destroy you later game, but there is no more rewarding feeling when you manage to flawlesly execute a mission, twice so when your about to get your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you and you manage to still win the mission by mixture of gritt, skill and pure bleeding luck.Clunky, unpolished and lacking in some aspects as it is I like it never the less.Its all fun and games until your ogre loses an arm.

Posted: January 6, 2016
												Possibly the greatest existing example of game developers hiding a unfinished, poorly executed game onto the market. The AI in this game does odd moves, ignores objectives, stares at walls, yet will B Line to your weakest guy and try and swarm him with no regard for the battle. It does this to simply inflict permanent damage on your warband, while its crew are just randoms that are totaly expendable. After investing a ton of time into developing a warband, 1 battle where the AI seems to stun your guys with every hit, never miss and somehow do damage that seems impossible, all your time has been wasted because of the overly harsh injury system. 1 armed archers, leaders with stupidity, game ending stuff.  The skill tree in this game costs so much yet delivers mostly marginal effects, maybe a %5 increase onto an ability. Only to see your investment wasted when your guy ends up with a headwound that turns him into a potato. Replacement guys are vastly overpriced for a measly 1 or 2 level character, and because they are the weakest , will be targeted by the AI and go down faster then a crack ♥♥♥♥♥ .  Yet this games most offensive, and just plain insulting aspect is its totaly broken and deceptive Random Number Generator. Stare in disbelief as attack after attack at %95 misses (not parried or dodged). Gaze in awe as the AI lands powershot after powershot on your warbands leader who had a %80 dodge enabled. From what I have observed in 300 hours of game on several accounts, the AI gets a %25 bonus and you get a %25 penalty. So go through mission after mission of danger, builld your followers up, only to watch them die . There is no end point to this game,it just grinds you down. Win 100 battles yet in 1 bad battle where the AI pulls♥♥♥♥♥♥from its♥♥♥♥♥♥and stuns on near every hit, and your main guys end up with game ending wounds. Wish a decent company had worked on this game, instead of this pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥brick muppets. They know exactly the problems but cant be ♥♥♥♥ed fixing it.Now up to near 700 hrs and all the issues still remain. One last detail Ive noticed, story missions are a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥ overly complicated, repetetive , and full of enemies that somehow appear from rooms or areas already cleared.  I have a new idea for a mission, go to the docks, find a barrell,♥♥♥♥♥♥in it till full, find game devs and drown them in it.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												Definitely not recommended. This is not a "broken" game. It is a game that is extremely poor by design. It will not "get fixed". Will highlight some of the -obvious and terribly cynical- design decisions taken, in order to artificially lengthen the game as well as creating a need for "DLC investment". The importance of the latter in the game's "strategy" became very apparent with their recent launch of laughable content (two extra options for characters - paid).There are many shortcomings but the following are the highlights:- The combat design is ridiculous. The whole concept of side objectives (which are necessary to meet to have any chance of progressing through the game, as the rewards are intentionally pitiful) is awful. Makes sense from the developers' point of view though. This is a game where the only plausible strategy is to keep formation and gang up on enemies (1:1 you will die most of the time. Outnumbered you will die almost every time - levelling up does not help; see below). The side objectives are aimed at just one thing: Preventing you to keep formation and ganging up on enemies. You basically only have two options. Go after side objectives and fall to statistics (hugely abused by this game, as a "bonus"), or win battles and get next to no rewards - so lose on the "strategy map". The whole loot system as utterly attrocious. Everything about it (when you can collect it, the fact that you essentially lose most of it when you win, the storage system etc). It is all aimed at one thing: Destroying rewards so you stay longer in the game, particularly through the crappy "veteran system".- Strategic progression and the "veteran system". This is where your warband progresses, in a poor excuse of what Mordheim is supposed to be. Coupled with the "Veteran system", which is supposed to earn and track rewards from multiple warbands fielded by the player over the course of "playing" this game. Neither works.Skills are so incredibly expensive that you cannot pay for them, as the rewards are too puny. You will watch your warband's characters accumulate skill points that you cannot afford to spend. There is a work around here, which is obviously intentional. Kill enough warbands, waste enough time mindlessly, and you will sllllllooooooooowwwwwllllyyy inch up the veteran system's ranks. One of the "benefits" is that it lowers costs and increases starting gold for warbands. See what they did there? That's an example of how the game is artificially lengthened, without any challenge or reason to engage in it.Until you get to that sweet spot (which requires many, many hours of extremely boring grinding and killing warbands), you actually get PUNISHED for levelling up. Whenever you are matched with an enemy warband, it is roughly scaled to yours. However, their characters, of any given level, come complete with the skills you never afforded for yours. With every level you add to your characters, they get markedly worse than their upskilled opponents of same "rank". Clever.- It has been a long time since I have seen a game that so cynically and obviously rigs the dice throws. It is getting a bit of a reputation for this and it is actually well deserved (Which is not the case in most incidences when this accusation is levelled at a game). Yes, I know how statistics work, yes, I know about the law of large numbers and, no, I am not "impressed" by some fluke throws that did not go my way. I am a 40+ post grad engineer; not a frustrated teen. Will not go into great length of what I tracked and for how long (it would mark me as OCD if I did). Believe me or not, but what they did is just stunning. It is now actually easier to track as (obviously in response to the aforementioned reputation), you can see the modifiers for each "roll". The transparency has made the rigging even more obvious and easier to measure.This old staple of lazy and cynical programming is usually nothing more than a nuisance - another artificial way of increasing difficulty and lengthening the game (both very important to marketers, in the age of DLC). Basically, it usually means save-scumming or pay for extra "power" to overcome the handicap. In a game with permadeath it is a complete dealbreaker.  Could add considerably to the list. Overall, a highly negative experience and a huge let down for a Games Workshop and Mordheim hobbyist who paid for this piece of junk from pre-release (an extremely rare choice for me - at least it taught me a lesson).

Posted: August 4, 2016
												I can't reccomend this game in it's current state. It says the game was released in November of 2015 but the game holds the quality of a game in early to mid-beta. The UI (as in every Game's Workshop game) is horrible. Engage-ranges are ambiguous and often leads to the AI or your friends edging walls and slipping past your defenses. Ambush works 50% of the time, where line of sight does not seem to matter (that is; if you stand around a corner, often the enemy will see you before stepping into your ambush range and just avoid your attack alltogether).A lot of these problems coupled with an unforgiving-post skirmish system makes this game a frustrating mess. If these problems would be resolved, I would call the game hard but fair. Atm, it just feels cheap when you lose because of technicalities. "Yay, my leader is now blind on one eye and has a maimed hand, because there were 5 centimeters between the area my guards threatened and the wall." If these issues are resolved, I'd reccomend it. It has potential.

Posted: January 22, 2016
												I want to like this game, I really do, but the "chance" aspect of this game is so ♥♥♥♥ed that its hard to call it a tactical strategy. I think a couple stories will describe this nicely.First imagine your magister, high level and very powerful. You take him into a normal difficulty mission that goes fairly well. The enemy has very low moral and is expected to break soon. As you go to cast a spell, you read that the success percent is nintey and so you cast it having action points to spend. After casting it, your magister is cursed. He takes 999999 damage (instantly killing him). Him bieng slow the round ends after his turn. Your warband then breaks and you lose the battle. After battle, your magister dies, perminently. You then proceed to delete that warband and almost the game.Next, imagine your winning a battle, all looks well. The enemies turn has just ended so you proceed to issue attack commands to your warband as combat is near. You miss every hit that round, and the next. Every percent chance says "seventy" or "eighty" but you miss, everything. After two round of bieng slaughtered your warband breaks and a majority of your party members suffer wounds.And I know, mordhiem is based on a tabletop game that comes down to dice rolls, but as someone who (once, age of sigmar is a thing) played warhammer fantasy, this game is not near as deep strategically, and I have a hard time understanding why it is considered a tactical strat. game when so much of it comes down to chance. What skill does it take to have your party leader die to an enemy scout because he cant hit him on an "eighty-percent" chance?

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												EARLY ACCESS REVIEVED FIRSTLY ON 20th OCTOBER 2015. (Update 8, Patch 4, EA rating - 95/100)This is an updated review after full-release. Changes are written with capital letters. (Release 19/NOV/2015, v. 1.0.4.1).My overall rating for Mordheim: City of the Damned: 100/100Another adaptation from Warhammer universe, this combines elements of real-time strategy and RPG genre. Decent atmospheric settings full of horror and merciless battles, that is what this game promises you. Add a management of your warband, improvement of skills and a decent portion of strategy with luck and you have, what it is really called. War over cursed city, which we will look into further in details.GAMEPLAY+ Good design and performance+ Strategic map+ Variety of actions and reactions (most of them are responsive)+ Good tutorials+ Warband management+ Commented objectives, stories before and after the mission+ VOICED STORIES AND INTRO ADDEDo Complex control- Four factions only (may not be negative at all)Gameplay is a decent part of the game and it is very well balanced. Now there are only four factions, but tactics, randomised elements on map and also important luck factor are creating a formidable game experience. Turn-based strategy is very well combined with RPG genre, so you have to improve your warband, change the position and disposition of the troops, after that, you have to fight your battles on the battlefield.Battles need another strategy guidance, you have to rely not only on your warriors, but also to environment and luck. Everything is possible in war, so also here, even the weakest unit can disable or rout the strongest enemy with the right conditions and events happened.Commented objectives, intros and outros to the mission are adding a great impression to the atmosphere of the whole game. Player can feel himself/herself like the biggest general and strategist in the world.VISUALS+ Excellent graphics+ Art style+ Cam view+ Wounds have influence on characters' appearance Visually is Mordheim stunning. Perfect set of backgrounds, various part of Mordheim, nice details on units and many features have a wonderful impression on a player. Also your warriors may suffer wounds and injuries, which are visible then, so you can tell, who is a novice and who battle-toughened veteran.SOUNDTRACK+ Well composed+ Theme for each faction, map+ RELEASED AS AN EXCLUSIVE OFFER FOR ALL PLAYERSSoundtrack adds points for Mordheim: City of the Damned, themes are adequately changing, underlining both nature of each faction and sinister atmosphere of cursed city of Mordheim. After full release it was added and automatically downloaded to game folder (link specified at store page).MULTIPLAYER+ Balanced+ Various modso Seeking by rating (adjustable)Multiplayer also provides another possibilities for your warband to perform, you can choose of plenty modes and community is fair and friendly. There is also "Exhibition" mode, where no penalties will remain after ending. For other, experienced units are recommended, because loss can disrupt your precisely build warband in one unlucky mission. Though you can seek the enemy just to suit your rank, so it is compensable and you do not have to have an elite unit at all.SUMMARYThis title is a very wonderful adaptiation of Warhammer universe, yet in the process of perfection through Early Access. Also turn-based strategy and RPG combination seems very promising, though there might be some bugs and people should be aware of that and considering this during their reviews, written or spoken, does not matter what. Developers are working fast, communicating with community and releasing patches regularly, each with huge balance.About the price, game is complex, replayable, I understand that 39,99 EUR might be expensive for some players (Early Access costed 31,99 EUR), but it is worthy, singleplayer for sure, multiplayer experience are giving also points to this title. Though it is very similar to late Early-Access phase, it has those improvements, which exactly were needed to be done.The game is recommended for Warhammer fans, turn-based strategy, RPG players and also players outside this genres. Each of us has a bit of dark fantasy within us.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								So I am going to try and be as informative as I possibly can with this game.The game has four factions each one with unique units that can wield and use varieties of armor and weapons. To start the game you are going to choose one of four factions, the choice of faction is crucial to your play style. Once chosen you are going to begin leveling, and yes you level everything, even the poor little meat shields you hide your damage dealers behind. This entire game is based on leveling, accept that fact and youll be perfectly happy with the game. Now the key detail of this game in my eyes is going to be resource management in the warband screen. EVERY MEMBER of your warband must be paid, and you must send wyrdstone to those who request it, miss four shipments and its game over. Inside your camp you can almost fully customize your characters (this is a detail of the game that i want more improvement on) by changing the styles of their gear and equipping them new armor and weapons, also training them over days in spell casting and skill use.now once outside of your warbands camp youll be placed on the campaign screen (the newest update added this finally!). Once on the screen youll be given a variety of missions to choose from, all with varying difficulty and loot. Once you get your warband high enough you will be given an end of act mission. These end of act missions have objectives that must be completed such as placing sanctified hammers on statues, and cleansing the corruption from holy artifacts.The actual gameplay is a turn based strategy format. Units take turns based on their initiation, this is lowered by heavier cumberson items and armor/weapons. In many ways I have found that the weaker glass cannon units go first most of the time, and depending on your faction you may or may not have any of those. Now one thing this games combat does very well is its implication of stances. there are many stances in this game including ambush dodge and parry, being the primary stances. Combat can be very difficult at times because your units move spaces may not get you in a proper postion to attack, and often leads to bottlenecking through doorways or over bridges. Each mission you recieve has a primary objective of killing all enemies or causing them to retreat. Retreat is caused by you forcibly removing morale from an enemy by either surrounding them and causing fear, or the killing of their units. (im not sure about this but it seems like killing enemy heroes and leaders causes a deeper impact on morale)One thing to be wary of is any kind of % chance, as this game is still in Alpha I will go back and change this review as needed but as of now a 78% chance of climbing over a wall seems to have only a 30% success rate, and yes I have tested this by losing over 3 units to trying to climb one wall.All in all this game is amazing, definitely a must have for any warhammer player, and a must try for any strategy enthusiast, this game will punish you through crippling soldiers or even permanent death though. So if you do decide to try it watch for ambushes, and stay away from charging Daemons! Enjoy!

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great game, feels very down and dirty and reminds me alot of excom (which i played in ironman mode, ofc.)  Although i do believe a difficulty setting should be added for those who are not up to the challenge, and for 1v1 battles against your friends to actually give you rewards,  it is a utterly fantastic game that can be EXTREMLY stressfull at times, but it also has moments that not many other games have.  Those moments where you have 3 units dead and all the rest but one are on 10 health, and you have to use the one with the low health to bait out an overwatch shot in order for your units to attempt to run up to your objective, and then you realise that you left an important item behind and have to go fetch it in order to succede while your men are under-fire but you somehow manage to pull it out and succede.  This game gave me a sence of pure joy that I have not had in gaming for quite some time.  An utter joy to play.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I was incredibly excited when I heard about this about a year ago cause I've always loved the table top game. When I first played it a year ago, however, it was just an incrediby glitchy skirmish game. Sure, it was set in the city of mordheim and had the right feel to it. It just wasn't mordheim to me without a campaign and progression. So, it sat in my library unplayed and unloved with me checking occasionally on the updates. It was encouraging seeing the constant support they gave the game over the year, but I wasn't truly happy until this week when I saw they had finally added what I believe is the heart of mordheim. and from what I've played, its amazing. Though, stats and skills work pretty differently from what it is on the table top, I believe it is amazingly done. The game was pretty easy to pick up and the matches themselves made sense and felt seamless. IF you enjoy turn based rpg combat this game is perfect for you. I can see theres a lot of depth to this game and I can see my social life suffering for the next few weeks while my skaven raid the city of mordheim for glory.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								If the multiplayer and magement/team progression aspects are thougtfully implemented I think that this will be a very successful game. There are a some bugs, such as camera issues and a few invisible walls, but this comes with early access and I'm sure these will get ironed out in time. I'm deffinitely Looking forward to the next update.REVIEW OF PROGRESSION - update 8.The game at the moment is very entertaining, slightly addictive, and requires some skill to keep your team going. There are small issues with balancing, enemy warbands seem to level more quickly and have +40% health, but again this is merely the beginning of testing progression; which will hopefully be perfected in the near future as this is what will affect replayability.   There are still some bugs floating around, the old invisble wall, but they are steadily being fixed by the developers. The only concerns I have as of now for the game are small UI things; the placement of buttons, perfecting icons such as those on the map; that reduce submersion into the game. Fingers crossed for the next few updates. Hopefully everything will come together seemlessly and the optimisation phase will make everything run a bit smoother and bring the loading times down.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a game I have waited for for a long time. I have finished playing the tutorials and played 1 skirmish and here are my current observations:The game is Mordheim! It has the real feel for the setting and feels like I am playing the miniatures game. Once the RPG elements of the game have been implemented this will be brilliant.I like the more dynamic move options instead of your standard turn based grid style of movement. It gives you a chance to explore different movement options and makes it feel more realistic.The camera views in the game need work. Nothing that breaks anything, just every now and then you get an angle where you cant see whats going on.There are points in the game that need graphics optimization...I am currently playing on the "Simple" Graphics configuration and in the main menu screen, my cards fan is screaming. During normal play its fine.To summerize, the potential for this game is huge and could be a really big hit once they get the game further down the road. Thank you so much for making this!

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												Its a difficult and fun turn-based strategy game with minimal tutorials, but very frustrating most of the time since a string of three bad rolls can be devistating to your favorite minion or even lose the entire match. Each match takes a long time (40 to 60 minutes plus) to resolve as the maps are massive and the enemies are hidden.  You are always the underdog and must skillfully maneuver your minions to win.  You must also get both the primary and secondary goals if you wish to keep pace with the game difficulty progression (hard to insane) and the economic demands (warpstone & coins) of growing and equiping your warband.  I use a laptop and my original computer was not quite up to the processing burden of the game, but my new intel core 17 laptop handles it fine.

								so far so good. obviously units are preset with varying weapon combinations to allow for playtesting but allows no real focus on a certain play style, which although takes away from the specialisation of a faction, does lend itself to a general pleasant playing experience. as a tabletop Mordheim enthusiast, love the initiative ladder. waiting around for a full turn without doing anything gets boring. loved the climbing and jumping down functions in the game, although laughed a little when a unit attempted to jump down, failed and fell to the ground, but next frame ended at the top again. surely a failed jump down makes you land on the ground regardless... would kill for dark elves but know that they'd be far, far, far off. would love to see the regulars undead and witch hunters but unsure if they'd be a little too similar to mercs, especially since the mercs get a warlock. great start so far so congratulations lads. keep up the good work

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												This is a good, engrossing, strategy game.Very deep mechanics, strategy from the start, and very unforgiving. Your warband will be slaughtered as you learn to play, go into this thinking of your characters as disposable and you will have a better time than if you get attached to them. Eventually, you will figure out how to survive and grow some powerful ones, but early on expect a lot of pain and (kinda) starting over.While the focus is on your warband, you are leveling your leadership in the background and this gives bonuses to new warbands you start, in effect, the game gets (ever so slightly) easier every time you are decimated, broke, and starting over.Game is only iron man mode, meaning no save loading when you mess up, be prepared.Due to the stakes being high, every match I play is full of "WTF?!", "CRAP!", and "OH♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; moments as well as "♥♥♥♥ yea!", "WHOO-HOO", and "RIGHT ON!" moments. Highs and lows....Who could ask for anything more?

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												As a former player of the tableetop version of Mordheim, I feel that the computer version has captured the feel of the tabletop version.  It is not a port of the table top version and I think that it is better for it.  There are moments of frustration, as your men can not hit anything or you leader gets his arm cut off in the second mission, I speak from experience, but I can not help but enjoy the narrative of my warband, as they grow,  develop, and sadly die.  I have become very attached to my one arm one legged archer who can no longer use a missile weapon.Now, there are issues, the AI could really do with an overhaul, a few more different warbands, undead, dwarves, pitfighters, would be nice.  The game would also be better if it had some more maps.  All that being said, I enjoy the game and think it is worth giving it a go.

												I love this game and recommend buying it.Three great things in this game :- the world of Warhammer and the Skaven- it makes you worry for your men (they accumulate xp through missions and you can chose a variety of skills)- and it constantly teases you to take risks (trying to get more money, at a higher risk).There are no saves and losing a mission feels really painful : your men that have been put out of combat have a small chance of actually being uninjured after the mission, but usually get some kind of permanent injury, which make them powerful/less usable - and I just got my 3 best men (incl. my boss and a hero) actually DEAD in a single mission ! (all right, I confess I was greedy and tried a "deadly" mission, which turned out to be a mission against sisters... mental note: don't do it again)But actually, aside from the "psychological" side, losing is not as damaging (in game terms) as you could think, because the difficulty of most missions depends on your strength.Going for a "normal difficulty" mission is a bit easier with a strong team than with a weak team, but not that much. (it's still a bit easier with a strong team because as your teammates level up, you can chose skills and usually, we humans are better than the AI at building "consistent" characters (with skills that work well together)).So I my opinion the game is great because it feels unforgiving without being actually completely unforgiving.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												These are the big pros to me:- The atmosphere. Graphics and sounds support Warhammer world very well and I like the narrator voices too.- "Roguelike" elements (injuries, deaths, no savegames) fit very well into a dark fantasy setting. A couple of injuries to a favourite character gives him/her actually.. more character :)- Asymmetrical factions make game more interesting.- Many kinds of viable builds for warbands.- Meaningful tactical choices in combat.The only bad thing I really come up with is the AI - a point that is relevant mostly when playing the single player scenarios. This is what I have to say about it:It is a popular complain that the AI REALLY sucks and that it is easy to win games using choke points. And it is true - except when it isn't. The scenarios also start with deployments that try to screw you up, like spreading your warriors alone across the map and enemies rushing towards you and engaging you when you haven't even had the chance to react. So while it's true that the AI is stupid and you can "farm" it, sometimes it's so much opposite that it's unfair (and it's kind of realistic and in the game's genre it is acceptable). And sometimes it's something in between. I admit it's by far the weakest part of the game - Luckily the game does it's best to minimize the effect.I haven't played multiplayer yet, but of course there the situation isn't the same.Overall this game gives me wonderful moments in a grim dark fantasy world.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												I have a love/hate relationship with this game, but I can't bring myself to rate negatively. I will, however, be leaving a lengthy review explaining my opinions of this game.First of all its one of the best tabletop to video game conversions I have ever played. The play mechanics are superb and feel refreshing for a turn based strategy game, aside from the RNG. The overall look and feel of the game are excellent, it is a great blend of horror and strategy. Great graphics, awesome artwork, cool noises, amazing voice acting, and genuinely creepy.Yes the game can be immensely challenging and unforgiving, but that is one of the best parts. Real true consequences that you will be feeling the effects of for a long while to come, so play smart, be cautious. The downside of the game is really that the AI, although incredibly tough, is incredibly stupid. Every match is basically a Zerg rush. The AI will throw everything it has at you (aside from one guy who will wander around aimlessly) right at the start of match.The goal of the game almost entirely revolves around collecting this precious green crack called Wryd Stone. The AI is not at all interested in doing that. Instead they will mindlessly pursue you like ravenous zombies.If they could improve the AI, wherein they actually cared about collecting the Wyrd Stone, as the game implies they should, and used some genuine strategy instead of 'walk straight at the closest enemy and kill' strategy it currently uses then this game would be huge win.Another sore spot is the RNG. I suggest you keep a pillow close by to bite on because you will be getting royally ♥♥♥♥ed in the♥♥♥♥♥ The RNG seems to purposely want to cause you to smash your computer in complete rage. I have lost numerous battles, where I overwhelmingly had the tactical advantage, simply because my team would continually miss attack after attack and take every incoming hit right on the chin till they where all decimated.There is little to nothing you can do about the RNG except pray and pray. It completely sucks the idea of 'being the smarter tactician' right out of the game. They should add in some fail safe so you can only miss so many times in a row or something along those lines because it seems no matter how likely your odds of landing a hit are its always a 3/10 chance you will actually land the hit... especially when you really really need to land that last freakin hit!Lastly, I absolutely love the fact this game has multiplayer support. Although it is neigh impossible to find a match unless you join a community group that host pvp tournaments. It may have been the saving grace of the entire game if not for the fact that multiplayer is not balanced at all.Every faction in multiplayer has some super cheezy tactic or advantage that will make them OP depending on what lvl your currently fighting at. Early on the Skaven move so far and fast they can easily swarm, poison, and kill half your team before you even get to move. Later on the Sisters will drop comet after comet, after comet, after... you guessed it more comets on your head till you have two guys remaining that they quickly surround and flog to death. Late game the Mutants if played right, will have uber mutations giving them more strength and health than anyone making them a wall of flesh and claws that will pound your face, body, and soul into the ground.If they where to improve AI, add a more forgiving RNG (so the game is more based on tactics than luck), and tweak the multiplayer balancing this game would be absolutely amazing. For now I suggest if you like tabletop games, turn based strategy, Warhammer, or are a masochist get this game next time its on sale.I'll be looking forward to updates... if there are any.

Posted: April 22
												So much wasted potential. I like so much about this game, but have just gotten completely sick of the flaws. You will get stuck in buggy missions where quitting causes your whole party to take permanent injuries and lose critical equipment. You will get trapped in RNG hell where the AI crits you over and over while your elite warriorf flail impotently at the air. You have no way to respec your party members, so if you pick the wrong skill (or your chaos troops mutate in a way that negates that skill you spent precious points and gold on) then you have no way to change it. Your enemies' turn in the initiative order, something that is CRITICAL to planning any sort of strategy, will alter itself wildely with no imput or action by either warband. While I enjoyed alot about it, my overall experience has been mostly frustration and now disgust at how much time I've wasted with it.

												This game is probably the most hardcore experience you can get if you are a Warhammer - Mordheim fan, as punishing as should be, withouth casualisation that is so common nowadays, you will get your chars crippled temporally or forever, you will get them killed, you will feel the pressure of the task of getting Wyrdstone and gold, heck, if you are new in this kind of games you will get wiped in the first escenario, also is one of the few modern games were you really need to check the tutorial.Pros+Challenging and complex gameplay+Skaven models are sweet+Graphics are good for an "indie" title+It gets the Mordheim/Warhammer atmosphere right+Gritty+I really like the musicCons-Lack of customization of your warband-Some models looks "ugly"-Not as much music variety-It needs more blood and goreIf you liked Valkyria Chronicles, Xcom or any turnbased strategic game don't listen to the negative reviews, this is a truly good game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Picked it up today and haven't stopped playing it all day. It is definitely in early release stage but by far one of the better early release games on steam. At this point it's more playable than most fully released games!Being a big fan of the Warhammer series from everything to lore and the table top (both Warhammer fantasy and 40k) I was really excited when I first discovered this a while back. Most of the games made with Games Workshop are usually the 40k space marine type or Dawn of War. This was obviously a delight because it looked like a “real” attempt at the fantasy style instead.I was a bit hesitant to pick it up at first mainly because of the bad wrap on early releases lately and from everything I read it was meant for a console and was still pretty rough for PC users. As I watched it though it went from “mixed reviews” to “Mostly positive” the developers were releasing some awesome new content and watching some game play on youtube it looked like it might actually become a real game instead of another early release disappointment (here's looking at you Day Z). The game play itself is pretty solid. You have the 4 factions all of which are pretty balanced and at this point pretty simple. At this point in the game you really on have the tutorials (4 of them which really do cover all the game and take less than an hour) and skirmish. You create a map and choose the opposing faction if it's against AI or you can randomly pair with another person for some PVP. The unique thing I liked about setting up the game were the vast options for starting locations or scenarios. For example you can can do standard set up (both teams start at opposite corners) you can do Ambush (one team starts all inside a building and the opposing team is surrounding the building) Fog of War (Both teams are completely scattered across the map) and the list goes on and on. The maps even at this point are impressive and I love that they randomly generate so you hardly ever get the same map twice.  The combat is pretty simple which might be a down point for some, but personally I enjoyed I. It keeps the game play fast and allows you to focus on other strategy rather than micro managing each character during their turn. You basically have two types of points for each unit Strategy Points and Offense Points (SP and OP respectively) your SP points allow for movement and your OP allow for combat which you can see pretty decently in the game play video. Depending on the skills or spells your unit has you are allowed to cycle through your available options each turn  by hitting Q or E. This helps make the combat smooth and quick. Most of the strategy is in placement of troops and sight. Much like in the tabletop game the first few turns are setting up your units in defensible areas or in getting the enemy in line of sight. This may seem tedious for those who want action but it is incredibly fun to run around as an Ogre or Cultish Wizard looking for positions of advantage. Outside of the match you do have the option to micro manage your troops which was also fun from a looting, leveling, and buffing standpoint. You can customize your squad with gear which can be looted from battles and eventually purchased, you can spend points and level skills, spells, or abilities, and you can enchant your weaponry (Hammer of Sigmar +5 awesomeness). This makes you invested in your war band but keep in mind this game also has perma-death so don't get super attached to your beloved hero. Some awesome things that stand out:The overlord view during a match that allows you to plan and scope the whole map was really a cool idea and works very well.In game log for all actions so you can see why you missed that hit or miscast a spell.Dark fantasy art and feel is seriously awesome as hell. They did a fricken epic job making Mordheim seem like a city of dark magic corrupted by chaos.Lore (though limited) is all accurate and pretty intriguing. It will be appreciated by fans of the genre and at the same time new players won't be confused or lost without background.9/10 would run around for an hour as a Skaven assassin again.This would be an amazing game for just an RPG in the style of Fable or Kingdoms of Amalur Reckoning. Give me this city as an open world map and let me build a character and I would pay an A list game price for that.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												Very promising and reminds a lot of the old cult classic tabletop game. So far only 2 warbands, Skaven and human mercenaries, but they will add a lot more over time. Mechanics are fun, graphics and sounds are good. Overall a fun turnbased experience with a very interesting new take on action points, and how they work.Update: With the full release here and 4 warbands instead of two. They added Sisters of Sigmar, a hard-hitting band of religious nutcases Warhammer style as well as adding Cult of the Possessed, which is a Chaos warband, with all that that brings. Mutations, weird way of thinking and just plain barbarism.With over 100 hours logged, I have this to say: The game is very unforgiving, and at times extremely frustrating. Very long load times, which seems to be something the company can't fix because of how the game is built. it has a built in anti-rage quitter system, meaning if you quit during any mission or skirmish, it treats it as if the warband got routed and EVERY SINGLE WARRIOR in the fight will have to roll on the injury table to see if they suffer any injury or lose any equipment. This is very harsh, especially for single player where you don't really hurt anyone by abandoning a mission that goes really, really bad (considering the loss of one skilled warrior can set you back around 10 hours of game time). it doesn't help the AI is dumb as bricks, and pathfinding for large units really is an issue. More than once, I see them stuck by a door and just can't move.Still, even with its flaws this game is very addictive and I stand by my early access opinion, the game is great.2nd and last update: Loading times has been fixed, it now loads very fast. Gone from over a minute of loading time to around 15-20 seconds. (I use a SSD).They've added 2 new Warbands: The Witch Hunters, a warband of Witch Hunters (think the psychos from the witch hunts in Europes history) and their cohors: religious nutcases (Flagellants and Zealots). Their impressive unit is a very large human with the suiting profession of executioner. He likes to set his enemies on fire. While they're alive.The second new is Undead, set to be released tomorrow as I write this (the 25th of october 2016). I can't wait. Vampires. Zombies. Dregs. Necromancers. Crypt horros. Oh my.

content:
Posted: April 11
												Mordheim: City of the Damned is a great game based off Games Workshop's Tabletop skirmish game.  If you're looking for a direct translation, this is not the game for you.  If you want a great tactical skirmish and management game, this should be on your wishlist.The important part is to keep both sides of the game in balance: tactical and management.  Your Warband can quickly find itself out of money if you lose matches, or get your Warband members skills without a cushion.  Adding Wyrdstone shipments to the mix, and you have an adequate representation of life in Mordheim.  It may not be true to the game, but it has Mordheim's spirit down.While playing against the AI is fun, it's even better when you are playing against a human opponent... although one might be hard to come by at tmes.  You can do both with the same game, switching back and forth as your friends hop on, or playing against the computer to get that last bit of Wyrdstone in before the shipment's late (miss three and the game's over).There is one piece of advice before playing against human opponents: get used to playing against the computer first.  The game is frustrating when you start out, as you don't know the lay of the land that well.  True to its namesake, Mordheim is merciless when someone doesn't know the layout of each map as well as their opponent.  You will find yourself flanked, and a great skirmish game will find itself shelved.Manage your Troops.  Manage your Gold.  Manage your Time.  Manage your Temper.  Do all these things, and you might survive Mordheim... for a while.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												Mordheim is a rather challenging turn-based squad management RPG set in the Warhammer world, with unforgiving rogue-like qualities that won't be to eveyone's liking. To be quite frank, people who head in thinking Mordheim willl be akin to XCOM will probably be rather let down. This is primarliy an old Games Workshop board game brought to life with all the idiosyncracies this entails, and it therefore has far more in common with Blood Bowl than regular turn-based titles. Don't let the 3rd person gfx trick you into thinking otherwise, that's basically just a way of getting scenary and elevation changes to work (something that wasn't needed with Cyanide's Blood Bowl conversion). The Blood Bowl comparisons continue through to the front-end, which is about as user friendly as a casual headbutt. However, perseverance with the steep learning curve and the obtuse management system does start to pay off. Trying to keep a fledgling warband afloat by selling everything and fielding guys with smashed up legs only to find you've then got no spare weapons for your next raid is the kind of experience you'll either like or despise - luckily for me, it's right up my street. I tried PVP in beta and it had a lot going for it but I've just been doing campaign stuff since I fired it up aagin and I am genuinely impressed with the solo experience. The meta actually has a lot in common with Darkest Dungeon (this is a good thing, DD is wonderful). Also of note is that the Xbox pad works nicely, meaning I can get my tactical on from the armchair.Mordheim has developed nicely into a game that now offers a fairly singular experience, though undoubtably rather niche. If you're looking for a mixture of Blood Bowl and Darkest Dungeon then look no further.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Decent game, Crashes at times but what did you expect from Early Access?The main problem is that WHEN you crash it counts as a loss in the game and since there is no save function at all (to stop people from saving during their turn and then loading when they know what the enemy will do/loses a unit) it leads to horrible damage to all your units and sometimes you have to start all over because half your warband died in a crash and the other half lost legs and arms (which is a ♥♥♥♥♥ if you want to use shields or bows) and you just dont have enough money to buy a new one.If you ever need to leave in the middle of a game you are ♥♥♥♥ed since leaving is always a loss and there isnt even an "pause this ♥♥♥♥ing battle and just let me return to this exact same point in the game when i start it again" function.The only safe time to leave is between missions and even then im scared.Another minor problem is that all skills cost a minimum of 100 gold to train (good ones cost 250) while a new level 0 unit costs 15 and all the things you sell (basic stuff which can be found in heaps all over the place) sells for 1-10 gold.Combine this with the fact that you have to pay around 5xNumber of units you own in salary after every mission and you might never get enough gold to get skills after a while.The campaign has only two missions at the time but they are hard as balls and require you to farm and level up all your characters and units (and all farm comes in either the same strength as your warband or stronger so there is no way to just farm lvl 1 slimes over and over until you get strong) to hope to survive them.Nonetheless with the customization tool, unique turn based strategy with first person control of all your units its worth the money for the entertainment and endless campaign.11/10 would play Khorne Sorcerer protected by his Slaneeshi tank, Nurglite Archer and Tzeenchian barbarian again.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												Update - I'm having more fun then before.  I've found more bugs and the story missions can be confusing sometimes.  But, the epic feel of survival is great.  I'm not one to complain that I miss a 95% roll.  I don't believe that game is broke or cheats, I believe I just had a bad roll.  I also hit the other day when I had a 7% chance on a shot.  It is random and it happens, but games like this are built that way.  I don't want to know exactly what is going to happen every sword swing that would be pretty dumb.  The injuries don't bother me.  I don't ever deploy my own troops, I always let the computer deploy them for me.  I like the difficulty.  I have a Human Merc warband and we've struggled and also dominated.  Nothing better then getting smacked around, scrapping together after the fight and going out and deciminating your enemy next time.  Yes you can do that.  This game is simply fantastic.  There are minor issues here and there and some odd graphic glitches.  But, overall the game requires thought and planning.  But, I think it captures the warhammer world very well and handles the mechanics of the boardgame.I wish it had multiplayer servers and warbands were stored online for online play.  Some kind of ladder or online campaign would be great as well.I would buy additional warbands as DLC.  I would also pay for multiplayer.  It is a great merc sim and really has been the kind of game I've been waiting for. Well done, Well done indeed.  9.0 out of 10.  Would like multiplayer ladders, servers, clans etc...  Also multiplayer campaigns.  I hope this is game is a hit and they look at funding or kickstarting some of those features.  We also need more custom options for faces.  All my guys look the same and that is annoying.  Make it so people can mod.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												Its kind of hard to properly mark this one since its yes or no. I'm giving it a slight yes in regards that it can be pretty fun when things are going properly. RNG is wickedly against you in this game as it is with most tactical combat games. You will miss quite often on 80% chance to hit moves and even on 95% in the same vein as XCOM would make you miss with a shotgun at point blank range. The game is unrelenting in its difficulty giving you no way to save and the fact that the AI will land impossible hits for incredible damage and when surrounded somehow rarely if ever break and run. You will feel scared to death nearly every battle of one of your men going down in battle because that mutant you've been leveling up since the start with all the shiny upgrades in gear can suddenly be dead because a gutter rat got lucky.Strangely enough this turns out to be fun if not frustrating as all hell. Battles are always tense especially when you really need that wyrdstone to keep your boss from kicking you to the curb and ending your campaign and a severe wound can put your best soldiers out of the fight leaving you scrambling for new recruits to piece yourself together until they recover. Missions that scatter your warband across the entire map can really suck when you got one guy on his own and he gets ambushed by the entire enemy team leaving you to desperately run for your life to try to save your poor doomed soldier. The main complaint I have is the loot and objectives. Many objectives require you to loot a certain amount of wyrdstone and you need to finish these or you lose out on bonus items which can save your life. Only problem is as soon as you break their warband the mission ends and you gather only a small chunk of whats on the map. I will gaurantee you that you will only finish maybe 1 out of 5 bonus objectives every mission until you have a godlike meatshield to hold the enemy while you go loot. Because they will always find you and then die and end your mission screwing you out of the objective nearly every freaking time. And the fact that you can't spend maybe 2-3 turns after they have retreated looting makes this game have a fake difficulty that is far more frustrating than fun.So..I could only recommend this if its on sale. If not, until the needless frustration of wasted time trying to finish objectives and huge amounts of lost loot due to the suicidal AI bumrushing to your location no matter where you are its not worth full price. A very hesitant recommendation to anyone who enjoys unrelenting difficulty and cussing at their screen.

								Short pre release early access review.Since campaign update there is so much to do and leveling up your squad named after your best friend is just too cool, super many upgrades, skills and item to unlock/ find. The battle per day works logically and the start of the game does not get you overwhelmed, together with the tutorials, you will be playing soon. and with that a lot of hours sink in.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Seriously, the developers are cramming out so many bug fixes and improvements on a regular basis that I'm amazed. It feels as though every week there's a new update fixing several bugs and improving the UI, adding new features that improve the experience, or simply add new content. The gameplay is solid so far and I'm eagerly awaiting the ability to play Multiplayer matches with injuries, xp & loot.UPDATE: Booted the game after having a hiatus of roughly one year. Game is still enjoyably challenging and mistakes are punishing so it's not for impatient or careless people. After you figure out strategies it gets kind of easy due to how you can exploit the weaknesses of the AI but multiplayer can solve that if you have friends to play with. Haven't looked for any random skirmishes so I wouldn't know if there's any community or not.

Early Access Review
								Just writing this as a fan/player of the old boardgame and of this early access. I've been in the EA for almost a year now. To start out it was very bare bones and glitchy, kinda what I expected. The constant updates are perfect. They iron out all the problems that I've noted/reported. The game looks great (graphically it's not the best, not the worst) thematically. They nailed the atmosphere of the boardgame/lore! Now with the addition of the continous campaign/warband!? This is the game I've been dying for!!! I absolutely love the advancement and the customization options. Not to mention the fact that I can take my exhisting band and throw it online against another person and keep all the loot/xp for my single player campaign (and vise versa) not to mention the possibility of losing one of my leaders/followers for good! It's the perfect platform for the RPG and TBS fan!I'm really enjoying this game now, and with the addition of the campaign I recommend it to anyone whos a fan of tactical turn based and roleplaying games!!! Can't wait to see where they'll go next!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								To properly review this game I think it's worth that I explain  a situation that occurred in one of my latest games as Sisters of Sigmar. My warband was battered during a story mission and I was certain I would lose the battle and pay dearly with tonnes of injuries, probably ending my run as this warband. Instead the Mercenary Ogre who was about to kill the VIP I had to keep alive missed three time in a row against her whilst she was stunned. The level 0 henchman Novice I had with her managed to land a critical hit, stunning the ogre, which led to my spellcaster calling a comet down from the sky and crushing the ogre where he stood, winning the battle for me.Now, this game is a beta. Like all betas, it comes with the "don't buy if you rage easily at faults only a game can do." Case in point: three quarters of my game time so far has been with my Mercenary Warband. I go into their fourth story mission and the games bugs out, the enemy I was facing never ends its turn, probably a unit I cannot see moving about  endlessly trying to reach one of my guys. I was forced to abandon the mission, and all of my warband was injured. All three of my heroes died, two archers lost their arms and would have to be fired, and my leader became a simpleton. Needless to say, I wasn't too pleased.Despite this, the game is immensely fun and satisfying if you can get over its rocky starting out phase. The interface tells you nothing on the surface when in-game, requiring you to be out in warband management or to go into a seperate menu to find out what "Righteous Fury" actually does and why it always misses. The payment and treatment system gets in the way a bit too, you will often be forced to fire and replace henchmen and heroes to keep your warband at fighting strength. However this can often be wasteful, the game seems to force you to pay for treatment and upkeep before you can fire any warrior in the warband, which seems utterly bizarre to me.Despite these negatives, the game shines on premise alone. The way characters are controlled is similar to turn based tactics games like Valkyria Chronicles. With the RPG elements of the tabletop Warhammer Fantasy Battles game, like the original board game was intended to be based around. The amount of customisation, stat variance, spells, skills, weapons, armours and trinkets in the game at present allow you to make your warband however you desire. This makes for some great innovation as people try to find the best possible set ups for your heroes and henchmen, but due to the diverse choice of loadouts, you can very easily counter these "metas" of soldiers should you want to play online.Multiplayer is not why you will buy this game mind you, the game's AI is not stupid, but can be exploited once you have figured out pathing, who it will target, etc. You will often find times when your spellcaster is near to death and hide them behind a shieldwall of heroes, and the AI will sooner run the length of the map for another attempt at that spellcaster than fight into your men. Ledges and cliffs are often exploitable too. Sisters of Sigmar come with no ranged weapons besides their spells, and the AI will refuse to use shortcuts like climbing and leaping, this results in very easy missions that are labelled "brutal" just because you stacked 5 archers on a cliff and put your captain and hero with a high parry chance in the way of the stairs up, leading to a Turkey shoot for your men.Overall, I would say this game has btrought me hours of fun already. I've been frustrated with how the game can♥♥♥♥♥♥you over sometimes, but that's just how these games go. XCOM fans who enjoy the iron man difficulties will find a passioniate love for this game. As it takes XCOM's "lose a man and that's it" style of gameplay and turns it up to eleven, with a whole host of mental and physical injuries that can steal your level 7 Champion from you in the blink of an eye. Needless to say, I do love this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												Very promising and reminds a lot of the old cult classic tabletop game. So far only 2 warbands, Skaven and human mercenaries, but they will add a lot more over time. Mechanics are fun, graphics and sounds are good. Overall a fun turnbased experience with a very interesting new take on action points, and how they work.Update: With the full release here and 4 warbands instead of two. They added Sisters of Sigmar, a hard-hitting band of religious nutcases Warhammer style as well as adding Cult of the Possessed, which is a Chaos warband, with all that that brings. Mutations, weird way of thinking and just plain barbarism.With over 100 hours logged, I have this to say: The game is very unforgiving, and at times extremely frustrating. Very long load times, which seems to be something the company can't fix because of how the game is built. it has a built in anti-rage quitter system, meaning if you quit during any mission or skirmish, it treats it as if the warband got routed and EVERY SINGLE WARRIOR in the fight will have to roll on the injury table to see if they suffer any injury or lose any equipment. This is very harsh, especially for single player where you don't really hurt anyone by abandoning a mission that goes really, really bad (considering the loss of one skilled warrior can set you back around 10 hours of game time). it doesn't help the AI is dumb as bricks, and pathfinding for large units really is an issue. More than once, I see them stuck by a door and just can't move.Still, even with its flaws this game is very addictive and I stand by my early access opinion, the game is great.2nd and last update: Loading times has been fixed, it now loads very fast. Gone from over a minute of loading time to around 15-20 seconds. (I use a SSD).They've added 2 new Warbands: The Witch Hunters, a warband of Witch Hunters (think the psychos from the witch hunts in Europes history) and their cohors: religious nutcases (Flagellants and Zealots). Their impressive unit is a very large human with the suiting profession of executioner. He likes to set his enemies on fire. While they're alive.The second new is Undead, set to be released tomorrow as I write this (the 25th of october 2016). I can't wait. Vampires. Zombies. Dregs. Necromancers. Crypt horros. Oh my.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												Mordheim, a game I have been playing on and off since early access, is a nice game turn based tactical game - resembling x-com, bloodbowl and other games where you have movement points and fighting points. You will get to know the characters of your warband, develop them and style them. But futher no real stretegic support of your party. You can insert character history and slighty modify their looks. I always like building up. However... the game is also quite merciless. My brave band of imperial mercenaries is led by a one-legged captain, assisted by a one-legged hero; covered by a archer with a permanent open wound; I have to admit. In other games I might have saved my sacred band of brave warriors and my twin-sister smugglers quite often and would have reloaded the missions time and time again to cheat my way out of the leg-losing and thus would have prevented the limitation of the range and actions of my beloved Captain Kenrick and his sidekick the couragrous hero Havok Sparrenschild. I would have re-loaded to avoid the loss of fighting points for my carefully contructed 6th level sharpshooter 'Lars Genade'. But alas. The loss is forever and final.... So much better this paralympic approach to find the green magical shards that are scattered throughout the city. Ofcourse you have to like the warhammer world to like the game, which is sometime a bit repetitious (but I didn't mind). If you can't stand skaven and ogres... don't buy this game. But if you feel like rampaging with blunderbusses and warhammers through a rotten, deserted, corrupted and decaying city (the artwork is quite nice): it is worth buying. Just be aware that you have to seperately buy the DLC.  That might be the true curse of Sigmar's comet.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
 Mordheim: City of the Damned is an infuriating, venom-dripping, and chaotic experience. However, it is an altogether pleasant experience and game. Mordheim: CotD is a turn-based video game adapation of the tabletop Mordheim game set in the Warhammer Fantasy universe, where the goal is to survive a hellish landscape in order to gather a rare, and dangerous, material known as Wyrdstone, known for its chaotic influence and ability to enhance magic. Being set in the more turbulent era of Warhammer Fantasy history, there is an abundance of weapons to use that are unique, magic with consequences, strict limitations and possible firing zones with ranged weapons (of which there are bows and firearms), and mythical races of characters. While this game does not have all of the races from the older Mordheim, the four chosen are very different and give a very accurate (read: grimdark) feel for the setting. The four races in CotD are the Empire Mercenaries, Skaven, Cult of the Possessed, and the Sisters of Sigmar. These races are divided into Warbands, consisting of (as time goes on) one Leader unit, up to three Hero units, one Impressive unit, and five Henchmen units. Following will be a generalization of each race, their purpose, and then a general playstyle (though this game is nearly limitless with how you create your Warband, and how you play them, especially with injuries being added into the mix). Spoilers will be placed for storyline, although only very vague information is given.The Empire Mercenaries are a warband of human mercenaries from the proud coalition of human factions. The Empire Mercenaries are part of the Order alignment, implying good intentions and care for the world.The mercenaries are sent to gather Wyrdstone for their employer. They do not care about his reasons.Mercenaries generally rely on tankier melee units and higher damage ranged units. Amazing in a team, this warband has issues if separated, for a ranged character is helpless if ambushed in melee, and will die from a few hits, while a melee character lacks the damage to best his opponent, leaving them locked in combat for several turns.The Skaven are a race of greedy and cruel humanoid rat-men, particularly from Clan Eshin, a clan of assassins.The Skaven are part of the Chaos alignment, working for selfish intentions and care little for anybody but themselves.The Skaven warband is attempting to gather Wyrdstone, which they call Warpstone, in order to increase personal prestige among the ranks of the influential Murderlord.The Skaven are low health with high Initiative (order of who goes first per turn) and high damage. They generally rely on quickly swarming an enemy (one of their racial skills, appropriately named Swarm, gives bonuses for every Skaven attacking the same unit) and wiping them out one or two at a time. Lacking any tanks until they get their Impressive rank warrior, they rely on Dodging and Parrying even more than the other races. The Cult of the Possessed are a faction of mutants and chaos warriors with no regard for life at all.The Cult is a Chaos-aligned faction, willing to murder and betray, and even mutate their own bodies, for more power.The Cult is attempting to obtain greater and greater power from an entity known as the Shadowlord, in exchange for Wyrdstone.The Cult is generally a more melee oriented unit, though they have a Magician as their Leader, and rely on overwhelming power to kill their foes. Lots of buffs, decent health, and high damage make them a force to be reckoned with, especially in the scarily narrow streets of Mordheim.The Sisters of Sigmar are a zealous group of religious fanatics, similar to Paladins from other games.The SoS are aligned with Order, hoping to combat evil and to spread the message of their god through face-smashing.The SoS are attempting to gather all of the Wyrdstone simply so that it cannot fall into the hands of evil.The SoS generally rely on powerful and high health units to completely destroy their enemies in combat. However they are slow, and have a very difficult time dealing with multi-level attacks.Mordheim is a very dangerous place often causing injuries to your Warband ranging from a simple experience loss, to amputation, and death. The game is very unforgiving, and you may make two or three Warbands, having them be crippled and ruined one after the other, until something finally clicks and you surge ahead, destroying your opposition and doing SO good until your main warrior loses an arm, and can no longer use that bow/halberd/shield that you relied on, and you scream into the night, causing dogs to bark, and you fume and pace around your room trying to decide if you should get a new Leader, make a new Warband, or accept the 20% dodge increase from losing an arm, and you just keep rambling and crying and pout... sorry, that hit a little close to home. As a game of incredibly high risk though, the RNG is downright out to get you, and you will often miss attacks you had an 85% chance to hit. Twice. This may seem unfair, however it is more accurately tied to the tabletop game where you'd roll upwards of five die per attack. Yet, even with an AI you swear is cheating, your best warrior being taken down by a stupid ambush that you totally weren't in range of, and RNG causing you to lose your best tank because he missed a 97% parry chance, victory is insanely addicting. Mordheim: CotD, despite being brutal and unfair, is one of the few games I've played in a long time that really made my victories feel hard-fought and well-earned. I'm addicted to finding out what I could do, and could have done, better. 8/10TL;DR: Hard game, lots of customization, game literally hates you, you may want to amputate your own limbs (I mean, hey, 20% bonus dodge chance!). Awesome.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												Update - I'm having more fun then before.  I've found more bugs and the story missions can be confusing sometimes.  But, the epic feel of survival is great.  I'm not one to complain that I miss a 95% roll.  I don't believe that game is broke or cheats, I believe I just had a bad roll.  I also hit the other day when I had a 7% chance on a shot.  It is random and it happens, but games like this are built that way.  I don't want to know exactly what is going to happen every sword swing that would be pretty dumb.  The injuries don't bother me.  I don't ever deploy my own troops, I always let the computer deploy them for me.  I like the difficulty.  I have a Human Merc warband and we've struggled and also dominated.  Nothing better then getting smacked around, scrapping together after the fight and going out and deciminating your enemy next time.  Yes you can do that.  This game is simply fantastic.  There are minor issues here and there and some odd graphic glitches.  But, overall the game requires thought and planning.  But, I think it captures the warhammer world very well and handles the mechanics of the boardgame.I wish it had multiplayer servers and warbands were stored online for online play.  Some kind of ladder or online campaign would be great as well.I would buy additional warbands as DLC.  I would also pay for multiplayer.  It is a great merc sim and really has been the kind of game I've been waiting for. Well done, Well done indeed.  9.0 out of 10.  Would like multiplayer ladders, servers, clans etc...  Also multiplayer campaigns.  I hope this is game is a hit and they look at funding or kickstarting some of those features.  We also need more custom options for faces.  All my guys look the same and that is annoying.  Make it so people can mod.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Decent game, Crashes at times but what did you expect from Early Access?The main problem is that WHEN you crash it counts as a loss in the game and since there is no save function at all (to stop people from saving during their turn and then loading when they know what the enemy will do/loses a unit) it leads to horrible damage to all your units and sometimes you have to start all over because half your warband died in a crash and the other half lost legs and arms (which is a ♥♥♥♥♥ if you want to use shields or bows) and you just dont have enough money to buy a new one.If you ever need to leave in the middle of a game you are ♥♥♥♥ed since leaving is always a loss and there isnt even an "pause this ♥♥♥♥ing battle and just let me return to this exact same point in the game when i start it again" function.The only safe time to leave is between missions and even then im scared.Another minor problem is that all skills cost a minimum of 100 gold to train (good ones cost 250) while a new level 0 unit costs 15 and all the things you sell (basic stuff which can be found in heaps all over the place) sells for 1-10 gold.Combine this with the fact that you have to pay around 5xNumber of units you own in salary after every mission and you might never get enough gold to get skills after a while.The campaign has only two missions at the time but they are hard as balls and require you to farm and level up all your characters and units (and all farm comes in either the same strength as your warband or stronger so there is no way to just farm lvl 1 slimes over and over until you get strong) to hope to survive them.Nonetheless with the customization tool, unique turn based strategy with first person control of all your units its worth the money for the entertainment and endless campaign.11/10 would play Khorne Sorcerer protected by his Slaneeshi tank, Nurglite Archer and Tzeenchian barbarian again.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11
												Mordheim: City of the Damned is a great game based off Games Workshop's Tabletop skirmish game.  If you're looking for a direct translation, this is not the game for you.  If you want a great tactical skirmish and management game, this should be on your wishlist.The important part is to keep both sides of the game in balance: tactical and management.  Your Warband can quickly find itself out of money if you lose matches, or get your Warband members skills without a cushion.  Adding Wyrdstone shipments to the mix, and you have an adequate representation of life in Mordheim.  It may not be true to the game, but it has Mordheim's spirit down.While playing against the AI is fun, it's even better when you are playing against a human opponent... although one might be hard to come by at tmes.  You can do both with the same game, switching back and forth as your friends hop on, or playing against the computer to get that last bit of Wyrdstone in before the shipment's late (miss three and the game's over).There is one piece of advice before playing against human opponents: get used to playing against the computer first.  The game is frustrating when you start out, as you don't know the lay of the land that well.  True to its namesake, Mordheim is merciless when someone doesn't know the layout of each map as well as their opponent.  You will find yourself flanked, and a great skirmish game will find itself shelved.Manage your Troops.  Manage your Gold.  Manage your Time.  Manage your Temper.  Do all these things, and you might survive Mordheim... for a while.
