number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												Mordheim is a rather challenging turn-based squad management RPG set in the Warhammer world, with unforgiving rogue-like qualities that won't be to eveyone's liking. To be quite frank, people who head in thinking Mordheim willl be akin to XCOM will probably be rather let down. This is primarliy an old Games Workshop board game brought to life with all the idiosyncracies this entails, and it therefore has far more in common with Blood Bowl than regular turn-based titles. Don't let the 3rd person gfx trick you into thinking otherwise, that's basically just a way of getting scenary and elevation changes to work (something that wasn't needed with Cyanide's Blood Bowl conversion). The Blood Bowl comparisons continue through to the front-end, which is about as user friendly as a casual headbutt. However, perseverance with the steep learning curve and the obtuse management system does start to pay off. Trying to keep a fledgling warband afloat by selling everything and fielding guys with smashed up legs only to find you've then got no spare weapons for your next raid is the kind of experience you'll either like or despise - luckily for me, it's right up my street. I tried PVP in beta and it had a lot going for it but I've just been doing campaign stuff since I fired it up aagin and I am genuinely impressed with the solo experience. The meta actually has a lot in common with Darkest Dungeon (this is a good thing, DD is wonderful). Also of note is that the Xbox pad works nicely, meaning I can get my tactical on from the armchair.Mordheim has developed nicely into a game that now offers a fairly singular experience, though undoubtably rather niche. If you're looking for a mixture of Blood Bowl and Darkest Dungeon then look no further.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												Update - I'm having more fun then before.  I've found more bugs and the story missions can be confusing sometimes.  But, the epic feel of survival is great.  I'm not one to complain that I miss a 95% roll.  I don't believe that game is broke or cheats, I believe I just had a bad roll.  I also hit the other day when I had a 7% chance on a shot.  It is random and it happens, but games like this are built that way.  I don't want to know exactly what is going to happen every sword swing that would be pretty dumb.  The injuries don't bother me.  I don't ever deploy my own troops, I always let the computer deploy them for me.  I like the difficulty.  I have a Human Merc warband and we've struggled and also dominated.  Nothing better then getting smacked around, scrapping together after the fight and going out and deciminating your enemy next time.  Yes you can do that.  This game is simply fantastic.  There are minor issues here and there and some odd graphic glitches.  But, overall the game requires thought and planning.  But, I think it captures the warhammer world very well and handles the mechanics of the boardgame.I wish it had multiplayer servers and warbands were stored online for online play.  Some kind of ladder or online campaign would be great as well.I would buy additional warbands as DLC.  I would also pay for multiplayer.  It is a great merc sim and really has been the kind of game I've been waiting for. Well done, Well done indeed.  9.0 out of 10.  Would like multiplayer ladders, servers, clans etc...  Also multiplayer campaigns.  I hope this is game is a hit and they look at funding or kickstarting some of those features.  We also need more custom options for faces.  All my guys look the same and that is annoying.  Make it so people can mod.

												Played the Free Weekend, will buy it next sale most likely,Feels Good to win, havent lost a whole Battle yet, but had some charackters die, some because i died stupid stuff, some because of a streak of bad luck. But overall the Game is entertaining.Pros:+Atmosphere+Sound+Customization (Active and Passive Skills)+Warhammer Fantasy+"Difficult" if you like it (opinion based anyway)+Different Warbands (Factions) that look quite different and probably play more differently (just have played 1 Warband, but had to adjust the tactic against the other Factions)+Different every time you start againCons:-UI (scrolling through every action instead of just being able to click the one you want in Combat)-the Combat Mode feels slow, would love to be able to speed enemy movement that i cant see-sometimes makes you feel horrible for just having a streak of bad luck-

content:
Posted: January 9
												This game is great, if you know what to expect and how to play. First of all, its as much strategy as it is gambling (which makes it that much better- you gonna cheer every time that sigmar-♥♥♥♥♥♥ misses your poor ratkin on 10 hp and curse when you fall climbing 2 meter wall 3 times). All you realy have to do is learn how AI works and act accordingly. Few pointers: most important thing is your survival. Do not overextend, dont go alone. Read the mission scenarios.Alwyas place your warriors by yourself. Study map, plan where you want to defend yourself, dont treat green stuff as a priority- you get some even if you dont gather it if you win. Take advantage of choke points.Rest, you must figure out by yourself. Key is the attitude. Oh and dont get used to your first warband. Treat em as an experiment. Thats it! Great gambling-strategy, only civ5 beats it for me. Get it on sale and buy globadier expansion! well worth itEdit; There are two things that i'd really like to see in that game: more character customization options, and possibility to deploy your guys from tactical view. The last one would save so much time!

												Hi Mordheimers and filthy skaven folks like me.First of all, an advice: This game goes the oppositte of anything i´ve tried, so, don´t think what nice tactic you would use, think "¿WHAT IS THE WORST THING THAT COULD HAPPEN?"... and then plan a tactic for that... :)Seriously, as a big old-school-hardcore-tabletop-player i think this game is worth playing, because of its difficulty, and its rawness. You can loot other players and even die without doing anything wrong? Prepare for banging your head against the monitor, because it would happen...At first, i thought that this game could be much better with an isometric view of xcom and the literal translation from the tabletop like bloodbowl... but I think that Rogue didn´t go for the easy, and they did a very good game.Still a few issues, but this is truly addictive and the developers made a huge leap since early access.You want to see your hands shaking? Praying to gods you don´t believe? Saying "please miss" involuntarily? And then cheering all by yourself shouting "Yes, yes, ♥♥♥♥ you Sigmar scum!"? Well... this is your game then...

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												I've had great moments in this game, even though at the time of writing this review, the game is far from complete. But I can see myself playing this game, until it is complete and allows me to manage my troops through an evolutive process. Mordheim is a game in the spirit of the many Warhammer themed games that already exists. The World of Warhammer is a grim world where life has no value and everyone, from the greatest hero to the lowest of the low, can die in an instant. It shall be the same with your troops. They will get hurt, light and grave, they will die. You will loose your Champions, but if you play your cards right, you will prevail ... at least that's how I hope the game will shape up to be ... like its tabletop equivalent, up there with tabletop Bloodbowl !Edit: I have now come back to Mordheim: City of the Damned after its launch. This is the game I expected so this review remains positive ! I'll give you my pros and cons:PROS:- Turned based epic fights- Character progression coupled with injury/death system that can be ruthless if you really are unlucky (your favorite hero/leader might die or have permanent injuries each time they are put out of action ... of they might get lucky and miraculously recover) ... don't put all your eggs in the same basket and you might want to wait until your characters are better equipped before training them for this 200 gold skill ...- The maps are fun. There's a lot of terrain to cover and you'd best remember to manage movements tactically.- Warband progression is, overall, very slow but I consider this a pro since it rewards long term planning and strategy. Bad luck can really mess with your plans ... but we accept that as one of the reasons we play such a game in the first place.CONS:- Long loading times. I understand the scale of the map and that warband generation is a complicated process but ... I can't imagine people at minimum requirements not ending up losing patience.- Random numbers generation (dice rolls) is weird. This game gives us percentages but I feel like it rolls d4s in its tests. It's come to the point where I started rolling dice as I made my throws for a couple games, to compare and I wish I could play with dice ... they never gave me 6 misses in a row twice in a game on 84% chances to hit, my dice respect statistics a lot more than the game seems to be doing. I mention this only because I'm usually very good at risk assesment in such games but I'm now almost convinced I have to threat a 75% chance of success more like a 40% chance of success when taking decisions. Is that only me ?- The user interface and user experience could easily be vastly improved. Menus could be arranged differently so that there's no counter intuitive stuff such as a list of incoming events in the Mission Selection screen (there could be a "general information" menu for that and other informations spread around different menus). The "Warband management" menu where you pay for treatments and characters upkeep is a button just like other buttons. It could have its own menu or be a bit more evident, since it opens a menu which is different from the menus opened by other similar buttons in the same page. I'm sorry that I didn't bother suggesting that before the game was released.- A lot of randomness which you cannot influence. For example, sellswords and shop inventories. I don't dislike the current system, I just wish there was a way for me to have a way to influence those. At times, my progress was slowed or my warband subefficient simply because I couldn't find anything good in the shop or because available sellswords didn't fit what I needed (when I could afford them, sometimes I had kickass sellsword worth 40 gold !!! Other times, I have over priced leaders who really aren't worth the price they ask ...)- Hard to navigate the map, to gain knowledge about it to better strategize. Sometimes I wish I could get out of my characters' perspective to inspect something he can clearly see even if the range was limited (it would have to be). I always have so much trouble finding building entrances ...- I wish there were more different warbands to chose from. DLC !Overall, this is the game I hoped for with longer loading times. It is a challenging game, but also a rewarding game. Don't get frustrated at your losses, learn from them ... and if you lose again tell yourself you can't win them all. Bury your warband, remember them and start a new one.Good hunting amongst the damned !

content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
												This game proved to be far more fun than I originally thought it would be.  I had gotten this as part of the HB Monthly and decided to go ahead and try it out because there was really no point in not doing so.  What I found was a rather impressive take on turn-based strategy that was wholly unexpected.While the game seems simple at first, the tutorials leave much to be desired and make things a bit more difficult than they have to be as a result.  The tutorials never really tell you how to loot or pick up items, though I was able to figure it out once I completed one of the tutorials.  The learning curve is a bit steep, since this game does things very differently from other strategy games I've played.What's Different?First of all, you get to customize a faction all your own.  While you choose the starting race and type of characters you'll play, everything beyond this is pretty much up to how you want to go about things.  You'll start with a small team of 4 characters:  your leader, a hero, and a couple of henchmen, and go out into the ruined city of Mordheim for loot and wyrdstones.  While the customization isn't great, there's enough there that you shouldn't get bored with setting your characters up.Character movement and actions are handled with a variety of points.  This allows you a bit more freedom with how you can take your turns, but means you have to strategize a bit more.  Henchmen are pretty weak and you don't really want them to rush forward and get slaughtered by a potentially powerful enemy you were unaware of.Characters can receive lasting/permanent injuries over the course of the game.  Fortunately, this is fairly balanced and doesn't happen too frequently, but when it does, look out.  You may need to retire that character and recruit someone to take their place.  Some injuries are minor and others can be outright crippling, so make sure you pay attention to the details; they are important in this one.Unlike many strategy games, it isn't necessary to take out all of the enemy to win.  Each mission has a variety of means that you can win, typically, such as routing the enemy, killing a specific character, or acquiring a certain number of resources.  So far, routing the enemy has been how I've completed most missions, as your inventory space is at a premium.Pros:  Customizable faction, time is a factor on what you do between missions (such as healing and training), lots of variety of weapons and equipment to allow you to further customize your team and how you play the gameCons:  A steep learning curve, and tutorials that leave much to be desired.In Conclusion:  A fun game with a lot of nuance, if you like the idea of strategy games where you have to plan a considerable amount more than you may be used to in other games and have a lot of customization options, this is probably the game for you.  If you aren't into learning a new way of playing strategy games and want to stick to the tried and true methods of other games, you may find this one quite frustrating.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1
												I am both surprised and not surprised to find this game has mixed reviews. What's more surprising is that a lot of the negative reviews are from people familiar with the tabletop game it was adapted from.I was a big Mordheim fan in my teenage years despite not having much affection for Games Workshop's more popular products. I loved how it mixed role-playing, which I was a big fan of, and war games. It really felt like a tabletop XCOM.I hate to say that people nixing this game are playing it wrong, but they are. Your warband is not meant to be eternal. While I think it's a bit of a design hiccup to add a campaign mode, thus the illusion of progression, but the Mordheim I remember isn't about that. It's about seeing how far you can get before you run your warband into the ground. Once you've done that, you're meant to roll up the next warband.You're not meant to form any kind of bond or attachment to your individual actors. They're tools. In time, they will wear out and break. If you have the gold, you replace them with fresh tools. If you don't, you go out of business. It's that simple.And while there really isn't a lot of variety to the combat in the early stages of the game...generally it pays to bait the AI into an ambush then gang up on them before help arrives...I don't mind because that's generally how Mordheim always worked. Your individual fighters are so brittle and weak, and risking them can be very costly, combat is all about managing the risk/reward of individual engagements. It's about setting up kill zones to lure enemies into where your best assets are covered by henchmen and efficiently knocking enemies out of the fight.I only wish maps were either larger or the AI a little less aggressive so that it would be possible to grab more of the wyrdstone and treasure on the map. Unlike the tabletop game, most of your income comes from items collected during the mission rather than rewarded after the fact.In all, if you enjoy games like XCOM but want something a little more brutal that requires a bit more patience and time to learn, I wholeheartedly recommend Mordheim.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
												Ridiculously difficult.  And by difficult, I really just mean the RNG system sucks.  I think it's just a bad mechanic at this point and doesn't have a place in modern vidya.  Missing three times in a row on a 75% chance to hit is not fun.  Enemy difficulty also seems to scale very badly, and you can easily build your squad "wrong."  As in there's a ton of non-viable builds possible.  There's no point in that being a thing unless you're trying to actively make the game frustrating to the player and not fun.  Seems like pretty linear progression until you're just ♥♥♥♥ed and there's nothing you can do about it.Great artwork, interesting random map generator, good VO and music.  The factions are distinct and interesting despite 3/5 of them just being different groups of humans.I'm not obsessed enough with this game to ever beat it by doing a bunch of math and finding out what the system exploit strategies are.  I shouldn't have to.  Early on in a campaign it's really fun, but that enjoyment shouldn't drop off so dramatically as you progress and get further and further hindered by permanent debuffs, drained of funds and forced to take rush missions.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has a lot of potential, but as a very early access title it's lacking a *lot* of content at the moment. The base combat system is easy enough to grasp (though the keyboard controls feel clunky at times) yet still hints at a lot of depth in gameplay. I'm really looking forward to seeing what they do with the single player campaign/warband progression. The game captures the world and atmosphere of Warhammer Fantasy quite well with good character and level models/textures. I did notice that a failed climb-down animation using a Sister parted her torso from her legs a bit and exposed the nothingness inside, but it's early access and that's only a small visual bug. The only gameplay bug I encountered was on the Temple of Sigmar map, skirmishing against AI and playing as the defender in the siege scenario. It took me a few turns to realise what was happening as I had no idea where the AI team was - they were trapped outside and didn't seem capable of getting in (which I think required climbing) so it would have been up to the defender to exit and engage the enemy. Given the newness I have no idea how good (or bad) the company is at updating and sticking to schedule etc., so can't comment on that yet. Looking forward to playing more as the updates come. The game is definitely worth keeping an eye on even if you're not interested in playing the early access (which I usually avoid, but I'm a fan of WHFB so I couldn't wait for this).

Posted: November 30, 2015
												A solid game, it’s hard to get going on this one but once you build up your war band it gets a little easier. This game makes you want to look after your warriors due to the perma death/injury system every decision you make counts. After 60 hours of game play I can say I would defiantly recommend this game to fans of the warhammer universe.RNG is a huge part of this game I would be lying if I said it did not matter how lucky you are, you will find times when you are about it attack an enemy and all you will be thinking is please hit! Please hit! and…… Swing and a miss! But that’s the game if you can deal with stuff like that you will have a blast.Anyone who knows what this game is about or even reads up on it should know what they are letting themselves in for it is not a friendly game, but by god once you get into it you don’t want to let go.I play Skaven it was hard going at first but I love my little warband now, you can even customize the colouring of the armour I mainly use it so I know where my hero’s and leaders are, the weapon rarity and choice leave a little bit to be desired having only 3 tiers of weapon quality. Its fine but I could think of better ways to do it. (not going to go into it in a review) the stats system works well and is easy to understand, the single player campaign is all I have played since release and I can say it works well and is very fun the campaign missions are nice and add a lot more depth into the game. The voice actor for the Skaven campaign did a great job, I have not played multiplayer since the release but I did play it during early access, it is just as fun as the single player IMO, a little harder depending on your opponent.8.5/10 from me for this game.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												I was on the fence, wether to recommend this game or not. Something between Walkyria Chronicles and XCOM, in a dark fantasy setting. If you love the setting, that should be a no-brainer I think. For others... I just don't know. Than again, it may be about 6/10 for me score wise,but I wouldn't just say to stay out of it.It is, in fact, a good game, but with a ton of things that irritate me.First of all, the game is hard. Which is not a bad thing in itself. First time I ran the game, did the first tutorial,fully customized my first warband and... I died almost instantly.So I read some tips in the Internet and also armed with my previous experience... I created a new warband and never lost yet. The game has an AI that you can exploit easily. In fact, just playing it slow and carefully is enough for the AI to not know how to tackle you. It promotes slow movements and usage of the choke points. Anything else is just inviting the punishment it seems (though If someone says I'm not doing it right, I won't object, maybe I didn't figure out other tactics).After that, it eventually gets repetetive. Shipments feel much more of a chore than fun, but it seems that they are the one thing that forces you to try and explore the map in search of resources.On top of all of that, the game is slow. Yes, it is a turn based game, but it is not slow because you have to think much, it is slow because you click end of turn and wat... And you wait more than you play. And you wait while it loads. It might be not fair to judge the game based on such a thing like this, but in the end - it affects the satisfaction you get from the game. Visually... There are not many models to choose from. There are plenty of color skins though, so I am on the fence here. It's ok, but it could have been much better. I think that customization and sticking to your characters with their backstories is the huge strength of the game.I see the potential in this game. It could as well turn 6 to 8 out of 10 if it is going to be worked upon. Otherwise, hard to say.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
												THE BEST PC GAMES YOU NEVER PLAYED (AND SHOULD) REVIEW SERIESOne the best games out there if you are into turn based games and or Warhammer fantasy world setting.The average person will get about 200 hours out of this game along with the DLC already available. And you will want the DLC. With witchunters, the smuggler, and the poison globe skaven being my favorites. Even if you dont buy the DLC's they will still show up in your game as enemies. So really its all free unless you want to play them yourself.This game is unforgiving and brutal. The learning curve will have you swearing and pulling out your hair. You can not manually save and if you screw up, your warband will pay for it in crippled or dead troops. You can manually cheat and save your games, but id suggest not as you risk corrupting the save file and losing it all. If you are used to save scumming and just taking back all your mistakes, then you will be rather annoyed with this game. AT least until you learn its generally ok to take a beating and unless you totally bite it three times in a row, then you can recover from a bad round or two.Some quick hints for new players:Keep your band together, dont try to one on one fight the enemies. Choose missions where your warband all starts around your wagon.Choose early on to what defense type you will use, being either dodge or parry type and seek out skills you can learn later on that allow you to use these defenses twice in a turn.Its ok to skip a day to let your team heal from injuries or train skills. Its not the end of the world to skip a day.Story missions are impossibly hard, well so it may seem. Make sure you are ready before diving in.This game has a good selection of warbands right now, but it really could use more. And hopefully there will be more ASAP. The table top version has so many options and in comparison the PC version feels a bit lacking. But 7 like the game has now is a decent enough selection of warbands. And they all have different play styles which makes it even better. But personally i wouldn't mind 14 of them, with each main warband re-skinned in a slightly different variant.The leveling system is addicting. The loot is just varied enough to be addicting, though i wish there were more to choose from on some warbands. Some warbands use rather specialized gear and it can be hard sometimes to find upgraded versions of it from all the random drops. The wolf priest being the prime example, i have never once found an upgraded version of his enhanced weapon of ulric.All in all this game will give you your monies worth. And hopefully in the future DLCs will up the ante even more. Its a total buy and if you find this game on sale and dont buy it, THEN SLAP YOURSELF! cause youre making a huge mistake not getting it.(also available on consoles if that is your thing)

content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Hey guys and gals this will be my second review ever.Mordheim:City of the Damned.what can i say about it? well until recently i woudl say it was a good single player skirmish game against an AI opponent...as i said Until recently.Recently there has been an update that saw to a little bug that would cause the game to go into ( cue ominous movie trailer voice )INFINITE LOADING SCREEN. this had cause many people to avoid the online portion as fear of being stuck thinking it was loading.Now with the recent update it would appear that the bug has been seen to...but then again im only going off of 1 online match so far... >.>;;As of RIGHT now there are only 2 warbands available while you can fight against 2 other in the tutorials you cannot access them as playable or contestable AI.The 2 warbands are the Humans and the RatMan race known as the Skaven.These two warbands are rather entertaining in the EA build but i do feel some of the fun in making a warband isn't there because as of right now it is premade warbands.( this is just for E/A) ( i also hope that the types of units will be expanded upon later hopefully AR (After Release) if not the ability to buy specific units ( which will Definitely be added later on in the E/A) might make for interesting play.The city of Mordheim is a Dark Fantasy Locale. When I say dark i mean DARK.  im nor one hundred percent sure if it's implemented but when i have tried to use a daylight setting in my games it still feels like night ( i think it may have to do with the everlasting storm over Mordheim ) there are some camera issues which are being adressed by the dev team. these issues, at least for me, mainly consist of the view going behind a wall and not being able to see your attacks.these are minro things that are being adressed.now you may ask then why bring them up? because i wanted to shwo you how in touch with the community this dev team is.lets get down to it then for you TL;DR peoplePros+Setting and atmosphere+ sound+ fun gameplay+ fun features to be executed at a later date+ Dev team that is in touch with the communitycons-Atmosphere can seem kind of stale ( when day and night don't appear, to me anyways, to be any different)-camera issues at current stage of E/A- E/A so not all features are availableSuggestion for youIf you wish to be part of a community that is iving feedback to the dev team and having their voices heard buy the game nowif you do not wish to have the E/A version hold off for a few months until it is farther along and purchase then..final suggestion... Purchase. this. game.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												Here is a list of reasons:Please note, I do enjoy this game, but with the current price it just isn't worth it. If you really want it, wait for a sale. Please note that this game is till being updated, so in the future you could buy it, after bug fixes and the game is more nicely ironed out. (Also note that this review may quickly become outdated. The bugs and other things I complained about may have been fixed.The game can be quite glitchy, for instance, one time one of my warriors randomly fell through a floor (Which by the way should not happen) and was stuck underneath a building for the entire game. There are many other glitches as well.The game is quite unbalanced, the skaven, for instance, are very unbalanced, instead of adapting the board games way of balancing it they decided to change it. See, the skaven in the board game are very weak and dull, but they come in great numbers. In the game however, they are very strong and almost impossible to hit. They have little health, but hit stronger than the sisters of sigmar, and your lucky to hit them.Oh yeah, and the game is based entirely on chance.I also feel that some of the impressives should be stronger, specifically the Sisters of Sigmars impressive. She's pathetic. I got into a map and I saw a skaven players rat ogre. So, I charged her at it because it was exposed and there were no skaven near by. Then she missed all of her attacks, and was killed in two turns by the rat ogre with help from another skaven who ran across the entire map, because, oh right, the skaven are also incredibly fast.If you want to win multiplayer battles, just play as the skaven!Just to clarify, I like this game, but it should still be in early access. This game is just so broken and needs lots of fixes and patches. The price tag is ridiculous considering how broken this game is, if it were in early access it could be excused. But I can't let this game escape from my talons. So I will say again, FIX THE GAME. (And lower the price.)

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												This has been masked as a 'hardcore' experience and that 'difficult is good' but that poorly considered term is so inappropriate for a game governed by dice.  It is simply issued as a means to excuse an appallingly negligent hi-lo RNG that is geared simply for that - you will fail an abundance of reasonable rolls because this lazy♥♥♥♥♥♥programming has been PR'd as hardcore.  ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ more like.Too many issues that still need fixing and I mean from the ground up, ambush, overwatch, dodge, placement etc etc (even picking up wierdstone, which is kind of currency, it auto selects to pick up the smallest quantity first, when there are more than one in your area.  COME ON!).  With a game with such a small catchment bracket, (I had never heard of this and bought it because I like the Dawn of War series) its further expansion from its original hardcore fans would require it to be successful in the combat, strategy stakes.  It fails so badly with one of the worst RNGs I think I've seen and that's after a recent RNG 'revamp'!!!3/10  and that is only because the baroque scenery and sound effects are, admittedly, very good but that's of little consolation.20.12.16  I have given this game a really good go and I'd take a refund in a heatbeat.  I wouldn't listen to any of the gaming review websites who have given this a score over 5, they either haven't played it, are drunk in the workplace or are the worst kind of chums.  This is ♥♥♥♥ing dire and is uninstalled (slap to the face).  A real shame as the underlying concept looks to be pretty good.  GW do this for a living, not sure if Rogue Fuctor can be accused of doing the same.10.02.16 Tried it again, after the recent patch and I take it all back. This game is a game of a winner. Winners who should offer a refund. I will grudgingly accept.  Seriously give me a ♥♥♥♥ing refund, you♥♥♥♥♥♥programmers.18.02.16  Tried it again, again, after apparently another rng tweak after some amateurish programming started killing saved games.  One plus before I get into it - the map has improved and although it's not for most I like the unique method (if you zoom in, you can tell the levels you are looking for for a shooting point etc).  Now, giving the opposition lesser weapons is not an rng tweak it's just lazy amateur ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, built by a business that put all it's accumulative intellect into the business name.  One glaring problem from the very start is that when you fail an All Alone test,  you will run and get chopped down, when the AI fails they skip a turn.  Just so laughably♥♥♥♥♥♥  Everything I've said already about this farce holds true.  This game is dead in the water and the programmers have nobody but themselves to blame.  I've a feeling it's only going to get worse for them, silly little people. They've even brought out DLC for this s#hit.  Talk about delusions of grandeur.  Make a game people willl want to play, make sure it works, make sure it isn't a ♥♥♥♥ing joke, give it difficulty levels so that people can play at their own pace, give it saved game so people can reload instead of having to restart and give it an ironman setting (although Xcom is still too buggy for that and this is far, far worse).  Don't, DON'T♥♥♥♥♥♥on the punters' tents and tell them it's raining with this hardcore ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, when you're too ♥♥♥♥ing lazy to put a decent RNG together.  If you can do the above then you may last.  If you can't - find another ♥♥♥♥ing job, one that you're actually good at and give me a ♥♥♥♥ing refund so I can get this♥♥♥♥♥♥off my library.I'm seeing a lot of flaky RNGs of late (this, the god awful Shadowrun series and Blackguards), all TBS and all being simularly criticised for just♥♥♥♥♥♥poor RNGs.  Is there a market to buy RNGs so you don't have to dev them yourself?  If so then these 'devs' really need to check what they're buying because such poor RNGs and subsequently poor games (as the RNG is the most important component of a TBS, where relevant) can kill a studio, before it's even got off the ground.That said, ♥♥♥♥-whit Home interactive have published far too many♥♥♥♥♥♥games.  One wonders if they have an agenda of publishing really♥♥♥♥♥♥games.  If so, then their business model is working out well.  Too many ♥♥♥♥-whits about.  Will have to see about this.09/09/16  OMGG.  This is how amateurish Rogue Fuctor is?  Now I know why no saves or difficulty levels were incorporated into this game.  They have no multiplayer support!!  They attempted to convert a TT game that relies on gang warfare for the streets of Mordheim, where each player's warband tries to topple the current top-dog and take turf from all-comers.  The most interesting part of the game and they're not able to actualise it.  Instead they have a farcical  mish-mash, where players grind they're warbands against a ♥♥♥♥ed AI and can use said warband to have one-off skirmishes, with no context or attachment for the players.Wow, you guys are dire.  Would still take a refund.One wonders if ♥♥♥♥-whit Home Interactive and GW are such a negligent bunch of ♥♥♥♥s that they throw their projects to the cheapest possible company, regardless of their capacity to make a competent, let alone good game.

												I read a lot of negative reviews for this game but after several hours of play i can happily say that the majority of those negative reviews are just mis-informed as to the game mechanics. The RNG is not terrible as they would have you believe, it's just that you not only have to hit the target, but also they have to fail their parry of dodge (whichever stance they are in .. not both) for a successful hit to do damage. The same mechanics work in your favor as well. The game is difficult, yes. It's not a game where you can roflstomp the opposition without thought. You have to use strategy and tactics to be successful but there is a huge sense of achievement in victories and even defeats are not the end.All in all, love the game anf highly recommend it to strategy enthusiasts.

												I've played and enjoyed many challenging and difficult games in my time, but none of them come anywhere close to the butt♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥this game dishes out.That alone wouldn't turn me off to the game, but what makes it completely inexcusable is that no ammount of planning or caution can guard you against it outside of taking advantage of the terrible AI. It all comes down to horrible random roll streaks that the AI suspiciously doesn't suffer while still having WAY better stats... Way to take the intellegence out of game design Rogue Factor.What's so sad is there is a lot about this game I like:• deep RPG progression• loot system• unit variety• dark gothic themeProblem is none of it comes even close to making up for the unavoidable absolutely horrendous punishment you're going to take.But the bad doesn't end there:• incredibly repetitive missions. It's almost always the same "kill or route all the enemies".• horendous AI. Either charge in or in the case of the large units, get stuck on collision• devs' attempt to balance terrible AI: give the enemy WAY better units and stats.• way too punishing and permanently crippling to be completely dependent on randomizers. You'll find yourself missing or falling flat on your♥♥♥♥♥over and over again as if those 90% likelyhood of success ratings are just there to force failure on you despite perfectly laid battle plans.I normally enjoy a challenge when a game like Dark Souls does it right. They make difficult challenges fun and rewarding because if played perfectly, you can succeed and do well. This game however punishes you severely for failing rolls out of your control over and over again and right from the beginning. I fail to see why the developers seem to want to♥♥♥♥♥♥their customers off. Where's the fun or success in that?So as much as I wish I could recommend this as a deep and rewarding strategy game, unless you're a masochist, don't even think about buying game. Find something fun to play instead! :D

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												I have enjoyed this game since early access so to me this game has only gotten better but i'll break it down into positive / negative things there are to look out for so you can decide on your own if you would consider the same things positive / negative.Negative:- Still has some optimization to do- There is a chance you will find an invisible wall or an invisible wall will be created because of something in the map- Has a relatively high learning curve if you have not played anything like this before which can be overwhelming and may need to be taken in more than 1 session.- Has no multiplayer unless you find a friend to set it up with or get very lucky some random person around your warbands lvl is looking for a game.- A total of 4 races -> humans, Chaos, Skaven and Sisters of sigmar is a big issue for some even though i once again am fine with this number since i don't jump between races a lot.- Most common complaint i can think of is the variation in missions (all missions are optional. Main objective is always to beat the opponents warband or make them rout before you lose or rout)    -> Wyrdstone Rush where you collect typically 45% - 60% of the wyrdstone in the map to complete the OPTIONAL      objective   -> Marked for death where you have certain targets from the other warband normally between 1 and 3 specific people you need to kill and take an insigna from   -> Crush their will where you are tasked with retrieving the opponents idol and bring it back to your own cartI completely understand why some people would consider this a too small amount of missions even though i am completely fine with them.Positive:- They have done a great job at making your warband feel like they matter giving you that classic fear of someone getting killed or sustaining a permanent injure like an arm or a leg that has been severed.- The insane number of different abilities both passive and active you can gain through the lvl up system- The ability to equip your mercenaries with different weapons and armor to suit your playstyle not to mention the rarity difference from common to epic quality- The depth they have put into the lvling. You are able to lvl up your warband, your mercenaries and give them stat ups, the different wyrdstone collecters and you can in a way lvl up the game with their veteran system.Some of these make very little difference but make a nice surprise sometimes while others will be looked at as a goal to obtain after 1 - 2 missionsSummary:I think the game has things to work on and i completely understand some of the concerns some might have but the most importent thing to me is the fact that the game runs well and provides a lot of things to do when you are not on a mission and a great tactical experience when you are in a mission. It is very easy to look at the game at first and think of it as unforgiving and very hard but once you get the hang of it the game becomes very interesting and i will absolutely recommend this game.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												Great game with some bafflingly stupid design decisions. The developers have done an admirable job imitating the feel of the classic Mordheim miniatures game. The systems work well and there's some interesting decisions to be made once your warband gets past the first couple of missions and gain a few skills. Persistent injuries, forced ironman and your main income being what you scavenge in the middle of combat makes the campaign compelling even though it's mostly random missions. If you wanted a 50-50 mix of Blood Bowl and X-COM, this is it.What pulls the game down is 3 things:- Less-than-stellar (read: bloody stupid) AI. A big no-no in a strategy game- Obscene waiting times. Maps take ages to load and if 3-4 enemies have a turn in succession you may as well tab out and watch a youtube video- Godawful 3rd person camera and WASD movement. The game is practically begging for an isometric/eye-in-the-sky view.If you can live with that, this is a solid game. Especially if you play it against people instead of the easily cheesable AI.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												Originally the Warhammer Fantasy equivalent of Necromunda, the miniatures game came out in late 1999 if I remember correctly. It is a skirmish game based on gang warfare in the ruins of the doomed city of Mordheim.All of the basic bands from the core rulebook (Human mercenaries, Skaven, Cult of the Damned and Sisters of Sigmar) are represented in the game, and the rest (Witch Hunters and Undead at this moment, more probably coming in the future) are being released gradually as DLC. The look and feel of the tabletop game are well adapted, without the inconvenience (some may not view it this way) of having to modify the miniatures when some of your warriors inevitably get mutilated or mutated by a wounds/mutation dice roll, or without having to keep an extensive array of scenery in the closet to prevent the games from becoming boring brawls.Also, the tabletop's ruleset has been well adapted, better than the original IMHO, as it allows for greater granularity and slightly reduces the luck factor from the original (and the power differences a single point in a stat could imply in the tabletop game, but I'm talking from old memories). Graphics are more than good enough for their purpose and don't have huge requirements.Regarding the gameplay, it fits the grimdark atmosphere of the source material - you hire a bunch of mercenaries to set up your band, and go fight other bands in the ruins of the city for a few fistfuls of wyrdstone, which is fantasy plutonium. Playing the full tutorial is recommended in order to understand all the nuances of the tactical part of the game and the band management part of the game, or you will probably lose hard early on. In line with the grimness (and the darkness) every time a critical strike is landed on someone, or someone is knocked out, a roll is made after the battle and there's a chance that character will end up maimed (this happens to the NPC bands too, and when you encounter them again you will be able to notice the effects of your handiwork on their bodies and minds). Some people get lucky and make a full recovery (or you can get a bunch of one-eyed guys with PTSD or mangled hands - most of the time not all at once). If your guys get knocked out, your enemy can steal their gear, and if you lose a battle you don't even get a booby prize - winner takes all. It's a hard life out there in Mordheim.If you ever wanted to reenact "Acción Mutante" in a ruined medieval city, play this game. And if you don't get what the hell I'm talking about, go watch "Acción Mutante". You'll enjoy it too.In short, buy this game. Buy it for your friends, too.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2
												My review of Mordheim: City of the DamnedI believe a rating system of 1-5 would be better than the binary yes/no Steam uses.  Overall I would rate this game somwhere near 2.5.  Since there is not, I would have to not recommend this game.The pros and cons:Pros:Immersive worldGood musicWarhammerGame-to-game advancementCons:Based mostly on randomnessShallow gameplayPoor balanceTo summarize, Mordheim is a squad-based game in which you complete missions to varying degrees of success in order to loot the remains of the city of Mordheim.  The game feels fairly tabletop-ish with most mechanics based on measures and die-rolls.  There is an advancement and permanent-ish injury system which leads to unique gameplay situations.  Overall I found all this as appealing, particularly considering this is set in the Warhammer universe.  Going game-to-game and playing for not just the moment but the next several as well in a post-apocalyptic warhammer world.Why I cannot recommend this game, however, is disappointing.  There are 6 factions available right now including DLC.  Considering the majority of missions revolve around one side retreating, these factions are not close to balanced.  The game has a definite hierarchy of concerning the difficulty of factions.  At the top, the easiest and therefore toughest factions are the Sisters of Sigmar and the Undead.  Slow but physically dominant factions.  In a rough order following those 2 are the Skaven, Human Mercenaries, Witch Hunters, and Cult of the Possessed.  Worse now, is that there are minimal differences between each of them as the game progress.All factions consist of 1 leader, 3 hero options, 1 prestige class, and 2 henchmen.  All classes have their own attributes, proficiences (which dictate gear), spells, and somewhat different skills.  Skills are mostly shared across all classes and are based on statistics.  Attributes are capped based on class but not that significantly.  Spells are the most significant difference between classes as either you have access to Divine or Arcane or neither.  The combination of these 4 facets differentiate classes.  This means that through advancement most classes can match others.  I find this rather undesirable as a caster can be as proficient physically as most melee classes.  This lends itself to the Sisters and Cult being rather better in the longer-game.  I have the Cult lower mostly because they start as the whipping boys that you are glad to see as your opponent early in campaigns.  Not to mention the fact that the devs somehow thought that giving the Sisters a normal-sized prestige class was somehow balanced.I bought the game on significant sale which made it mostly worth.  Hopefully further content will be released which expands upon variety.  I wouldn't spend more than $20 on it as it currently stands.  I feel most people looking for a challenge will end up at the same point I am at.  The game is either too easy or unskillfully difficult which leads to boredom.

content:
Posted: March 25
												This game has been in a number of states over its development but at the moment is still poor in many of the base mechanics and now is unbalanced. I've played a fair amount of tabletop and this is nothing like it, a brave move but one that i think didn't pay off. In tabletop you fight the battles and then afterwards did the exploration phse for wyrdstone. The game combines the two, this sucks as 1. the exploration phase was one of the best parts of mordheim and 2. It feels every time you go looking for wyrdstone you run in to someone else's warband making it feel like there's a warband in every house, not a deserted city. The mechanics have a lot of problems as well. First of all guessing measurements, AI getting stuck on doors and a number of other problems with the janky movement suggest to me at least a rough grid system would've helped massively. The map design doesn't help one bit with plenty of bits for the AI to derp around on and design that can leave each warband just wandering around collecting bits for several turns with no reason to fight and slowing down a system that drags on anyway. The recent addition of undead and witch hunters have unbalanced the game significantly. WH are fine but the undead are massivley unbalanced (dregs were designed in tabletop to help exploration and not much else where as here they're equvilent of merc champions) Zombies have a ridiculously high initiative and the same pace as regular humans. The vampires themselves could do with a buff however as again they only really have the same stats as a human captain, a bit disappointing for whats supposed to be a supernatural killing machine. Overall I as a long time fan of Mordheim am very disappointed with this game and while its fun for a while frustration at the issues sets in. I'm still hopefull they might iron this out and it has come a long way from the early days but all in all still not a good game quite yet

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												Well done game.  It appears lovingly created to capture the atmosphere and feeling of tabletop Mordheim while making reasonable changes for PC gameplay.  The balance between being cautious to keep important characters alive, capturing warpstone, and moving in for daring kills is a wonderful experience - much like tabletop.  The skill options are quite varied and I've now had about a hundred hours of fun just playing through one campaign carefully all the way to the end.  Despite the unforgiving nature of hardcore mode, I found the game balance to be quite good.  On my first playthrough I was able to complete the campaign, so don't be scared off, though I did have a few years of tabletop Mordheim experience under my belt and I do regularly play other strategic turn-based games like X-Com 2 and the like.  In all, what makes this memorable is its flavor.  In a world where Age of Sigmar now dominates Warhammer Fantasy tabletop, and the PC experience either provides the harried pace of FPS titles or immersive rpg titles, this occupies a special niche full of loving attention to traditional Mordheim flavor.

number of helpful: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2
												While I wanted to like this game, I cannot help but feel there are some serious underlying issues under the hood.First off, I would say I am a big fan of games that are difficult. I enjoy a challenge and don't mind if the AI has a leg up on me to compensate. However, unlike X-com or even Darkest Dungeon, this game fundamentally seems to think that introducing arbitrary hardness to every encounter while offering the player very little choice in how to face it is somehow the same as providing a genuine challenge. First off, there is very little in the way of tactical decision making available to the player once they get on the ground. Despite the AI often having an advantage in unit power, it is usually easy to cheese by bottlenecking a corridor or just massing your units into a single large group that roams the map and turns each battle into a tedious chore of mopping up the stragglers. Given the AI's advantages, what this means is that hoarding your units into a massive group and slowly roaming often guarantees you a victory, while one-on-one fights are usually losses for you (assuming you are fighting with equal units). In theory you are supposed to treat each match as a scramble towards gathering wyrdstones to support the upkeep of your warband, yet you can usually grab enough in your slow trot across the map from the enemy corpses that grab them first. There is simply very little incentive to seperate your units. As such, each match feels tedious and very much like the last.That said, there is the rare time where the AI may still manage to get the drop on you, and this is entirely due to the aforementioned arbitrary hardness. Like X-COM, you are given a percentage to hit chance that usually seems to border anywhere from 60% to 90%, yet I assure you that you will never hit this much, especially not starting out. Whether it is true that the RNG is genuinely, deliberately stacked against you or not is unknown to me, but I can see why so many people feel that it is.  This persists in to the later stages of the game (I have more playtime than steam is showing) and continues to enforce the notion that the game is deliberately making itself mechanically biased against the player to make up for its shortcomings in AI. Gradually your units do manage to feel competent and varied, though starting out is quite painful. There is not a ton of variety or customization offered in the appearance of your units which was a bit of a bummer, but its good enough. Yet, I never really felt attached to any of my characters like I did for my X-COM soldiers. Not much else about the game is particularly noteworthy, good or bad. The graphics feel pretty rough albeit fitting to the universe, and the UI is wonky but not unusuble, unlike what some reviewers have said. The campaign voice acting is nice and the sparse amount of lore building we get is enjoyable for me as a long time Warhammer fan. That said, don't expect there to be any kind of a real "story". The line of sight system definitely could use some big improvements but again, I feel the RNG is the biggest pitfall of this game.In summation, this game tries to present itself as being a hardcore tactical strategy game, but often comes off feeling like the devs ran out of ideas on how to actually provide a challenge for the player and instead decided to just rig the system to make it 'feel' difficult. The lack of any real strategy outside of hoarding your units or bottlenecking the enemy turns each encounter in to a slog against an obnoxious RNG system that feels like a cover-up for the AI's lack of intelligence. At some point, it stops feeling challenging, fun, or risky, and instead simply becomes a frustrating chore that loses its appeal for the player to continue onwards when they know that there is little in the way of strategical decision making open to them.All of this said, everything I have seen from the developers seem to imply they are open to feedback (albeit quite unlikely to fundamentally change anything of note at this late in the game's life) and do intereact with the community a lot still, despite the relative age of this game. DLC continues to trickle in and even though some are not fond of the pay model, I don't find the DLC prices all that bad. There does seem to be a small but active community built up around the game, and I imagine multiplayer may relieve some of the game's shortcomings. Still, the bulk of the game is single-player only, so I have to ultimately say I cannot really recommend this game to anyone unless they can overlook the wonkiness of the AI and the short comings of a purely RNG style of gameplay.

number of helpful: 13 of 24 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8
												(NOTE: Hours in game is inaccurate by ~10 hours)Unfortunately, I can not recommend this game for three main reasons. First and foremost, as has been touched on by many others, this game employs a Random Number Generator as a core combat mechanic which, in and of itself, would not have been terrible had they not disguised various factors which affect your characters chance to hit. For example, your Hero may well appear to have an 85% chance to hit, but that 85% is not factoring in dodging etc. Whilst 'get good' might well be a valid argument in some cases, it is insanely disheartening to nearly perfectly play a series of moves to corner and outnumber an enemy, only to have them last through 2 rounds of your 4 combatant's attacks, in time for their own team to arrive and seriously hurt your odds of winning.The second issue flows on from the first, in that the game becomes mind-numbingly repetitive. After around 10 battles, you have seen all there is to see. You do not control your characters in a dynamic sense, only instigating the start of their attack animations whilst moving them around like chess pieces on a board. Once again, this is not an inherently flawed game mechanic, but instead was butchered in implementation. Instead of having suspense, tension and thrills come from, say, an emergent story within the combat wherein your characters evolve through the things they do, the feel of the game is very much, 'move animatronic doll here, whack or miss, rinse, repeat'. This is compounded by the fact that the game very much funnels you into one mind-set; gang up on a single enemy until you kill them, giving you the numbers advantage. Nearly all battles boil down to the same core ideology: gang up on them before they gang up on you. Once more, after a certain amount of battles, you've seen every attack, spell and movement animation your faction offers. The third issue conveniently flows from the second issue; the atmosphere, whilst very, very immersive, is ruined by the combat mechanics in that the overly-punishing RNG elements detach the player from the game, disallowing immersion as the player is dragged out of the Warhammer universe and into their room, study or basement of choice, becoming a spectator and interloper to the combat as opposed to an active participant. It's hard to feel invested in the characters when you are little more than some omnipresent grand-strategist whose actions have a somewhat open relationship with the gameplay itself. Often I was too focused on not having my squad obliterated to take in the sights of the maps, with their little idiosyncrasies which culminate in what is a rather aesthetically pleasing visual design. In summary or TLDRThe game is pretty, sporting a rather nice visual design yet shallow game mechanics ruin all immersion and result in slot-machine level frustration. Also, this DLC model is: overpriced, over-reaching and underwhelming.

number of helpful: 13 of 24 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
												There's a lot I like about this game but there's a few infuriating sticking points that made me not enjoy it as much as I should. Things I liked:-The harsh difficulty level-The graphics-The main skeleton of the game.-The controlsThings I didn't like (there's a bunch of them but many are small so it looks like they outnumber the good points but that's not really true)-Even though the Wyrdstone gathering encourages exploring the fact is it's usually too risky to go ham on farming Wyrdstone. The fog of war means you can rarely tell where is safe. The enemy combs the battlefield and once they find you it just descends into a battle. If you try and send out lone guys to find out of the way loot pockets they will most likely get taken out.-Buildings don't usually make sense. You can't open doors or shoot out of windows. Often you can't jump down or climb up where you want to. You can waste a lot of time messing with scenary with no benefit so it's usually best to not bother.-Not enough character model options in customisation mode.-Consumable items mostly suck to the point where I don't usually use them. You can't tell who you're fighting beforehand so taking anti-poison or anti-fear items is a crapshoot as you may not even need them.-Not being able to get past your own guys in choke points.-The thing that made me quit in the end was set mission I-III for the human mercenary faction. If you're going to make a game where combat is deadly and consequences of injury are permanent and dire, please please please avoid using a teleportation maze with one-way teleporters. This game is really not suited to missions that require trial and error to find the way around. It's not fun. Not at all. I could have persevered through the rest of the little niggles but this level was too much.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I was enjoying my adventures through the Damned City for a while, having hired and trained up a pair of Warlocks from youth while leading a human warband, because their lightning strikes are dazzling. It was the first time a man went down in a while, as one of the mages got downed early on in a recent encounter with Sigmar by an unlucky stun, while the other blew himself up in an unavoidable spell backfire effect known only as Tzeentch's Wrath, causing him to lose consciousness instantly, in the same encounter as the first. Although my Ogre and leader pushed back the Sisters of Sigmar, I feared I would have to gather wyrdstone without the Warlocks for a while, but they both ended up with mental scars... Megalomania, meaning they could not cast spells ever again. An unrecoverable psychological illness, they might as well have died in the service of the empire, so I sent them into an early retirement.Making matters worse, this could be the end of my warband. With a pressing wyrdstone shipment deadline and not enough good men left to survive an encounter with the wandering demons, recovering resources to hire good men is out of the question while I muster up the courage to drag inexperienced henchmen into battle, training them up from scratch.This story is why Mordheim has potential -- I cannot wait to lead other bands of warriors into battle, but I would like to bring a medic for long-term treatment of the most insidious afflictions.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												The new campaign mode is every thing I was hoping for! I love a tactics game that allows for random non-story line missions that can be done as often as desired! The game is challenging and you are just as likely to take a loss as you are to push through to victory! I highly recommend this game and am so looking forward to more to come! UPDATE 11/21/15100hrs into the game and I still love it just as much as I did at hour 1. I have already suggested this game to many of my friends. As a turn-based rpg fanatic I love the way the game plays and the unique abilities for each warband. The permanent injury system is a nice touch, if not heart breaking at times (your star hero gets swarmed by skaven and ends up losing an arm). The maps are great, have a very Mordheim feel to them and pleasing to the eye. Some suggested improvements:*In-battle equip system. On the occasion I've accidentally sent my warband in and my warrior only has a dagger after getting robbed the last battle. After killing a rival, I can put a sword in my backpack but not simply hold it in my mainhand. I'd even be cool with the action costing strategy points to equip, etc.*Skills are way too expensive for the amount of gold you are able to make. I literally have an entire roster of warriors with 2-4 skill points because I simply cannot afford to pay for all of them to skill up and still meet the constant demands for wyrdstone shipments. Average low skill is 95 gold (and I have the scholar veteran skill too), the higher level skills range to upwards of 280-300 gold. Even after completing a 259lb wyrdstone shipment I'm only able to pay for two or three skills before I'm in danger of not being able to pay for treatments, equipment loss, and upkeep. I suggest perhaps a separate currency system for skills? or a lowering of their price, or an increase in wyrdstone shipment payouts? Or maybe even just dropping the gold cost as you already require skill points themselves?*Wyrdstone shipments come at regular intervals with increasing amount required and it is a great idea. It gives you a huge reason to harvest the pesky green crystals. However, the demand is a bit strenuous. It would be a lot easier to pay for skill upgrades and my warband in general if the demands weren't so constant. I love the system, but maybe a reprieve between shipments would help tremendously? Sometimes being able to send small shipments to one of the side smugglers helps out a lot, but then in doing so puts me behind the 8-ball on the next demand that comes within a day or two of the last completed.Love the game, keep up the good work. I've got three open games going so I need to get back to my mercenaries. Look forward to updates and hopefully more warbands. (I'm looking at you Dwarves, Undead, Orks, elves (both kind), Witch Hunters, and *hopefully* lizardmen.)

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												This is a great game. a lot of people are complaining that a turn-based game shouldn't be first-person, but to me it seems like they just can't think outside the box. once you get used to the gameplay you'll realize that there's a great deal of strategizing to be done. Example: I hide one of my men behind a wall and set him to ambush stance while having another run out in the open and shoot an arrow at an enemy. I then leave the archer out in the open as i am out of movement points. the enemy runs towards my archer but when he passes the wall my warrior attacks and locks him down.The graphics are fine and i have yet to encounter a bug. the difficulty appeals to me especially the fact that the game auto-saves whenever you finish a battle, leaving you no choice but to press on and feel the consequenses of each battle.While the game is great, it could do with a little polishing and i won't recommend buying it unless it is on sale.

content:

Early Access Review
								At this stage of its development, I have to say I am thoroughly enjoying the game, the graphics are great and I think the city itself is quite atmospheric.  Navigation takes a little practice, but after a while any awkwardness sort of fits the twisted nature of the place.  Gameplay is good, game speed needs refining but I am sure the developers will iron things out as they continually make well thought out improvements.  Really impressed so far and am happy to have parted with my cash.  Character development is also fun - you may find that the peg leg, one eyed survivor of many a nightmarish encounter will still be in your team long after he may have wanted to retire.....I think this is worth a blast, but be prepared to have plenty of time to complete some of the main campaign missions as no saves in game (at least that I could find) mean a long session unless you want to force your team to retreat in order to turn the computer off and get on with real life!

content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great game, but there are some things i really hate.1. Characters will have to make all alone checks even though there are friendly characters 2 ft. away from other friendly characters.2. stupidity checks from skull fractures completely destroys a chrarcter's usefullness. my warlock has a 14 intellegence, is lucky to pass a stupidity check 20% of the time. tone down the difficulty of the checks.3. exiting the game causes the match to be a rout and all of your characters take injuries. ive had it where i had to exit the game because the game crashed and when i turned it back on, 3 of my guys had missing arms. i shouldnt be punished for having to turn off the game. i realize that the devs dont want players to exit the game when their warband is being beat, but there are better ways. XCOM EU had the ironman mode. the game would save whenever a action is completed. that way players couldnt just go back and redo past actions.4. Blue items get lost on characters way too often. i beat a warband decisively and only had 1 casualty. the captain comes back without injury BUT somewhere along the lines, he lost his blue shield, sword and helmet. thats insane. blue items seem to get lost more than white items. maybe its just me overreacting, but those blue items are insanely useful when it comes to fighting stronger warbands or doing story missions. losing them with the frequency as I have can have terrible effects in the long run. i dont want there to be no chance of dropping them, just a little lower chance of it. maybe add in a perk that makes it impossible (or extremely unlikely) for them to drop a designated item?5. Not being ablr to leap across a gap because there is a enemy 1 story below you. i dont think this was intentional. probably just a glitch.I really REALLY like the game, but its a really frustrating game. A lot of it comes from the RNG, but thats just the nature of the game. i really hope that the devs listen to the players and tweak the game for the better.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I was enjoying my adventures through the Damned City for a while, having hired and trained up a pair of Warlocks from youth while leading a human warband, because their lightning strikes are dazzling. It was the first time a man went down in a while, as one of the mages got downed early on in a recent encounter with Sigmar by an unlucky stun, while the other blew himself up in an unavoidable spell backfire effect known only as Tzeentch's Wrath, causing him to lose consciousness instantly, in the same encounter as the first. Although my Ogre and leader pushed back the Sisters of Sigmar, I feared I would have to gather wyrdstone without the Warlocks for a while, but they both ended up with mental scars... Megalomania, meaning they could not cast spells ever again. An unrecoverable psychological illness, they might as well have died in the service of the empire, so I sent them into an early retirement.Making matters worse, this could be the end of my warband. With a pressing wyrdstone shipment deadline and not enough good men left to survive an encounter with the wandering demons, recovering resources to hire good men is out of the question while I muster up the courage to drag inexperienced henchmen into battle, training them up from scratch.This story is why Mordheim has potential -- I cannot wait to lead other bands of warriors into battle, but I would like to bring a medic for long-term treatment of the most insidious afflictions.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								At this stage of its development, I have to say I am thoroughly enjoying the game, the graphics are great and I think the city itself is quite atmospheric.  Navigation takes a little practice, but after a while any awkwardness sort of fits the twisted nature of the place.  Gameplay is good, game speed needs refining but I am sure the developers will iron things out as they continually make well thought out improvements.  Really impressed so far and am happy to have parted with my cash.  Character development is also fun - you may find that the peg leg, one eyed survivor of many a nightmarish encounter will still be in your team long after he may have wanted to retire.....I think this is worth a blast, but be prepared to have plenty of time to complete some of the main campaign missions as no saves in game (at least that I could find) mean a long session unless you want to force your team to retreat in order to turn the computer off and get on with real life!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								I purchased the early access game on Halloween after reading some pretty great sounding reviews. Just a little bit of background I don't write reviews on video games EVER as I haven't found any that stand out to me enough to warrant a review (please note I'm 21 and have been gaming since I was about 6). I am a fan of strategy games such as xcom, civ 5, galactic civ, Dawn of War 1 & 2. Mordheim as an early access game has already managed to push them out of my mind. It is challenging but not ridiculously like dark souls (which is important as at that level of challenging the game is no longer fun). I find myself attached to the characters on my team and worrying way more than I should about my characters surviving. The things I love about this game- Warband team style play offers customization for play style ergo you can use 1 hand weapons, 2 hand weapons, archers, magic all to your play style- 2 resources gold and wyrdstones which can make for some extra complexity as you have to ensure you have enough of both otherwise you'll tick someone off (not enough gold and you can't pay for treatments or pay your soldiers not enough wyrdstones and you won't be able to make your quota to your employer)- Have yet to find any really overpowered units. using 1 hand weapons for example you lose damage if you compare it to a 2 hand weapon but you gain dodge chance or you can equip a shield and be able to parry. - Magic abilities have the chance to backfire or curse characters as you use it so you can't train your mage up to be as ***kicker and use him to kill the whole enemy team (atleast from what I've seen so far). - It's only early access which means they are actually looking at reviews and bugs and game suggestions and actually fixing them and modifying the game so it can only go up from here!Things that I feel should be addressed- I say addressed as it's in early access still so most of these are just things that need to be tweaked as they're still working on the game.- the percentages for tasks appear a little skewed to me. what I mean is I'll have a 75 percent chance to hit someone I'll attack them 4 times and miss all 4 times. This get's a little irritating when you have your havy hitter who has a big 2 handed weapons that does but loads of damage but can only attack once per turn and he constantly misses. Or when you are trying to climb a wall and you have a 70 percent chance and you use all of your moves falling and injuring your character who is wearing cloth armor and is an archer (near killed him doing this). If you ask me archers are a little underpowered making them reload was a good check and balance however they do very little damage and can only attack once per turn (keep in mind they're just hitting the first skill point for me so I may be able to upgrade them down the road to be better)Ergo just off of the campaign to the first act this game is awesome! I haven't even touched the multiplayer yet!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great game, but there are some things i really hate.1. Characters will have to make all alone checks even though there are friendly characters 2 ft. away from other friendly characters.2. stupidity checks from skull fractures completely destroys a chrarcter's usefullness. my warlock has a 14 intellegence, is lucky to pass a stupidity check 20% of the time. tone down the difficulty of the checks.3. exiting the game causes the match to be a rout and all of your characters take injuries. ive had it where i had to exit the game because the game crashed and when i turned it back on, 3 of my guys had missing arms. i shouldnt be punished for having to turn off the game. i realize that the devs dont want players to exit the game when their warband is being beat, but there are better ways. XCOM EU had the ironman mode. the game would save whenever a action is completed. that way players couldnt just go back and redo past actions.4. Blue items get lost on characters way too often. i beat a warband decisively and only had 1 casualty. the captain comes back without injury BUT somewhere along the lines, he lost his blue shield, sword and helmet. thats insane. blue items seem to get lost more than white items. maybe its just me overreacting, but those blue items are insanely useful when it comes to fighting stronger warbands or doing story missions. losing them with the frequency as I have can have terrible effects in the long run. i dont want there to be no chance of dropping them, just a little lower chance of it. maybe add in a perk that makes it impossible (or extremely unlikely) for them to drop a designated item?5. Not being ablr to leap across a gap because there is a enemy 1 story below you. i dont think this was intentional. probably just a glitch.I really REALLY like the game, but its a really frustrating game. A lot of it comes from the RNG, but thats just the nature of the game. i really hope that the devs listen to the players and tweak the game for the better.
