content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												This is a great game. a lot of people are complaining that a turn-based game shouldn't be first-person, but to me it seems like they just can't think outside the box. once you get used to the gameplay you'll realize that there's a great deal of strategizing to be done. Example: I hide one of my men behind a wall and set him to ambush stance while having another run out in the open and shoot an arrow at an enemy. I then leave the archer out in the open as i am out of movement points. the enemy runs towards my archer but when he passes the wall my warrior attacks and locks him down.The graphics are fine and i have yet to encounter a bug. the difficulty appeals to me especially the fact that the game auto-saves whenever you finish a battle, leaving you no choice but to press on and feel the consequenses of each battle.While the game is great, it could do with a little polishing and i won't recommend buying it unless it is on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								With the release of warband progression, this game has taken a giant leap ahead. I feel obligated to also help put down some criticisms that I've been seeing on the forums. Firstly, and perhaps most importantly, this game is a PORT OF THE ORIGINAL MORDHEIM game from tabletop fantasy warhammer. This game is made by mordheim fans FOR mordheim fans. The reason that there are bubbles around the characters is because of Movement Bases. The reason that you cannot loot everything on the map after youve won is because you couldnt loot everything on the table after youve won. If you want to do that then youll have to cripple the other warband and hope they dont route. The reason that there are only 4 warbands is because ........ you guessed it, in the original Mordheim there were only 4 warbands. Human, Sisters of Sigmar, Skaven, and Chaos. There were other warbands created by the community, but nothing official by games workshop. Ive been playing Mordheim for over 16 years off and on and I find todays gamers to be quite spoiled and childish with some of these complaints on the forums. Mordheim isnt for all the whiney little griefers, its for the die hard fans of warhammer and its franchises. Grow up steam community.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												The new campaign mode is every thing I was hoping for! I love a tactics game that allows for random non-story line missions that can be done as often as desired! The game is challenging and you are just as likely to take a loss as you are to push through to victory! I highly recommend this game and am so looking forward to more to come! UPDATE 11/21/15100hrs into the game and I still love it just as much as I did at hour 1. I have already suggested this game to many of my friends. As a turn-based rpg fanatic I love the way the game plays and the unique abilities for each warband. The permanent injury system is a nice touch, if not heart breaking at times (your star hero gets swarmed by skaven and ends up losing an arm). The maps are great, have a very Mordheim feel to them and pleasing to the eye. Some suggested improvements:*In-battle equip system. On the occasion I've accidentally sent my warband in and my warrior only has a dagger after getting robbed the last battle. After killing a rival, I can put a sword in my backpack but not simply hold it in my mainhand. I'd even be cool with the action costing strategy points to equip, etc.*Skills are way too expensive for the amount of gold you are able to make. I literally have an entire roster of warriors with 2-4 skill points because I simply cannot afford to pay for all of them to skill up and still meet the constant demands for wyrdstone shipments. Average low skill is 95 gold (and I have the scholar veteran skill too), the higher level skills range to upwards of 280-300 gold. Even after completing a 259lb wyrdstone shipment I'm only able to pay for two or three skills before I'm in danger of not being able to pay for treatments, equipment loss, and upkeep. I suggest perhaps a separate currency system for skills? or a lowering of their price, or an increase in wyrdstone shipment payouts? Or maybe even just dropping the gold cost as you already require skill points themselves?*Wyrdstone shipments come at regular intervals with increasing amount required and it is a great idea. It gives you a huge reason to harvest the pesky green crystals. However, the demand is a bit strenuous. It would be a lot easier to pay for skill upgrades and my warband in general if the demands weren't so constant. I love the system, but maybe a reprieve between shipments would help tremendously? Sometimes being able to send small shipments to one of the side smugglers helps out a lot, but then in doing so puts me behind the 8-ball on the next demand that comes within a day or two of the last completed.Love the game, keep up the good work. I've got three open games going so I need to get back to my mercenaries. Look forward to updates and hopefully more warbands. (I'm looking at you Dwarves, Undead, Orks, elves (both kind), Witch Hunters, and *hopefully* lizardmen.)

Posted: August 8, 2016
												Free Weekend Review11hrs over the weekend, i followed this game since early access i decided to finally purchase the game now that its been released and i was given the free week end to test it out. im not a fan of most games workshop games i think most are cash grabs and dont capture the table top essence which made all these types of games enjoyable. Mordheim does for me feel like the table top, which is very important as i want that feeling, i want to feel like each game is something i can easily imagion being played out on a table top in front of me. ive only played 11hrs so my experience is quite limited ive completed the tutorials and spend the rest playing about 11 games as a choas warband. i love the gameplay there just aint enough good turn based strategy games atm which i like so finding one that i enjoy is a blessing. ive only played solo so cant say anything about mp. Well done devs a gameswork shop game that feels that the tabletop its based on instead of just using its name to grab some cash! hats off to you!PROStabletop feel ( feels like Mordheim)customizing your warbands (i name all my warriors and give them unique apperances)depth ( im only 11hrs but it seems like mastering this will take some time)ai seems ok atm ive only seen a few stupid moves, but then again i only played the table top against friends and we all made quite alot of stupid moves so i cant complainbasics are easy to learnruns wellhas some intense momentstactics are importanthas me shouting at my screen ( i like games bring out emotions)flashbacks, which mainly seem to be of me making terrible dice rollsconsgraphics are abit slack in places, especially some of the human faces, but who careswould like more detailed info on battle reportsneeds more different map types and layouts, we used to make some silly stuff with this game, or better yet, creation kit? has no dice roll animation, my biggest h8 maybe theres an option ive missedtraps could be more interestingatm its all 1v1, maybe later game has it but i want some 1v1v1v1 actionlike i said limited review only 11hrs but i love it!

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												An interesting take on Mordheim, pretty damn true to source.I'll reccomend it because I had a lot of fun playing it. Pros:Lore accurate representation of settings, characters, races and abilities.Reasonably well balanced matches, rarely are battles impossible or very easyDeep and interesting character levelling and equipment progression systemsYour warband develops real character naturally over the course of a campaignCons:Graphics are not up to par for something this recent. I'm the first to say "Graphics aren't everything" but also they are not to be ignored.Random deployment missions are often skewed to be impossible, edge case scenarios in rare circumstances make certain battles unwinnable. Some injuries should not be permanent. High level units can be injured and permanently lose all value, forcing you to replace them with rookies and play another 20 hours to level them up, or be satisfied with a perpetually sub-par warrior. I understand the injuries are also a great aspect of the game. Peg Leg Grunhir the giant ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with the halberd was one of my favourite warband members, and I don't want his leg healed by any means. We have magic potions, we can teach people spells and enchant weapons. Can we really not send Rolf "Basically Legolas" Murnheim off for a week to have some mojo done to reverse his brain damage? It was just a concussion bro. Get over it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												Very engaging strategy game focused around building up your units. Lots of variety in advancement options and lots of possibility for permanent injuries and even death that keeps things challenging and realistic. I legitimately worry if one of my important units falls in battle. Comparable to Blood Bowl in these respects and warband management does parallel a sports sim in many ways.Combat can get a little bit repetitive. Not a lot of story mixed in, unfortunately, but good background and setting. Ability to customize units' appearance is good, but being forced to do so for each one as they all start off looking identical (instead of randomized) isn't ideal.DLC nickel and dimes you to death, as with anything Games Workshop related.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												This game is a hard sell, and honestly not for everyone. but, if you like perma death and an AI that wants to take your stuff more then it wants to beat a map, its for you. Custimization is good, and once you learn the ACTUAL game ( the tutorial is full of it ) then you can start to actualy enjoy it. Protip: dont get attached to henchmen, hand him a number instead of a name and keep your hero and captain alive. Sure 6 just got gutted by three rat people and 37 went toe to toe with a Chaos spawn and lost a few bits, but they did there job and let the commander shoot at them from a safe distance, and let 65 gather the wyrdstone needed to get that XP buff hes going to forget again because he was hit a little to hard in the head by a Sister of Sigmar.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												This game has given me PTSD!I bought the game knowing full well that it was going to be challenging, with perma death, warband management and no obious advantages in a match. when i started the game i went through  all the tutorials and studied the character management screen and noticed the change name and write biography screen.so i though to myself this could be fun and started naming them all and giving them a back story. my mercinary warband was lead by a captain in the old city watch and his son was the youngblood hero i had with him. i had a pair of brothers who were hunters from the forests of the empire and a swordsman who had come seeking fame and fortune. They did exceptionaly well until it came to the first story mission. a warband that had not suffered a casultie was suddenly in the sewers below mordheim confronted with a rat ogre!By now i had become quite attatched to my warband and i had to watch in horror as my leaders son lost a leg to the ogre, the sell sword was killed almost imediately and it was up to my leader to save the warband! He was not successful. one of the hunter brothers lost an arm so could no longer shoot and the other surrendered. my warband leader was knocked out and suffered amnesia so could not even remember the destruction of the group and  there was no money left to pay for the medical costs or even pay the wages of the troops.Three warbands later I came back to this mission and was actually worried about starting it. i had become so attached and protective of the only successful warband i had that i didnt want to risk their lives against the ogre again. this is something that a game hasnt made me feel for a long time and when these little faceless digital heroes finally brought it down (once again leader got amnesia but no other casulties) i actually felt a sence of achivement.So yes the game isnt as polished as it could be and the RNG may make you screem at the screen when your guy fails to climb a wall for the fith time but these are minor problems when compared to the joy of getting all your troops home without injury and a butt ton of loot!Would definately recomend this game to anyone willing to stick it out to the bitter end.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Mordheim: City of the Damned is not for the faint of heart. It's tactical and relies on strategy and wit, but luck plays an important part, and it may not always be on your side. But if you're up for a gamble, then there's no denying it; Mordheim is one of my all-time favourite turn-based tactical rpg's.Making good use of the Games Workshop franchise in terms of atmosphere and looks, the devs managed to create an extremely addictive and engaging game, which will gradually suck you in until there's no getting out. It's great fun to level up your soldiers and unlock skills that will offer whole new ways of approaching each match.If you're a fan of games like X-Com (1 and 2), know that Mordheim does share a few similarities, but it's also very unique. It's much less forgiving of your mistakes, but it also feels much more rewarding when you are successful, as it really puts you to the test. If you're not afraid of trial & error, and occasionally getting your behind slapped by Lady Luck, then don't think twice and dive right in - this game is totally worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												Best game ever! I hope they do Necromunda next!! :)Update:The game is great and theres a hell of a lot of unseen work building the databases for all the fighters and warbands. The games main problem is the AI. The enemy warband usually separates from each other and goes straight to your warband leaving themselves vulnerable as they attack one by one. Every warband seems to employ this tactic and I have yet to see the AI warband either hole up in a building together and wait like a sensible mordheim player would do or just attack you from one street like a bowling ball. This wouldn't be too difficult to achieve as warband fighters just have to stick together and attack or wait it out. The normal split up and attack tactic could be kept as well for different warband tactics.The other problem is the AI using impressives and wandering monsters. They always get stuck in the map terrain / scenary and the debris littering the streets which you would normally climb / over pass through on the tabletop. If they removed the collision boxes for those scenary models it could be fixed and clipping would only be a minor problem as they pass through. Otherwise it just breaks the AI and leaves their gang at a disadvantage. Reducing the impressives bounding box and make them avoid narrow litter strewn streets could also fix this. It just doesn't make sense for all characters being unable to move through these small obstacles and its a major part of all warhammer games that use battlefield terrain.Multiple gangs on one map would be another wish for me but the games awesome as it is. They put a ton of effort into this game and its not right to see it slated so often over things you didn't even have in the tabletop game.

content:
Posted: January 15
												pro: awesome gamecon:1) very buggy2) battles can get exceedingly drawn out to a point where you're no longer having fun you just want to go to bed 3) no saves4) although it is theoretically "possible" to miss 2 hits at a 95 percent chance the chances are 1 in 400 and coupled with the fact that the computer will DEFINITELY hit you with many more criticals that what you will hit them, the RNG is questionable and I believe there is an undisclosed 'hardcore' element coded into the RNG rolls to ensure that you are never TOO comfortable5) when playing a skirmish game you will not get the option to save out and quit, you can only withdraw (for statistical purposes this counts like all of your guys were taken out of action) which affects your all time warband stats6) enemy reinforcements show up too quickly - there should be a counter or something on the screen that says something like "Enemy reinforcements arriving in 5 turns" but a fresh assortment of reinforcements arriving EVERY TURN when your warband has taken a hammering is a little too much7) not everybody likes the idea of getting forcefully bent over and ravaged in their rear which is what this game feels like a lot of the time. 8) In keeping with its 'hardcore' element, the game can overlook its enjoyment factor at times All things said, I really enjoyed the game... I've never played a game where I literally got out of my seat and started punching the air and pulling my hair... but everyone should know that this game is a HARDCORE EXPERIENCE WITHOUT EXCEPTION. NO HAND HOLDING HERE. NOT recommended for the casual gamer. But if you're the type that gets off on brutal BDSM, this game is for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												Well done game.  It appears lovingly created to capture the atmosphere and feeling of tabletop Mordheim while making reasonable changes for PC gameplay.  The balance between being cautious to keep important characters alive, capturing warpstone, and moving in for daring kills is a wonderful experience - much like tabletop.  The skill options are quite varied and I've now had about a hundred hours of fun just playing through one campaign carefully all the way to the end.  Despite the unforgiving nature of hardcore mode, I found the game balance to be quite good.  On my first playthrough I was able to complete the campaign, so don't be scared off, though I did have a few years of tabletop Mordheim experience under my belt and I do regularly play other strategic turn-based games like X-Com 2 and the like.  In all, what makes this memorable is its flavor.  In a world where Age of Sigmar now dominates Warhammer Fantasy tabletop, and the PC experience either provides the harried pace of FPS titles or immersive rpg titles, this occupies a special niche full of loving attention to traditional Mordheim flavor.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Of course, it's not finished and needs a lot of work. And yet, rather than strengthen play with modern technology it feels like they've attempted to engage a new audience with camera tricks. Rather than attempt to re-create the playstyle and assets of the real-life game, making use of the computer to resolve LOS issues and streamline warband book-keeping, the developers have opted for an awful 3rd person POV with a poorly implemented 'tactical map'.Which is a real shame. The original game was a joy to play, along with Necromunda. All we needed was a virtual re-creation of the physical game, with all the advantages modern technology can offer. Instead, we have a game that seems like its trying to pretend its not based on an excellent board game.While I hope things will improve I can't see the developers devianting from the core design choices already made - and those design choices have not improved gameplay but instead made it worse.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												This will be lengthy, as I had plenty of time to write this while I download Patch 3 slowly because my internet connection sucks terribly. Also, my computer's terrible, but that's besides the point. Anyway, hold on tight.PreludeI grew up with a game called Warhammer: Shadow of the Horned Rat. I had the PS1 version of the game, and for some reason I only had half of the instruction manual for the game. I had gotten the game from a yard sale of a neighbor who was moving and wanted some cash, presumably to join a caravan of gypsies. When I played it for the first time, I thought I was doing well until I had to do some mission where you had to patrol and kill numerous Skaven early on. I learned that I was bad at tactics. So I had to get good.I got good... or so I thought. Then I got mauled by an orc riding a wyvern or something. It was terrifying, as I was a dumb tween when I first played this game.Many years later I came back to it and eventually beat it, even after numerous deaths. I still wish I had the half of the instruction manual that included the psychology section though.Anyway, I wrote about Shadow of the Horned Rat because this game brings back memories of my training montage of getting good at Warhammer.This GameI first heard of Mordheim: City of the Damned when I subscribed to Sheepdog Gaming on the Youtube sometime after I got into Blood Bowl 2. I saw a video about a Skaven warband, and immediately I had to watch it. I learned that Mordheim was a strategy-based game with permadeath and various other things. I decided to watch a bit more of various people playing Mordheim to get an idea of whether I wanted this game or not. Eventually I decided that I'd get it and start off as the Skaven, because I find them hilarious compared to the other factions. I eventually started at least one warband from each faction (as of this edit, there are five in total).I had to turn my settings to the lowest that I possibly could, because my PC is rather bad for gaming and I need to upgrade both my computer and my internet connection at some point in the future. Regardless of this, I can tell that the game is good looking, even if my settings make it so that my human captain has no pupils (he also went amok after getting pounded by cultists, so I could consider that a side effect of him being mentally deranged). I can also tell from seeing other reviews and noting Youtubers saying so that the loading times are pretty long regardless of my computer's performance. Hopefully this patch helps a little with this. (A patch helped with this somewhat.)Anyway, the RNG of this game does get to me sometimes, but I'm very much used to the punishment as a result of my aforementioned experience with Shadow of the Horned Rat. I've had some good RNG too, thankfully, such as being able to end certain Marked for Death battles fairly quickly with the bonus objective completed or having a metric ton of wyrdstone at a good place to screw with the AI.I have no input regarding multiplayer, as I'm afraid of losing my internet connection while playing it. I'll update this when or if I can get some experience in.Regarding gameplay, it's a pretty solid strategy game. The AI can be rather dumb sometimes, but challenges happen just as much as dumb AI activity happens for me, so I can't complain too much. There have only been a couple of occasions where the AI got stuck on corners for me, although I have also had a couple times where the AI cannot decide whether it wants to jump down or climb up a ledge, and will do so back and forth until the unit moves within ambush range of my deranged captain who wants an excuse to not flee from combat. Anyways, the AI could be worse, but it could also be better.Rating:For me, I give this game a whip designed for self-flagellation arranged in the form of an 8 out of 10. Well, it'd look more like a B, but close enough.For a general audience, I give this game a whip designed for self-flagellation arranged in a 7 out of 10. The punishment of the RNG stings a fair bit, but you feel absolved once you manage your RNG, achieve victory, and dominate your foes through clever tactics. If you're into Warhammer, strategy, and challenge, pick up this game. It is possible that the challenge may not be the sort you're looking for, so this is rated a 7 instead of an 8 for that reason.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												If you love Warhammer Fantasy lore and love RPGs such as this, then Mordheim's the game for you! I can see a LOT of potential with the game. The game is still new so things are still being added... BUT! Do not let that scare you off, adventurers! If Orks, Elves, Dwarves, etc were added then I can see some insane amounts of fun with that! The Elven leader could probably be ranged focused and all.A protip would be getting and keeping your warband as close as possible as SOON as possible. Skaven can absolutely destroy you if you let your people stray too far away.  Highly recommand this game. Don't dislike it because of a few problems, it's still new as I said but that just means there's things to flush out and goodies to add in!  Spell casting is also really crazy. I've seen only one time so far where the enemy caused their Magister to explode. I do NOT recommend casting a spell if you're wearing armor or a helmet. (unless either gives a strong enough buff against the curse penalty)."More blood for the Blood God! More skulls for the Skull Throne!" Yay for Chaos!Happy adventuring!Protip: Bring ALL of your troops when you're doing a story mission, they don't scale based on your warband size and it's a GREAT way to level people up!

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												Well...after spending 60+ hours in this game I think that I'm starting to have a clear idea of how it works.I really suggest this game to warhammer lovers, the graphic is good and it respects the background very well! The Game is hard...I mean VERY HARD, even for turn-based rpg experts and the time you need to learn the mechanics is long.You will lose games, your favoure heroes will lose limbs, eyes or will become idiots...but hey, it's Mordheim! RNG works pretty well for me and when start learning how your heroes work you can manage the bad rolls with the acquired skills.Sometime you will hate it, sometime letal games will look too easy, but it's normal, it's random, but I enjoy the challange a lot.Warbands have different play style and having few maps is not a big issue, since you start always from a different point with different missions.Developers are very present and listen to the community.The game is worth the moneys, i am very happy about it. Buy it if you feel you can accept the challenge :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												I recommend this game only for hard core strategy players who agree and respect the RNGods in all their glory.  If you think I am joking you are wrong.  More then likely you have played the new Xcom (I assume Steam has send you to here from there) if you think that is a challenge or has unfair RNG .  Then this game you need to stay away from.  To sum it up, you can have a 95% chance to hit, however if they have a 95% dodge, then In fact you have a 4.75% chance to do any damage.  So keep that in mind when I say this game is The domain of the Almighty RNGods.  If you liked the old X-com however this is for you.  This game is unfair and unforgiving, and you have to abuse the system to the fullest.  That said the biggest flaw is the game-play gets stale fast.  I do like the game play, however it can get stale fast due to it does not feel like anything changes mission to mission.  Sum it up, you have to move in a group and hope you do not get in a fight before you can do the secondary objective.  Then gang up of the lone guy before their team can get to you.  Also the collection game play can drive you mad due to it is important; however tunnel vision can lead you to getting your beloved champ a third peg leg at best.  Also the game is slow.  Even AI is slow, I had one bout last up to two hours.  Only down hill in pvp.At this point I would give you the positive, but I feel that if you can get over the Beware signs then you will enjoy this game.  So giving a list of all that I like and think you may like, is pointless.  If you can get over the negatives I pointed out, then you can get a great game.  However if you have any doubts I urge you to wait for a free weekend, or just not look at this again. This game is for hardcore fans, not the faint of heart.  You have to be willing to grind, where games get repetitive fast, last a while, and rewards will seem lack luster.  Also results can turn sour fast at a bad decree of the RNGods.  If you can enjoy this; then this game is for you.  If you waver at the thought, then this game is not for you.  This game is not for people that take half measures; The majority of people will not like it, but for the population that this is targeted for, then just buy it.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												Mordheim: City of the Damned is the first game I’ve played that has so much going on! I have to admit, I seriously underestimated the sheer amount of mechanics there are to think about when diving into the city of Mordheim.Not only do you need to think about the units you’re hiring but you’ve also got to consider what types of weapons they can use, stats, paying for their upkeep, completing shipments to sponsoring groups and heaps more.The StoryAfter being engaged in civil war for years, the Empire finds itself with no Emperor. Rivalling powers were in competition for control of the throne. In the Imperial year 1999, a twin tailed comet was sighted in the sky. This comet was believed to herald the return of Sigmar and bring in a new golden age. Flocks of people travelled to Mordheim, filling the city to it’s brim. With a lack of law in the city, citizens of Mordheim degenerated to giving themselves over to personal worldly temptations. An increasing state of anarchy rose within the city and the situation became worse when even more made the journey to Mordheim. Soon, the city’s streets were plagued with demons. Chaos and corruption had long since claimed the souls of the thousands who now resided in Mordheim.When the comet fell on New Years Eve, the coming of Sigmar everyone hoped for, did not happen. Instead the comet came crashing down into the city, killing all who gathered around it. Word spread that Sigmar had smitten those he judged unworthy. Mordheim was filled with fear and paranoia. But word got out that a mysterious stone had been discovered scattered throughout the city known as Wyrdstone. This stone had all sorts of qualities and vying factions would pay great deals of money for this precious stone. Soon warbands started travelling to Mordheim in hopes to make vast fortunes by finding and selling Wyrdstone.Getting StartedTo fully comprehend how to play Mordheim: City of the Damned, it’s a very good idea to start with the tutorial. At the time of writing this review there were twelve separate tutorials branching across how to do basic things such as moving around, ending your turn, and more advanced things like ambushing opponents or dodging/parrying attacks. The tutorial then goes into how to manage your warband.Getting Down To ItEach character you hire costs an initial hiring fee and require upkeep to be paid in order for them to stay in your team. If you choose not to pay for upkeep or treatment for injuries (or can’t afford it), each day that passes in the game, interest will accrue and injuries will get progressively worse. So make sure you loot that gold!Also in the warband management area is the option to customise each individual troop. You can change the look of their head gear, skin colour, armour style/colour and more. If you’re really into role-playing and coming up with your own story, there’s the option to give your characters new names and even write a biography for them. Unfortunately the biography can only be seen by you.As you will learn in the tutorial, whilst you’re in a match, each character has their own turn and can be controlled by the ‘WASD’ keys. Movement is limited by the amount of movement points a character has and attacks are also limited to a character’s combat points.There are so many ways to plan your attack on an opponent. If you have a ranged character, find an ideal position up high so you can fire down upon your enemy without running the risk of them coming over to you next turn and beating your♥♥♥♥♥♥down. Otherwise you can just run straight in and start pummelling an opposing unit as many times as you can.Once your turn is over, depending on how many movement/combat points you have left, you can change to a dodge, parry or ambush position. Dodge will give you a higher chance to dodge, parry gives a higher chance to parry, and ambush will force your character to charge at an enemy who ends up within your ambush range. Be careful how you use the ambush range, as you could easily make up the extra gap between you and a horde of the opposition’s team, and ultimately lose a character.When a troop dies, your team’s morale decreases. If your team’s morale falls below forty percent of it’s maximum, your team leader undergoes a leadership test. Should your leader be out of action, the test falls to your team’s hero. Henchmen cannot take the leadership test, therefore if your leader and hero are both OOA, the team will “route”. Routing basically means a loss for you.If the leadership test is passed, you can continue fighting. Should it fail, your warband will route. With this in mind, if you prefer to deal as much damage as you can to the opposition, try to refrain from taking out the enemy leader or hero. Take out the henchmen first and then focus on the remaining troops who can undergo a leadership test.Don’t Panic, Chaos is at Work! AKA RNG GaloreMordheim: City of the Damned combat relies heavily on RNG (random number generator). As everyone who has played a game with RNG mechanics knows, percentages aren’t necessarily something you should get excited or disappointed over. A ninety-five percent chance to successfully attack an opponent can miserably fail… quite often as well. But then again a five percent chance to parry an attack can very likely be a success. Of course it’s all down to luck, but then again sometimes it can feel like luck is always against you but completely on the side of your opposition.RNGs can often be the difference between your team routing or winning a match, but other factors can also hinder you such as hidden traps. Scattered randomly among the procedurally generated stages are a number of hidden traps. These traps can be quite frustrating, especially if you end up running through an area that you know will most likely give you an annoying debuff, but forget, and end up doing it anyway.Progressing Your WarbandEach member of your warband gains experience for doing different things. For example, performing the attack that puts an enemy out of action will net your troop an extra bit of XP. After reaching a set amount of XP your warband members will go up a level. Levelling up provides them with points to go towards attributes. There are quite a few attributes to build up which provides even more strategic planning.Some stats might increase your chance to attack successfully, whilst others will increase your dodge or parry chance. Because of the vast range of stats to increase when levelling up your warband, you can have one troop specifically designed for long-range fighting whilst another can be decked out to become a supreme spell caster.Don’t Forget to TipYou’re probably thinking, “So what’s with this whole Wyrdstone business?”. Wyrdstones work as a currency to purchase certain things as well as a commodity to send to your “sponsors” or primary faction. Each warband has a primary faction that requires a certain weight of Wyrdstones to be delivered to them within a set period of time. Along with the primary faction are extra sponsors you can build your reputation with.However, if you leave your primary faction wanting and miss a shipment, your warband will disband. All gone. Poof in a cloud of smoke. Start again. Essentially this is game over. Game over will also occur if your leader dies from injuries, so yet another reason to horde that gold.Final ThoughtsIf you think you’re ready to tackle an advanced game such as this, Mordheim: City of the Damned is a great investment. But if you’re new to intensely customisable strategy games, but are prepared to learn, Mordheim: City of the Damned also does a great job at taking you by the hand in it’s tutorials.Read the full review[gamereviewsau.com]

												Im loving this game so far. I have not had any of the issues that were detailed in the negative reviews, in fact I almost passed this one by becuase of the reviews. As far as I can remember back playing the tabletop version , this is just about spot on in returning that experience to me, and alot of great memories of bringing my then early teen son into the hobby. That first warband you create , use it to learn the basics, but do not get attached. Now ive got a Reiklander band and a Possesed Band and they are life takers! The only problem im having is that the urge to keep tweeking and playing my warbands is all consuming , and I have to force myself to take breaks from the game. Take the time to make the adjustments in the options to suit you and have fun ! Im playing on a HP Pavillion laptop that I got a week ago, with no issues . I purchased the two DLC heros and the smuggler is in my  Reiklander warband the " Red Blades". She is a badass! And often saves the day despite twice having Brain damage from combat (one of which times she had an arrow stuck in her head while still fighting, the second occurrence being when she wandered too far at my request, and got jumped by the Sisters of Sigmar, luckily I got her some help in time ) Ive yet to make a Skaven band to use the Globadier with, also Globadiers can work for possesed warbands as well. The smuggler can work for the Sisters of Sigmar likewise. To the Devs, thanks for a great game!  I look forward to the upcomming warbands !

content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												Someone finally nailed tabletop gaming.If you played Modheim on the tabletop. Or Warhammer FB/40k. Or D&D. Or any other tactical miniature game on the table you recall hours spend crafting the perfect hero, squad, army. You had dream of how it would perform on the table, visions of fantasy glory. But often the game itself would get bogged down in rules and pitched battles would take hours to complete. The Mordheim successfully captures the enthrawling character/army building process and then pairs it with a very engaging, fluid combat system. You can build, fight, die, and build again several times in one evening. The mechanics are intuitive and easy to grasp but deeply tactical with enough RNG to harken back to those days around the table when a brilliant plan went spectacularly bad or a horrible idea went astonishingly good. I would love to see more races and more units, though there is a very healthy selection of themes, tactics, and strategies available now. And I would love to see a support tournament and league mode, which would further recreate our collective tabletop experience. The bottom line is this: late at night, after my family is asleep and my adult responsibilities are done, I can load up this game and push minis across the most beautiful city of the damned ever assembled. No organization, no preplanned event nights, no massive amount of money and time invested in collecting and painting. How perfect is that?

Posted: August 5, 2016
												A turn-based tactical game featuring no manual save, a Warhammer fantasy setting, heavy combat RNG, and an obnoxious inventory/side objective system.The RNG can really make this frustrating, even if you escape an ecounter with a win it can feel more like a loss when a lot of your soldiers end up heavily wounded in need of a few days resting period and money to get him that medical help.I can forgive the RNG and no manual save because the title advertises itself as extremelly cruel and punishing, but what i'm not sure I can get used to is the side objectives that I mentioned earlier, having to stall fights to send troops running around the map just to collect a bit of loot is beyond annoying, and from what i've seen (please correct me if i'm wrong) I couldn't stack Wyrdstone so you have to send someone who's inventory isn't already full and most of the characters i've gotten have about 3-4 slots to fill. Some plus sides:Great audio and visuals, the music and environments blend well with the grim dark setting of Warhammer.Lot of skills/attributes for your warband troops with a bit of customization looks wise. If there was a middle ground review option I would go with that but for right now, i'll recommend it on sale to masochists and lovers of Warhammer.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												So when I started out in this game I thought that maybe the naysayers had it right as it seemed ludicrously difficult, but 33 hours in and I love it.  It took me seven warbands to even get out of the blocks but that is becasue it is a learning experience.  Now I've got the hang of how to bring my squad together and focussing on preparing the battle ground that I want I can make pretty good progress.  That said it is still not a case of rinse and repeat.  If I make a mistake I get punished, and severley.  Yes the RNG can be punitive but it cuts both ways - Hero caught out in the open about to get mashed by a leader and hero from the enemy and then my lowly archer on the roof gets a stun on both bad guys in same round.  Without RNG that could never happen - I think the game gives you more extreme highs and lows as a result but I kind of like that.My biggest problem so far is that I cannot for the life of me see how I will ever amass enough cash to be able to skill up - got tons of skill points available but never have any money to be able to apply them.  Maybe it will get better in time.  Always seem to end up in combat very quickly and get a rout before I collect a fraction of the loot.I don't know the table top game or the Lore surrounding it but I hope we get DLC where I can have Greenskin and Ork warbands.  On warbands I should add that I'm not wild about the warband representations.  I've got a chaos crew who I think look the best of the bunch.  Think the Mercenaries (particularly the starting Hero unit) look like they'd fall over if you sneezed on them and why are there now mixed gender groupings?  Got to be boys or girls.That said it's got me hooked so thumbs up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												I am sure with 100's of reviews you can get a good feel playing a Workshop Videos if this game is for you. It is a board tactical turn based games with a lot to like and a lot not to like. It will infuriate you and challenge you, and rewards great strategy and knowing when to equip the right items. However, since failure is deadly in this game, especially in story campaign, many will give up, especially the novice or inter. player in that their hard work doesn't pay off. You count on luck, not skill, especially early in the game.If you adore strategy games, turn base games, there is a lot graphically to like, but I caution the cons.PROSA: Like X-com wonderful camera perspective in this game. It is in your face graphics and terrific action finishing sequencesB: Simple puzzle solving and map planningC: PC controller friendly with instant switching from mouse to controllerD: Nice customization, terrific factions which I am sure more DLC factions to come, the dead and knights, and fun skills and abilities to matchE: Fun storymodes for all factionsCONS and there are a bunchA: The lack of save kills your replayablity-Your faction continues like it or not. You don't get do overs. You will get death, dismemberment and cruel ailments if you fall. Now inter. and expert gamers may love this, but novice gamers, may not. Really up to your style. A novice player will get extremely frustrated because he will feel unrewarded for properly distributing skills, armors and positioning. It is all dice rolls. B: It is simple Stratego Flag positioning, Rock, Paper, Scissors and luck. Have 95% and higher hit rates and miss which gauls me to no end.C: One of my biggest issues is armors are useless, because of Armor Penetration, swords rule and again not rewarded at all for armors. They are adjusting this somewhat, but swords still rule.D: Heavy Weapons which can do so much damage, have too many negatives to warrant use. For example, you can have this mighty hammer and have an initiative penalty, tire and get just destroyed by dual weaponry with high initiative, agility and armor penetration, no sense.  Attacking 2-3 times will nullify heavy armored units. Heck with 2 times, wait till u fight bosses that hit u endlessly you having 95% dodge. That BS I quit moment. E: Early your range members are awful. F:  The game needed more complextion in its choices, A Diplomacy section, Proper Medical Section where u can interact and have strategic value to it, strategized goals or have great scenes of resolvement to the character you invested in. In faction character interactions, treason, more inventive skill chocies etc. Adding more player choices, would have enhanced the core or rock, paper, scissors. It honors the board game but it is stuck in that mechanic. Game lacked in game depth.G: Another killer is the objectives in missions are pointless in any battle. Collecting material mid battle is a waste since all you have to do is let them collect them and kill them to get the goals. See? makes no sense. However, player vs player different story.H: Skirmishes PVP, can get one sided quickly. Novice players may feel inferior at times.OVERALL: I can only give my take on it. I would wait as I did till Mordheim is less that 10 bucks and try it. I got it a 75% it's not worth it at full price. There is a wonderful beginners tutorial in workshop and if you wanted to try it. If you love Mordheim, that is great. Nothing I will say will change your mind. I found the battles to get too redundant, and even as the party grows, it is all gang up warfare. I do think this game will be improved upon in either another version or additions. It is possible they add some missing mechanics and elements, but don't hold your breath. Also follow the system requirements, lower older machines may not handle the game well. Mordheim is a good start. So some love hate here.MY SCORE: 3 of 5 stars-passing.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												This game is a 3D Hardcore, Permadeath, Final Fantasy Tactics. You are encouraged to play slow and tactically. If you rush in your character will die. But I love this game! There are many intense moments, where you don't know if the risk that you took with over extending to pick up a Wyrdstone was worth it or not until the end of the round. Your characters are EXPENDABLE as much as you would love to keep them and in perfect health. If you play cautiously, you will die less, but get less rewards, and vice versa. Sometimes the RNGesus is not in your favor and sometimes it is. A lot of people highlight the horrible moments they had in the game that caused them never play the game again or ALT+F4 the game. I have been there too, but i get sucked right back in after im over it. This game is like Licorice or Cilantro. You either HATE IT or you LOVE IT. Much like the Dark Souls Series. There is a steep learning curve, but once you get past that it's awesome. If you are on the fence, i say buy it, then give it about 3-5 hours, if you love it, keep it, if you hate it, Steam's refund policy is awesome. Welcome to Mordheim............. City of the Damned!

												Excellent game.  There is a learning curve but this is sped up by reading through the tutorial mission.  The game ios hard at first as your warband has no abilities yet.  I notice people reviewing this poorly with 8 hours played, etc.  I would honestly ignore those reviews as it takes longer than that to really get to know this game.  The different factions all add good replay value as well as dictating how you approach missions as fighting the Sisterhood is vastly different than fighting the Skaven or the Undead.  The hardcore aspect where characters can be maimed or die adds consequence and grit to this game and adds to the feeling that you are managing characters rather than pixels.  If you are looking for a challenge with tons of play value for a very reasonable price then you can't beat this title.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												I dont write too many reviews unless the is incredibly bad or amazing. This game is the latter.. AMAZING. Mordheim takes the combat system of Valkyria: Chronicles, the unit customization of X-Com, psychology system of darkest dungeon, the unforgivability of an Ironman Mode and throws into a interesting story with an immersive atmosphere. As a note, I'm not a fan of 40k/warhammer etc. and have never played the tabletop.. Yet I love this game. I'd write more but I linked a video below that says it all.TL;DR -Pro's -RPG progressionGreat Combat SystemUnit Movement is intuitiveIn-game Currency/Management system is well balanced PvP is intenseReal concequencesGood StoryAmazing AesteticsImmersive atmosphereGood Customization of UnitsCons -AI is stupidSteep Learning CurveIronman ModeContinuous Autosave prevents you from taking back a mistake


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



There is a very steep learning curve which may put off the majority of casual players. I went through about 30 hours of loosing my entire warband (4 restarts) and having to start all over before I finally achieved a successful combination of soldiers. Of course once I learned the basics.. exploiting the AI became incredibly easy. 98% success rate on missions. Which leaves PvP for the challenge, and yes it is a challenge with real rewards and real consequences.The Ironman mode you will find yourself in is Unforgiving. If your character gets critically hit (your standard high dmg crit in any game) he will suffer a permanent injury. By permanent injury, I mean he will loose an eye and have -10% chance to hit for the rest of the game, or loose an arm and never be able to dual wield or use a 2hander. He could loose a leg and never be able to climb again (Which is really important in this game). You will find yourself becoming the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ company man and firing any worker who gets hurt lol.The movement system is amazing, just like in valkyria chronicles. You will recieve strategy points which can be used for certain types of active skills (Parry stance, climb, leap, jump down, etc.) or for movement. Each character has it's own movement radius based on his agility stats and gear equiped. Movement itself consumes 1 point giving you a radius to within, moving past the radius consumes another strategy point automatically. Early in the game you will have 4-6 strategy points while fully leveled up characters will have 7-12 points. Didnt get to the position you wanted this turn? Simply run back through your waypoints and get your Strategy points refunded.The combat system is amazing

content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												EDIT (26/10/16): A good number of the issues/bugs mentioned below have been fixed with the latest Patch 9, thus enabling the player to continue the game smoothly. Here I would once again like to thank the devs who responded in a timely manner and were able to put out a well constructed fix. As it was never my original intent to malign well designed turn based games if they do not suffer from lethal bugs, I am happy to flip this review to Recommended as Mordheim did provide me with many hours of suspenseful challenge and fun, in particular the story campaign missions.P/S - I got a message that flipping the review would erase ratings and would just like to note for the record that before this flip 9/20 found it helpful>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>This a really intriguing tactical game with good depth, many colorful classes featuring a myriad of skills, steeped in heady Warhammer lore and bearing moody graphics, which is unfortunately greatly marred by a horrid user interface that clips and hides text/figures and can even render certain story mission icons non visible in the majority of the resolutions chosen. The way in which deployments are handled: having to press A/D repeatedly to even place 1 unit properly is beyond tedious and there is no simple way to check the whole list of enchantments you have besides clicking on every enchantable slot.However the most damning thing about the game is that it still bears many horrid random bugs that unfortunately render it unplayable for the luckless. One such bug involves a random "Round 1" freeze where the only way out of it is to abandon battle, thereby taking automatic injury rolls on all warband members, quite likely resulting in permadeath or permanent injuries. Yes, as there are no separate save/load files, such a bug effectively completely cripples a once promising warband through no fault of the player. To add insult to injury, after such a bug, you might also find your inventory completely emptied through some form of file corruption. Another deadly bug involves a character getting stuck in a position in another character's zone of control whereby no actions may be taken and the game cannot proceed even if it's the player's turn. Once again the only choice is to abandon the battle and face the above penalties, which may well mean complete warband decimation and loss of many hours of play.Of course there are also the numerous crashes to desktop and issues with Directx 11 and many many more and all of these issues are well documented in the bug subforums here. The issues I've highlighted barely even scratch the first page of said bug forum and there are literally 1.8k threads there.There is the mark of a great game here and a persistent warband concept with hardcore leanings where mistakes are poorly tolerated and where it is fun to pick your battles/deployments well and to carefully manage your way to the top. But unless you don't mind seeing literally everything taken away in an instant because the game decided to throw you a random bug, I would suggest trying other turn based games. I reserve the right to flip this review when all these issues have been fixed but seeing as it has been nearly a year since this game has been out and had a fairly long beta testing phase before that, I doubt the bugs and UI issues are going away anytime soon.

Early Access Review
								I Only got a chance to play 1 skirmish but already I'm hooked. At the moment there are only 2 pre made warbands but its still plenty fun and is a really refreshing take on turn based combat. The atmosphere is gritty, the graphics are great. Once everything is added, which doesnt look like it will be long, such as character progression, items, campaigns its truley going to be an amazing game.I only played the table top version a couple times but this looks like it will be a great port from tabletop to video game.It has a few niggely bugs, mostly camera bugs (looking at walls etc) but towards the end of my first game I suffered a bit of packet loss and the game never recovered and i had to end processUpdate:I've played a couple more games with a friend and its still great fun but also frustrating. Although you dont see any "dice rolls" you still fail at times and can do nothing but condemn RNGesus.Since they have released the warbands compendium which has explained a couple of things to me I finally managed to get ahead in a game as the Skaven. I'm ahead on kills. All my monstrous creature needs to do is kill the mercenery leader and his buddy. First turn he fails his stupidity check, the next turn he misses all 3 84% attacks and promptly gets ♥♥♥♥♥ slapped in the face. It was a total turn around.The whole line of sight system and ambush moves works really well. Watching my opponent walk into 2 tanged overwatch skavens and a melee is too satisfying. A perfectly executed ambush. I cant wait for the progression and loot system to be introduced.Another bug: My rat ogre was able to walk into a building through the doorway (just) but once he was in, he wasnt getting out :(

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												Solid Game, Turn based, Stratagy,I have played this game for about a week now and have zero regrets in purchasing it. If you are a stratagy/tactics and warhammer fan this is a fantastic game for you. This is a thinking persons game, its not a shooter or an action game it is fairly slow paced and methodical. if you dont use stratagy and tactics this game will be very frustrating for you. The AI isnt all that smart, but it is extreamly agressive, and can be very brutal when your not prepaired for it (learn to use this against it) even on the average dificuly maps.PROS:- Solid game, very few bugs- fluid turn based gameplay- Challenging- good graphics and soundCONS:- early game can be pretty brutal- AI is agressive, but not all that smart (see above)- game modes are limited, very little variation except in story missions where you see some unique objectives- warband customization is limited (I.E unit types)- warband members can suffer permant injuries/death (as well as item/gear loss on being downed in combat)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23
												One of the most frustrating, yet satisfying games I have ever played. I haven't been so addicted since the original release of "Civ II." I actually wake up at 5am excited to get an extra hour of playtime before the day starts. There is a lot of randomness, and you will die. It keeps you coming back to prove you can do it better. Sort of like "Darkest Dungeon," that way. Turn-based combat in most games tends to have top-down views and less impressive graphics, which keep you feeling removed and God-like as you orchestrate the strategy from afar. Mordheim feels like a polished third person adventure...only slower. You only get the point of view of the character whose turn it is, and the enemy is often hidden. It's very real and the art is excellent. After every battle, you get the option to equip, upgrade, and customize your party; hire or fire new members; and sell your booty. Your skill choices are permanent and will greatly influence how effective your team becomes. The costume and character design is very well done: dark, gritty, practical, and aesthetically pleasing. I want to give a hug to whoever designed the Sisters faction. They look like real women. No ridiculous swaths of skin exposed. No gigantic boobs. The leader has a pudgy, matronly face that I adore. This game is probably not for everyone. If you don't have patience and a passion for strategical planning, best to steer clear. Personally, this is one of the best things I've ever discovered.

content:
Posted: March 7
												This is, at least for me, exactly what I'm looking for in a Games Workshop game. Turn based strategy, cool level progression, lots of customization. It's close to the table top games people love. All the warbands have their own stregnths and weaknesses. I only wish there were more warbands to choose from. With the endless font of crap GW vomits up this one stands out as a gem. I'm very looking forward to Necromunda, hopefully they keep the things that make this game great. This game is quite difficult, so I only recommend it if you enjoy a challenge. Expect your first couple warbands to join the corpses strewn about the Mordeheim landscape, but the first time you actually reach endgame will feel like a huge accomplishment. Many people complain about the game feeling unfair, their guys missing repeatedly with an 80% chance to hit. However 80% isnt 100 and you will hit about 8 out of 10 times. Its all about positioning, using your tanks to block and hold units while you surround and destroy others with your damage classes. The only thing that seems kind of weak to me is the magic, you're better off equipping your mages with 2 handed weapons and actually doing damage... but then I was never much of a magic player, maybe someone else figured out how to make the most of it.Highly recommend this game. Its atmospheric and immersive, and you actually come to love your units. I recommend giving them all unique names and backstory to enhance your gaming experience. Please GW, more of this, stick with this developer, we would love it if you put out more high quality games like Mordeheim than the endless stream of garbage we have been getting.For those of you having trouble, a couple tips. Keep your warband together. Don't even take missions that split your warband up (particularly the ones that split you into 3 small groups) Make sure to keep your lighter damage units behind your heavy tanks, resist the urge to use their faster movement to take them out front. When you set up ambushes make sure that they don't end up pinching the enemy in a doorway where you can't surround them. Impressive units can be a real problem if they wind up in the middle of your warband where they can create absolute havoc. Try to use the alleys and doorways to trap enemy impressives, as the AI won't be able to get them unstuck. Above all never engage anyone alone, especially with your leader and heroes. They are too valuable to risk, disengage and run to your minions who are expendable. Don't spend money on the minons until late game, if some of your units have to die, better them than your Bosses and heroes.You really have to invest some time to make your warband great. Don't give up after an hour or two of playing the game, and really try to go for the extra objectives, as getting them will make your levels spring forward.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												Every update this game becomes more and more like what I originally hoped it would be. Pros +It's a Mordheim video game, and it is good. If you understand what that means, this should be an auto-purchase. +First person turn based works awesomely, I've never seen it done like this before and I think it really fits the game. The developers clearly put a lot of work into those environments (They look amazing) and first person really compliments that well.+All 4 Warbands are interesting and fun in their own way. Even the humans (Very rare for GW media)+Good variety of skills/spells, good character progression as well. It's fairly similar to XCom +Vertical movement almost as important as horizontal. Very unique to Mordheim I think, and its very fun+Fun as ♥♥♥♥. Really the most important thing.+I'd imagine finding a group of people to play a large scale multiplayer campaign (Like you could on the tabletop) would be fun. I don't have any friends though, so that's just me theorizingCons-Only 4 war bands without that many kinds of units. -Campaign nothing special (not that this is meant to be played for the story lol) collecting wyrdstone can be annoying and they make you do it-The UI is very strange and almost feels like it was designed for consoles? I'm hoping more war bands come out soon, because right now that's really the big flaw for me. There simply isn't enough variety within warbands themselves to justify only having 4 and calling this a finished game.

But then again it's not chess.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
Product received for free
												This is a short first impressions after playing the game for just under 2 hours (during the free weekend). The short conclusion is the game is good and very fun showing lots of potential, with a couple of critical issues that might put off a few people (in terms of gameplay and design decisions). Longer version - the game is solid. Indepth party system where you can make your warband anything you want as the time goes on and the level of customisation is impressive. I can see that over a campaign, players could really bond with their little toy soldiers through unique experiences. Feels like this might be better done that even something like Xcom. The strategy in it is good and overall reminds me of Valkyria Chronicles (VC) without the obnoxious cutscenes, overbearing story and general animeness. The missions have an interesting way about them and you have to balance danger, party ability, demands for resources and local mission requirements making for an interesting risk reward system that relies on your ability to command. Feels very organic, though I cant say how it will last in the long run. Basically - the actual gameplay of the game is satisfying and I enjoyed it a lot.There are a couple problems here though. The UI is, in a word, crap. Mouse+keys or gamepad (I actually found gamepad more viable in mission mode due to some weird camera acceleration, but mouse in the menus) - its all really clunky. Lots of small windows with masses of stats and info. Very cool for showing all you want to know - but it is pretty intimidating at first and then its just a bit messy. This is all forgettable, however. My biggest issue, as many already have pointed out - the AI turns are dull as hell. For around a third of most rounds youll be stuck watching the back of your last soldiers head as all the AI units move about unseen on the map. This takes a long time. Genuinely - the game has an unreasonable amount of downtime between your movements and I found myself feeling as if my time was being wasted. Comparing to the peers, VC shows you all the enemy troops off the getgo and you see their moves - feels like youre part of the game. Xcom has pretty quick turns and some feedback in the form of sound waves (helped by the isometric view). Here its just "wait for a couple minutes till the AI is done and then get back to playing". Its annoying and actually detracts from an otherwise fun strategy experience. Finally - Im not into WH lore so I dont know about the fanbase, but the factions of offer were a bit bland and samey from a first look. Humans, different kind of humans, a 3rd kind of humans, a 4th kind of humans (now posessed by chaos) and ratmen. Doesnt exactly feel like the creative muscles were stretched there.  Ultimately - I liked what I saw so far and will finish off my free weekend with it to see further in. People who like turn based tactics games a-la Xcom will enjoy this, especially if they like the WH fantasy universe (Im ambivalent to it, but the game suits the setting well). People who are used to faster games will probably find this too restrictive. An overall thumbs up from me, but the long AI turns combined with a messy interface could genuinely make this a dealbreaker. Ive yet to see. I recommend looking up videos and maybe finding someone who already has the game to see if the issues ive pointed to matter to you. If they dont, get the game - youll have fun.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Still in early access, but they seem to be making pretty good progress with it.The progression (Campaign) is already in the game a bit and takes the form of running what amount to skirmish missions (Kill or route the enemy team with some optional objectives) with story missions placed in that you have to run skirmish missions to rank up for.The game is a tactical RPG, instead of both sides taking turns, each unit has an "initiative" score that determines when it is it's turn to move.Movement is free flowing and controlled by WASD keys. You can move a certain amount of points in any direction, with unlimited backtracking (As long as you aren't overwatched/ambushed/trapped) until you confirm the movementA loot system is within the game, and before and after each battle, you will need to deal with the warbands equipment and stats/skills.The setting is pretty neat, it takes place within an Empire city that was destroyed by a Chaos meteor that has strewn valuable Warpstones all over the city.Each of the current 4 warbands has a neat play-style and reason for being within Mordheim.Sisters of Sigmar: Heavily armored nuns that lack ranged weaponry. They are trying to purge the city and destroy the Warpstone.Reiklander Mercenaries: Medium to heavy armored humans that have an abundance of ranged weaponry. They are trying to collect the warpstone to sell to other Human nations.Cult of the Possessed: Mutants and Demons that are fairly medium to heavily armored, they lack good ranged weaponry, but make up for it with a variety of neat mutations and mechanics. They are trying to collect all the Warpstone to appease their god.Skaven douches: Light armored mostly, dodge everything, and moves all the ♥♥♥♥ing time. They want the warpstone cause they are greedy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s or something.The persistent injury system is very unique, a unit going down in a battle is not the end of the world, and very easy to recover from. Often they may not even die, but can be effected by a variety of injuries that alter the way they play.And example is my Chaos Magistrate who originally started out as a caster...well..a blow to the head has convinced him he is actually a god, and only ever uses melee weapons now...thought I should fire him, but damn, he is making it work.Any-who, I enjoy the game.

Early Access Review
								It is really refreshing to see this game aiming to stay so true to the original Mordheim games' rules. The turn-based action in this game really brings to life the strategy that was such a part of the game in its tabletop format. The game is not without its issues and bugs, it is still in early release, but I am very excited to see how this unfolds. So far, there are only two playable warbands and you have no customization available, however, in the tutorial two other warbands are revealed and the potential behind the campaign customization is viewable. I am curious to know how they will balance offline and online play and as to whether a warband can engage in either or if it will be restricted to one. Either way, I think anyone who ever engaged in Games Workshops' Mordheim had best take a serious look at this game and even if you never did, it is a great game if you are into strategy and tactics.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												An underrated gem of a game. An absolute must-play for any fans of TBS, RPG, or the Warhammer universe. The various factions are unique in their playstyles and motivations ensuring countless hours of replayability. It is a bit of a niche title, the initial difficulty may scare some players away, but if is worth enduring the initial learning curve in order to truly experience Mordheim. I am very impressed with the story missions of the game, which add much more incentive to continue with a warband in the campaign. I am also impressed with all of the DLC to date, it all adds to the experience and is reasonably priced for what it provides. My only concerns with this game would have to be the occasionally flawed A.I. and RNG, and just a lack of players for the multiplayer base. One of those two is easily solved by buying the game and joining in on the fun, I sincerely hope the community continues to grow, I am absolutely in love with this game.

Posted: February 23
												One of the most frustrating, yet satisfying games I have ever played. I haven't been so addicted since the original release of "Civ II." I actually wake up at 5am excited to get an extra hour of playtime before the day starts. There is a lot of randomness, and you will die. It keeps you coming back to prove you can do it better. Sort of like "Darkest Dungeon," that way. Turn-based combat in most games tends to have top-down views and less impressive graphics, which keep you feeling removed and God-like as you orchestrate the strategy from afar. Mordheim feels like a polished third person adventure...only slower. You only get the point of view of the character whose turn it is, and the enemy is often hidden. It's very real and the art is excellent. After every battle, you get the option to equip, upgrade, and customize your party; hire or fire new members; and sell your booty. Your skill choices are permanent and will greatly influence how effective your team becomes. The costume and character design is very well done: dark, gritty, practical, and aesthetically pleasing. I want to give a hug to whoever designed the Sisters faction. They look like real women. No ridiculous swaths of skin exposed. No gigantic boobs. The leader has a pudgy, matronly face that I adore. This game is probably not for everyone. If you don't have patience and a passion for strategical planning, best to steer clear. Personally, this is one of the best things I've ever discovered.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												This is a Warhammer tabletop game conversion into a video game. And it is amazing. Hailing form GamesWorkshop. Into the grim dark Warhammer world, this game really immerses and sets the enviromental/atmosphere of the tabletop and fantasy world. I don't think they could of done better with that aspect. The music is eerie and the maps of Mordheim itself are rather halloween gone dark.  Nothing is happy and yay, but grim, dark and pulsing chaos mutations growing on the walls kinda thing. ITS GREAT. With buildings and walkways all over the maps, it really does feel like a city gone to ghost town and believable. Choose to make a warband out of 5 possible factions. Chaos, Skaven, Empire, Sisters of Sigmar and Witchhunters.  Within each warband you get characters to make thus warband. Choose a hero and a leader that will be the mainstay and backbone of your army. You only get one of each and this is where you can really design what your warband will be capable of or designed to do in game. ( If you are going kinda ranged or melee or spellcasting )Then you get henchman. Henchman are the simple guys that you get more out of their numbers then your ''one man army'' characters. You do get to custimize names and outfits and really make the warband personal, so dont be afraid to! Also the RPG aspect of the game of leveling your warband as individauals and as a warband is there. Equipment is important and make sure you got your warband in tip top shape before you venture out!  So in Mordheim; CIty of the Damned,  you have the  controlling your warband- leveling them up , equiping them and learning skills and paying the henchmen, a shop- to buy/sell equipment for your warband, Skirmish -where you can do fights against other online warbands, Vetern-where your compiled expereince and acheivments and such, from all your warbands lets you spend and upgrade points that all your warbands gain access too. Then the two big points is the campign and your shipments. The whole point of the game and your warband is to steal, pillage plunder wyrdstone. The missions are played in tactical turn based combat style. It's extremely unforgiving and you need to make some tough dicisions. There is alot fo rolling dice going on with the attacks and defence. Extreme luck and randomness happens. Magic? HAHA well remember that things dont always happen the way you want to... Map awareness is to be learned and your warband to work together as a team. Cliche? yes, but men stay dead when they die and loot can be more vauable then life! Wyrdstone is what your fighting over and killing/stealing from the other warbands from in missions in the campign mode. All the missions are about gaining these goods so you can make shipments to your supreme leader/god/king. Making shipments and doing missions is good for your warband and the'll level up and equipment and your warbands numbers will grow. FAILURE to get your hands on the green rocks and dying in combat, makes perminant injurys to your warband and will make life harder for you to complete more missions. After failing to ship out the wyrdstone up to 4 times, your warbands and your life is forfit and die. GRIM? Well its Warhammer. The game is to be hard, and to experince the stress and toll pillaging and killing can be. For good or bad, its a tough life. SO, can you keep your warband together? Think you have the leadership to be succesful in the pit, deseased rotten Mordheim ? With creepy music and lots of screaming/blood animations in combat, this game is as dark as it goes. Referances to Dunes '' The spice must flow'' comes to mind while playing this game...

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												I'm reluctant to thumbs-down this because there are some very cool elements to this game. I dig the character building to an extent, but it's pretty rudimentary. There's so many skills on display, but you can't access them. Overall, there's so much depth to the game, and yet it feels so shallow--why? I want to like this game. I really do. Even though I'm not a huge fan of the muddled universe that is Warhammer, the concept of this game is great.That being said, it's just too poorly executed. Mordheim suffers from a similar problem that XCOM 2 has, where the AI not only takes far too long to make a decision, but it always ends up doing the most obvious lemming-esque choice. If you're just gonna keep auto-attacking, why do you need more than a couple seconds to figure it out? To top it off, while the animations *do* look nice, they have this weird ending lag where the characters are just kind of awkwardly staring at each other after one just bashed the other in the face with a flail. Everything just takes too damn long. You know it's a problem when you feel more relieved being out of combat not because you achieved a victory, but because you're bored. In sum, though, I'll say this:PROS:* Character customization, building your own team is always fun.* Solid animation.* Cool art overall, as one would expect from Warhammer, it's a dark universe.* Playable with both KBM and controller, button callouts change as you swap between them.* Decent soundtrack and voice acting.CONS:* AI takes too long.* So much to learn, but so little to do with it.* Environments are fairly bland, but hey, it's Warhammer.* Witch Hunters are DLC, yet they stand prominently in character select, dead center, and highlighted as if they're playable. That's kind of an insult to gamers. Like, if I were to boot up Diablo 3 or something, go to make a new character, and, say, I wanna make a Witch Doctor or something--nope, sorry, you have to pay $2.99 first! That's a super special DLC character! Why stop there? Make every character/warband/what-have-you DLC!All in all, if this is your cup of tea, try it and see if you like it. The game is *almost* mechanically sound, and has some redeeming qualities, but I'll pass on this snooze-fest.
