content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												This is a really fun adaptation of Mordheim.I've been a big fan of games like this and Inquisitor for quite a long time in table-top land, and I love the Warhammer universes. However, I will do my best to not be biased here in the hopes of helping you decide if this game is for you or not!To begin, this game is tough as nails, and can be even tougher depending which warband you pick and how you set up your team. Much like tabletop Mordheim, your future success largely in part depends on how well you do in the first few missions. If you do well, rack up lots of stuff to sell and Wyrdstone, all while hardly getting anyone injured, you should get to the part where the game becomes more manageable, even if you make a mistake and fail a mission horribly. Let me say this loud and clearly though, for every new person in the room:Melee. Trumps. Range.Yeah, you heard me. In this game, you will suffer many, many to-hit penalities. You will set up overwatch shots just slightly at the wrong angle and watch helplessly as your archer gets smashed in one round. This is a game about gangs, and what do gangs do to get the advantage? They GANG UP on a smaller number of units, normally in melee, in this case, and they pound them into the dirt. In table-top, you want to swarm enemy models and roll as many dice as possible. Missing is guaranteed, hits are god-sends, and it's the same formula here. Mostly melee (of all varities - don't be that person who goes all swords/shields and then finds themselves losing because dual-wielding rats are stabbing you in the back,) with a few good ranged units. To put it into perspective, I start like this: I immediately go to the market and see if I can buy a decent ranged weapon for my warband leader. Bow/etc is -okay-, dueling pistols/warlock pistols are what you want, though. I then slap those on my hero's alternate equipment, recruit ONE archer henchman if available (not a special character - I strongly suggest taking the melee special character first,) and then fill up on melee.Next up, optimize your weapons. Bonuses to hit, bonuses to ambush damage, parry chance, etc - all great. Heavy weapons? Best used on characters who hit well on their own. Armor is also not always the best choice for every character either. Sometimes taking that 50% dodge is the best choice you can get, and the cheapest, too.If you try the above, and play carefully (be sure to give your archer two daggers or something in their offhand, too. Archers I tend to give armor asap as well,) you should be gravy. With those first 3-4 missions done, you'll be feeling good.I bet you'll even feel great.But then?The first story mission happens.And you're in for a whole new level of hell.Don't even click on that mission until your rating is closer to what it says the enemy has. You can see this by clicking on but not accepting the mission. It will destroy your life, your warbands life, and♥♥♥♥♥♥your pockets. It really will, especially a particular few races (RNG can be really rough on the humans for that first mission. Believe me.)Graphics are decent, controls take adjusting to (your first warband is doomed to death if you're like me and mess up the controls for a bit before getting used to them,) and sometimes you will get grumpy that so-and-so enemy just charged through a narrow crack between three ambushing characters.But hey, welcome to Mordheim. It's all about luck and tenacity and a whole lot of death. Do suggest, 8.5/10, needs more races with cheaper DLC (the current price model is 'meh.')Multiplayer suggested over everything else, even if you do the one where no changes happen to your warband, but thanks to the RNG and the computer's tendency to stick to the 'gang up and pound you' strategy, even playing vs the computer can be fun.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
												A 3D, 3rd-Person, Turn-Based, Tactical, RPG set in the world of Warhammer Fantasy. Mordheim: City of the Damned has everything that I love in a game: a grim-dark universe rich with lore, simple controls, procedural encounters, customizable characters, and a difficulty that cannot be altered or lowered. This game is hard, not because it requires skill but because every action taken by your characters, (walking is mundane and requires no actual roll), will be resolved randomly based on a percentage of your characters' skill; this percentage will be bigger or smaller from how high the skill is required to perform that action is. This means, you, as the player, have no actual control in how well your characters perform, the most that you, as the player, will be doing is moving your characters to an enemy and telling them to attack or up to a wall and telling them to climb it, all you can do is watch and hope they succeed. The player is soley responsible for strategy on the field and building up your warband to get better percentage rolls.So let me reiterate, this game is hard, and you will become frustrated when you fail but the replayability for this game is extremely high and I advise playing as each of the available factions because they each require different types of mindsets to play them, and nothing feels better than settling with a race or faction that just speaks to you on an emotional level.Anyways, I recommend this game to anyone who is a huge fan of unforgiving turn-based random number generators, meaning if you really liked Darkest Dungeon you are gonna enjoy this. I have been playing since the Cult of the Possessed were first added during Early Access so I am very pleased with how this game has evolved.Oh and I highly recommend looking up the official lore and fluff for Warhammer Fantasy, you'll be suprised at how vast the universe can really be.Thanks for reading.

Posted: February 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								This games looks like it is coming along great!  I can tell that there is much more to come and that they are spending some time on balancing.  Have played a few games with my buddy and I think the Cult are a little overpowered.  Sisters had 77% or better to hit on them and they missed all but 2 attacks in melee?  My buddy playing Skaven failed most of his climb and jump checks which just didn't make sense to me.  Overall reminded me of rolling poorly nonstop at the gamestore I used to play Mordheim at! LOL  Only question I have really is when will Sisters of Sigmar get thier whips?! =) Overall I think they hit the right feel for Mordheim.  The play controls once learned are good.  You can really tell they are trying to make it work for controllers as well as keyboard and mouse.

They GANG UP on a smaller number of units, normally in melee, in this case, and they pound them into the dirt. In table-top, you want to swarm enemy models and roll as many dice as possible. Missing is guaranteed, hits are god-sends, and it's the same formula here. Mostly melee (of all varities - don't be that person who goes all swords/shields and then finds themselves losing because dual-wielding rats are stabbing you in the back,) with a few good ranged units. To put it into perspective, I start like this: I immediately go to the market and see if I can buy a decent ranged weapon for my warband leader. Bow/etc is -okay-, dueling pistols/warlock pistols are what you want, though. I then slap those on my hero's alternate equipment, recruit ONE archer henchman if available (not a special character - I strongly suggest taking the melee special character first,) and then fill up on melee.Next up, optimize your weapons. Bonuses to hit, bonuses to ambush damage, parry chance, etc - all great. Heavy weapons? Best used on characters who hit well on their own. Armor is also not always the best choice for every character either. Sometimes taking that 50% dodge is the best choice you can get, and the cheapest, too.If you try the above, and play carefully (be sure to give your archer two daggers or something in their offhand, too. Archers I tend to give armor asap as well,) you should be gravy. With those first 3-4 missions done, you'll be feeling good.I bet you'll even feel great.But then?The first story mission happens.And you're in for a whole new level of hell.Don't even click on that mission until your rating is closer to what it says the enemy has. You can see this by clicking on but not accepting the mission. It will destroy your life, your warbands life, and♥♥♥♥♥♥your pockets. It really will, especially a particular few races (RNG can be really rough on the humans for that first mission. Believe me.)Graphics are decent, controls take adjusting to (your first warband is doomed to death if you're like me and mess up the controls for a bit before getting used to them,) and sometimes you will get grumpy that so-and-so enemy just charged through a narrow crack between three ambushing characters.But hey, welcome to Mordheim. It's all about luck and tenacity and a whole lot of death. Do suggest, 8.5/10, needs more races with cheaper DLC (the current price model is 'meh.')Multiplayer suggested over everything else, even if you do the one where no changes happen to your warband, but thanks to the RNG and the computer's tendency to stick to the 'gang up and pound you' strategy, even playing vs the computer can be fun.

content:
Posted: January 15
												Initially I wrote a negative review about this game because it spanked me and I ragequit.  I've deleted that review and persisted with the game, read some articles and learned how to play it and I have to say it's a lot of fun.  There's some rich tactical strategy to be had here.  This is a game of positioning and attempting to outmaneuver your enemy.  The combat is quite savage and I think a lot of the negative reviews would go away if the developer simply let the player decide what difficulty level they wished to play at, rather than forcing the player into the way they want the game to be played.You will get no easy, normal or hard campaign.  Each mission is rated starting at normal, hard, brutal and deadly.  Right from the get go.  The AI stays about the same but the enemies get massive buffs as the difficulty increases.  Of course, you don't have to do these hard missions.  But there are better rewards if you choose to do them.  And it's incredibly satisfying when, either by skill or luck, you win a challenging mission.There's a lot of customization of your warband and it's a lot of fun naming and making your troops into characters.  Your fighters can be injured and a couple of mine are missing arms and one now has a peg leg.  There are definite consequences in this game and no save scumming.  There's no saving at all, its all autosave and you cannot reload.I'd say this is an excellent game, but it's also very hard, there's no doubt about it and if you don't like to lose you'll have to get good if you want to survive the deadly streets of Mordheim.

content:
Posted: January 6
												Although There is no Neutral Catagory when Rating Games, My impression of the Mordheim Game Is Neutral. on the one hand It is Challenging and Requires Thinking, LOTS AND LOTS OF THINKING. and can Be Quite Rewarding. However on the Other hand, Two of the Six Warbands Are DLC and Can be Encountered in Singleplayer; Even if you do not own the DLC, One of those Two Said Warbands is completely Game breaking and overpowered. I am Of Course referring to the Undead.the Undead are the Most Frustratingly Broken Opponents to face, and from my point of view, are so powerful that they make playing the game Rather Pointless. Their Leader Is Almost Unstoppable and their Foot soldiers Far Outstretch Everyone Else. You can Have Good Equipment and Good Strategies, but the Undead are Almost Always Even better.It is Frustrating and Sometimes even Aggrivating to Encounter these Opponents, as it makes it almost impossible to play the game and NOT get the Pre-shipped DLC that you must pay for before Using. The only way you can Even the Field is with Long Ranged Troopers. and they will Immediately get Run over by the Undead's Footmen.If you are into XCOM or any other Game like it, I would Heavily Warn you before Purchasing this Game.But Aside from the Undead, the Rest of the Warbands seem to balance each other out, The Human Mercenaries are your Run-of-the-Mill Mercs. who are almost always going to Beat the Rat-Peeps, and the Cultists who are almost always going to lose to the Sisters of Sigmar.The Witch hunters are another DLC Warband that Comes Pre-Shipped with the Game, and you can Encounter them within the Game even on Single player. I have only encountered them once, So i don't have much of an Opinion on them.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												Whilst its quite unpolished with clunky UI, its an excelent strategy game that manages to be challenging and rewarding.I cannot stress enough that it is VERY challenging, you might get on a winning streak for a while, but one bad loss can leave your veteran soldiers permenently dead or with debilitating wounds.Whilst that sounds frustrating (and is!) it creates a brilliant atmosphere where you have to constantly judge the risk and reward of each mission, often encouraging you to use new recruits as meatshields whilst your elite troops look for safer opportunities to attack.Thankfully the game comes with a progression system so that even if your entire warband gets killed, you will have earned a bunch of bonuses to any new warbands you create which helps the difficulty not feel too opressive.in short:-A challenging game of calculated risk taking, it is not a game of certainties but rather of adapting to misfortune.-Somewhat unpolished, UI is poor and controls are unintuitive.-Fairly repetetive gameplay, there are story missions with unique objectives but the bulk of the game is within familiar streets of the city fighting against roughly equal forces.-consistently creates interesting strategic situations without clear 'best' solutions.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
Product received for free
												This is a short first impressions after playing the game for just under 2 hours (during the free weekend). The short conclusion is the game is good and very fun showing lots of potential, with a couple of critical issues that might put off a few people (in terms of gameplay and design decisions). Longer version - the game is solid. Indepth party system where you can make your warband anything you want as the time goes on and the level of customisation is impressive. I can see that over a campaign, players could really bond with their little toy soldiers through unique experiences. Feels like this might be better done that even something like Xcom. The strategy in it is good and overall reminds me of Valkyria Chronicles (VC) without the obnoxious cutscenes, overbearing story and general animeness. The missions have an interesting way about them and you have to balance danger, party ability, demands for resources and local mission requirements making for an interesting risk reward system that relies on your ability to command. Feels very organic, though I cant say how it will last in the long run. Basically - the actual gameplay of the game is satisfying and I enjoyed it a lot.There are a couple problems here though. The UI is, in a word, crap. Mouse+keys or gamepad (I actually found gamepad more viable in mission mode due to some weird camera acceleration, but mouse in the menus) - its all really clunky. Lots of small windows with masses of stats and info. Very cool for showing all you want to know - but it is pretty intimidating at first and then its just a bit messy. This is all forgettable, however. My biggest issue, as many already have pointed out - the AI turns are dull as hell. For around a third of most rounds youll be stuck watching the back of your last soldiers head as all the AI units move about unseen on the map. This takes a long time. Genuinely - the game has an unreasonable amount of downtime between your movements and I found myself feeling as if my time was being wasted. Comparing to the peers, VC shows you all the enemy troops off the getgo and you see their moves - feels like youre part of the game. Xcom has pretty quick turns and some feedback in the form of sound waves (helped by the isometric view). Here its just "wait for a couple minutes till the AI is done and then get back to playing". Its annoying and actually detracts from an otherwise fun strategy experience. Finally - Im not into WH lore so I dont know about the fanbase, but the factions of offer were a bit bland and samey from a first look. Humans, different kind of humans, a 3rd kind of humans, a 4th kind of humans (now posessed by chaos) and ratmen. Doesnt exactly feel like the creative muscles were stretched there.  Ultimately - I liked what I saw so far and will finish off my free weekend with it to see further in. People who like turn based tactics games a-la Xcom will enjoy this, especially if they like the WH fantasy universe (Im ambivalent to it, but the game suits the setting well). People who are used to faster games will probably find this too restrictive. An overall thumbs up from me, but the long AI turns combined with a messy interface could genuinely make this a dealbreaker. Ive yet to see. I recommend looking up videos and maybe finding someone who already has the game to see if the issues ive pointed to matter to you. If they dont, get the game - youll have fun.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7
												This is, at least for me, exactly what I'm looking for in a Games Workshop game. Turn based strategy, cool level progression, lots of customization. It's close to the table top games people love. All the warbands have their own stregnths and weaknesses. I only wish there were more warbands to choose from. With the endless font of crap GW vomits up this one stands out as a gem. I'm very looking forward to Necromunda, hopefully they keep the things that make this game great. This game is quite difficult, so I only recommend it if you enjoy a challenge. Expect your first couple warbands to join the corpses strewn about the Mordeheim landscape, but the first time you actually reach endgame will feel like a huge accomplishment. Many people complain about the game feeling unfair, their guys missing repeatedly with an 80% chance to hit. However 80% isnt 100 and you will hit about 8 out of 10 times. Its all about positioning, using your tanks to block and hold units while you surround and destroy others with your damage classes. The only thing that seems kind of weak to me is the magic, you're better off equipping your mages with 2 handed weapons and actually doing damage... but then I was never much of a magic player, maybe someone else figured out how to make the most of it.Highly recommend this game. Its atmospheric and immersive, and you actually come to love your units. I recommend giving them all unique names and backstory to enhance your gaming experience. Please GW, more of this, stick with this developer, we would love it if you put out more high quality games like Mordeheim than the endless stream of garbage we have been getting.For those of you having trouble, a couple tips. Keep your warband together. Don't even take missions that split your warband up (particularly the ones that split you into 3 small groups) Make sure to keep your lighter damage units behind your heavy tanks, resist the urge to use their faster movement to take them out front. When you set up ambushes make sure that they don't end up pinching the enemy in a doorway where you can't surround them. Impressive units can be a real problem if they wind up in the middle of your warband where they can create absolute havoc. Try to use the alleys and doorways to trap enemy impressives, as the AI won't be able to get them unstuck. Above all never engage anyone alone, especially with your leader and heroes. They are too valuable to risk, disengage and run to your minions who are expendable. Don't spend money on the minons until late game, if some of your units have to die, better them than your Bosses and heroes.You really have to invest some time to make your warband great. Don't give up after an hour or two of playing the game, and really try to go for the extra objectives, as getting them will make your levels spring forward.

content:

Early Access Review
								Its great to see Games Workshop are finaly branching their tabletop games and replicating them in desktop! So far im really enjoying the early access to this game.ProsNot bad graphics, would love to have a full HD option though and more intense visual options to put my computer to the test. (16gb gpu, 32gb ram, 4.8ghz i7... TEST ME BABY)Multi layer gaming top! Fight from the sewers or the heights of ruined buildings sniping off your enemy. This makes the game really diverse in terms of tactics.A never ending option of routes to flanking your enemy or achieving your objectives. There is no funneled gameplay which gives you the freedom you need!Simulates accurately the tabletop game mechanics in every aspect, Fear checks, Moral.. etcConsPicking up items and aquireing focus points doesnt seem to work at the moment or is too complicated to understand through the UI. Hopefully this will be fixed.Camera Views can be quite anoying as you view the action from behind a wall (cant see anything) when fighting close to buildings.Would be nice to see some new objectives rather than wipe out the enemy team.So far though this early on in the access I loved the experience. Im really looking forward to future updates.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												I saw all the early reviews and waited Ages before I bought this (On Sale, only reason I gave in). What a mistake! I should have bought this when it first came out. It's superb, up there with the best of them. Combat is sleek and stylish, the animations varied and detailed. If you want a quicker experience you can speed up AI movement - otherwise, you've got deep tactical combat with strategy elements. Yes, it is HARD - but only if you rush in without thinking. This isn't a never-ending-supply of Troops game - it's gang warfare with full RPG elements and it's awesome. At first you will struggle, I think the first mission I did I lost at least a couple of limbs. kind of hard to be an archer with one arm - but fkkit, I just found a pistol so he's back on board! if you like Tactical Strategic Combat a la XCom or JA2, you'll love this. If you love the Warhammer setting, you'll love this. If you can play a game that requires a little thinking and finesse, you'll love this. If you don't love it right away - play the tutorials - then you'll love it. Insta-Buy. And I'm only a few hours in.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Just to get it out of the way, *no* the game is not worth 20-30 dollars in it's current state. It's less an Alpha and more a 1v1 combat demo of the four warbands with no campaign or warband management that made the original Modheim, Necromunda, and Blood Bowl games so fun.Is it worth the 20 dollars as a pre-order for the full game? I'd say yes.The game is fun. I wasn't sure when I first saw the original videos, but it's a lot more of a tactical RTS game then you would think. Instead of player turns you go by unit initiative turns, and map vision is 100% based on your troops line of sight. They have changed the looting system to an almost scavanger hunt while in the middle of a PvP match - You now search for the warpstone and enemy chests during the fight, instead of getting a list of rewards after the match. Looting is also a team effort as each warrior of yours has 2 open inv spots, plus 1 extra spot per 4 str. So the entire warband will need to work on gathering the loot instead of having 1-2 packrats. The movement system is really simple to get the hang of as each point of movement your character has opens up a set distance shown in a blue ring, and as long as you don't run into an enemies range, you can always revert changes and move him in a different direction at any time. Combat reminds me of Fallout - each trooper seems to have 3-5 action points, and different combat maneuvers cost a different amount of your pool. When your warriors can actually gain xp and purchase skills and new equipment I could see this system being a helluva lot of fun.I can't say anything about the magic as you basically get an attack spell and a buff spell and that's it. Again, when the warriors can be developed more I could see this system being fun, but right now it's just a fancy bowman.Multiplayer is less fun. It's a bit buggy, it's full of a lot of rage quits right now, and since there is no warband progression 99% of what makes these types of games great is missing. In a patch or two when they hopefully have the xp system working and people start forming leagues, multiplayer will be worth it. Right now, I can't say it's a selling point.The fact it's shipping with only four warbands (more will come via paid DLC I am sure. :/  ) is dissapointing as well. With all the great races and backstory the Warhammer world has, you would at least have hoped to see one of the Dwarven warband types, along with one of the Elven warband types, included in the base game. As it stands you basically get the Germans, the Joan of Arcs, Humans-but-cultists, and the awesome Skaven (rat assassins).

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												Ok first of all, love it, love warhammer, really love mordheim. I really don't do many reviews i'm more of a silent person when it comes to that type of stuff. So lets do this!Things to note:1. Games still in its infancy theres bugs, and other mishaps2. Customization is there but its limited it will probably get better3. theres 4 warbands(for now) maybe more in the future (ORKZZZ!)4. RNG is not your friend, personaly just subtract 15 from whatever the number says and thats roughly how you should play it. I.E. you have a 87% chane to it , its more like 72 and they have a 80% chance to dodge/parry and you have a 13/28% miss chance. 5. The game is against you, take it slow. play it safe, especially if your Skaven!6. Sister of Sigmar are mean and hit hard and use magic, think of each sister as a paladin and thats roughly what your dealing with.7.Did i tell you how much i hate the sisters of sigmar? A LOT!Ok, if you read through that, then yeah man its a great game, take your time, 2v1/3v1/4v1 etc as much as you can, RNG isn't reliable so don't rely on it, move every move like your character is your child, and invest in Weapon Skill over Accuracy!!P.S. Sisters of Sigmar are pain incarnate!

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												You will learn how to avoid, or deal with, loss.  You will make choices, knowing that there is no "best choice."Loss: Yes, random rolls can pile up, forcing you to lose a treasured unit.  You are fighting with other mercenaries over the "City of the Damned", people will die.  You might actually care for them.  It will hurt.  You may quit.  Or you may find the young replacement and swear at how wortheless they are compared to the veteran that they replaced.  It feels like a warzone, and that's what I wanted.  Learn to dodge.Choices: The optional objectives are woth more than the primary.  The primary is, usually, easy.  Beat the not so smart AI.  When just starting, I did lose a few primary objectives.  You learn to stick together, and if you don't start together, get together ASAP!  Then you start winning primary objectives.You start looking at those optional objectives.  And realizing that if you want to accomplish them, you might have to break out of your comfortable, stick together, everybody comes home safely routine.  Maybe you start taking risks.  And you like the rewards.  Then somebody gets caught alone against a swarm, or maybe just a single impressive unit.  And it hurts.  And you wonder if those rewards were worth it.Stick through it, learn.  And you can find yourself making most of the optional objectives and making it home in one piece.  And sometimes you look at the map/setup and realize it's the day to just hunker down.Those two things are why I love Mordheim.It does have some negatives. Managing inventory during a mission could use the ability to drop items. I get annoyed when the enemy routs immediately after I take down the one guy I needed to take down, only to not get the chance to grab his token before the rout ends the mission.  Deployment could be made more user friendly (selecting deployment from the map instead of cycling). The game has gotten a LOT better since it first came to Early Access, and I hope they continue working on some of those.  But the good things more than make it worth dealing with the few annoyances in the game, in my opinion.I hope they continue, either through DLC or just updating the game itself, to develop more warbands, more equipment, more customization of models and more mission types (story or procedural).  But I love the game as it is today.  I would just love to have more too :).

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												Note: I only played for the free weekend.Negatives:- The game plays at such a slow pace, that I'm typing this between turns. Sometimes there's a long block of enemy turns till my next unit moves and it takes forever to wait.- There's a lot of loading, which coupled with the above point makes the game feel unbearable. Fighting 1 battle and returning to camp can be 30-60 minutes. - Climbing and jumping down have a success rate. Fail the former and you stay low and take damage, fail the latter and it's just damage. It makes sense in practice, but seeing cloth-wearing warriors fail to climb makes me VERY angry.- Non-story missions are repetitive. You have 1 of 3 bonus objectives, but all battles boil down to knock out enough of the enemy and force them to retreat. The one story mission I did play (First Sisters Mission) was agonizingly long. I killed the opposition, but I had to run a sister all over the map just to tag locations. I had the match won and they artificially increased the length by 5-10 turns. - BUGS. On 2 occasions I found my soldiers transported to different locations, On one map, my soldier was transported through a cart that was blocking an alleyway with no exit and no means of returning to the group. The other happened while trying to climb a chapel wall outside, and next turn magically found herself inside.Positives:- Challenge. The game feels difficult and you have to learn how to properly play. Going into a risky mission feels risky. The inability to save scum allows me to really feel the jeopardy and think strategically. Random Thoughts:- When RNG works against you it hurts. A LOT. Remember, even if you have 95% chance, that means 5 attacks will miss out of 100.- I want prettier Sisters model. Vain, I know. But I want to lead an army of heavy armored supermodels. Overall, I can't give this a positive review. Too many flaws for too little benefit.(This review was made while waiting 5 extra turns for Sister Selma Holtzman to run up to the god damn chapel to bless the god damn bell.)

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
												Morheim: City of the Damned is a turn based game where each character takes their turn based on their stats. The game is based off of a table top game so alot of the percentages that decide outcomes are based on dice roles. Each of the four factions in the game, well five with the dlc, all have their own strengths and weaknesses. Even the fifth faction plays different enough than the other factions where if you are enjoying the game and want something new it is worth getting. The other DLC so far are additional characters that can completely change how you run your warband. The reason I bring up the DLC is that even before I got the DLC I had to fight against the DLC warband. An interesting feature in the game is that any of the warbands you can make you will have to fight in the game. With how many ways there are to build a warband that makes a variety of things you can run into in the game. Also if you see an opponent in the game with an interesting build that you like it is possible to make a build similar to it regardless of whether it is a player or AI's warband. Cons i have heard are that people enter the game thinking of it as a character management game but it is a warband management game. The reason it is not a character management game is if a character gets taken out in combat at the end they can either get a minor injury, major injury, killed, or a combination if you are really having bad luck. Injuries in the game effect a characters overall stats so sometimes you have to decide whether to keep a charcter or hire a new guy to replace it. This makes it where you sometimes you have to risk the possibility of loosing a guy permaneantly for the better of your warband. In one of my warbands i had a guy loose his arm so he can only loose one-handed weapons but it increased his dodge rate. This is just one way of how a permaneant injury effected one of my characters. Also never in the game click abandon match no matter how bad things are going wait till you can either retreat or don't care about the consequences of what happens. If you click abandon the match every single one of your characters has to make the injury rolls and anything can happen.So far I have mainly been playing against the AI but have been enjoying the game the whole time. I actually enjoyed the fact that the game gave major penalties for trying to abandon matches if you didn't like what was happening. Luckily in multiplayer you pick whether you want a friendly match or competitive (not sure what actual titles are called). In a competitive match if you loose you can get the permaneant injuries or have your gear taken while in friendly no injuries and no gear taken. If you like challenging games and can handle loosing a character permaneantly that you have had since the beginning of the game I would recommend this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												The game is a lovely Turn Based Strategy with a couple of flaws in the execution only.  Often the characters themselves appear as if they can fit through something, but they cannot when you try.  Also there are times when enemy units have immunities to various mechanics, and it does not show this on the buff/debuff menus when you inspect an enemy unit prior to attacking.  That being said, this game does not show mercy or cut you any slack, but that is part of the appeal.  It is a very tactical and thinking man's game, where you can easily lose a character mid-mission, and they end up being useless or near useless afterwards, and you are counting the days until you can buy a replacement.  It is a beautiful application of a masochistic strategy game, that makes you feel reaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaly good when you out-maneuver your enemy, and leave them in a horrid position to fight from, while you overwhelm them with debuffs and swarm tactics.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Despite always fancying it I delayed getting this as the luke-warm reception it recieved put me off. However, I must say I'm getting pretty hooked.The virtual dice rolls won't always go your way. You simply have to make peace with that if you want to enjoy this game. Though sound strategy will see you right most of the time in single-player. It is pretty common to have one or maybe two out-of-action party members per match even when things are going well. And there is always the chance they end up perma-dead or with such a debilitating injury they become next to worthless.Multiplayer is another matter, there will be players out there that can take your beloved warband to pieces. But you have the option to play in exhibition mode with no permanent repurcussions, but no rewards either. Or just have seperate relatively 'safe' SP and riskier MP warbands. It's worth knowing that there is a veteran system letting you level up and keep bonuses to running your warband that carries over to the next even if they all end up dead. You even get to choose how you spend your earned bonuses for each warband. I've got 25 hours of fun out of this to date and I've only played with 2 of the warbands on offer so far.More customisation options would be very welcome, it is hard to make your party members look individual, which is a shame. Another niggle is that the game always suggests a parry stance for my warriors that are better at dodging and vice-versa which gets tiresome after dozens of battles.

Early Access Review
								This game has so much potiential. i agree with others when mentioning the lack of content at launch the 25th of nov, this is a complete joke... if i had done some more research before hand, i would have waited to buy the game. From my point of view, the developers should stick to the mechanics of the board game e.g. instead of going "heroes of might and magic" with the fighting animations, this gets bored and repetitive quick, i would like it if it would be like the Blood Bowl game or the org. tabletop mordheim game, where you can see the number of dice being thrown, and then if you crit, you roll again to see what happens, but in the game you can see the following animation e.g. beheading, stunned, break legs (e.g. when falling or jumping from heights), loose an eye; that would be so awesome. but i guess it could also work just as a text notification.i did not like that you cannot zoom out and see the whole map, i can see the point and fun with the locked character view, but i hope that the developers will make this a choice when setting up the game amongst other game rules. (weather conditions which would effect your vision, game quests, missions,)They could also make a map editor, to create your own maps or arrange tournaments just like in the blood bowl game.i could go on with the things i would like to have in the game, but in the end I bought the game since i have had so much fun with the tabletop version of Mordheim.I really hope that they do not drop the ball with this one, this has the possibilities of becoming a great game.

												Definitely recommended, especially at the current sale price!The difficulty level is not as bad as some are saying, especially if you play the tutorial.I started with a Skaven warband, who are now level 3, and have a 90% win rate (twoof the wins were decisive victories -- doing the extra goals).I do have a couple of criticisms:Diversity of maps.I am hoping this is just my limited perspective having only recently started, but themaps feel homogenous.  I would have liked to have seen more design diversity.An eery garden/park district, a sewer (there was one in the tutorial), or ann all insidedistrict (like a palace), to name a few....If it was a port city we could have battles on corrupted ships!  =)Match ending immediately after rout.Would it be game breaking to allow one more round for the victor after the rout?Isn't it reasonable to think a warband would gather whats relatively close to thembefore leaving.  We are suppose to be scavengers after all.Anyway, thanks for the free weekend!  Now off to buy the game and the DLC.

												I found this to be a great Warhammer strategy game. Does a great job capturing the feel of the (classic) WH world, and is property difficult. 												If you plan to 'play' this game, be warned, because the game will play you. It will screw you on over every chance it will get. Don't expect to win every fight, the game will find a way you mess you up, everything that can go wrong will go wrong. content:
Posted: January 20
												After I let this game rest for about half of a year, I come back and I'm pleasantly suprised.This game is hard, it's rougelike hard. Don't assume you'll have the perfect warband in the end.To clarify how hard here an example from my recent warband: My lvl 8 leader got injured and got the 'stupid' trait. Meaning most of the time he sits around and does nothing. I had to abandon this warband, because leveling up another leader was unrealistic. I think it's 'rougelike-hard' in the way that after any mission your warband is a wreck. Half dead, stupid, lost gear and you don't have money. The developer counter this by giving you boons which you unlock by just playing the game (aka 'Veteran System', this doesn't affect the battles but the management of your warband, so there is no direct benefit in PVP).  It doesn't make the game a breeze but it's nice to have.This game is in my opinon not so much about crushing the enemy but a game which rewards carefull, tactical play.If you like banging your head against walls, or games like 'Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup' ( in terms of learning curve and tough luck moments) I recommend this game. If you hope to roflstomp this game you'll gonna have a bad time.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												Utterly, massively, unplayably based on RNG which can and WILL destroy all your best-laid plans for victory.I would compare it to classic XCom, but that's not an apt comparison. In XCom, your technology gradually improved, allowing even your rookies to have half a chance of hurting what they hit and surviving being flicked by a wet towel. Furthermore, you had a ton of warm bodies to throw into the meat-grinder. In Mordheim however, you have a very small band and your tech in the end-game is going to be largely the same as what you started with. Instead, you're expected to nurture and grow your little warband into a team of elite fighting badasses who can pick their teeth with the business end of a bloodthirster's battleaxe.The problem with this is that the costs of keeping your team alive and in the fight are astronomical and the odds of being downed in a matter of moments are heavily against you. Your team never survives long enough to become even halfway reliable, without a shower of shooting stars over a field of four-leaf clovers and quadruple-amputee white rabbits! Your enemies will always seem to hit you on a 60%+ chance, while you struggle to land half your blows on 80% or higher. The game is entirely based around chance and simply cannot be beaten by anything less than a professtional Russian Roulette player!But I suppose if you're the kind of masochist who enjoys having a game feed you your own elbows in literally every encounter, then have fun, you lunatic. Personally though, I'd save your £30 and go punch a biker instead.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												This game has been on my wishlist forever. After the debacle with most of the early access games I have invested in before, this particular game gave me hope that there are companies out there really willing to work hard.There are very few games like this that have been released. It is a diamond in the rough, and is apparently based off of a tabletop game that I had no idea even existed. I have delved into the turn based action and immediately felt right at home. I loved the way my warband could be customizable, but I almost wished there were more options. Maybe this will be a patch or DLC they may release.Pros:- Great tactical gameplay- Classic well designed turn based action- Interesting preparation experience- Customization options for combatCons:- Good graphics, but not the best; however, I have seen most of these games being played for depth rather than glitz and glammer.- The AI isn't the smartest as yet, but I am sure they will make the necessary changes. (I was able to snipe a baddie because he didn't know how to "jump down" from a ledge, and just moved back forth in a 3 foot pattern for 7 turns)-I would have liked to have seen more customization options, which I am sure they will be making available from DLC.I would recommend this game for fans of the old fanfaire of turn based games. It isn't Final Fantasy Tactics by a long shot, but it is the only title that I have personally played that has even had a chance of comparing to it. Not bad guys, not bad.P.S. after three days of playing this game it has corrupted my soul. This game is HARDCORE. If you are easily discouraged, I would not recommend it. lol... WOW... great stuff.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												Ok never played Mordheim (the tabletop one) but am a Warhammer fan, this game is good, even for early access its good (its no longer in early access and is still awesome) and you can see all the signs of it reaching significantly awesome when its finished (it did), if you like strategy games you'll like this, if you liked xcom (the good one) but thought it needed less guns and more stabbings then this game is for you. If however you think this game is not for you then its time to rethink your life and play this game.This game did for a considerable period of time have a difficulty spike that went from reasonable to you will die which in a game like this is beyond brutal that has now been removed, so while you'll still find the game pretty brutal it is no longer unfairly so.This below relates to something no longer in the game thankfully and I would give the developers every credit they listened to the fans and updated this.Incase you think that maybe I just wasn't up to the challenge here is how it goes. Effectively (and you wouldn't know this until you start the mission) when you reach the top of the stairs you are instantly and ambushed by creatures that can only really die if you hit them with items from the rest of the level, with the problem you can't get to them because of the combat you've just been forced into, this killed 3 consecutive warbands of mine, as in 50% or higher dead or maimed to beyond useless. This in a game that to get to that point will take 5-10 hours at least per warband is...irritating

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												I really enjoyed the free weekend and hope this goes on again soon (hopefully next time i'll actuallly be able to afford it).Yes the rng can be unforgiving, but much like Blood Bowl and all dice based games, it is a matter of calculated risk. That said, there will be times you get stomped from the start through no fault of your own; such is the roll of the dice.The atmosphere is pure grimdark and the voice acting is well done. Procedural generation constantly keeps battles interesting despite the scenery itself being a bit same-same after a while. My main complaint would be lack of visual customisation of your warband- in particular the gear. Would be nice for a purple item to actually look superior, or at least different, from the vanilla starting gear. Would be great if those rare, expensive, paid-for-in-blood-and-tears items would actually be shiny.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												Finally the release is here.This games scratches an itch I have had for years.  Turn based combat - with character growth, and character injury.  The first time your veteran loses an arm, a leg, or an eye - you will feel it.The first time your one armed veteran returns to action and shows he still has what it takes, you will feel pride in this little digital warrior - or you'll use him for fodder.The game has great atmosphere, decent art, decent sound, and amazing gameplay.  It does have a small campaign available for each warband that mixes things up a little bit.I have just really enjoyed my time searching and scavenging the city of Mordheim.  I have recommended this game to several people at work who have bought it and also have enjoyed it.If the devs read this, here is my wishlist:- more customization options, I would even be willing to pay for this.- new art for blue and purple items compared to white items- birght wizards!- more warbandsah you know - just keep adding on to this amazing game.  I look forward to seeing what else is coming!

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												If I had to summarize this game in one phrase, it would "turn based, tactical, dark souls, rogue-like".  If that intrigues you then I highly recommend this game to you.  But if any part of that doesn't interest you then you will probably hate this game.It's not strictly a rogue-like, but if you go into this knowing that your units will die, your gear will be taken, and you will lose then you will enjoy it much much more.  When you restart a new campaign, not only will you have a better understanding of the mechanics, but your commander will have leveled up giving additional starting bonuses like gold and other perks.If you can appreciate that a 95% chance is not a given, that a 5% chance is not an impossibility, and are willing to stick out a steep learning curve, you will find the gameplay to be very rewarding. 8/10Good:- Intense and addictive gameplay.- Deep, balanced and fun mechanics.- Well developed theme and backstory.Bad:- Forgettable campaign storylines.- Steep learning curve.- Your best hero losing an arm.Ugly:- Some of the voice acting is truly awful.- Totally random and unpredictable mini-boss encounters that you have no chance of winning.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Well.This game shows a lot of potential.Of course it's early access and so some of my critique may quickly become obsolete .Strategy combat around city scapes where you can climb, drop and leap is a lot of fun.Even though I am ignorant to Mordheim I greatly enjoy fantasy and this game has bucketloads of it.A nice choice of starting warbands although I am a bit unsure about the lack of female mercenaries ( I wouldn't use them anyway but I find it odd) Perhaps there is a lore based reason?  Great potential for future growth. The ambience and atmosphere of the game is great however I am not too sure about the suitability of the soundtrack. While I think the soundtrack is quality it sounds like the drums of war and great battles at points. But these aren't great battles: they are skirmishes for ones life in the dregs of a corrupted world.   Anyway it seems insignificant. Stylised music for each warband would be great also. Ironically the opening menu ambience is fantastic but it does not seem to be replicated in skirmishes.At the moment the games engine doesn't seem quite capable of supporting itself and I would highly recommend the coders get their butts in gear as to fixing critical game glitches for example playing versus  player seems to get stuck and 4/5 times will not get unstuck and you are left thinking of what might have been. Load times that don't seem to be done justice by the in game content. There are some minor graphical glitches  mostly in chraracter models. The human impressive unit looks bald from some angles if he has no headgear. The ogre has an invisible buttcrack when he's stunned. Sisters are miraculously empty on the inside of their armour and it's particularly evident when they fail a drop check. Brethrens robes spazzing out.  Overall the graphics are solid, stylised and make a positive impact on the game.Quite a few quality of life problems and glitches that need to be fixed up. There are spots in the map that are bugged one way or another. For example in the sewers of the church of sigmar there is a reddish tentacle-ridden area that one of my sisters got stuck in. There are multiple places where, as a ranged attacker, you can walk up a wall and get stuck in it for an added height boost and sniper spot particularly in houses of the merchants quarter. Seems to be a few problems with characters magically falling down walls they just climbed.  And the menus in skirmishes could really do with full mouse capabilities. There are people who are griping and giving this game a bad rap. You must understand that there will always be people who give a game a bad rap and in the last 5 years they seem to have crawled out from under every rock and basement known to man.  If you have a reasonable intellect you can master the keyboard menus quite easily. The game is quite the very definition of early access and an excellent early access game with the promise of great growth potential for 2v2 and great customisation and strategy. However I'm extremely fearful that this game will collapse or I will have to boycott it because it will become a left right and centre cash grab. Indeed, the game already shows omens of it in the form of currencies of wydrstone and coins. The "Smugglers Den". The potential to buy boosts for your characters for exp and expedite their learning of new spells.Purchashing mercenaries (Priest of Morr etc), While the wyrdstones and currency and upkeep are all in tune to the rules of the game it does not mean a player should have to fork out unreasonable amounts of real cash to manage them.The seeming potential for your warriors to become incapacitated or injured for periods of time, while realistic, is probably more about the potential for customers to purchase boosters that let them recover completely or faster. Depending on how overboard the group goes with cash grab if they do and I imagine they will. ( And come on, it's sanctioned or run by Games Worskship the people that sell, while of good quality, small figures of tin or plastic at prices going beyond twenty dollars and then squeezing you for the paint($36 for 2 medium pieces), the glue($12) and the tools(32+18) as well. Bless them.) Considering that the base game is not free to play they will be walking on thin ice with me and I imagine a lot of players if there isn't a reasonable means for those who can't fork out money to build their warbands up and give them a sanctuary to play and enjoy the game where they don't constantly get stomped on by someone who has already learnt grand true comet of sigmar and  has 200 damage weapons. Sigmar forbid they make it so you have to WAIT because your lack the funds to pay for your warband or you don't have enough warriors and can't afford to buy a new one.That will drop the game to the status of a glorified facebook game and I would be severely disappointed.That aside I will try and remain positive for this game and hope to see it blossom into a popular title of its genre or atleast become a cult classic.For those of you considering the purchase of this game in early access please consider the following.o The PvP is not thriving yeto You can't build up resources or exp at this pointo There are some fatal game errors o The game requires more resources to run than it appears

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												I don't normally review games but I will make an exception this time for a few reasons. This game is exceptionally good, and it's current reviews do not reflect that. When reading other negative reviews I encourage potential buyers to read with the question in mind "Would this person's problem have been solved if they had just been better at the game?"I read review after review and nearly every negative one I read was filled with paragraphs of "The RNG is broken, Its impossible to recover from deaths or serious injuries". Having played the game a significant amount I can confirm that these extensive reviews could easily be replaced with "The game was too hard for me"Mordheim is hard, think Dark Souls. There is a sharp learning curve to it and even with my brother and I playing and sharing information I still couldn't get a lvl 10 warband decent enough to beat the last mission until I remade it 3 times. This was not as frustrating as it sounds though because there are plenty of options and variations to try, and each on has a particular niche that it works best in. Lastly, I have had this game since early Beta and the team working on it is one of the best I have experienced. Currently the game is only lacking in a few quality of life tweaks like the touchiness of shooting through windows or ambushing through dorways. But in the short time I have owned this game these problems are repidly disappearingMy point is, the game is too hard for the people leaving poor reviews and I highly recommend it

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												As a fan of Games Workshop I was looking forward to playing this game.  Positives first it looks great, has not lagged, crashed or frozen on me once.  Sounds great and does a dame good job is emulating the table top game it is based on.  The reasons why I am not recommending this game boil down to the combat.  To be fair to Rogue Factor they have done a good job in merging the rolls to hit, wound and save into one single action but however there are some major problems.  First the percentage chance show when about to hit an opponent is just wrong.  It only shows your chance of hitting after your characters modifiers are taken into account, but not the enemies.  The community keeps pointing out that the opponent’s modifiers are shown; they are just not included in the calculations for hitting.  This is especially frustrating when despite being told you have a 95% chance to hit, you miss four times in a row.  Second and perhaps the biggest the range for the RNG used in this game is too high.  When turning a table top game that requires dice to play into a computer game using an RNG is a good way of measuring the dice rolls.  In this case however Rogue Factor have taken a game that uses dice numbered between 1-6 and ups it to 1-100.  This is a major issue as it greatly increases the chances of missing and failing to repel attacks.  The worst one of these I experienced was having a single Novice from the Sisters of Sigmar kill two of my henchmen and my war band leader on her own because I could not roll a single hit.I would suggest you play Bloodbowl instead as Cyanide has done a far better job at converting a tabletop game into a computer game.

While I think the soundtrack is quality it sounds like the drums of war and great battles at points. But these aren't great battles: they are skirmishes for ones life in the dregs of a corrupted world.   Anyway it seems insignificant. Stylised music for each warband would be great also. Ironically the opening menu ambience is fantastic but it does not seem to be replicated in skirmishes.At the moment the games engine doesn't seem quite capable of supporting itself and I would highly recommend the coders get their butts in gear as to fixing critical game glitches for example playing versus  player seems to get stuck and 4/5 times will not get unstuck and you are left thinking of what might have been. Load times that don't seem to be done justice by the in game content. There are some minor graphical glitches  mostly in chraracter models. The human impressive unit looks bald from some angles if he has no headgear. The ogre has an invisible buttcrack when he's stunned. Sisters are miraculously empty on the inside of their armour and it's particularly evident when they fail a drop check. Brethrens robes spazzing out.  Overall the graphics are solid, stylised and make a positive impact on the game.Quite a few quality of life problems and glitches that need to be fixed up. There are spots in the map that are bugged one way or another. For example in the sewers of the church of sigmar there is a reddish tentacle-ridden area that one of my sisters got stuck in. There are multiple places where, as a ranged attacker, you can walk up a wall and get stuck in it for an added height boost and sniper spot particularly in houses of the merchants quarter. Seems to be a few problems with characters magically falling down walls they just climbed.  And the menus in skirmishes could really do with full mouse capabilities. There are people who are griping and giving this game a bad rap. You must understand that there will always be people who give a game a bad rap and in the last 5 years they seem to have crawled out from under every rock and basement known to man.  If you have a reasonable intellect you can master the keyboard menus quite easily. The game is quite the very definition of early access and an excellent early access game with the promise of great growth potential for 2v2 and great customisation and strategy. However I'm extremely fearful that this game will collapse or I will have to boycott it because it will become a left right and centre cash grab. Indeed, the game already shows omens of it in the form of currencies of wydrstone and coins. The "Smugglers Den". The potential to buy boosts for your characters for exp and expedite their learning of new spells.Purchashing mercenaries (Priest of Morr etc), While the wyrdstones and currency and upkeep are all in tune to the rules of the game it does not mean a player should have to fork out unreasonable amounts of real cash to manage them.The seeming potential for your warriors to become incapacitated or injured for periods of time, while realistic, is probably more about the potential for customers to purchase boosters that let them recover completely or faster. Depending on how overboard the group goes with cash grab if they do and I imagine they will. ( And come on, it's sanctioned or run by Games Worskship the people that sell, while of good quality, small figures of tin or plastic at prices going beyond twenty dollars and then squeezing you for the paint($36 for 2 medium pieces), the glue($12) and the tools(32+18) as well. Bless them.) Considering that the base game is not free to play they will be walking on thin ice with me and I imagine a lot of players if there isn't a reasonable means for those who can't fork out money to build their warbands up and give them a sanctuary to play and enjoy the game where they don't constantly get stomped on by someone who has already learnt grand true comet of sigmar and  has 200 damage weapons. Sigmar forbid they make it so you have to WAIT because your lack the funds to pay for your warband or you don't have enough warriors and can't afford to buy a new one.That will drop the game to the status of a glorified facebook game and I would be severely disappointed.That aside I will try and remain positive for this game and hope to see it blossom into a popular title of its genre or atleast become a cult classic.For those of you considering the purchase of this game in early access please consider the following.o The PvP is not thriving yeto You can't build up resources or exp at this pointo There are some fatal game errors o The game requires more resources to run than it appears

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												If I had to summarize this game in one phrase, it would "turn based, tactical, dark souls, rogue-like".  If that intrigues you then I highly recommend this game to you.  But if any part of that doesn't interest you then you will probably hate this game.It's not strictly a rogue-like, but if you go into this knowing that your units will die, your gear will be taken, and you will lose then you will enjoy it much much more.  When you restart a new campaign, not only will you have a better understanding of the mechanics, but your commander will have leveled up giving additional starting bonuses like gold and other perks.If you can appreciate that a 95% chance is not a given, that a 5% chance is not an impossibility, and are willing to stick out a steep learning curve, you will find the gameplay to be very rewarding. 8/10Good:- Intense and addictive gameplay.- Deep, balanced and fun mechanics.- Well developed theme and backstory.Bad:- Forgettable campaign storylines.- Steep learning curve.- Your best hero losing an arm.Ugly:- Some of the voice acting is truly awful.- Totally random and unpredictable mini-boss encounters that you have no chance of winning.

I look forward to seeing what else is coming!

content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												I don't normally review games but I will make an exception this time for a few reasons. This game is exceptionally good, and it's current reviews do not reflect that. When reading other negative reviews I encourage potential buyers to read with the question in mind "Would this person's problem have been solved if they had just been better at the game?"I read review after review and nearly every negative one I read was filled with paragraphs of "The RNG is broken, Its impossible to recover from deaths or serious injuries". Having played the game a significant amount I can confirm that these extensive reviews could easily be replaced with "The game was too hard for me"Mordheim is hard, think Dark Souls. There is a sharp learning curve to it and even with my brother and I playing and sharing information I still couldn't get a lvl 10 warband decent enough to beat the last mission until I remade it 3 times. This was not as frustrating as it sounds though because there are plenty of options and variations to try, and each on has a particular niche that it works best in. Lastly, I have had this game since early Beta and the team working on it is one of the best I have experienced. Currently the game is only lacking in a few quality of life tweaks like the touchiness of shooting through windows or ambushing through dorways. But in the short time I have owned this game these problems are repidly disappearingMy point is, the game is too hard for the people leaving poor reviews and I highly recommend it

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												Loads of fun, yet very challenging. Round by round, the game might not seem challenging, but when you start losing powerful characters and have to start from the bottom, and struggle to catch that character back up, things can get rough. THankfully, the game is very rewarding. There is something called the Vetran system. The more you play your different warbands, the more all new warbands will benefit. Such as higher level characters you can purchase later in the game, saving you the trouble of re-leveling a character from scratch, but at a hefty price. Also, starting your warband with more gold.The only real issue with this game, is it needs more content. I'd love more warbands to be added. But, it is a small fault. The core game is still great, I'd just like to see it grow even more.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
The "Dark Souls" of Tactics GamesFirst lets clear up the "RNG" conspiracy all of the negative reviews are focusing on. When you see 67% for a hit that is what your chance to land a blow is. IF you roll that check and IF you get your 67% your opponent WILL THEN roll their Dodge/Block chance. That is not taken into account into the % to hit chance you see. Settle down and do some research before crying about the difficulty.With that said this is a great game, it will make you go rage mode but will keep you coming back for more if you truely enjoy tactics games. This game requires that you have overwhelmingly solid tactics making use of choke points etc. You need to keep a pretty deep roster because you will lose guys in a fight. You will need lots of trial and error but that makes a win more rewarding, and unlike some games when your guy gets "knocked out" theres a chance he will make it in the end, albeit with possibly one less arm.This game has hundreds of hours in it if you want to invest in trying out all of the different factions. I haven't even beat the game yet and have over 80 hours. I recommend this game to anyone who can do the math and do not to those who scream RNG and hit the refund button.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												Very simplistic turn based stategy game, don't let that trick you into thinking it's easy. RNG rules and it doesn't favor you in the least apparent 80% will miss three times in a row for your warband but the AI doesn't seem to obey the rules of Chance.But even if it did it serves to highlight the real problem with the game. The complete lack of depth to it's gameplay to give context, at the ten hour mark you may have characters with two or three abilities all behaving much the same. Some warbands have purely worse troops that still cost the same...management is shallow and limited, deployment is more often then not taken from you.All the preparation in the world and all the careful management (or what little the game offers) matters little when all but moving your troops is reliant on a dice roll.Other tactics games simply do more, often with much less powerful hardware.Add to that an abusive requirement to hand in resources regularly forcing you to focus on collection in battles where the AI can simply focus on you.The entire game seems like it was designed by a dev team who didn't know how to make a challengeing game but still wanted to plaster "Hardcore" on eveything.If you're a warhammer fan you've probably already brought it and are playing it like me simply because it's a warhammer game that's vaguely playable.In even simpler terms, this focus on making as simple a game as possible but also as "Hard" makes a game that only real masochists will enjoy beyond it's warhammer skin. If you want more challenge then that afforded you by making your way through a brick wall with your face there are many other roguelikes available to play.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												A game that has so much potential. But it is undeniable that there are SERIOUS balance issues. Sisters warband and Skaven are superior hands down.The start of the game is MUCH too brutal to players.There is no increasing difficulty as the mobs increase at the same rate your warband does.Items at the start of the game are completely pointless. If you work for hours and hours and don't die you MIGHT get a better weapon or armor.Almost all potions have a downside to them that typically outweighs any benefit and they also take up inventory space, which means you will not be able to loot as much.Ranged units are trash until MAYBE they are OKAY at the end-game when you have lots of units (MAYBE).Progression takes too long and by the end of your progression you aren't even happy with what you ended up with. If you pick a good faction, and then only go after missions that are the easiest type (warpstone rush) then the game is super easy mode. But if you stray from that, you will probably not play the game for a few weeks when your leader falls and dies. Customization is poorly labled... instead of picking colors for your clothing/armor you get to flip through a list that is just numbered (lazy programming here). You also get to do that for every single character since you cannot do a pre-built color scheme similar to the original 40k games. Final impression: This is sorta like the "kife-game" of video games. It looks so cool, and that's probably why you want to play it. But after the pain of actually playing the game, you will be filled with remorse and sadness. The balance issues really just kill the game right now along with only having a few units and a few warbands to choose from. At best this is a watered down intro to the tabletop game. At worst, it is a waste of any time you put into it.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												The game, in it's current state is poor.The main reason for this, is that the mission briefs are complete and utter bs, there's absolutely no reason for it to be like this, it doesn't improve gameplay, it doesn't help the story, it literally is like an idiot wrote a little summary for a completely unrelated incident and stuck it on your loading page.Let's give you an example, just loaded up a mission "Enemy has split into three strike squads, you must split into three teams and deal with them (in other words) as they are running scared". What does this mean to any normal people? The enemy is in three groups? Wrong, the enemy are all initiative 70 skaven clustered in a little group consisting of their entire warband, in sight of after one move, who methodically go around and in 4 on 1 or 5 or 6 vs 2 massacre your men. Meanwhile your strike teams have deployment zones that are too far away to be able to get there to assist before everybody is dead.So you put time into building a warband, then have it massacred. If the brief was "the enemy are concentrated" and there is a brief that says that, different game.Oh and did I mention now that warband is dead, you may as well start the game over, because you won't have the gold to replace them, low level recruits will get massacred in any game mode you play, and you won't ever be able to fulfill your wyrdstone shipment again after your main squad has fallen.The game has so much promise but is so poorly executed. Oh and the customization, yeah you can change your guys colour, thats about it. Stick to the tabletop game, this is a poor copy.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												I have played over 30 hours of this game since it's offical release and I have enjoyed every minute of it. Yes the game does have it's glitches, which I hope the devleopers are looking into and going to try and fix, but I have seen few games roll out without a few glitches at release time. The game is unforgiving, but the table top game was just as unforgiving and I enjoy that part. It makes you feel like this mission could be your last so you need to use tactics to not just win, but to survive. If you run up and attack a whole warband with only one guy, well bad things are going to happen to your one guy. The game also makes you think about future missions. You can't just go and blow all your gold on members and equipment. You have to save money in case you need to replace that equipment or even replace a member who died or was too injuried to be worth using anymore. Luckily they have the reserve system, so members who are injuried can be put in reserve while they heal, or even train (yes training takes time in game also) and a fresh member can replace them. The controls are a little hard to get use to at first, but after a while playing the game, it became easier. While the load time is horrible and the AI seems to take forever to make its move during it's turn, it has yet to push me away from this game.  Overall, it is a good, horror filled game that you never know what is coming at you around a corner and you never know when it will be your last. If you enjoy these types of games or if you enjoyed the table top game, this is definitely one to pick up. I think you will enjoy it.

								As an early access I would normally give it some wiggle room, but considering the price tag, I would expect a lot more out of this game.Pros:  It isn't done, so maybe it will become a good game.Cons:* Very excessive load times for such a short skirmish (1-2 minutes for 15 minutes of play), this should be a big fix target.* Not sure if it is because I am new, but perhaps the computer enemies should not get 3 attacks to my 1-2 and somehow have 2 extra people at the same time.  Game balance is for crap, and without difficulty settings, I don't even want to fight 100 fights to figure out how to finally beat them.  (Worst part, they were the same faction, so it is not factional aspects).  And when they ran into 3 traps and still killed me so completely, something is wrong.* Management doesn't seem to say much, not sure how to "configure" people to win, assumed the default would do it.

												I want to love Mordheim, but I can't. The idea of it is great, but disheartening in practice. For one, your enemies always seem to be better than you. They dodge more often and hit more often. They sometimes even outnumber you while being better than you. And you have to spare troops to acquire special stones while your superior enemy swarms you, so you can send the stones to your faction's benefactor every few days, cause if you don't do it four times then your warband is finished.I love games that challenge me, but Mordheim just feels like I'm being punished.Oh, how silly of me. I forgot to mention the entire map is a clusterf*ck of traps. Traps on the floor, on the walls, I'm surprised there's none on what few ceilings there are.
