content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												I really want to love this game, but I just can't in good conscious recommend it to anyone. There are too many issues.In case you aren't aware, Mordheim is based on a skirmish tabletop by Games Workshop, though as I understand it it doesn't use the original game's rules. The adaption is a turn based strategy game in a really dark fantasy setting where you build and manage a warband. You recruit heroes and henchmen and slowly build them up by surviving randomly generated missions. There are permanent consequences anywhere, from permanent injuries after dying to downright permadeath. There is a constant race against time too since you need to deliver a ressource in time that you can gather during missions every few ingame weeks. If you manage to do it the timer is reset, but if you don't the whole game is lost. Losing too many people permanently and not being able to go to missions to gather the ressource does in essence also lose you the game permanently. This doesn't happen after 3 or 4 hours by the way, this will become a problem after 20 or 30 hours.It would all be fine if it would all be down to your skill as a player, but there is a TON of reliance on RNG in this game. If facing permanent debilitations because of things completely outside your control is something that bothers you, dear god stay away from this game.But it wasn't what made me quit playing ultimately (no I didn't ragequit after losing the game). What kills it is the slowness. There is a ton of waiting for enemy actions during missions and slow animations that can't be skipped or sped up. Also, the story missions are absolutely terribly designed. They are on maps that are confusing as heck with totally unclear mission directions. And they take forever. The first try you are almost guaranteed to lose until you figure out what the mission is even about. They are just a complete drag and no fun at all. After 20 hours of building my warband, seeing the forth mission of the sisterhood and thinking that I will have to face more of that♥♥♥♥♥♥after 20 more hours I just lost all energy and motivation. Thanks but no thanks, there are games that are simply more fun than this.

number of helpful: 12 of 23 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12
 Unforgiving and repetitive… but also challenging & nerdy!So in this black or white system from steam there’s just thumbs up or down. The question is: Would you recommend this game to others? The answer to this question is… NO!Why?This is not a mainstream game like XCOM, HOMM & Co. It’s a hardcore Warhammer niche game for freaks & nerds! So if you consider yourself more of a mainstream player, then this game is most likely not for you. The /ragequit chance is probably over 95%... (There’s actually an achievement for it.)If you want to test the waters for turnbased RPG & strategy RNG games, I strongly recommend to get XCOM first (It’s easier and better in most aspects than Mordheim & I enjoyed it tremendously). Put it on Classic & Ironman mode to see how it goes. If you enjoy this kind of gameplay & want more of it, get XCom 2. If you done with that, there is nothing else on your plate & you get Mordheim in a Steam-Sale, then go for it and try it out.I have some likes and dislikes about the game.1st  dislike: You can’t start at once. You have to go through boring tutorials and then watch guide videos and read guides online. You have to carefully plan your Warband (party progression) and execute everything by the book or else you’re most likely not gonna make it.2nd dislike: It contains several of my personal game design No Go’s:-	Dead Ends -> Did I mention that you’re most likely not gonna make it?-	Missing difficulty settings -> Sucks… /ragequit… / You’re most likely not gonna make it…-	Unlimited spawning of enemies -> In story-mission, which are optional & can be ignored-	Limiting the savegame options (fixed savepoints or online-only savegame) - As a PC player I want a free savegame-system -> If you manage to get your sgame broken it’s… Game Over!-	Repetitive MOTS gameplay & mindless grinding -> There is not enough content to keep you entertained for long, maps, enemies, loot, names => everything repeats itself after a few hours.-	Missing space for exploration and experimenting -> The game is about perfection and extremely unforgiving-	Absence of logic -> Mission ends when the enemy flees or gets killed… What do you do now? Right, you loot the map or auto-collect the rest of the loot like in XCom… But no, not in Mordheim, you only get a small fracture of the uncollected loot, so all you just did in this mission was practically for nothing… As the AI normally attacks you in the 2nd or 3rd round, you’ll have a very small window to explore freely.It’s also very hard to fulfill optional sidequests, for example you need to collect stuff from certain enemies. This is very hard due to the early routing of enemy warbands. After 3 from 7 or 4 from 9 are killed they rout and the mission ends immediately – especially frustrating if just beat down the one you needed and this ends the mission before you can loot. In this cases the game should marked the sidequest as fulfilled. I mean think this through: You get the order bring the trinket of a certain enemy home, you beat him down and his homies run away and you leave the area without the trinket… yeah, right…-	Unhelpful & boring tutorials-	Cheating AI (in general, not sure if the AI cheats in the game…)Likes:+ solid engine, great core game play, rogue-like ‘challenge factor’, nice graphics, no critical bugs+ Game has it’s moment, e.g. when you’re hiding behind a door in Ambush Mode, the enemy walks through it and you instantly kill the unit with a critical hit… Muahahah… - Pretty rare though…+ Crazy stuff like this seems to happen (Cult of the possed): Mnezocles 19 Dec, 2016 @ 8:58am Got severed arm on a mutant. Next rank had a mutation, grew it right back.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												I want to like this game, the actual design of the game seem pretty fun but unfortunately the digital implementation of it is awful. The controls and UI particularly make me unable to recommend this game, they are really atrocious, which is quite unforgiveable as the actual design of the mechanics was already made for the table top, so other than art assets the UI and controls were basically all they had to do.This is a game that should be perfect to play with a mouse and keyboard, with a similar control system to a game like XCOM, unfortunately it has clearly been designed for a controller and even when using a controller it's not much better. Getting the information you actually want, like what an ability does or the debuffs and buffs on your character always takes multiple button presses to get to instead of just being displayed on screen or as a tooltip.You can't zoom out and get a good view of the battlefield, you are always locked behind whatever characters turn it currently is, I think there is a sort of 2D map you can look at but it it would be much more useful to just be able to zoom out in 3D and pan around the map.The graphics are also really mediocre, very flat lighting and shaders. But it's really the UI and controls that are a game killer for me.Again, the game its self is quite fun and compelling, I can see why it gathered a following in its table top incarnation but the developers have managed to make it such a chore to try and play that I honestly don't see myself going back to it.

content:
Posted: February 16
												A very fun game set within the Warhammer Fantasy universe, plenty of depth and customization and all sorts of fun ways to leave your mark, both on your warband and on the faces of your opponents.I must say, however, the Random Number Generator for this game is seriously perverse, on the verge of being actually bad. Worse than X-Com by a damn sight, anyways. I've missed far more than one in five +80% attacks, I've been hit repeatedly with well over a 50% chance to dodge or parry, and the number of times my warriors have wiffed a 95%, with so much on the line, it's pretty sickening. Not saying the game is broken, but I'm saying there is a surprising amount of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, not numbers, being generated. I am writing this review after having gotten my warband creamed due to poor rolling, but my complaint stands on it's own merit.

												A great twist on turn-based strategy. Overall a huge win with very deep character and party progression. Could use some AI improvement, but it remains challenging without feeling like it's cheating at all.This game is unforgiving, which makes the battles feel a lot more important than other games. If you've ever played blood bowl, it's similar in punishing you for making mistakes. content:
Posted: February 24
												This game is not for people that like their wins handed to them or for people who can't handle it when things don't go their way because things won't go your way in this game. It's an odds game and you have to play like the odds are heavily against you, because they usually are. Some tips for getting the upper hand at the start of the game (which is where it's hardest):The AI doesn't play fair so throw any notion of being 'honorable' against it out the window. It knows exactly where your units go once they see them (even if you go out of view) and always has boosted stats over your units and will straight up murder you if you make a mistake, so use every trick you can against them. Be nasty, hide around corners and ambush them with multiple units when it sends some poor sucker for that last wyrdstone you left as bait.  Once they see one of your units, they will usually send everything to that location, except sometimes they won't send units that are on the kill list for the optional quest, so use that to your advantage.  You can set up a bottleneck in pretty much any area and ambush them as they come through so it becomes 1 vs 3 while their other units are locked away behind their one ambushed unit. Probably the best piece of advice, especially for early game, is choose the right missions. If you pick a mission where the enemy AI has easy access to a solo or small group of your units, they will suffer.  Never ever choose a "both warbands are spread out" and avoid the 3 groups split one (for those you can just bring 4 units and make it a 1 group thing). Early game you never want to go 1 on 1 (or worse) with a unit. Later on you'll have awesome units that can murder henchmen solo in 1 round but that takes time. The mission type defines the difficulty so much more than the actual normal/hard/brutal/deadly thing does. Although with brutal or deadly you can get surprise ambush missions which are basically the same thing as "both warbands are spread out" except the ambushee gets negative OP at the start so avoid those as well. In the later game ranged damage is really good at level 10 with good passives, but it's a little difficult to get a ranged unit to level 10 because they pretty much suck until level 8 or so.  You can buy warriors that are already leveled up later in the game, so remember that.If any of this sounds exciting, then this is your game.  I love this game so much more than many other strategy games because it's very difficult at first, and then you get that victory feeling once you start figuring things out.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												This game is very good if you're not afraid to lose a few characters here and there. especially on your first playthrough.People whine about the Random Number Generator because they missed a few hits in desperate situations, but my guess is they skipped statistics classes in college, and they shouldn't have put their characters in a desperate situation in the first place.If you flip a coin five times and it lands on heads five time, you're not gonna claim you've solved the coin flipping rule of the universe. Sometimes, in Mordheim COTD, you need to shackle the opponent's impressive character, but somehow your 95% succes chance Magister fails and gets stunned in front of everyone, and your poor sod facing the impressive character will have a bad time.Sometimes though, you play tight and get a lucky crit on their most dangerous character, and turn a uneasy battle into a piece of cake. You never hear people whine about lucky crits, though.You could see this game as an XCOM set in the Warhammer world with a default hard difficulty (which isn't that hard once you get the hang of it).Some of your characters will die, and that's ok, learn to manage a rooster big enough to handle those situations.If you want a blissful experience without any character dying, stick to the first xcom reboot on easy difficulty.Mordheim: COTD is beautiful, challenging and fun.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												As the kids would say, "This is my jam."I'm not usually a fan of games that punish you for losing, but there's something very compelling about Mordheim: City of the Damned.Love the levelling up of a whole roster of warriors. Love the unique third person view of the battlefield. Love the brutality of failure when members of your warband get dismembered or worse. Love the careful strategic planning and setting of ambushes in a fight, only to suddenly have the tables turn on me at the last moment because I got overzealous.While the current setting and the available races are very enjoyable, I hope to see this being expanded upon greatly to include more landscapes, more warband options, more variety in loot and rewards, simple more Mordheim and beyond!Recommended to anyone who likes some punishingly strategic game-play with swords and progression.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												8/10Mordheim is a great turn based strategy game set in a dark and gritty city plagued with evil and greedy beings. This comes straight from the Warhammer Universe, and i enjoyed it without ever playing the board games or really understanding the lore.The game is a lot like Valkyria Chronicles where you control each character from a third person view and have a large area to navigate in each short battle.PROS-maintains the dark and gloomy theme throughout the game-you have your own squad/warband and are able to upgrade them over the duration of the game-a lot of customisation which means you get attached to your squad -it is difficult to the point where one wrong move and you have resulted in your best soldier being knocked out and needing an arm amputation (difficult is good in a genre where you can steamroll the whole game without a challenge)-the battles are strategic and enjoyable-graphics and music are very appropriateNEGS-the "random" luck element in hit/dodge/parry chance is in my opinion rubbish (call me salty but 4 x 80% chance hits missing in a row is pretty bad) The dice rolls will infuriate you-Each sector of the city you play in is very similar. There are the odd differences but not enough to create a variety.All in all it is a very polished and enjoyable game and is a must buy when on sale!

												I've finished a few battles and learned a lot:1. Don't just sit there and get pommelled to death.2. Try to lure the enemy into abushes.3. Pick up Wyrdstone! You need to sell and trade it for reputation.4. You have to decide whether to go for treasure or position for the next battle.Pros +++ Fun!+ True line of sight - You might be able to see the enemy moving around the map but you aren't exactly sure of where they are until you're freakin' ambushed :P+ Overwatch using ranged attacks+ Lots of skills and spells+ The game saves before each move (I think) to allow you to pick up from where you left off.Cons- A map stopped loading at 88% once, but I just killed/reloaded the gameI recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												This game has 1300+ positive reviews and only about 400 negative, however, 4 out of the first 5 reviews you see are negative. That would almost make someone instantly change their mind about buying this game. Why aren't their more positive reviews up front for people to see? And steam, shouldn't the out dated reviews be moved down the list so people can see reviews about the current version? (I know iPhone and iPad app store only keep reviews about the current version.)In my opinion, the recent patch totally fixed most of the RNG problems and a bunch other glitches. About people who said that their character "missed 5 95% shots in a row ". I'm gonna make an arguement. First of all, max level (10) leaders and heros have 9 offense points, which are enough for 4 one-handed hits or 3 two-handed hits. If your heros or headers are using ranged weapon, they could do 3 gun shots or 4 bow shots. A max level impressive warrior also has 9 offensive points, so 4 hits also. So I don't understand where you got those 5 shots.... So why don't you guys be a responsible reviewer and remove those negative reviews that are not true to the current version any more? Plus most of those posters just sounded like they did not know how the game works.But anyway, Mordheim is an awesome turn-based strategy game. At first I played it on my boyfriend's account and leveled up my sister warband to 10. Then my boyfriend bought me a copy, and since then I have played over 250 hours. I have enjoyed this game a lot. To those who have enjoyed Mordheim, I suggest you all write a positive review to bring more players into this game. I believe we all need more skirmish players!

content:
Posted: February 24
												This game is not for people that like their wins handed to them or for people who can't handle it when things don't go their way because things won't go your way in this game. It's an odds game and you have to play like the odds are heavily against you, because they usually are. Some tips for getting the upper hand at the start of the game (which is where it's hardest):The AI doesn't play fair so throw any notion of being 'honorable' against it out the window. It knows exactly where your units go once they see them (even if you go out of view) and always has boosted stats over your units and will straight up murder you if you make a mistake, so use every trick you can against them. Be nasty, hide around corners and ambush them with multiple units when it sends some poor sucker for that last wyrdstone you left as bait.  Once they see one of your units, they will usually send everything to that location, except sometimes they won't send units that are on the kill list for the optional quest, so use that to your advantage.  You can set up a bottleneck in pretty much any area and ambush them as they come through so it becomes 1 vs 3 while their other units are locked away behind their one ambushed unit. Probably the best piece of advice, especially for early game, is choose the right missions. If you pick a mission where the enemy AI has easy access to a solo or small group of your units, they will suffer.  Never ever choose a "both warbands are spread out" and avoid the 3 groups split one (for those you can just bring 4 units and make it a 1 group thing). Early game you never want to go 1 on 1 (or worse) with a unit. Later on you'll have awesome units that can murder henchmen solo in 1 round but that takes time. The mission type defines the difficulty so much more than the actual normal/hard/brutal/deadly thing does. Although with brutal or deadly you can get surprise ambush missions which are basically the same thing as "both warbands are spread out" except the ambushee gets negative OP at the start so avoid those as well. In the later game ranged damage is really good at level 10 with good passives, but it's a little difficult to get a ranged unit to level 10 because they pretty much suck until level 8 or so.  You can buy warriors that are already leveled up later in the game, so remember that.If any of this sounds exciting, then this is your game.  I love this game so much more than many other strategy games because it's very difficult at first, and then you get that victory feeling once you start figuring things out.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Solid 8/10Pretty good game, I bought it because X-COM2 wasnt out yet and I surprised myself stucking on that game instead of actually buying X-COM2.The fact is : This game is really harsh, I should say unfair and over-punishing with new players. Other player`s opinion may differ, but this was my experience. Dont get me wrong, its not a bad thing. This game was MADE to be that way.WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW : -----This game should have a warning on its label : You are going to get intensely r4ped for the first 10 hours or so. Its totally normal if you feel sad and angry, just accept it...Learning curve ?...No way, you are thrown into it and you are going to drown. Pretty much the reason of all bad reviews.-----The game also doesnt warn you that its almost impossible to stay with your first ever warband, so dont get attached too soon. You are going to replace them often, disbanding and re-creating at least once. They going to get killed, crippled, ransacked and sick poor again. You are going to want to bash your whole house and family with your keyboard, but its part of the first stage of the game.-----To be honest, once you get past the " initiation " step, its one of the best bucks$/game ratio I ever played, and I bought it full price so I reccomend you jump on it, especially if its on sale. The game also greatly rewards new warbands, depending on your easily obtainable achievements.Most of bad reviews come from people with less than 15hrs. Give yourself a chance, you are missing a great gem of a game. The game is still challenging and hard when you gear up and lvl up, but really less unfair. Damn good game.My point is : Dont buy if you dont like getting angry on a game. Dont buy if you want a "walk in the park" gaming experience.NOW THE HONEST REVIEW : Dont buy if you dont like unexpected and "against the odds". Whole game is based on dice-rolls and odds. Once again, reason of most bad reviews...Personally I call that " Challenging" and "Refreshing" ...Mostly "Refreshing" But most gamers nowaday calling that... " Broken"...go figure....And I am not even that old. I am not even an hardcore gamer.PRETTY  SIMPLE :You want to win on each tries, you want forgivness on your stupid/rushed plays?You want to load a previous save because you ♥♥♥♥ed up?  Steam, Origin, U-Play, name em are full of those kind of un-original games, of any genres. 70-80-90$-DLC not Included, and you will get erected at how much copy-paste/recycled games are appealing and how much dev team doesnt care about you and your elite community. Btw, I got these kind of games on my pc. Some I love, Some I regret. I am no hater, I love games.Rogue-Factor`s first game...Not perfect, but damn impressive for a little bunch of devs. Promising future if you ask me, just dont bury em under false bad "under 10 hours game experience" meaningless-seen-better-meh-IamtheShit opinions.Worst of all, every negative stuff I read about this game is absolutely wrong on most aspects. Too little time into it to make worthy reviews. I have seen about 3 constructive bad reviews, with points I agreed on, but never to the point of calling that game-breaker.IMPORTANT TO MENTION : -Great ambiant music and great grim victorian dark atmoshpere. I mean, its dark, and grim. Like the first Diablo compared to Diablo3. -...You have to be patient...You have to let time to the enemy to place their warriors, can take several seconds.-I never tried multiplayer, due to real life stuff. But from what I heard, its not optimal yet.-Dev team often on forums and answering constructive posts.-Speaking about the forums, many experienced players are there, always happy to give tips.long read, sorry. By the way, I never played the table-top version. I heard there is some inaccuracies. Some people like it, some dont. Anyway, the game is awesome.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
This review is for a single campaign, I haven't touched the multiplayer yet.First of all, I would like to say, that this game has a great potential and I hope it will get better in time. Still, I can't recommend it for now even if you're a Warhammer FB fan. And here is why:RNGBack in release days game was literally unplayable - you could miss 6 times in a row with 95% hit-chance and it was "normal". This horrible dice roll system was, for example, in new X-COM or Blackguards and caused so much rage and back blood, that you could raise a permanent Bloodthirster from it. But we don't need to learn from other's mistakes, right? Frankly, devs heard your cries, so in the current state the roll system was fixed and you will not miss as often, but it still has THIS MOMENTS, when the enemy dodges two of your attacks with 9% chance, when you can't dodge even once with your 40% chance. Or you miss 3 of 4 your 85% attack. Or a Tzeench kills you on a first spell with 9% mishap.But still, now it's much better and I'm hoping for the best.Stupid Strange ideas and overall balanceLike you can't parry with two-handed sword(!), but you can with a halberd(!!!). Maces and hammers have no armor penetration, but axes do. Hell, even rifles(at least, the hunter rifle) in this game have no armor penetration! Instead of that you have a crit chance or a crit strength! Yeah, sure.You get tired from using two-handed weapon(+1 attack point and - 20% damage for each next attack) or dual wield, but you don't get tired from using a one-handed weapon and shield. Should I tell you, why it's better to do 2 hits with one-handed than 1 with two-handed? Besides that, you're getting tired even from using guns! Even pistols! But it's not the funny part. The funny part is that you don't get tired from using all kinds of bows! WHAT. THE. FFFFFF~...and the daggers are just garbage. And you can't shoot in melee, but you can cast in it(really?!).   And you can shoot into melee fight even through your comrades. Ahaha, game, what are you doing, please stop!P.S You CAN parry with almost anything. Yes, even with a two-handed hammer. Just not as effective. Just not in this game.Loading time and Enemy turnEvery mission is loading forever. Like windows 95 on your old Pentium. And after that you need to wait when bunch of ugly women do all there jumping and falling, while they're slowly moving throw the map. And it's takes as much time as loading. So get yourself a good FB fluff book and alt+tab, because you gonna wait a lot. If you decide to buy this game of course.MissionsThere is two types of missions in this game: story missions and boring missions. Story missions are very good and I don't have much complaints about them, but you will rarely see them. The boring missions are only one type - smash the enemy faces. Yes, you can call them "Warpstone rush" or "Domination", but these are side quests. The major task is always one - make them flee. And it's fun. For a first hundred times. After that it's became a routine, which is not that bad due to an interesting gameplay, but still. The major issue is that often you can't even complete the side-quest because when the enemy morale passes some threshold the battle is over and you stand victorious on a pile of NOT picked warpstones. Ha-ha, too bad, boy, here is your 3 small pieces and get out of my map! Rrrrrrealy annoying. At least give me two extra terns to pick up my stuff.AIAI in this game is dumb and buggy. It will stroll around the map, when you are beating sht out of their comrades. It will choose  the retardiest way to engage or to move. It will stuck in the corners. In close combat with multiple targets it will start randomly shooting comets rather than kill a stunned 2 HP enemy. Et cetera, et cetera.And it will cheat with onslaught and ambush, I swear it.Allocation and MinimapPlacing you warband in this game is pain. First of all, you can't do it from minimap. Second - you randomly choose the next or previous positions. So you will bounce across the map like a ping-pong ball untill you get sick. Especially on the ambush maps.PerksThe skill and leveling system in this game is really good and has a potential. So much skills, active/passive perks and parameters like a balsam on my black heart.However, there is a fly in the ointment - there is no perks for a certain weapon. And I can't understand why - we have heavy armour and shield passive perks, but not for exact weapon or even a weapon type? This is a huge variety limitation and it's really upsets me.Second - there is a useful perks for all, and there is never-ever-ever use perks. Same for the spells: 1-2 "must have" spells(like lightning or chaos chains) and garbage. There is not much of variety - use these or be a gay.Third - the cost of learning is overpriced. You waste too much money and time on even basic perks. 200 gold for armor wearing, really? I can buy a purple armor for 200 gold! And it's a basic level perk! There is some corruption in this warrior school, investigate it.DifficultyI really like hard games, I really do. And I also like hardcore/ironman run, It makes me feel alive. But there is a line between a hard interesting challenge and BDSM. And Slaanesh sees, devs have crossed it. Even If you're winning, you can get an unpleasant situation, when one of your fallen warriors gets some nasty injuries, but it's fine. Worse when you get some really bad trauma, like arm or leg loss. For some of you, who think that it's cool - no, it's not. Your 5-lvl veteran becomes crippled garbage and there is nothing you can do(waste some of your warpstone for regeneration for example). But this is life, right? Ohoho, but don't even try to lose, you filthy little casual, because game will give you a full-strenght stomach punch and then spit on your writhing body. Half of the team will be dead or crippled to an unusable condition. You will waste tons of money and time to even heal them, not talking about replacing. Or you'll just delete your glorious unbeatable warband, like I did with my 6-lvl warband today. Game did everything it could to beat my leader magister and his patrol(No, I don't want to send a patrols, I'm a commander here god damn it!), including gay RNG stunnes and misses.There is a bright side actually - there is overall progress, which will make every new warband easer to progress, but still. At least make this game less fluky.What is good in this game, you might ask? Well, It's Warhammer in the nutshell - dark, unforgiving place where is no good at all - just less bastart. The atmosphere is great, the maps are looking cool, the customisation of your warband is unique. And like I've said before, this game has so much potential for further development. And I hope the devs will implement it in full.

Product received for free
												I thought about getting this for some time. When the game came out for a free weekend, I was thrilled. However the trill was short lived when I actually started playing it. Some people have complained about the steep learning curve. Elite Dangerous has a steep learning curve, this has a learning cliff with no climbing ropes. The tutorial was not informative and crushingly boring. Meanwhile the campaign is half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and lacks much of a story other than: Go here, do this, kill this, loose half your men ect. The mechanics are very clunky and the overall camera controls are rediculusly constricting. The veiws that you get are third person and third person. This would not be so bad if it were like Dragon Age. It can take 3-4 rounds to kill an enemy one on one which will leave your man crippled regardless of whether or not he is covered in heavy armor or clad in a burlap sack. Weapon type is also imaterial a halberd/spear has nearly the same combat range as a sword or dagger wielding hostile. Bows are made useless from the combonation of short range and low damage. But the logic envolved with this is also flawed. Combat, especially in the story missions is encredibly one-sided and your entire team will run off under stupid conditions. Once I had the enemy down to one and backed into a corner 5 on 1 and lost the leader. All 4 of the others cut and run.  If this had nothing else to compair it to, we would think it was incredible, but let me make a list of games like this that are better.Dragon Age, all 3Divinity 2 Divinity Orginal SinPillars of EternityBaulders GateIcewind Dale Temple of Elemental Evil (TOEE) Dungeon SeigeBlackguards 1&2Your favorite game hereOn an up note, this does beat out Sword Coast. Then again, contracting Leishmaniasis beats that. My point is, there is no point in getting this when there are a slew of other games out there that are so so much better that cost far far less.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												As a longtime fan and player of the tabletop game, I was thrilled to see Mordheim was being made into a computer game. My old computer didn't meet the minimum specs, but after buying an ASUS ROG rig on clearance at Best Buy this spring, I have to say Rogue Factor did not disappoint! This is a fantastic conversion, with four of the iconic warbands included, and now a fifth -- Witch Hunters -- available as DLC, as well as several hired swords. Keep it coming, devs!Like the tabletop version, the gameplay is highly tactical. Ganging up on lone enemies, while preventing the enemy from ganging up on you, is the key to victory. Yes, you will lose warriors from time to time -- get used to it, it's Mordheim! Keep your heavy hitters in front, while your weaker members grab wyrdstone and loot until they're strong enough to fight. Hire a reserve leader so you don't miss days when your primary leader gets injured -- make those wyrdstone shipments to your sponsor on time! That keeps the gold flowing and lets you build up your warband. Now, my Level 10 Ogre is a killing machine!No, the game isn't perfect -- there are occasional spots in some maps where you should be able to move but a small obstacle blocks your path. And the AI does get hung up once in a while, especially with the large monsters unable to find a path or blocked by a wagon. Also, the persistent arrows after you get shot really need to go away -- having your warriors running around fighting with an arrow right between the eyes or through their skulls looks pretty dumb. So those glitches still need to be ironed out. But overall, this is a great game of Mordheim. The visuals are spot-on, the story missions are fun, and you don't even have to paint your warband. Now let's get that Undead warband into the game! And then, Necromunda...

Posted: August 20, 2016
												This game does not deserve this many bad reviews.  The game is not high priced. Has affordable DLCs even when not on discount. Its a visual beauty and the gameplay harsh and unforgiving.  You make yourself a warband which you can customize to some extend. And you set off in the grimm city of Mordheim to gatehr wyrdstones for your faction.  You win some and you lose some, but everything comes down to choices as you won't be able to sweep the battlefield after the match is done.  If you lose a fight your merc have the potential to get wounded this includes losing limbs, eyes and even permadeath.   IF you have an unlucky streak you might find yourself a crippled warband and you will have to reroll again.  The game is not designed for an easy game with godmode on.  Expect to die, a lot.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												I bought it in early access ages ago as I played this tabletop game as a child and loved it.I waited until it was out of early access before playing it as I didn't want to ruin it (just like I don't watch trailers for movies).I am loving it. The game mechanics are very different to the original game but they work very well as a video game. Amazingly well in fact. This is the best designed game I'm played in a long time.I love the open-ended, rogue-like nature of the game. I got brutally slaughtered in the first game (before I realised not to split my band up) but still enjoyed it as I was immediately spending XP and changing my choice of weapons.Losing is common, but it's not so bad as your warriors don't die (some get injuries, usually 1 max). Just keep grabbing Wyrdstone on the matches.I've had zero crashes in 13 hours, of playtime. It is slow to load the matches (~40 secs) but once they start it's fine.If you like tactical combat and open-ended gamepleay, I can honestly say this is the best game like this that I've ever played in the last couple of years.Edit after 150 hrs:Still enjoying the game very much. The main flaw, and it's a big one, is that the AI pathfinding is pretty poor. This means that sometimes the AI warriors get stuck and essentially waste their turn. I hope they fix this in a patch as this game could otherwise be a classic.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												If you enjoy games such as XCOM and Darkest Dungeon, you'll probably enjoy this too. Don't expect AAA production values or fairness. If you come into this game expecting a smooth run, you're gonna be disappointed. If you enjoy the ups and downs of a game of this nature and take it as it comes, you'll find a satisfying experience tactically on par with the aforementioned games.I actually enjoyed that unlike XCOM or Darkest Dungeon, downed soldiers will usually survive and are more likely to be injured than dead. It's a bit more granular and allows for more balanced fights where you can have multiple downed soldiers but still win, rather than all-or-nothing (either you kill all the baddies, or it's a total failure). The 'rout' system plays into this nicely as well. Coming from XCOM I found it refreshingly forgiving while still keeping the fear of death at every mission-end screen.It's not a beautiful game and it could certainly have more variety - if I paid full price for it, as a frugal gamer, I might feel a bit ripped off. But at £10 it's a steal. It fills a niche that few games do, and it's gradually getting better over time as they add more warbands (even if you don't buy the DLC warbands, they'll show up as enemies) and fine-tune the balance. The devs are very communicative too. I hope to see the game expand even more over time.There's unfortunately lots of folks downvoting genuine reviews and trying to trash this game, which is silly. It seems a lot of folks have never played an RNG-based game before and are stunned that 90%s can miss and 10%s can hit. Those moments where your archer fails to climb up a wall three times in a row are hilarious BECAUSE they are unlikely. The moment when your henchman nails a 10% to hit a vampire lord, or when you lose your leader to bad luck - that's why we play these games. It enables a narrative that other games don't have. The triumph of victory against steep odds, the crushing defeat of failure. You don't get that feeling in most games. It's not for everyone, but if you're one of those people - you know who you are - then you know that there's no substitute.I suggest looking at hours played for reviews and check out some youtube lets plays if you're on the fence.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												Mordheim is a turn based strategy game with some vague similarities to the XCOM series but set in the dark, gritty fantasy world of Games Workshop's Warhammer Fantasy setting.This game is an adaption of the classic tabletop game Mordheim (which was itself the fantasy reskin of the excellent TT game Necromunda) and it captures the setting extremely well. The graphics and music evoke the right atmosphere and look damn good, especially when you realise what a small team it was working on this game.The game itself is hard. Like, really hard. Particualrly at the beginning, where the learning curve is like an overhanging cliff (and the wide skill selection is an avalanche that starts when you're part way up). The tutorials are good but they don't cover everything, they're definitely worth going through though. It does get easier and you'll find that you're able to do Brutal and Deadly missions and generally win, although that doesn't mean you won't lose people to going Out of Action during those wins.Ah yes, out of action... This game has permanent consequences for your actions. There's no save scumming, although there is an ironman style autosave feature in case of crashes, etc. Other than that you have to live with your decsisions and, due to it's TT roots, the roll of the die. Yeah, sometimes RNG can screw you, it's just that sort of game. Your mooks will go down and out and, when they do, they will end up picking up injuries or straight up dying. That part of Mordheim and, at least for me, part of the fun!So the purpose of the game? You've been sent to Mordheim by a baacker who is funding your activities in the city. Their exact nature and reasons for sending you there vary from faction to faction but suiffice it to say you work for them. And what you're doing for them is collecting warpstone, a resource that's scattered throughout the maps. You will periodically have deliveries to fill for them where they require a particualr amount of warpstone. Failing to make those deliveries will eventually lose you the game so try to make them on time. Other than that you will be levelling up your warriors and your warband, as well as you as a player via the Veteran System whereby you get perks like additional starting gold and access to Veteran Skills. Your warband will gain stat increases, more strategy points and offence points, as well as gaining skill points to spend on the bewildering array of passive and active skills available (warning: they aren't cheap, especially when you master a skill). Some of your guys will gain access to spells, and as you level up new hero types (and eventually the mighty Impressives) will be come available to your warband.  You'll also loot more powerful equipment and begin discover magical formulae that allow you to place marks on your weapons and armour, that do a variety of things.All in all I would definitely recommend the game. I very much enjoy it and can't wait to have a try at multiplayer (I've only done single player thus far), where I think the game will really shine. Just be aware that it is a hardcore exsperience. You will lose matches, you will have people get injured and die, your equipment will be looted from their bodies, you will struggle for gold to pay your warband and buy skills and replacement warriors. That's an integral part of Mordheim and might mean that the game isn't for you, which is fine. It is for me though, I absolutely love it!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												A surprisingly very good game with its fair share of flaws. Allows you to have a warband of mercenaries, customize it, build it up, lose it, gear it, love it, hate it (all that with more charisma and style than any conversational simulator such as mass effect), all that in an endless gameplay mode that allows you to play for as long as you want even if you completed (or not) the main campaign attached to each warband.For those interested in pvp the game offers matches against other players but for that itwould be good if you join the gentlmen of mordheim group to arrange games, otherwise the game list looks like the Sahara desert 99.9% of the time. I have no interest in pvp so good for themThe art style in this game is quite an achievement of ugly looking people in proper dirty clothing and real life looking weapons for the most part,  contrary to the horrible color palette abuse and toyish designs most developers seem to follow (cartoon style, how I hate it). While the graphics themselves are not that great, the game itself looks good.If you are buying this its not going to be for the graphics, but the gameplay.The game has its fair share of flaws like I mentioned at the start, some of them being:Rather poor animations that could use a lot of more work.Limited variety of maps (4 maps if i recall correctly, and despite that every time you play the maps have different starting locations and random features such as blocked paths, holes in the walls and different routes, so all in all is not that bad).On that regard some more map(s) could improve this lack of variety. Sewers and catacombs and underground tunnels connecting buildings would make such a great addition... even if it is in the already known maps.Certain mission goals are a bit anal, such as the already discussed "steal the idol from the enemy cart, then place it in your own cart". Should not be enough to just steal it?.On a personal level I would love to see some kind of weekly or even daily randomly generated special missions featuring some narrative and rpg elements allowing you to play with the dramatis personae of your warband (the dramatis personae is the npc which acts as your "boss" and gives you the campaign missions). Maybe even reusing some of the campaign maps (which btw are different from the usual maps you get when you play normal missions).All in all, my best purchase from the previous year along with Space Hulk Ascension. Kinda funny that these small developer teams are making better turn based strategy games (and understand the concept) when compared to the big budget productions with lots of marketing and shiny graphics.However if you have mental issues with losing, and expect a game to be fair towards the player, or this is just a casual interest because it belongs to the GW franchise or whatever, then save your money.As a diamond in the rough it wont please everyone.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
												I had previously written a review for this when it was in Early Access.  Now that it is in full release I figured I'd better get with the program.Mordheim is a turn-based strategy game based on the Game Workshop Mordheim setting.  Four different warbands (six if you get the DLC) square off against one another in a ruined city, competing for control of the city and the resources it contains.  It is difficult, unforgiving, and I love every second of it.One of the things that stands out most to me is the way the gameplay functions.  When a unit takes their turn, instead of relying on any sort of grid, they are free to move around in a third person free roaming mode, limited to their movement range.  This gives the game a very open and exploratory feel, and really feels like a skirmish instead of a board game with pretty graphics.  Each army is unique and favors different playstyles.  They have their own unique skills, equipment, stat limitations, and unit types.  This provides a huge range of options with which to customize your playstyle.  On that subject you'd better get good at the playstyle as well, because the game will punish you if you don't.One of the core principles of this game is that choices matter.  If one of your units falls in battle, they may suffer injuries that will affect their stats, lose equipment, or even die and have to be replaced.  If you do well, they will be rewarded with experience points that level their stats, provide skill points, and increase their health.  The PVP is a solid experience, though sometimes bugs get in the way.  Occasionally there will be issues causing you and your opponents games to "desync," causing different outcomes for checks.  This could mean that sometimes a unit falls out of action for you, but not your opponent.  It's a problem.  Most of the time though it works just fine, and battles against a skilled opponent are still very rewarding.  It works well enough, that I've done some one off games on my YouTube channel, and even joined six other YouTubers and participated in a PVP league that ran for at least 16 battles.  My point here is don't let the occasional bug scare you off.  Another benefit to this game is the DLC.  Since release they have added two additional factions.  The Witch Hunters, and the Undead provide very different styles of play from the other four, and I still don't feel like any faction inherently rises above all the others.  In addition to this, they added a Hired Swords DLC that added another four units to the game that can be usable by the original factions.  This includes the Poison Wind Globadier, Smuggler, Worf Priest of Ulric, and the Doomsayer.  The Globadier and Doomsayer can be hired by the chaotic aligned factions while the Wolf Priest, and Smuggler are hired by the order factions.  It's a great way to mix up your war band and through an unexpected wrench at your opponent.All said and done I would highly recommend this game.  The great support from the development team, the wonderful art style and game features, and the originality in the maps and warbands combines to make a very memorable and enjoyable experience.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												This game has 1300+ positive reviews and only about 400 negative, however, 4 out of the first 5 reviews you see are negative. That would almost make someone instantly change their mind about buying this game. Why aren't their more positive reviews up front for people to see? And steam, shouldn't the out dated reviews be moved down the list so people can see reviews about the current version? (I know iPhone and iPad app store only keep reviews about the current version.)In my opinion, the recent patch totally fixed most of the RNG problems and a bunch other glitches. About people who said that their character "missed 5 95% shots in a row ". I'm gonna make an arguement. First of all, max level (10) leaders and heros have 9 offense points, which are enough for 4 one-handed hits or 3 two-handed hits. If your heros or headers are using ranged weapon, they could do 3 gun shots or 4 bow shots. A max level impressive warrior also has 9 offensive points, so 4 hits also. So I don't understand where you got those 5 shots.... So why don't you guys be a responsible reviewer and remove those negative reviews that are not true to the current version any more? Plus most of those posters just sounded like they did not know how the game works.But anyway, Mordheim is an awesome turn-based strategy game. At first I played it on my boyfriend's account and leveled up my sister warband to 10. Then my boyfriend bought me a copy, and since then I have played over 250 hours. I have enjoyed this game a lot. To those who have enjoyed Mordheim, I suggest you all write a positive review to bring more players into this game. I believe we all need more skirmish players!

Early Access Review
								[ EARLY ACCESS ]This means not all features are present.As far as I understand at least for chaos side, only skirmish is available.There may be a campaign for chaos if not all races in the future but it is not yet implemented.I run the game on a old laptop MSI FX603 and the game runs smooth with low setting gfx.The game is interesting at the core. Stats seem perhap confusing at first but reading with automatically gauge an understanding of characeristics and capabilities.Gameplay functions seem long to reach between Q and E rolling out left or right but the game is playable and I am hopeful more optimization will come along the way.This game is for casual turn base strategy players. The game is slow paced.  The atmosphere is great. Decors on low on my low spec machine are ok. Pretty unusually slow and long SKIRMISH loading time (2 minutes or a bit more) for my old machine using an IDE 5k4 RPM hard drive but again this is early access and thing "may" improve along the way.I recommend this game to anyone who like to pose a strategy while 3D strategy element at first is somewhat boggling, anyone quickly take marks of position and location to defend, ambush, attack, skirmish, flee, counter and more, and the so the game suddenly deepens!

content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												As the kids would say, "This is my jam."I'm not usually a fan of games that punish you for losing, but there's something very compelling about Mordheim: City of the Damned.Love the levelling up of a whole roster of warriors. Love the unique third person view of the battlefield. Love the brutality of failure when members of your warband get dismembered or worse. Love the careful strategic planning and setting of ambushes in a fight, only to suddenly have the tables turn on me at the last moment because I got overzealous.While the current setting and the available races are very enjoyable, I hope to see this being expanded upon greatly to include more landscapes, more warband options, more variety in loot and rewards, simple more Mordheim and beyond!Recommended to anyone who likes some punishingly strategic game-play with swords and progression.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												At first i gave this game a poor review. However the dev team responded so I felt like i should respond My innitial complains were about the Terrible story missions and the fact that the reforcement mechanic is pull. However as the Dev was kind enough to respond about the long load times i felt that alone is enough to make up for its fault as you can enjoy the game for endless hours without doing the storied missions. Also to make it clear it is not the story in these mission that is poorly done but the mechanics that our added to them, Like not showing the objectives till you have completed the current so you cant forward plan. Also the fact that many of the missions end with getting stuck and stalled on a single stairway. Really i wish i could give a medium rating but thier is no middleground rating.  Also Skaven for life.Hi Chex 86,It seems you’ve had trouble with a unique Story missions. Here’s some elements that might help you out:- Only Story missions have the “reinforcement” mechanic- Story missions are not mandatory, you could ignore them entirely if you desire- Story missions do not grow in power with you, so you can come back when your rating is higher to have an easier timeWe are constantly working to improve the loading time and will keep doing so for the upcoming weeks.We hope these cues will help you enjoy the game.

Posted: September 12, 2016
												8/10Mordheim is a great turn based strategy game set in a dark and gritty city plagued with evil and greedy beings. This comes straight from the Warhammer Universe, and i enjoyed it without ever playing the board games or really understanding the lore.The game is a lot like Valkyria Chronicles where you control each character from a third person view and have a large area to navigate in each short battle.PROS-maintains the dark and gloomy theme throughout the game-you have your own squad/warband and are able to upgrade them over the duration of the game-a lot of customisation which means you get attached to your squad -it is difficult to the point where one wrong move and you have resulted in your best soldier being knocked out and needing an arm amputation (difficult is good in a genre where you can steamroll the whole game without a challenge)-the battles are strategic and enjoyable-graphics and music are very appropriateNEGS-the "random" luck element in hit/dodge/parry chance is in my opinion rubbish (call me salty but 4 x 80% chance hits missing in a row is pretty bad) The dice rolls will infuriate you-Each sector of the city you play in is very similar. There are the odd differences but not enough to create a variety.All in all it is a very polished and enjoyable game and is a must buy when on sale!

												So I LOVED XCOM and XCOM2 - I love Turn based Tactical/RPG games.... I hate this game, mainly because it's strategy light and luck heavy with perma-ironman. I know that people who played XCOM(s) will complain about missing constantly on a 90+% chance, but this is worse - it's so incredibly trolly with the numbers it presents - and the random fear, morale, and trap checks are just another way to keep the grind on. Which the difficulty was worth it in the XCOM series because it had a lot more than just getting trolled by the game over and over - it has a plot. This game possesses all the vacancy and empty promises that No Man's Sky provided, with the exception being that No Man's Sky is far more enjoyable. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone but hardcore Warhammer Players - because it's a lemon of a game. If I could get a refund I would, because it's a loser.

												A very fun game set within the Warhammer Fantasy universe, plenty of depth and customization and all sorts of fun ways to leave your mark, both on your warband and on the faces of your opponents.I must say, however, the Random Number Generator for this game is seriously perverse, on the verge of being actually bad. Worse than X-Com by a damn sight, anyways. I've missed far more than one in five +80% attacks, I've been hit repeatedly with well over a 50% chance to dodge or parry, and the number of times my warriors have wiffed a 95%, with so much on the line, it's pretty sickening. Not saying the game is broken, but I'm saying there is a surprising amount of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, not numbers, being generated. I am writing this review after having gotten my warband creamed due to poor rolling, but my complaint stands on it's own merit.

content:
Posted: February 24
												This game is not for people that like their wins handed to them or for people who can't handle it when things don't go their way because things won't go your way in this game. It's an odds game and you have to play like the odds are heavily against you, because they usually are. Some tips for getting the upper hand at the start of the game (which is where it's hardest):The AI doesn't play fair so throw any notion of being 'honorable' against it out the window. It knows exactly where your units go once they see them (even if you go out of view) and always has boosted stats over your units and will straight up murder you if you make a mistake, so use every trick you can against them. Be nasty, hide around corners and ambush them with multiple units when it sends some poor sucker for that last wyrdstone you left as bait.  Once they see one of your units, they will usually send everything to that location, except sometimes they won't send units that are on the kill list for the optional quest, so use that to your advantage.  You can set up a bottleneck in pretty much any area and ambush them as they come through so it becomes 1 vs 3 while their other units are locked away behind their one ambushed unit. Probably the best piece of advice, especially for early game, is choose the right missions. If you pick a mission where the enemy AI has easy access to a solo or small group of your units, they will suffer.  Never ever choose a "both warbands are spread out" and avoid the 3 groups split one (for those you can just bring 4 units and make it a 1 group thing). Early game you never want to go 1 on 1 (or worse) with a unit. Later on you'll have awesome units that can murder henchmen solo in 1 round but that takes time. The mission type defines the difficulty so much more than the actual normal/hard/brutal/deadly thing does. Although with brutal or deadly you can get surprise ambush missions which are basically the same thing as "both warbands are spread out" except the ambushee gets negative OP at the start so avoid those as well. In the later game ranged damage is really good at level 10 with good passives, but it's a little difficult to get a ranged unit to level 10 because they pretty much suck until level 8 or so.  You can buy warriors that are already leveled up later in the game, so remember that.If any of this sounds exciting, then this is your game.  I love this game so much more than many other strategy games because it's very difficult at first, and then you get that victory feeling once you start figuring things out.

												The look and feel of this game is very appealing and I found it extremely addictive from the start. The characters and sceneries follow the warhammer theme extremely well and you can tell it's a game created by gamers and fans of the original. content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												Mordheim is a turn based strategy game with some vague similarities to the XCOM series but set in the dark, gritty fantasy world of Games Workshop's Warhammer Fantasy setting.This game is an adaption of the classic tabletop game Mordheim (which was itself the fantasy reskin of the excellent TT game Necromunda) and it captures the setting extremely well. The graphics and music evoke the right atmosphere and look damn good, especially when you realise what a small team it was working on this game.The game itself is hard. Like, really hard. Particualrly at the beginning, where the learning curve is like an overhanging cliff (and the wide skill selection is an avalanche that starts when you're part way up). The tutorials are good but they don't cover everything, they're definitely worth going through though. It does get easier and you'll find that you're able to do Brutal and Deadly missions and generally win, although that doesn't mean you won't lose people to going Out of Action during those wins.Ah yes, out of action... This game has permanent consequences for your actions. There's no save scumming, although there is an ironman style autosave feature in case of crashes, etc. Other than that you have to live with your decsisions and, due to it's TT roots, the roll of the die. Yeah, sometimes RNG can screw you, it's just that sort of game. Your mooks will go down and out and, when they do, they will end up picking up injuries or straight up dying. That part of Mordheim and, at least for me, part of the fun!So the purpose of the game? You've been sent to Mordheim by a baacker who is funding your activities in the city. Their exact nature and reasons for sending you there vary from faction to faction but suiffice it to say you work for them. And what you're doing for them is collecting warpstone, a resource that's scattered throughout the maps. You will periodically have deliveries to fill for them where they require a particualr amount of warpstone. Failing to make those deliveries will eventually lose you the game so try to make them on time. Other than that you will be levelling up your warriors and your warband, as well as you as a player via the Veteran System whereby you get perks like additional starting gold and access to Veteran Skills. Your warband will gain stat increases, more strategy points and offence points, as well as gaining skill points to spend on the bewildering array of passive and active skills available (warning: they aren't cheap, especially when you master a skill). Some of your guys will gain access to spells, and as you level up new hero types (and eventually the mighty Impressives) will be come available to your warband.  You'll also loot more powerful equipment and begin discover magical formulae that allow you to place marks on your weapons and armour, that do a variety of things.All in all I would definitely recommend the game. I very much enjoy it and can't wait to have a try at multiplayer (I've only done single player thus far), where I think the game will really shine. Just be aware that it is a hardcore exsperience. You will lose matches, you will have people get injured and die, your equipment will be looted from their bodies, you will struggle for gold to pay your warband and buy skills and replacement warriors. That's an integral part of Mordheim and might mean that the game isn't for you, which is fine. It is for me though, I absolutely love it!

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												Mordheim.This game is definetly NOT for everybody, in fact it is very niche. All you 30+ gamers will like it a lot. I have grown up playing turn based strategy games, which were very popualr in the 90's and been waiting for a good title for years.Playing this game will require careful planning and a lot of patience. In exchange it is a very rewarding experience and a serious time sink.After playing for some hours, my advice:take only easy missions for as long as you can. Be careful to keep the deadline with your shipments -though i don't know what is going to happen if you don't, i did it so far, but based on the rest of the game it will not be good for you.Gather the green crystals during missions, you have to produce a given number after some battles, like a tax.When engaging on missions, keep your group together, always use ambush stance and charge as much as you can. Avoid being charged is essential.All of your enemies will be evil scum who try to kill your soldiers. You must keep them alive!Your hero will become a terminator.If you loose a battle nothing punishing happens, in fact you won't have a flawless campaign.Don't get too attached to any of your soldiers, they might die during any mission.If you play recklessly, your soldiers will get knocked out. Be patient or you will be angry. Luck is not on your side vs CPU, but not unfair either.On low level, don't bother with scavenging, don't make detours for a chest. Stay alive and gather crytals instead.You can visit your wagon during missions and put items in the chest, making room on your solder to pick more stuff up.Your soldiers dont necessarily die when they hit the floor in a battle. After the mission you will get to know if he died, needs some days to recover, got some long lasting negative state, or recovers fully.The loot your soldier is carrying is lost if he gets knocked out on a mission (very frustrating)If the enemy warband is loosing, they tend to flee the battle, making the goals of the missons very hard to complete.Be careful using the shop not to buy items instead of selling (menus look like made with consoles in mind sadly), i spend half my gold by mistake when i tried to sell my junk.Pros:If you play it correctly it can be a very enjoyable and rewarding experienceArt direction is very well doneSolid rules and well executed gameplayBug free and very stable (Win10x64)4 factionsWARHAMMER FANTASY TURN BASED GAME!!!Meh:1 music track throughout the whole gmae and its about 5 minutes long. It is well written and sounds good, but seriously....No voice acting during combat. I think adding a lot of varied one-liners during combat would make this game 2 times better.Character models are  limited to one or two per faction and the customisation is lackluster to say the least. I never played tabletop WH, but if im correct, the painting and pimping the figures is half the fun.Console style camera, menus and controll are still horrible and shameful on pc. I hated the new X-COM for that and it is very similar in this game too. Auto camera actions are not optional.The game looks so much worse then the sample pictures which is a mistery since the screenshots are nothing special.Animation is very repetitve and overall not very excitiongThis game is doing so much things good and is for a very misstreated part of the players out there. With more work (patches, graphic update and new races pls!) it could be an outstanding game. Definetly pick it up if you are and oldshool gamer.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												By the numbers:  91/100The Short Review:Do you like the following?Knights of the Old RepublicX-Com (the original moreso than that modern... thing)Tactical squad-scale combat simulationsTurn-based gamesThe old SSI DnD gold box gamesWarhammer loreIf you answered yes to all of the above, push the Buy button.  I can guarantee you will not be disappointed.The Long Review:Part 1, The GoodIn the way of a preface, I've not played the Mordheim boardgame, but I am a Warhammer player from the very beginning of the franchise.  I ran a Warhammer FRP campaign while aboard ship (The USS Tarawa, to be precise) in 1991.  I later got into the miniature scene-- both the WH and WH40K side -- and I've a deep love of the Warhammer universe, especially the fantasy side.  This game fairly oozes Warhammer atmosphere.There is an attraction in managing a party of characters in an RPG that cannot be duplicated by MMOs.  It creates an emotinal investment born of the natural leadership impulse in competitive personalities.  Seeing your warband grow stronger and more powerful is a pleasure unto itself.  The recent resurgence in popularity of roguelikes is -- to me, at any rate -- an indication that many gamers are becoming bored by the "customer is always right" mentality that has come to dominate modern tripe-A game design.  Intelligent people get bored quickly when they always win the fight and there is no real threat of loss; only a challenge will keep them interested.  Mordheim provides challenge in spades.The developers of Mordeim understand that being a leader is the imporatant part of a tactical wargame.  Gradually developing your warband into a force to be reckoned with is the point of a successful party-based RPG.  The individual warriors become real to you; they are people to be trained and used to greatest effect, rather than disposable products of a factory.  The loss of a trained warrior has a real impact on your long-term strategy, as it should.  But it also opens up new avenues for advancement, forcing you to consider alteratives that you may not have seen before, often resulting in a complete rethink of your approach.Do not misunderstand me; this game WILL make you mad.  There will be matches where the RNG gods will frown upon your existence and you'll wonder if any of your party have actually even held a weapon before.  But there will also be engagements where everything goes right, where the universe smiles upon you, where you dominate your foes so completely that you will be convinced no one can stand against you... until the next battle.  That is the essence of a good tactical wargame, and Mordheim has it in spades.The beauty of the game is that any given engagement may or may not favor you.  Sometimes you will be allowed to deploy to greatest advantage, other times you will be caught off guard, scrambling to get your team together.  Much as with real war, the enemy doesn't wait until the situation favors you, rather you must analyze, adapt, and attempt to overcome.  A word of advice:  your first priority is always to Get the Band Back Together.  As a squad, you are strong.  As individuals... Well, there's a very old aphorism in the Marine Corps:  never employ the soda strategy.  SODA is an acronymn for Spread Out, Die Alone.Plan your strategy.  Train your squad.  Fight smart.  That's Mordheim.Part 2: The BadThere are a few minor issues with the game.  The most prominent is looting.  The rules are written in such a way that you must make looting items -- especially wyrdstone -- your first priority.  I put this in the bad category, but it's not necessarily all bad.  I understand the background:  you are a mercenary force in Mordheim.  Your reason for being there is to acquire the extremely valuable wyrdstone and sell it, either to your sponsor or alternate factions.  That's good; it's a great mechanic, as it forces you to always consider what you can get out of any given engagement and balance it against the risk of splitting up your force.  The problem comes with the loot rules.  You can ONLY loot that wyrdstone when you're standing on top of it during active play.  Even if you defeat the enemy and you're standing on top of an entire field of wyrdstone, you can't loot it afterwards.Imagine that you're a bank robber, (you're not I know, but just put yourself in his shoes for a moment).  You hold up a bank, you kill all of the guards and tie up all the patrons.  Now it's time to loot that vault over there fifteen feet away from you, right?  Nope!  You killed all the guards, so it's game over.  No loot for you. If you wanted the money in the vault, well by God you should have looted it while you were killing the guards, eh?  That makes sense, right?  OF COURSE IT DOESN'T.  But that's the loot mechanic in Mordheim.I understand the balance issues.  The devs don't want you to be able to loot the whole map, as it will result in a rapid build-up of gold and you'll easily defeat the AI.  I get it.  But there should be one full turn after you defeat the enemy warband wherein you can loot what you can reach.  Because killing an enemy while you're standing in a field of wyrdstone and not being able to BEND OVER AND PICK IT UP before the match ends is... well, it's just frickin' stupid -- boardgame rules notwithstanding.Part 3:  The UglyConsolization.  The interface was designed from the outset for a console release, despite the fact that the game's initial release is on PC.  I can deal with it, but it does become annoying from time to time.  For example, during deployment phase, you can't simply click where you want to deploy a warrior.  Oh no; you must go through every single possible position One. At. A. Time. in third person view.  On missions where there are dozens of possible deployment points, this can become extraordinarily tedious, since you can't deploy your warriors from the map.  You have to constantly switch between third person and map for each warrior for EACH POINT, examining sight lines and location.  It takes far, far longer than it should and is an inherent weakness of play-with-your-thumbs design.  It has a smaller but noticeable impact in the warband management screens.  An irritant more than an annoyance, really.  But it's there.That being said, however, the console-biased interface is not game-breaking.  I put up with KOTOR's ridiculous console interface because it was such a great game.  The same is true here.Part 4: The Indifferent S L O W.  I put this in the indifferent category because everyone will see it differently.  I love slow progression; the slower the better, in fact.  If you're impatient, craving a continual stream of satisfaction and reinforcement, you will almost certainly dislike this game.  It takes many, many hours of play to advance your warband even a little.  Magic-using characters, for example, start off weak and essentially useless; you must spend a lot of time and gold to make them powerful.  But with enough time and a great deal of gold, they can become the lynchpin of your strategy.  Leaders are vulnerable (some moreso than others) and must be carefully nurtured into powerhouses who can sway the outcome of a battle.  If you're looking for quick, easy satisfaction, you will not find it in Mordheim.  This is a game of time and patience, development and planning.   If the idea of investing an hour into a turn-based battle that would play out in mere minutes in real time annoys you, I cannot recommend you buy this game. Part 5:  Random Thoughts While Drinking Some Liquer Called Ke-Ke Which Tastes EXACTLY Like Key Lime PieBest Mechanic Ever:  Morale is separate from morale impact (on death).  It's far too complex to explain, (Steam says No More Words For Me), but essentially Morale is unit cohesion while Morale Impact is unit fragmentation.  Just try it.  Once you figure it out, you'll see the awesome genius of it.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												This game is pretty good, albeit far from perfect. The mood is amazing and immersive and the gameplay is really solid and innovating. The 4 clans (5 if you get the expansion) all play very different and provide vastly different experiences, even if some of the DLC has toned down some of uniqueness of some clans (e.g. adding a very range-focused character in a clan that had no ranged characters).The game has a few problems though.The AI is weak. It will try to find you and then run straight to you with every unit, which makes it easy to pick them off one by one if you keep your warband together. Worst of all, it will constantly get stuck with pathfinding. After a while, when you've leveled up your warband to the max or near max, you'll just feel like you are grinding without purpose. There are campaign/story missions...but they get boring soon.When you choose a mission, the composition of your opponent will be selected based on your warband. So if you have 10 units, you will face a big warband and if you have 5, you will face a smaller warband. Also, if you take one of those expensive "impressive" units, the opponent will have one also and if you don't, your opponent won't either. This means it's no use investing on a big and diverse warband and you are better off keeping your warband small.Finally, despite the AI, the game is difficult as your characters can easily injured and maimed and become worse. Also, especially in the beginning they are very frail, so it's very easy to have them dropping like flies. Once you get how the game works, you can easily avoid it though, but in the beginning it will be very frustrating, also because you can save at your wish.

You can legitimately watch a twenty hour warband become critically flawed after a series of statistically impossible rolls, when you've done everything right and made no mistakes. Nope. Graphics are great, gameplay is good when it isn't so ridiculously frustrating as to defeat any fun it previously offered.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												I played this game since early access and I have to say it has come a long way.Warband management is easy enough and has enough depth, without falling into unnecessary micro-management.You equip gear and items to your soldiers, level them up, buy skills and that's that. If you are into it, it also offers (limited) optical customization options for your soldiers.The turn-based battles are VERY intense. You always end up thinking about the best placement of your troops. "Should I run back to my cart with my leader or hero and get rid of the warpstones that cripple him in combat? If I do that, then my weaker characters will be without backup."Decisions are hard to make and they are always final. Your high level master Skaven assassin might end up loosing an arm in battle, thus rendering him nearly useless in the future (only one one-handed weapon, no shields, no climbing, etc.), and so on.Bashing this game for too much RNG is absolutely stupid, since it is an adaption of a table top game played with ... tadaaa ... DICE! Saying it is too difficult, because it doesn't allow to "save scum" is also pretty useless. If your people get slaughtered, then it happens in 90% of the cases due to wrong decisions made by the player. In the original table top version you cannot undo your turns, either. It is an honest adaption, although it lacks content compared to the original (a lot of warbands still missing, etc.). This is definitely NOT a game you will finish in one or two attempts in one afternoon and that's exactly what I love about it.It is like playing a Warhammer/X-Com mix with permanent iron man mode.It is glorious!Graphics are neat. They are not impressive, but they catch the atmosphere well enough and do a good job. That also means that this game runs on weaker machines with 4 GB of RAM and any 1 GB GPU.
