content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												Okay so this game is really good at its core gameplay! but only to a point I mean so basically the only way to be able to play on equal grounds with your friends is to make brand new warbands or use Exploits which I will not mention due to the fact they're a must to have a warband that isn't completely maimed after a certain point because the Smuggler's Den system is absolutely insane, You can actually drain a map entirely of its resource of Wyrdstone several matches in a row and that won't even be enough sometimes and having to put my units in danger to get Wyrdstone because of the fact that They're in even more danger if I don't fill out those orders the warband will shatter in time. The hired swords costing as much as 650 coins at level 3 is completely uncalled for that makes no sense If someone has that much spare money that warband is much past the use of a level 3 character with the constant upholding of payments you're required to do, I realize the developers are going for progression and that feeling of accomplishment but the reason the most voted helpful comment is negative and with many of the same complaints is because that's simply the case and the percentages shown are not accurate, to not factor in the dodge chance or some other factor into the deciding player's action is unfair you're missing shots that are 1/20 consistently because you didn't have the information and now you have to fire a level 10 character because the stupidity checks he now has make him useless more than 70% of the timeIt simply creates the feeling or helplessness which is the worst thing a player can feel in a game, Some cool ideas could be presented to fix some of these, Mercenaries could use Steam Punk limbs as replacements at a price, Cult could have Skeletal limbs using magic from the "Shadowlord" the Skaven could have re-attached limbs threw sewing like the rat Ogre its just that the Helpless feeling needs a supliment and my gameplay shouldn't be permanently destroyed by some streak of bad luck it simply isn't acceptable because I love the game I've always been a Warhammer fan and I can't tell anyone to spend 40 dollars on something they're going to get that feeling from

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												I am glad that a company took the time to take an older game that wasnt avaible to the masses and port it to the PC, and I have spent many hours playing this game. I honestly like the concept, and feel it is a great game...For people who are use to this type of game. It has a steep learning curve, and most of the people I have introduced into this game have struggled with it for quite some time, but that was not the only issue. Another flaw that stands out is its % System, and I am not a programer so I can not say wether or not It is working the way it should. However I can tell you that it is infuriating missing 90%s all the time, and this paired with the unforgiving system of losing soliders leaves an undesirable aftertaste. This is coming from someone who has spent over 200 hours playing Xcom Longwar, And I can honestly say it feels as though the chance system should be reviewed. I would not recommend this to people unfamilar with this system, But overall I feel it is a good game.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Good game but make sure you have a high-powered rig or you won't be able to enjoy the full graphical goodness.  This is a technically challenging game.  To excel you must really study the various attributes and capabilities of your warband and how they impact gameplay.I have a lot more hours now playing this game and have to say it is one of my favorite games.  The early levels are challenging as your warband is very weak.  Suggest reading some of the excellent strategy tips on the community hub.  Wish there were more Mordheim city level maps as the 4 or so maps for the regular encounters start to get fairly boring after a while.The campaigns are good but tough.  I suggest having a fairly strong warband - at least level 5 before taking on the first campaigns.  Once you are at level 5 or above the campaigns are good.  They almost always have impressives so be ready for that.  A weak warband level 2 -- 4 probably won't do well.  You  can't get impressives in your warband until you are at level 5.

												I wanted to like this game, I really did since I'm an avid player of the tabletop game. Mordheim: City of the Damned has all the elements that make a tactical game fun. I could sense the fun to be had with this game, but all I ended up with was more frustration than fun. With limited gameplay time, this game is getting uninstalled and downvoted.

												7/10  Good game that aims for hardcore players.But i have a few issues with it.- Lack of options around the difficulty, as well as options to save when you want.- No correct numbers around what the chance of a succesful attack or move is. content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												This is a Random Number game with heavy grind. There is ridiculously harsh penalty for losing at the start. Your starting warband can lose all its important equipment through random rolls before it ever gets started. Once you get a good warband the random number generator can decide all your good characters die. HA HA HA delete and start over! Your characters will miss 10 plus attacks of better than 75 percent to hit but the AI NEVER does, Your high dodge of 50 or 65 percent will stop 1 out of 5 attacks if you are lucky. Its more dumb luck than strategy.If you try to talk to the developers the game has a very poorly behaved community who will try to stop you. The game looks nice but  had very slow loads. Every time you play a scenario the game stops and downloads.  It should be called Waitheim City of the Download. There is no comparison tool or any useful way to plan out your character builds. I had to go find the original minatures game site to get important information. They spent their money on some hack actor who annoys you with the same winning or losing message over and over and over. Its like nails on a chalkboard to lose and then wait while this imbecile cackles out bad acting.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												This game started off with amazing potential and, at it's roots, is fun in a twisted, masochistic kind of way. Unfortunately, the developers have got it into their head that it's a good business practice to cater to the super hardcore masochist crowd and ONLY to that crowd. In the same vein as Dark Souls, you'll really only enjoy this game if your idea of fun is getting brutally mauled over and over and over again, mostly because random dice rolls decided you're going to die.Then there's the community. God forbid you have a concern that the game might not be perfect, for the tiniest voice is discontent is met with contempt, scorn, and mockery from the aforementioned masochists. They will actually TELL you to ♥♥♥♥ off and don't play the game if you don't enjoy the savage beatings the game gives you, even if you did everything right, and yes, you CAN do everything right and still get your warband destroyed because of the RNG, but the hardcore crowd will blame it all on you, tell you that you suck, and should either suck it up and enjoy it or leave. They seem to have no idea how detrimental to the game's longevity this is, nor do they appear to care, so long as they preserve their precious "hardcore" status.The devs, unfortunately, have plainly expressed their intent to NOT implement certain features (like a basic Save/Load mechanic) because they want to be "hardcore like Dark Souls," they have no plans to expand upon the pathetically lackluster customization, and generally have made it very clear that they don't intend to do anything but cater to the most hardcore of hardcore players.In short, if you liked Dark Souls or XCOM on Hardcore Ironman, you'll like this. If getting bent over and destroyed at the whims of the mad ocelot god that lives in Jeff's head doesn't sound like your idea of fun, skip this game.

Early Access Review
								[ EARLY ACCESS ]This means not all features are present.As far as I understand at least for chaos side, only skirmish is available.There may be a campaign for chaos if not all races in the future but it is not yet implemented.I run the game on a old laptop MSI FX603 and the game runs smooth with low setting gfx.The game is interesting at the core. Stats seem perhap confusing at first but reading with automatically gauge an understanding of characeristics and capabilities.Gameplay functions seem long to reach between Q and E rolling out left or right but the game is playable and I am hopeful more optimization will come along the way.This game is for casual turn base strategy players. The game is slow paced.  The atmosphere is great. Decors on low on my low spec machine are ok. Pretty unusually slow and long SKIRMISH loading time (2 minutes or a bit more) for my old machine using an IDE 5k4 RPM hard drive but again this is early access and thing "may" improve along the way.I recommend this game to anyone who like to pose a strategy while 3D strategy element at first is somewhat boggling, anyone quickly take marks of position and location to defend, ambush, attack, skirmish, flee, counter and more, and the so the game suddenly deepens!

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												This game has 1300+ positive reviews and only about 400 negative, however, 4 out of the first 5 reviews you see are negative. That would almost make someone instantly change their mind about buying this game. Why aren't their more positive reviews up front for people to see? And steam, shouldn't the out dated reviews be moved down the list so people can see reviews about the current version? (I know iPhone and iPad app store only keep reviews about the current version.)In my opinion, the recent patch totally fixed most of the RNG problems and a bunch other glitches. About people who said that their character "missed 5 95% shots in a row ". I'm gonna make an arguement. First of all, max level (10) leaders and heros have 9 offense points, which are enough for 4 one-handed hits or 3 two-handed hits. If your heros or headers are using ranged weapon, they could do 3 gun shots or 4 bow shots. A max level impressive warrior also has 9 offensive points, so 4 hits also. So I don't understand where you got those 5 shots.... So why don't you guys be a responsible reviewer and remove those negative reviews that are not true to the current version any more? Plus most of those posters just sounded like they did not know how the game works.But anyway, Mordheim is an awesome turn-based strategy game. At first I played it on my boyfriend's account and leveled up my sister warband to 10. Then my boyfriend bought me a copy, and since then I have played over 250 hours. I have enjoyed this game a lot. To those who have enjoyed Mordheim, I suggest you all write a positive review to bring more players into this game. I believe we all need more skirmish players!

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												This game, dare I say, is even better than the tabletop version. No arguments over line of sight, no disagreements over if someone is in charge range or not, no loud discussions over the terrain features and how they affect your movement and most importantly, no one is getting dice pelted at their face when the above situations occur. There are some features of the tabletop version that I like and that are missing from this iteration however these are small things, and far outweighed by the impressive array of skills, a much better percentile system (over the old D6) and better opportunities to really customise your gang of misfits.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												This game does not deserve this many bad reviews.  The game is not high priced. Has affordable DLCs even when not on discount. Its a visual beauty and the gameplay harsh and unforgiving.  You make yourself a warband which you can customize to some extend. And you set off in the grimm city of Mordheim to gatehr wyrdstones for your faction.  You win some and you lose some, but everything comes down to choices as you won't be able to sweep the battlefield after the match is done.  If you lose a fight your merc have the potential to get wounded this includes losing limbs, eyes and even permadeath.   IF you have an unlucky streak you might find yourself a crippled warband and you will have to reroll again.  The game is not designed for an easy game with godmode on.  Expect to die, a lot.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												This will be short, cause I'm not a pro at this.Very poor/lazy animations, and the character models could be a better. The aesthetics of the terrain/buildings are very nice though, and in theme with the Warhammer world. On topic of animations, the trap and parry/dodge stance animations are a little on the long side, and the stance animations are a little odd looking.For the most part though, I very much enjoy this game. The character leveling is fairly deep, actually deeper than the source material I think (I admit, never played table-top Mordheim, but I've got experience with tabletop Warhammer Fantasy, the two being very similar). There could be a lot more variety in mission types, and deployment is kinda clumsy, but game-play overall is fun.It should be noted too that the game suffers from XCOM-itis, in that RNG can really hose you from time to time.Would I recommend? Absolutely. And I am. I hope that the devs release more warbands.. I'd love to try the Witchhunters and IUndead.  I do find it intersting that several of the characters they did release dont appear to be in the original game (although I will also add that I only have the main book, and dont know if there is any other source material). The Poison Wind Globadier has always been a Warhammer Fantasy favorite of mine so its cool to see it in this.Ok so it wasn't as short as I said it would be.TL;dr: Go in with low graphical expectations and you'll have fun. :D

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												This game is amazing. I've been playing the original Mordheim since it came out. It's not exactly like the table top version, but it does a great job of capturing the atmosphere. The campaign is open enough to allow limitless street skirmishes and build your warband the way you want. Character customization is spectacular. And I love the risk in every mission. You can spend 20 missions building up a hero just to have him criippled or killed by a skaven hiding in a closet.The best part to me is the city itself. At a glance, it doesn't look like much, but on the ground, it's a labrynth. Climbing to the top of a ruined house in search of wyrdstone or treasure, hiding in doorways to ambush enemies. It's just like I imagined playing the tabletop.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												First mission almost my whole warband gets wiped and i only killed 1 of them. Mission randomly ended and said i had succeded and completed the objective.I make this review as somone who plays xcom, wastelands 1 & new 1, divinity:OS ect..The gameplay is incredibly boring every character seems to be the same just with different numbers (Though some might not have a ranged weapon though u can just equip them with 1) same animations, same abilities, same stances, even look the same. Then there is the leaders, heroes and henchmen which are all the same thing anyway, infact my henchmen seemed to be signifcantly better than the heroe and leaderThis game is so overly complicated when it doesnt need to be. The gameplay is so simple and dumbed down (walk over to the guy and hit him, set a stance, end turn   Mayby set to overwatch instead). But they just have all these terrible UIs filled with symbols and numbers that really dont need to be their. The tutorial is basically just walls of text at random during a setup skirmish where u cant really even do any of things its teaching u, instead sometimes the enemy will for reasons i will never understand.Customization may as well not be there, you can choose from about 10 colours 3 of which are black and 3 of which are red (i played the chaos guys mayby the others are better?) and each bit has mayby 1 other style which might add a spike or symbol to that armor piece.For $40 its buggy, low quality, low content mess, that seems to have been made by fans of the board game that were very inexperienced with games development.$40 for 4 classes each with 7 apperently identical character types and no story (unless you include diologue and text dumps in load screens).Oh and ranged characters are♥♥♥♥♥ cost extra points to use ranged weapons, more points to reload, more point when hey have to switch to mele on there 2nd combat turn and on top of all that they do ♥♥♥♥ all damage and lose 30% accuracy just because they target is engaged in combat for some reason.edit:Decided to try again whilst waiting for some other trash to download.The continue button after loading the save didn't work. ♥♥♥♥it i said ill try skaven then.Skaven were significantly more powerful and actually had usefule leader but all the other issues were still present. Managed to win a mission with a few casualties. Saved the game came back later couldn't load. 'So marking this game as unplayable, until they fix the many bugs.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
												So my leader was against enemy leader with a 84% to hit and all I need was 1 hit to knock him out of action but somehow the enemy leader dodges 2 of my attacks and manage to knock my leader out of action when my leader had more than half hp left. If you want a game that rolls favors AI, this is your game. Its like you always roll 1 and the enemy rolls 20. There was another time where I literally wasted all my enemies except one tiny soldier but that soldier manage to do a critical ambush attack on one of my soldiers and instantly knock him out of action and I lose the morale rout roll and lost the map. Its like the developers couldn't make a decent AI so instead they just give AI 100% rng for attack, dodge and parry. This game is beyond frustating. If you dont mind the AI having that huge advantage then go for it. I dont mind a challenge but this is not fair nor fun to play for me.update: after a dozen of missions or so I decided to try the first campaign mission. Enemy has infinite reinforcement and a giant skaven ogre that attacks 3 time, which if it all hits will one shot any unit you have. For added difficulty the troll appears inside the small tunnel so you cannot overwhelm it with numbers, only 1 or 2 units can attack the ogre at a time.And the objectives is to find and move 15 explosive barrels inside the enemy tunnels. Yup fending off neverending enemy hordes while moving barrels. As you would expect I lost the mission. Dont bother buying this game even if it is in sale unless you like losing a mission for stupid reason like enemy always causes crit and or stun damage, while your's rarely proc. RNG heavily favor AI. Another example, I literally have to put enough enemies out of action to lower the morale to less than 0 and get an automatic win in a map cause the AI keep winning the morale rout roll check which starts at 44 btw. I have no doubt that if the morale rout check could go lower than 0 the AI would pass it with flying colors. This game only makes you feel angry and frustated at the RNG(its not really a random number generator its a whatever favors the AI number generator)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												I love this game... If you are a Warhammer fan, I'd expect you to have a similar response, though there is a steep learning curve.  Young players (possibly with ADHD ;) complain that the game is too hard at first, but the challenge is part of the excitement and fun.  Once you figure it out, it is addictive!  The bugs, long load times, and other problems that players justifiably complained about in earlier reviews have been fixed; the game is now a joy to play.  The Devs care and are responsive to player concerns and questions.  All the DLC is worthy too.  Chaos, Skaven, and the Witch Hunters are my favorite factions to play, but they're all distinctive and interesting. Like other reviewers, I'd prefer more character customization options and maps, but those are minor quibbles.  Tip: Make sure you go through the tutorials before you start your first warband. In short, this is one of my all time favorite Warhammer games... I can't stop playing it...

												I was playing with my cult of the posses warband and I was about to attack an enemy with my archer, selected aim to better my chances to hit the enemy, 95% possibility to hit...MISSThen attacked with my other archer in my next turn, again used aim to better my chances, 95% chance to hit again...MISSThe percentage to hit is just an ornament on the screen, the game doesn't calculate the actual percentage you have to hit a specific target, I kept on trying to hit an enemy while having 95% to hit, which is the cap, and missed five times IN A ROW.This game uses the same character models for a clase, so you will have up to 6 clones of the same model in your warband, and some models are just so ugly -sister's leader- no I wouldn't recommend this game in its current state.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Don't buy this game.  It's actually worse than if it was just awful because it's just good enough to convince you to invest hours into it only to set you in a horribly lopsided scenario where you watch helplessly as all the heroes you've worked hard to build up are mercilously beaten down in situation so one-sided as to leave you completely helpless.  Then watch them die and become disfigured rendering your whole warband essentially worthless.  You could argue this is an attempt to reflect the Mordheim miniature game, which can be pretty brutal, but knowing it is pretty brutal, in the miniature game you can volentarily rout a mission pretty early on when you see the situation is hopeless and minimize casualties.  This game forces you to continue suffering a beat down until nearly all your forces are taken out.I like a challenge, I like the gritty nature of the Mordheim world, but I have too much to do and too many games to choose from to invest hours of my life into something that crushes your efforts that callously and so do you.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												Some games strongly rely on grinding to become powerful and successful. This game keeps the worst part of that, it's just grinding and that's all. Choose one of the only four factions that are in the game. Choose a bunch of warriors between a few types of units to assign to the only three classes that form the band (leader, heroes and adepts). Put them again and again on the field to scavenge for wyrdstone and steal the enemy's flag. Level them up so you can collect wyrdstone with more efficiency and most important of all, do not let the rival gang cripple one of your fellow servants because if the wound is permanent that character is ruined for the rest of the game.I still don't get what's the fun about the purpose of the game. Despite of that I still not fully regret the purchase because the graphics, the ambientation and the atmosphere are great. But that's all I can remark from the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												So after not playing this game for about 2 weeks due to lying difficulty, horrible RNG, and being punished for something I can't control (RNG) I finally picked it up again seeing how it was apperantly fixed. Low and behold I'm wrong. I was severly disappointed seeing not once but twice, in a row, my leaders get brutally destroyed. I would be more forgiving had it not blatantly been the OP AI. I can not at all recommend a game that is buffing the AI instead of just adding in a bit more code. My mercanie, using sword shield, is fighting right now with back up. Misses a 73% charg, ok I just came back not like it's going to be like that all the time. Get smacked in the face by a two hander for 48 damage, 1/3 of my health is gone and the enemy didn't even have a buff. Dread instantly sets in seeing the enemy leader now whip a corner, he has a mace and shield. Ok not going to be so bad my guy might still survive this! Get charged, ok I'm in 44% parry stance, charges are usually pretty low with 60-70% of hitting I should be able to parry, I mean, RNG was supposedly re-worked! Nope, 45 damage + stun on a charge. Another attack followed by it and leader already dead on a normal in my FIRST GAME. Oh my guy was able to get ONE hit off, a 22 damage hit. Now the enemy leader was buffed, he had green (not white) damage indicators but for a 100% damage increase buff? ok that's just dandy why bother with this mission. I was literally forced to restart on the first god dam mission. This isn't hardcore, this is just set up for player failure! THAT'S NOT HARDCORE! So far, from teh two restarts that I had RNG is still blatantly in favor of the AI as they never once missed out of their 10-12 hits on me while I had a 2/4 chance of hitting majority being 80% of hitting. Difficulty is still blatantly lying to your face about "normal" missions which really just means enemies are tougher, more health and damage. That's not what normal means in most games, normal means a fair battlefield everyone is equal not AI are heavily favored and buffed. I could forgive the game for buffing (even though it's a 45% ♥♥♥♥ing buff) on Brutal and deadly, the ones that are meant to be a challenge and far more difficult. Normal should not though and it makes the game far more frustrating especially when piled on top of the unforgiving punishments and RNG. The die rolls for dodge/parry are different from hit chances. They do not affect each other, at all. It's more along the lines if you rolled a hit but your opponent rolled a dodge, the dodge will over right the hit. I'm going to the feedback forums themselves and see if something might be going on, a bug or glitch mayhap with this RNG since it's supposedly fixed.All in All the game is still buggy, hopefully that's the case, or clearly throwing over powering AI at you to compensate for it's failure of "hardcore". I'm still going to play it due to my love and adoration for Warhammer but to recommend this game to someone else is just something I can't live with. I keep hearing it gets better as you survive and play but my question is, how can it get better when I can't even get past the first day?edit: it's becoming more and more difficult to keep this review from a scathing hate review. The RNG is becoming more notible in just either being "oh my god I can hit everything!" to "I'm missing 95% all the time and my 70% dodge is NEVER dodging!". This will never be in the case of the AI however which is the most infuriating part, they seem unaffected by any form of faultiness, they'll have a miss here and there but it doesn't occur often. If you want a game that's a challenge, fun, and rewarding go play Xcom, this game just offers the challenge but none of the reward or fun.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												This game needs some serious balancing. The RNG is is out of whack, spent the better part of 4 hours getting into melee bundles where the entire enemy warband almost one shot all my members including hero and leader (60+ damage a swing) where as I can only deal 15-20 (assuming I'm lucky enough to hit at all) no matter the troop type so if im lucky 3 or 4 of my members can take down one enemy, this is with a starting warband on what was meant to be a basic map. Resource gathering is far too hard in the early part of the campaign and it's far too easy to be left with no warband and no gold or wyrdstone to be able to come back from. I appreciate the gaem is suppossed to be hardcore in that your band is persistent but the difficulty curve is waaay too high to be fun. Tried 3 different warbands varying between ranged or melee heavy or a mix and none of them could win a match or gather any resource of note. Found the menus and interface annoying and hard to navigate, causing some frustarting mistakes in battle, nothing feels intuitive and all the information feels like an overdose so nothing really sinks in. I did like the look and atmosphere of the game and it's always nice to have some customization options so that kept me entertained naming my bands and coming up with backstories, shame they all got hacked to bits  so deftly by uber buffed ai. More warbands choices might draw me back eg. Vampire Counts, but I'd be very cautious after this 1st taste tbh. Really unsatisfying and frustrating experience in it's current form. So disappointed. :<

content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												The game is a bit intimidating at the start but if you can push through it the game really opens up and becomes a lot more fun. Currently the only real complaints I have are: 1. the game has a limited amount of ways to make money early on and if you arent completeing certain tasks it can be easy to go bankrupt if you dont keep some money in reserve. Try not to spend too much money early on in the game or you can wind up losing just because you're broke. 2. Some of the factions seem a bit unbalanced in some ways. The skaven seem to have a lot of health early on and what I mean is their weakness is supposed to be low health but early on they seem to have around the same as everyone else but are more maneuverable and do more damage, so at the very start skaven have an advantage. Later on however it balances out as their sustainability problem compounds making them work as intended, as fast moving and precise ambushers.I enjoy the customizability and I enjoy the gameplay and I also like how injuries can be cosmetic. For example one of my guys now has a peg leg he got from a battle after his leg got severed from falling in battle. I also enjoy how countering other factions requires different tactics like countering skaven you have to stick together and overpower them because if you run off with your warband split up they'll just out maneuver you and hit one group with everything they have however if the skaven are ever caught split up and you can move fast enough you can drop one or two and push it in your favor.It's really a fun game that I recommend giving a try as there are almost no games with this kind of gameplay out there right now.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												A turn-based squad RPG with roguelite elements inspired by the Games Workshop franchise. Player combat takes place on different locations of Mordheim, offering a new strategic challenge at every match. The static setting and the evenly matched skirmishes gives it the feel of an "arena"-type game.Out of combat, players manage their characters and with a reserve pool avalible early on, the game feels similar to Blood Bowl (another Games Workshop franchise). Characters avalible in the four factions are highly customizable, also owing to the tabletop minature background. Characters accumulate injuries and experiance over time which makes each run in Mordheim a unique challenge, as players are tasked to prioritize between collecting the valuable Wyrdstones and fighting the competing group. Comes with multiplayer so you can play online after getting tired of the extremely poor singleplayer AI. Easily recommended to Warhammer strategy fans.

content:
Posted: January 19
												Pros:Interesting team rpg progressionStrategic gameplayDifferent factions offering various playstylesLots of replayabilityGreat visualsCons:Steep learning curveRNG aspect for calculating hits, dmg, etc, can be frustrating sometimesVsing AI can get stale once you start vsing other playersConclusionMordheim: City of the Damned does very well to replicate a tabletop game onto a pc format. The RNG dice rolls for calculations will deter some people, but it's very much like playing cards or gambling. The frustration of fails at 90% chance is superseded by the success of 10% chances. You win some you lose some. The game allows you to strategically play your odds, establishing an interesting core gameplay mechanic.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												This is the first game i've taken the time to review on steam.  I would love to recommend it to people, but sadly i cannot in its current form.  If your looking for a game that is fair or at the least plays by the same rules you have to, then keep moving.  This game is designed from the ground up to be unfair towards the player.  All because they are unable to make an even remotely decent A.I.  You WILL miss 9/10 attacks, even when they have a 95% chance to hit,  Meanwhile the enemy will roll 5's all day so they get multiple criticals and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t hits in a row.  I don't have a problem with RNG.  It is obvious however when playing this game that the deck is severaly stacked.  I wouldn't doubt if there is a 50% chance on every roll to add 30 or more to your roll.  You will NEVER roll a 1 or anything near it.  You will however roll 85-95 on every other roll.  This wouldn't be a problem if they allowed you to choose if you wanted high or low rolls to be good, however that is sadly not the case.  On top of that, every match that you do really well on(complete all the objectives/no one is taken out of action) you will,for no reason, still have 1-3 heros with wounds that have to sit out for several days.   In case you are wondering if im just a baddie at the game, i have yet to lose a round yet.  Despite all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that causes me to curse and scream in fury at this game, it still cant manage to beat me.  Thats how BAD the A.I is.  They will walk the opposite direction of the nearest ally/enemy fighting to go stand in a random doorway and try to ambush something. Despite the fact no one is in that direction.  This means instead of feeling like you had a good match, or that perhaps you made a mistake and could learn from it and improve, you instead just got RNG'd.  The same goes for improving your characters.  You want to put a hero in heavy armor? Well, too bad.  You sure as hell aren't gonna be able to buy it from the shop.  Wanna two-handed sword instead of an axe? Well, F*ck you.  You damn better hope an enemy in one of the upcoming matches has one, and is stupid enough to rush you by himself so that after killing him you can actually loot the body.  Cause if his teamates are around you wont be able to stand close enough to loot it,  Do you want a specific enchant on your weapon or armor? Again, you can just f*ck off.  There is an amazing amount of them to choose from.  To bad they only way to get them is RNG from a mission reward unless you just so happen to want one of the horrible ones offered by the other factions.   Also what the hell is with the RNG time on deleveries?  Sure the last time you sent a shipment to the pit you were paid the next day.  This time?   Well its gonna take about 3 days.  Really?  You will never have enough gold to train the skills and spellls you want.  You will find yourself selling a ridiculous amount of looted treasure and stone, just to pay and heal up the scrubs on your team that get injured from stubbing their toe,  On top of that, why the hell do i have to pay these idiots AND supply the equipment for em?  Can they not supply their own tools/weapons and armor? Maybe the fact i've paid these idiots in the neighborhood of 500g a piece would mean they could pay for their own damn training and weapons?  Also spellcasting is useless in this game, unless you consider risking doing 9999 damage to yourself to MAYBE succeed in casting a spell that MIGHT reduce a random stat.(or other equally uselss spell.)  I kid you not.  Not even the 10th time i try to cast a spell and my only caster,and leader, manages to one shot himself.  I mean come the hell on.  Meanwhile the only negative you will ever see an enemy caster get is the on that just so happens to stun himself and EVERYONE near him.  "Oh, so his spell failed to cast, so my leader and two heros are now stunned,  Great,Tl;Dr :  If you ever see a programmer respond to this saying they have looked at the♥♥♥♥♥♥poor rng, buy the game, Otherwise this is just another Vermintide.  It looks like warhammer, almost feels like warhammer, and is only fun to die hard fans, and even then only briefly,

												Cons:- Heavy random number generator focus on most gameplay mechanics.- Enemies are scaled to the player's warband rating.- Lack of a minimap means constant backtacking with the fullscreen in combat map to make sure your warriors are heading in the right direction. - Story mode missions have tedious objectives with the purpose of prolonging the duration of the mission.- DLCs required to unlock additional warbands. - Many of the optional campaign objectives cannot be completed. Enemies will either concede or die too early before players can have a chance to complete them. This means a loss of experience points gained. They add up.  Rating: 4/10Did not enjoy aspect of the game. The customization was disappointing. The levels themselves were large but clunky in design. The combat felt unrewarding. For a freeform tactical turned base strategy game it failed to keep a turn based strategy fan like myself entertained. I suggest skipping it entirely.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												This Game is made all the more infuriating by how good it could be, but it is just frustration and anger wraped in a pretty bow. A brawl disquised as tactical combat. I had to delete it to prevent myself from trying to progress because I feel like if I smashed my head against this brick wall long enough I might find gold underneath. The cake is a lie, and this game is just a turn based third person shooter.After some time I decided to give the game another go, and really put in some hours to see if the game improves as you progress. It does, alot. If you can get past the first 10 missions there is a fun game underneath the pain and agony. I like games that punish poor decisions, not so much games that punish bad luck with rolls. This one is unfortunately the latter, a little good luck can get you a long way but the best flanking manouver can go horribly wrong when every attack misses even though it claims your odds are over 80%I still cannot recommend this game; even though I am personally enjoying it and will likely continue playing. Even a victory is a defeat early on as the route mechanics just do not function properly for low level groups making most optional objectives completely unattainable. If you are a stubborn sort who can get past the first 10 hours then go for it, otherwise look elsewhere.

Posted: December 10, 2015
												Very slick X-COM style game inspired by Games Workshop's Mordheim.  Pros:Permanent consequences force strategic and tough choicesLOTS of skills, upgrades and units4 initiatal warbands feel and play differently despite strong overlapsIt is faithful to original mordheim without being stuck to D6'sCons:AI can be pretty stupidIt's mordheim, prepare to HATE random chance.  (As a table top player, it was far far worse)-You'll miss key rolls to hit, climb, or cast spells-Your favorite character will die-You'll be on a roll then the next encounter is AMBUSH and suddenly all tactics are out the windo(This can suck by modern gaming standards, but that's part of the charm of the original)Loading times are stupid long - apparently nearly every aspect of map and oppenents team is randomly generated on the spotEarly campaign is boring.  You need at least 3-5 games before you get enough skills to build a warband to your liking and not just vanilla.  Once you hit level 3, then you're going places.  Overall, I would strongly recommend this game to roguelike fans, strategy game enthusiasts or nostalgic games workshop players.  It's not perfect, but its one of my favorits.

Product received for free
												I thought about getting this for some time. When the game came out for a free weekend, I was thrilled. However the trill was short lived when I actually started playing it. Some people have complained about the steep learning curve. Elite Dangerous has a steep learning curve, this has a learning cliff with no climbing ropes. The tutorial was not informative and crushingly boring. Meanwhile the campaign is half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and lacks much of a story other than: Go here, do this, kill this, loose half your men ect. The mechanics are very clunky and the overall camera controls are rediculusly constricting. The veiws that you get are third person and third person. This would not be so bad if it were like Dragon Age. It can take 3-4 rounds to kill an enemy one on one which will leave your man crippled regardless of whether or not he is covered in heavy armor or clad in a burlap sack. Weapon type is also imaterial a halberd/spear has nearly the same combat range as a sword or dagger wielding hostile. Bows are made useless from the combonation of short range and low damage. But the logic envolved with this is also flawed. Combat, especially in the story missions is encredibly one-sided and your entire team will run off under stupid conditions. Once I had the enemy down to one and backed into a corner 5 on 1 and lost the leader. All 4 of the others cut and run.  If this had nothing else to compair it to, we would think it was incredible, but let me make a list of games like this that are better.Dragon Age, all 3Divinity 2 Divinity Orginal SinPillars of EternityBaulders GateIcewind Dale Temple of Elemental Evil (TOEE) Dungeon SeigeBlackguards 1&2Your favorite game hereOn an up note, this does beat out Sword Coast. Then again, contracting Leishmaniasis beats that. My point is, there is no point in getting this when there are a slew of other games out there that are so so much better that cost far far less.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												I don't do many reviews but I thought i would put something for this game.(I have played quite a few hours on this with my offline PC)(Edit - Spell check lives again so corrected a lot of errors... Sadly was on an odd day)Personally i thought this was a good although very difficult game when i started, but i found despite the few issues and UI the game was actually quite good.If you are looking for another casual turn based game where you can just pick some classes and tank up then I would recommend avoiding this game. Every mistake you make will come back an haunt you at a later date including avoiding some side objectives,I think it would be easier if i gave a basic description of the pros and cons for this game...Camera: The camera is a 3rd person camera that locks onto the unit you are meant to be moving that turn, Doesn't allow free roaming with the camera and makes seeing around corners and in buildings a little more difficult when trying to avoid ambushes.Movement: This caught me off guard at first.. Using the standard movement keys WASD to navigate was a bit odd for a turn based game but once I figured out the blue circles were something akin to movement areas, you would only lose a movement point when changing to a different ring giving you free movement within your Movement points.Actions: This i found a little off at first but every action has a reaction.. Firing a gun means it needs you to use a reload action, gives you arm fatigue for the rest of the turn lowering accuracy.  Climbing walls needs at the jump points Isn't always guaranteed with a chance of a sprain if you are very unlucky ect. Usually it is best to prepare for the consequences for most actions.UI: I agree with most people... It is a little clunky and not the best.. But when you look past most of its appearance you mostly use Q & E to change action instead of a menu. Regardless it shows everything you need.Ok now for a simple list:Pros:On High graphics settings it looks goodAI is hard and sometimes unforgiving (Well good in my opinion)Soundtrack is fittingOpen maps in most levelsExcellent customizationConsequences for loosing affect appearance of unitsRandomly generated map placementsSome replay abilityUnlocks persist through multiple play throughWays to deal with enemy vary based on your preferred tacticsCons:AI is hard but can predict how they act based on the game modeVery few game modesUI is a bit clunkyMaps look a bit samish even if they are randomly generatedOn low graphics looks appalling compared to most modern gamesDon't always get chance to loot stuffThe game is hard, fun but at times frustrating when it goes from bad to worse. Not always the end of the world but makes progression harder.  Worth it if you like difficult games that seek to destroy you in as many ways as you can.. until you figure out AI tactics but even then still easy to die.I'd give this game a 7 out of 10.. Despite its flaws it has some merit and room to improve.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												A TLDR at the bottom of this review to summarise my points.I really enjoy this game, though it is anything but a 'pick up and play' game for when you have ten minutes to kill. The graphics are beautiful and illustrate the lush environments of a seedy and damned city. The gameplay is challenging from the outset and learning curve (if you ignore the tutorials) can be steep. I chose to play through as Skaven, and haven't tried the other races as yet, so my opinions may be invalid or void with regards to their gameplay. The customisation of characters is adequate, it's not an integral part of the game, and seems to be purely asthetic, though it is a nice touch, as is the injuries, for example; if a character maims a hand, their hand on the character model is mangled. The story missions, character progression and warband management are all solid, on the whole, the game is well made and fun, whilst having a high level of strategic gameplay. However... and this is my only gripe about the game thus far, the load times are ridiculous! I have a high end machine, and yet sometimes I can go away boil the kettle, make a cup of tea or coffee and return and it still hasn't finished loading the map. This is the main reason I have yet to try any of the online features. Also, it is annoying when the voice overs from the mission and the narrator fight it out trying to talk over eachother, resulting in a garbled mess of voices and leaving you to read the mission objectives etc... for vital information you need.TLDR: +graphics+voice acting+ gameplay+story+ challenging- load times- voices overlappingOn the whole a great game, but not for the impatient.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								tl;dr There are very few features currently in the game, but what's there is very good and very promising.So, point of mention: I never played Mordheim before this; I'm familiar with the game and its concept, but never had a chance to actually get in a campaign. Also note that this review is current as of the second content updateCurrently the game only really has the combat more or less. There's 4 warbands (essentially Skaven, Empire, Warrior Priest Empire, and Chaos), and they all have unique units with different skills and abilities, including a powerful Leader unit and 1 impressive unit (Ogre, Chaos Spawn, Rat Ogre, or Super Sister) The rest of the options are fairly simple as to be expected from a starting warband, usually with only a skill or two differentiating them besides their different stat lines. Unfortunately, this does make the units feel very generic, but that's how I imagine they are until level ups and injuries anyways.Surprisingly, combat/movement does not take place on a grid, but in 3D environments using circles to mark how far you can move with each movement point. This does create some weirdness moving around objectives, because you can end up eking out a lot more movement in some situations, looping around obstacles without leaving your circle, but largely looks really nice. The movement is also interestingly handled by WASD, so you actually get to run around with your guys, which was a refreshing change and felt really good. A nice side effect of this as well is that the entire game is playable with a gamepad, hinting that they may move into consoles at some point. Circles also dictate enemy threat zones and ally "control zones", which is an area that keeps other allies from performing actions. It sounds strange, but basically its simply to keep you from stacking 30 guys on one enemy. Nice to note that although there are many missing features currently, the game does include a fairly polished 4-part tutorial that also gives you a chance to see all the factions. Load times were a bit of a bother, but that could also be my machine. Lastly, the interface during the game was very nice. You're able to easily open windows with a single button press that will allow you to see a summary of your active character's stats/buffs, the target character's stats, or a breakdown of what modifiers are on certain actions (explaining why your success chance is higher or lower than expected). All in all, it allows the player to only be confronted with the information they feel they need without requiring lots of popping back to a settings menu.Insert standard comment about bugs and it being in early access so hopefully they will be polished out.Currently, the only form of customization that exists is choosing what weapons your guys have equipped. Dual wielded weapons can be equipped in any combination, so there's actually some nice variety here in, even just with equipment, deciding and executing specific roles for your dudes. As warband management is the newest feature, it's pretty light, but there's lots of promising space on the screen to be filled in. Notably, there's something like 12 locked equipment slots, hinting at lots of consumables and magic items coming in the future (one of the tutorials actually mentions something about enchantments). The Skills page is broken up into something like 10 different tabs, also hinting at lots of customization incoming (currently you can only skirmish with the starting armies, and loot + XP are not applied).Graphically, the game is, frankly, amazing. I'm running it on a 3-year-old laptop and I was getting decent FPS on the "good" setting, which is better than the vast majority of games I've played. Surprisingly optimized for an early access game. I'm not a huge fan of the maps and environments, but that's mostly a question of taste; I'm not one who really enjoys OMG SO GRIMDARK!!!1 all the time. That being said, for that vein they do look absolutely fantastic. They also sport lots of points of interaction, allowing you to climb and leap through different elevations. Nice level design so far from what I've seen. Traps and looting are in, though can't really say how big a role they currently play.All in all, I have to say that I am very impressed. Like I said, the game still has lots of missing key features, but the thing is that they seem to be taking their time and making sure that they do everything right the first time around rather than spit out a bunch of features and try to massage it into a playable state. Personally I won't be playing a whole lot of it right now (since I'm mostly looking forward to the warband growth aspects of the game), but it is totally playable and, compared to almost all other Early Access games I've played, seems to really be starting on the right foot.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												Mordheim: City of the Damned is a Masochist wet dream.This game is possibly the funnest time you will have getting your a** handed to you on a silver platter especially late game. This game has a entire list of just painful factors that'll leave you rage quiting after every game you play, but like an abused girlfriend, you'll just keep coming back for more hoping to pull off those tight decisive victories and bloody battles that make you cheer alongside your warband.Now Mordheim is a game that doesn't go easy on you and one bad mistake could cause your entire warband to be brutally defeated and lose you the game. Just to list a few, AI is tough and they will hammer as many soldiers as they can into a battle line just to take you down. Not a problem, but you'll be fighting against harsh RNG that definitely favors the AI in most fights. Criticals could knock out warriors leaving them completely vulnerable to even more hits, the AI will dodge what feels like every other hit you make before delivering their own blows that'll have your guys hurting or REALLY hurting. If you think that's cruel, the enemy doesn't have to kill everyone, only enough of your warband to bring your moral down till you route, which can be typicall 3-5 of your guys in a warband of 6-8.Good news though, the enemy warband can also break, instantly winning you the battle. The Bad news is if the enemy breaks, you lose out on completing any optional objectives that are vital for leveling up your warband. "Complete optional objectives before you fight" I hear you say, which would work except you forgot about the brutal AI enemy that'll block, charge, and murder your warband if you try to run around them, or would route before you could kill enough enemies to get on to completing the objectives.After a battle, you'll have to deal with managing your warband, paying for their service and any medical bills from them getting injured, outfitting them with better gear, customizing them a bit, training new abilities. If a warrior is injured, they could be out of service for days which means you won't be able to fight with them, which is painful if you're leader becomes injured.And to put icing on this hot-tamali cake, you have a timer! Throughout the campaign you will be required to pay your Warbands sponsor/leader/murder-lord shipments of Wyrdstone which you will collect during missions and receive a bit after a mission. And not small shipments, HUGE shipments of over a hundred pounds of Wyrdstone must be filled in the manner of 2 weeks, and every shipment will be larger than the last. If you fail to fill these shipment requests (I believe twice), you lose the game. Game over, Warband disbanded, please try again.....oh ya. And the game auto saves so no loading an old save if you lose, cheater.NOW for AAALLLL of that...it's still a really good game and very, very rewarding when you win. The RNG is effected by a lot of skills you earn from leveling up that can swing things more in your favor. A clever player can usually lock down enemies and swoop around with faster troops to gather the wyrdstone and I've noticed wyrdstone piles seem to grow more fruitful as the game progresses so fulfilling those requests for your sponsor/leader/murder-lord never trully get's impossible. If you manage skills right and make sure to pull your soldiers out if they're hurting, you can avoid a lot of problems down the line. Optional objectives are still tough but smart planning (and a little luck) can achieve you a decisive victory.Probably what I have to say though most for the fun factor is that it's tough, but never impossible. The feeling you get from just having enough gold to pay for one more battle, to just barely pay off the request with one more day to go. To pull of a clutch victory from the grasp of defeat  or see you're warriors beat down a powerful enemy who seems so impossing is so satisfying. It's what makes the game so good. It isn't being defeated and restarting from a checkpoint.This game isn't about how hard you hit, but how hard you can get hit and keep moving forward. How much you can take and keep moving forward. That's how winning is done!

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												i like that we are now getting good games in the warhammer universe, and hoped that this game would be played alongside vermintide. unfortunetely the pure RNG in this game is a huge turnoff for me.the good-good graphics and art style: the world is well realised and everything fits well with the theme of a city distorted by wyrdstone.-wide range of tactic choices: i enjoy how unique the different factions feel, i unfortunetely didint get deep into this aspect as i wanted to refund this game, but what was there was good.the bad- the load times are long: i have a fairly fast SSD and this game still takes multiple minutes to get into a level, to the point i frequently tabbed out and watched videos while waiting for the music changes to let me know the loading was done.-slow paced: the game takes a long time to get going, and most of the time you spend the first 2-3 turns just running towards objectives not knowing where your opponent is going to be.-unclear RNG mechanic: i enjoy games that use risk management as a primary mechanic, but this game is really bad at giving you all the numbers to make an informed dicision. sometimes you will miss repeatedely with 80% to hit, is flanking usefull at all? etc.-bland warband management and custimization: th amount of freedom you get with your warband is limited, perhaps later on this is expanded, but going 3 missions in and replacing a character with clones of himself is dull and none of the units feels unique. i was also dissapointed the the extent of the costimization options are colors.

Posted: December 2, 2015
												The art feels pretty much exactly how it should feel. Spot on.Game play, and running a warband is hardcore and feels right. There is a learning curve here, but this is because there are so many character build options. The AI does get a bit easy to beat after a while but for me that is not a huge problem because a bunch of us have bought the game in order to play against each other. Still, it feels downright hard when you start because you will make so many mistakes while you learn.To run a "Campaign" against other players requires a bit of admin from someone because the game does not support it but you do keep your loot, items and injuries so for us its perfect. One small moan here is that the amount you have played grants you "Perks" that could unbalance the warbands a tad. An option to flag a warband as a No Perks warband would be nice.Overall, one of the best games I've played recently. Definitely enjoying it more than some other recent big titles.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												The game has a learning curve and the RNG can be a little annoying at times but also adds some suspense to the game.  Sometimes, you have a great plan but your warband can't execute and sometimes, a lone soldier holds the line against the odds.  Unlike a game like X-com, even a novice henchman has pretty good chances to hit but they have shakey morale.  Don't let novices get surrounded or they might rout and get themselves killed.  Remember that collecting Wyrdstone is your primary goal.  Killing the enemy is secondary.  Of course, if you spot a lone enemy, kill him/her and if a bunch of enemies engage, they send in all your warband to fight, but in the beginning of a skirmish, try to gather some loot and wyrdstone before hand.  This will help you greatly after the battle as you need the wyrdstone and loot to pay for the treatment of your wounded and salaries of your troops.Overall I have had a lot of fun so far.  Challenging game but satisfying as well.The multiplayer scene is not great, but I think it will get better over time.  Regardless the AI is challenging enough for me.

												Borderline on yes vs no; overall love the game and concept but the UI, rolling and AI quirks really ruin the overall experince.  The interface is almost as hard as the actaul game.Depth and character sheets are extremely close to classic tabletops; really good stuff.GREAT hard game that will make you hate yourself over and over again; 1 mistake can cost you the game.  Really a blast to play.  I am on the fence for this; if you are a Mordheim fan; then a defineite buy; otherwise I would probably not reccomend. Now the bad:1.  UI is miserable; inventory, leveling and skill points is only a slight step up from doing it on paper.  I can see they are trying to maybe make it similiar to true D&D style maybe?  Overall is could of been made much easier/simplier without losing content.    2.  As other have said; RAND rolling is skewed against you; 75% success rolls and you end up losing 5 times in a row.   Something is amiss; happens over and over again.  I am sure they have some reasoning; but the dice in D&D have never been as mean as this game.3.   Stupidity of interface during battles; confirm mouse clicks after cycling or spacebaring through 5 opitions; over and over and over and over andddddd aaaaHHHHH where am I?!?!?!  Hotkeys guys; we have more then 2 buttons on a keyboard.4.  Hidden map idea; wish they made this a toggle.  Not knowing where your enemies are is a bit of change from typical tabletop; (for obvious reasons); and adds a ton of diffculty to an already burtal game.  Not sure I like the dynamic; forces you to play in a compelty different style and cuts back on tatics quite a bit.Overall it almost looks like a bad console port where you only have 6-8 buttons; buts its not...  The other quarks i can overlook; but this is just in-excusable.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												As a longtime fan and player of the tabletop game, I was thrilled to see Mordheim was being made into a computer game. My old computer didn't meet the minimum specs, but after buying an ASUS ROG rig on clearance at Best Buy this spring, I have to say Rogue Factor did not disappoint! This is a fantastic conversion, with four of the iconic warbands included, and now a fifth -- Witch Hunters -- available as DLC, as well as several hired swords. Keep it coming, devs!Like the tabletop version, the gameplay is highly tactical. Ganging up on lone enemies, while preventing the enemy from ganging up on you, is the key to victory. Yes, you will lose warriors from time to time -- get used to it, it's Mordheim! Keep your heavy hitters in front, while your weaker members grab wyrdstone and loot until they're strong enough to fight. Hire a reserve leader so you don't miss days when your primary leader gets injured -- make those wyrdstone shipments to your sponsor on time! That keeps the gold flowing and lets you build up your warband. Now, my Level 10 Ogre is a killing machine!No, the game isn't perfect -- there are occasional spots in some maps where you should be able to move but a small obstacle blocks your path. And the AI does get hung up once in a while, especially with the large monsters unable to find a path or blocked by a wagon. Also, the persistent arrows after you get shot really need to go away -- having your warriors running around fighting with an arrow right between the eyes or through their skulls looks pretty dumb. So those glitches still need to be ironed out. But overall, this is a great game of Mordheim. The visuals are spot-on, the story missions are fun, and you don't even have to paint your warband. Now let's get that Undead warband into the game! And then, Necromunda...

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								tl;dr There are very few features currently in the game, but what's there is very good and very promising.So, point of mention: I never played Mordheim before this; I'm familiar with the game and its concept, but never had a chance to actually get in a campaign. Also note that this review is current as of the second content updateCurrently the game only really has the combat more or less. There's 4 warbands (essentially Skaven, Empire, Warrior Priest Empire, and Chaos), and they all have unique units with different skills and abilities, including a powerful Leader unit and 1 impressive unit (Ogre, Chaos Spawn, Rat Ogre, or Super Sister) The rest of the options are fairly simple as to be expected from a starting warband, usually with only a skill or two differentiating them besides their different stat lines. Unfortunately, this does make the units feel very generic, but that's how I imagine they are until level ups and injuries anyways.Surprisingly, combat/movement does not take place on a grid, but in 3D environments using circles to mark how far you can move with each movement point. This does create some weirdness moving around objectives, because you can end up eking out a lot more movement in some situations, looping around obstacles without leaving your circle, but largely looks really nice. The movement is also interestingly handled by WASD, so you actually get to run around with your guys, which was a refreshing change and felt really good. A nice side effect of this as well is that the entire game is playable with a gamepad, hinting that they may move into consoles at some point. Circles also dictate enemy threat zones and ally "control zones", which is an area that keeps other allies from performing actions. It sounds strange, but basically its simply to keep you from stacking 30 guys on one enemy. Nice to note that although there are many missing features currently, the game does include a fairly polished 4-part tutorial that also gives you a chance to see all the factions. Load times were a bit of a bother, but that could also be my machine. Lastly, the interface during the game was very nice. You're able to easily open windows with a single button press that will allow you to see a summary of your active character's stats/buffs, the target character's stats, or a breakdown of what modifiers are on certain actions (explaining why your success chance is higher or lower than expected). All in all, it allows the player to only be confronted with the information they feel they need without requiring lots of popping back to a settings menu.Insert standard comment about bugs and it being in early access so hopefully they will be polished out.Currently, the only form of customization that exists is choosing what weapons your guys have equipped. Dual wielded weapons can be equipped in any combination, so there's actually some nice variety here in, even just with equipment, deciding and executing specific roles for your dudes. As warband management is the newest feature, it's pretty light, but there's lots of promising space on the screen to be filled in. Notably, there's something like 12 locked equipment slots, hinting at lots of consumables and magic items coming in the future (one of the tutorials actually mentions something about enchantments). The Skills page is broken up into something like 10 different tabs, also hinting at lots of customization incoming (currently you can only skirmish with the starting armies, and loot + XP are not applied).Graphically, the game is, frankly, amazing. I'm running it on a 3-year-old laptop and I was getting decent FPS on the "good" setting, which is better than the vast majority of games I've played. Surprisingly optimized for an early access game. I'm not a huge fan of the maps and environments, but that's mostly a question of taste; I'm not one who really enjoys OMG SO GRIMDARK!!!1 all the time. That being said, for that vein they do look absolutely fantastic. They also sport lots of points of interaction, allowing you to climb and leap through different elevations. Nice level design so far from what I've seen. Traps and looting are in, though can't really say how big a role they currently play.All in all, I have to say that I am very impressed. Like I said, the game still has lots of missing key features, but the thing is that they seem to be taking their time and making sure that they do everything right the first time around rather than spit out a bunch of features and try to massage it into a playable state. Personally I won't be playing a whole lot of it right now (since I'm mostly looking forward to the warband growth aspects of the game), but it is totally playable and, compared to almost all other Early Access games I've played, seems to really be starting on the right foot.

Posted: February 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you like stratergy, in a battle to battle type set up (think XCOM battles) then this is right up your street. I would however be remiss, if i didnt mention that at the moment Feb 6th. There is only skirmish mode availible to play(free fights, with no unit concequences. I.E. no woundings/death/battle damage or exp gain to player units)  and a limited Warband (unit customisation)  that allows you to change out you units Weapons and Armour and Units, so you can get a an idea of your play style and what the game has to offer.As for controlling the game, its really straight forward:Use mouse to look around and change direction (like any First or Third person game) and confirm Actions/skills. Q&E to change actions/skills and select enermy units. W for moving.(personally I havent used the map yet. so I cant comment on that one)The one thing that I found a little jarring was the opponent movement camera. The player camera cuts to the nearest character unit witnessing the enermies movement a bit to quick for my liking.  not that this is a major problem. Just my preferance.I admit I have never played the board game, so i cant compare the two,But I'm pleased with the game so far, I'm really looking forward to the campaign content when it drops.I recommend looking for some player videos on the web, to get a better idea of what the game is about, before buying.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												This Game is made all the more infuriating by how good it could be, but it is just frustration and anger wraped in a pretty bow. A brawl disquised as tactical combat. I had to delete it to prevent myself from trying to progress because I feel like if I smashed my head against this brick wall long enough I might find gold underneath. The cake is a lie, and this game is just a turn based third person shooter.After some time I decided to give the game another go, and really put in some hours to see if the game improves as you progress. It does, alot. If you can get past the first 10 missions there is a fun game underneath the pain and agony. I like games that punish poor decisions, not so much games that punish bad luck with rolls. This one is unfortunately the latter, a little good luck can get you a long way but the best flanking manouver can go horribly wrong when every attack misses even though it claims your odds are over 80%I still cannot recommend this game; even though I am personally enjoying it and will likely continue playing. Even a victory is a defeat early on as the route mechanics just do not function properly for low level groups making most optional objectives completely unattainable. If you are a stubborn sort who can get past the first 10 hours then go for it, otherwise look elsewhere.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19
												Pros:Interesting team rpg progressionStrategic gameplayDifferent factions offering various playstylesLots of replayabilityGreat visualsCons:Steep learning curveRNG aspect for calculating hits, dmg, etc, can be frustrating sometimesVsing AI can get stale once you start vsing other playersConclusionMordheim: City of the Damned does very well to replicate a tabletop game onto a pc format. The RNG dice rolls for calculations will deter some people, but it's very much like playing cards or gambling. The frustration of fails at 90% chance is superseded by the success of 10% chances. You win some you lose some. The game allows you to strategically play your odds, establishing an interesting core gameplay mechanic.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												A TLDR at the bottom of this review to summarise my points.I really enjoy this game, though it is anything but a 'pick up and play' game for when you have ten minutes to kill. The graphics are beautiful and illustrate the lush environments of a seedy and damned city. The gameplay is challenging from the outset and learning curve (if you ignore the tutorials) can be steep. I chose to play through as Skaven, and haven't tried the other races as yet, so my opinions may be invalid or void with regards to their gameplay. The customisation of characters is adequate, it's not an integral part of the game, and seems to be purely asthetic, though it is a nice touch, as is the injuries, for example; if a character maims a hand, their hand on the character model is mangled. The story missions, character progression and warband management are all solid, on the whole, the game is well made and fun, whilst having a high level of strategic gameplay. However... and this is my only gripe about the game thus far, the load times are ridiculous! I have a high end machine, and yet sometimes I can go away boil the kettle, make a cup of tea or coffee and return and it still hasn't finished loading the map. This is the main reason I have yet to try any of the online features. Also, it is annoying when the voice overs from the mission and the narrator fight it out trying to talk over eachother, resulting in a garbled mess of voices and leaving you to read the mission objectives etc... for vital information you need.TLDR: +graphics+voice acting+ gameplay+story+ challenging- load times- voices overlappingOn the whole a great game, but not for the impatient.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
Product received for free
												I thought about getting this for some time. When the game came out for a free weekend, I was thrilled. However the trill was short lived when I actually started playing it. Some people have complained about the steep learning curve. Elite Dangerous has a steep learning curve, this has a learning cliff with no climbing ropes. The tutorial was not informative and crushingly boring. Meanwhile the campaign is half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and lacks much of a story other than: Go here, do this, kill this, loose half your men ect. The mechanics are very clunky and the overall camera controls are rediculusly constricting. The veiws that you get are third person and third person. This would not be so bad if it were like Dragon Age. It can take 3-4 rounds to kill an enemy one on one which will leave your man crippled regardless of whether or not he is covered in heavy armor or clad in a burlap sack. Weapon type is also imaterial a halberd/spear has nearly the same combat range as a sword or dagger wielding hostile. Bows are made useless from the combonation of short range and low damage. But the logic envolved with this is also flawed. Combat, especially in the story missions is encredibly one-sided and your entire team will run off under stupid conditions. Once I had the enemy down to one and backed into a corner 5 on 1 and lost the leader. All 4 of the others cut and run.  If this had nothing else to compair it to, we would think it was incredible, but let me make a list of games like this that are better.Dragon Age, all 3Divinity 2 Divinity Orginal SinPillars of EternityBaulders GateIcewind Dale Temple of Elemental Evil (TOEE) Dungeon SeigeBlackguards 1&2Your favorite game hereOn an up note, this does beat out Sword Coast. Then again, contracting Leishmaniasis beats that. My point is, there is no point in getting this when there are a slew of other games out there that are so so much better that cost far far less.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												I don't do many reviews but I thought i would put something for this game.(I have played quite a few hours on this with my offline PC)(Edit - Spell check lives again so corrected a lot of errors... Sadly was on an odd day)Personally i thought this was a good although very difficult game when i started, but i found despite the few issues and UI the game was actually quite good.If you are looking for another casual turn based game where you can just pick some classes and tank up then I would recommend avoiding this game. Every mistake you make will come back an haunt you at a later date including avoiding some side objectives,I think it would be easier if i gave a basic description of the pros and cons for this game...Camera: The camera is a 3rd person camera that locks onto the unit you are meant to be moving that turn, Doesn't allow free roaming with the camera and makes seeing around corners and in buildings a little more difficult when trying to avoid ambushes.Movement: This caught me off guard at first.. Using the standard movement keys WASD to navigate was a bit odd for a turn based game but once I figured out the blue circles were something akin to movement areas, you would only lose a movement point when changing to a different ring giving you free movement within your Movement points.Actions: This i found a little off at first but every action has a reaction.. Firing a gun means it needs you to use a reload action, gives you arm fatigue for the rest of the turn lowering accuracy.  Climbing walls needs at the jump points Isn't always guaranteed with a chance of a sprain if you are very unlucky ect. Usually it is best to prepare for the consequences for most actions.UI: I agree with most people... It is a little clunky and not the best.. But when you look past most of its appearance you mostly use Q & E to change action instead of a menu. Regardless it shows everything you need.Ok now for a simple list:Pros:On High graphics settings it looks goodAI is hard and sometimes unforgiving (Well good in my opinion)Soundtrack is fittingOpen maps in most levelsExcellent customizationConsequences for loosing affect appearance of unitsRandomly generated map placementsSome replay abilityUnlocks persist through multiple play throughWays to deal with enemy vary based on your preferred tacticsCons:AI is hard but can predict how they act based on the game modeVery few game modesUI is a bit clunkyMaps look a bit samish even if they are randomly generatedOn low graphics looks appalling compared to most modern gamesDon't always get chance to loot stuffThe game is hard, fun but at times frustrating when it goes from bad to worse. Not always the end of the world but makes progression harder.  Worth it if you like difficult games that seek to destroy you in as many ways as you can.. until you figure out AI tactics but even then still easy to die.I'd give this game a 7 out of 10.. Despite its flaws it has some merit and room to improve.
