content:
Posted: January 2
												Where to start?The game is generally good, graphics are alright, nothing to get overly excited about. Game play is good but gets really repetitive really quickly.... A few annoying factors in the game, such as the 'Hit' mechanic, it comes accross as random to me without any real difference between characters or traits or skills. You can still miss on a 95% hit when you really need that hit, yet a 47% chance to hit actually hits! Boogles me at times.Then there are the bugs! I've lost count on the number of times my game has crashed on me, for no apparent reason throwing up a message with the heading 'ops'.... 'Oh, im sorry, did you have an accident there game?' SO to round off, if a Warhammer fan, then get the game, if not a Warhammer fan, then I wouldnt recommend this one.If I had to score this game, I'd give it a 6 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												I love this game.  Feels like a tactical board game brought to life.  It's got a lot of problems:  It's got quite a few bugs, and some clunky UI and controls.  The learning curve is steep and the tutorials suck.  Parts of the core game design look flimsy:  The game is supposed to be unforgiving, and losing a battle means less xp and permanent injuries making your guys less valuable.  But it doesn't stop you from totally avoiding it with an unfortunate exploit.  Just grab a friend to play against, and cut your internet connection during battle and the game rewards you both with a victory.  Makes it kind of trivial to build up a powerful warband.The objectives are so lame.  I mean, OBJECTIVE, singular.  Always it is to kill the other guys, and collecting loot is sort of a bonus.  It is repetitive, and just assumes that both players will clash somewhere in the middle of the map, or near a big pile of wyrdstone.  Nothing stopping one player from running away forever like a troll, not letting the game end until someone gets bored and forfeits.  IMO the game should also end if all the wyrdstones are collected from the map.  That's like the whole premise of the game anyway.This is definitely a niche game, for those who love tactical board games and have the patience to figure out the mechanics.  It is a lot of fun if you can look past the bugs, clunky UI and controls, and some poor design decisions.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful11 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												TLDR - Its like a fantasy XCOM but with the difficulty of playing Dark Souls with your toes with zero reward.PROS-Concept and ThemeExcellent 50% praise of devs 50% to the original tabletop. Its an authentic representation thematically.- Party membersCan lose limbs through fighting/grow new ones via warp corruption (see tentacle surprise)CONS- The AnimationsToo long and artificially slow the game down. Gathering warpstone (like a 2nd currency which you HAVE to gather) takes literal years to do and breaks immersion)Risk/Reward is way off - If (and its a big if) you win a battle, you get about 5% of the total loot on the map. That means you either spend the combat aspect of the game doing fetch quests or you fight stupidly close battles for next to no reward.Maps are WAY too large- For real, Ive had games where its taken 6 guys 8 turns to find 1 of 6 dudes on the other team. The AI is massively imba- You know how in XCOM it feels like RNG is both rage inducing and gives you those 'Holy balls how am I still alive?' moments?. Yeah this skipped the second part. Every enemy you fight even the plebs are dead-eye, power-armoured ninjas. They deal dmg that would make an Exocet Cruise Missile blush, their loin cloths are being loaned to the US Army, their weapons have radar guidance systems and either your dudes all fell out of a pub in East Belfast after 16 hours of heavy drinking before coming on the mission or the enemies got spitroasted by The Flash and Quicksilver because good luck hitting any of them. Your guys are BAD- Their attacks are as ferocious as the blind hamster the knitting club keep around for morale. On the point of morale, the void where it should be is conspicious in its absence. The mere suggestion the going is getting tough they (literally) drop everything they own and run for the hills faster than the vegan your friend just introduced you to iforms you of their moral highground. You just spent 20 mins collecting valuable warpstone? ♥♥♥♥ that - Michelle thought she saw a ghost in this haunted city so now we are going to run away and cry on Tumblr. You think you can hit that guy? Nope, the success rate for your guys hitting that dude (who youve surrounded on all sides for a warpstone ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥) is lower than stunted half blind twins conjoined at the♥♥♥♥♥♥scoring a touchdown at the Superbowl. They take a hit worse than Rihanna and move at a pace that has glaciers feeling oblidged to slow down so they feel like they aren't a drain on society and should be euthanised.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
												Great game, but you need to be into this sort of style of gameplay otherwise you will hate it.CONS- large upfront amount of game mechanics to learn, sometimes the stats pages look like something out of an excel spreadsheet.- Slow gameplay, so if you are into arcade style speed and action then this is not for you.- Difficult and punishing, which is a pro or a con depending on your preference.PROS+ Fantastic atmosphere and Warhammer Lore+ Very deep, if you stick around it will last hundreds of hours before you have seen all the game has to offer.+ Its addictive, in a 'just one more mission!' sort of way.+ Having perma death results in you becoming quite attached to your little soldiers, resulting in you rooting for them in fights and being upset when they die. (Similiar to pokemon Nuzlocke runs)

Posted: November 2, 2016
												I like tough games, but seriously, this is insane? Dev's need to work on the random seed or something, becaue the player is at an extreme disadvantage. I can get a victory here and there, but it is rare, and leaves no time to gather loot which apparently is required part of the game.My own forces miss attack after attack, while the enemy seems to have a 95% hit rate. The enemy also seems to always hit for 40-50 damage+ and take much much less damage back. Your average soldiers can only take 2 or 3 hits before they are down. Even my hero gets two shotted by a normal soldier with a two hander. (Which is realistic, but not very good when the rolls constantly favor the computer).

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												I've greatly enjoyed the game, as much for the thematic elements of the warbands of undead, mutants, witch hunters (and so forth) as for the warband campaign and progression system. Fighting around mordheim, completing faction quests  and leveling up and customizing my warband is a lot of fun. I would recommend buying this game! (On sale of course...only ever buy games on sale). My only complaint is that its a little too easy. More on that below. But first, add on about 20 hours to the amount of time I've played; I spent a lot of time playing disconnected from steam, and even when I resynced the hours played didnt update. Go figure.So I dont get people complaining about this game being too hard. Sure, my first warband got wrecked, but after that it got alot easier. Maybe its because I'm an over-cautious player (doing whatever I can to keep my precious, customized, stylized warband from dying), but with my current warbands I win about, um, 100% of the engagements (vs. AI mind you).Yes there is a perma death/injury system, yes there are the wyrdstone deliveries, but they arent crazy difficult if you PLAN around that aspect and position/group your troops accordingly.To those complaining about RNG; no such problem on my end. Sure there are untimely enemy crits, and terrible misses from your party, but nothing about that shouts out "broken RNG!!" to me. All to be expected.My only complaint would be that the enemy warband setups are too predictable; in order to have an easier time balancing the strength of your warband vs. the random skirmishing AI warband the developers made it so that your oppsoing enemy will take the EXACT SAME unit slots at you.So if you take 2 heroes, 1 impressive and 3 henchmen, guess what your enemy will bring? 2 heroes, 1 impressive and 3 henchmen. O____OIt takes ALOT of strategy out of the game. No large mobs vs small elite forces. Its always large mobs vs. large mobs, or small elite forces vs. small elite forces. It would make my day if the developers released a patch that changed that. Right now the predictability makes the game too easy.Also, if the developers ever put out a full set of customization options for your warband (like different heads, armor appearances, etc) I would totally get behind that!

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												Update:-----------As of yesterday, I managed to connect to a Multiplayer game, so looks like something has been fixed in one of the patches. Thanks devs! I'm still unable to play the game in windows, so I played in WINE after dual-booting.It was a fun game for MP, and I enjoyed the ability to scan around in 3rd person while the opponent was scurrying around trying to sneak up. The turns went fairly smoothly, with no discernible lag between turns.Original review follows.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Every game results in a hard lockup of my PC. I have to hard-power-off every time. Drivers updated, reinstalled, tried all the settings, checked temps yada yada.  Support responded with boilerplate questions and never replied after I provided the info they asked for. I have 400 other games that do not lock up my PC.It does run under WINE in linux (on the same hardware as above) but have been unable to join a friend and play online. It's pretty straightforward but drop a comment if you need help to run in wine.Could have been a great game that I would have sunk some hours into, but  I can't recommend a game that locks up my PC in windows and doesn't work MP in linux.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												This game is complete and utter garbage for one reason only. The random number generator is broken as all hell in this game.At first I loved this game and thought it was the most accurate conversion of a GW game that I had played, but when all your hard work and tactics is thrown under the bus in every single match its insulting to the player that the Developer is either so inept or so careless that their "random number" generator is bias and broken.When your leader has a 75% or more dodge rating and EVERYTHING HITS HIM EVERY TURN, it shows how broken it is. I understand that occasionally you get back luck and bad rolls, but this game consistantly ruins your efforts. Dodges are failed enmasse, and yet when you attack an enemy with an 85% chance to hit and you fail 5 attacks in a row, every turn it demonstrates that the developer has skewed ot the numbers to fail you and favour the AI.This is an enormous deterant to playing seeing as your Warband has to carry from game to game with all its failures and setbacks while the enemy AI gets a fresh team every single match. If this was just a difficulty setting I wouldn't mind so much. If it was bad luck every now and then I wouldn't mind so much. However all the high percentages set in my favour, fail about 80% of the time. Whenever the enemy has a low percent, they seem to succeed 80% of the time.It breaks the game and mean no matter how much effort you put in or how much time you spend learning the mechanics, it means ♥♥♥♥ all. Because its auto set to fail you.\O/   DO NOT BUY THIS BROKEN GAME   \O/

number of helpful: 40 of 80 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Coming from a background laden with the likes of Mordheim, Necromunda, Gorkamorka it is safe to say that I am no newbie to the Warhammer universe, albeit somewhat disenchanted with the recent developments at Games Workshop. I was originally thrown into the wargaming hobby whilst young and grabbing up a copy of Space Crusade and Warhammer: Quest and I personally always favoured the Games Workshop adaptations that featured tonnes of "fluff", whose being warband campaigns that did not count on you buying the latest or greatest mini's but really becoming immersed into play system that demanded tactics.Over the years Games Workshop has failed to meet the bar with many of its video game adaptations of its franchises. Blood Bowl was an epic example of how to mismananage, annoy and isoloate an entire sub culture of gamers away from your product by failing to meet basic demands.Mordeim: City of the Damned is however a massive step in the right direction! The gameplay is immersive as ever with rich environments and fantastic graphics, the W,A,S,D controls in third-person rather than a strict "overhead only" approach layer upon another dimension of interactivity and narration. The actions and cut scenes have been carefully crafted to actually look good! The controls are consistent and easy to use, along with being able to grasp the basic rules for the game.What I must commend Rogue Factor on the most is the balancing of the game. Many players threw the Mordheim original rulebook out of the window, because of many broken atrributes, the favoured the fan moderated and constructed 'Coreheim' rules. Rather than using the broken original rules, or further breaking or basterdising rules to fit, Rogue Factor have balanced this gameplay beautifully, making it a pleasure to play.Please Rogue Factor, once you have completed this, do Necromunda: Tales of the Underhive.

number of helpful: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Mordheim City of the Damned is an excellent game.  Because I have crummy Internet I am not able to download it as quickly as I would like.  However, the patches for the game have been amazing.  I would reccomend it to anyone who likes nitty gritty turn based games.My thoughts on the different warbands:Cult of the Possessed: So far they are my favorite warband to play as.  They have good attacks, but lack in defense.  That is okay considering their henchmen start with two handed axes.  Thier leader starts out with a decent spell and their hero does have the chance of random mutations.Clan Eshin: They are my second favorite to play even though they lack physical prowess.  They are not able to hit very hard, but their leader does start out with a poison weapon.  On the other hand, they are all excellent at dodges from the start making you harder to hit.Sisters of Sigmar: The Sisters of Sigmar are the absolute worst warband to face in my opinion.  I have yet to win a battle against them and they all seem to be overpowered even at low levels.  When I try to play them, they always end up doing awful.  They seem to have a pretty good chance of doing well later on down the road though.Mercenaries of Reikland: I have honestly not played them as I have never been a huge fan of the Empire.  I don't know all that much about them.Overall, the game is very difficult to start, but it the game is very rewarding to players who do well.  The game itself is a little clunky, but it is a very good game.

content:

content:
Posted: March 3
												Excellent, hard, and honest turn-based strategy game in the vein of XCOM, etc. You take a warband of character classes into a spooky city and engage other warbands. The game allows for wonderful customization of your characters' stats and you can design a particular warband member just so. Then that warband member gets annihilated in combat and needs his leg amputated and you have to rethink your build for him because he can't climb walls anymore. It's an Ironman-mode only game, so there's no coming back from a maneuver, decision, or result. If you aren't thinking about strategy your warband can get wiped easily by the AI, suffer permanent injuries, and you're back to square one and need to hire a few new characters. Do you risk going for loot or a gem and exposing a character to a potential ambush, or do you hide for one round so a few other characters can catch up and add security against a potential engagement? Decisions like that happen on practically every turn, and they add incredible atmosphere to the combat. It's procedural, so every non-story mission is unique and the replayability is fantastic.A hard game at first but you eventually get the hang of things and learn to be patient and think carefully before you act. There is a nice selection of guides written by members of the community that I found invaluable. They cover things like warband management, combat tips, levelling, which skills to train for X builds, etc., and make many aspects of the game much more approchable for new players.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												This has the potential to be a really good game - in some ways it is a good game already - and it may well become one in all ways. If it does i'll certainly change my review to positive, but at the moment, despite a lot that's good in the game design, good atmosphere and good graphics, there are some annoying design flaws and some basic necessities lacking.If i could i'd have given it a neutral review at the moment, as a i like a lot of things about it, despite being frustrated by several others, but Steam only allows positive or negative.The atmosphere is good and some design choices are good too - e.g being unarmoured gives less protection from damage if you're hit, but it also gives a higher chance of dodging attacks - and of climbing and jumping successfully.The AI is pretty good - not perfect - but about as good as I am at any rate.However some other design choices do not work.The amount of equipment characters can lose from being knocked out in battle is excessive, as are some of the permanent injuries. You can play say 8 missions with a warband in the single player campaign, win 7 heavily, then lose so much equipment from one defeat that your campaign is over.(EDIT : Above not entirely true - once you've played enough of the game, even if you lose campaigns, you get Veteran Skills for all your warbands, which include some giving you a 5% chance over so much time of getting free armour, but still, armour is rarer than it should be imo)This is even more so, as , even if you do have money, the shop frequently has literally nothing to buy in it - and even when it does have anything to buy, sometimes very little, and  rarely much armour.The penalties for abandoning even a single player campaign mission are often equally campaign-ending. I abandoned one mission and practically my whole gang were injured as a result, even though none had even lost any significant number of hitpoints in the part of the mission i played.One hero ended up losing an arm, while my only archer developed megalomania, meaning he could no onger use missile weapons - and he was pretty high level at this point.This is made even worse by the lack of any save game function in for single player campaign - so if you get one disastrous mission you can't reload from before it and try again, you have to start the campaign from scratch with a new warband.The game has included the variety of set ups from the original tabletop miniatures game, but, while these worked well for the tabletop game, they don't all work in the computer game. For instance when one side is deployed inside buildings in the tabletop game, they can leave them quickly and easily in a single turn. But some of the computer game buildings are confusing mazes that can take a while to get out of at all.The overhead map you can switch the view to in battles now makes it a bit closer to the tabletop game - but unfortunately the map is sometimes misleading, showing what are actually rows of houses that can't be entered or crossed to look like they are a drop or have gaps them in - and this can result in defeat in some missions because you just can't find how to get half your warband to where the fighting is.The 'ambush' stance in battles allows for "ambushers" to "ambush" while standing in the open. I've even had enemies run up to within two feet of me in plain sight in the open, go into ambush stance - and when i move the two feet to attack them they "ambush" me , attack first and cause my character a "surprised" penalty. This encourages sitting back and waiting over attacking, as if you stand back and ambush, you will almost certainly get all the first blows in, whereas if you attack first, the enemy will often get the first blows in using ambush.The zones of control around your own warband's members can often block the movement and attacks of other members of your own warband, which is pretty bizarre and annoying at times in narrow streets. Sometimes you can get round this by climbing up nearby buildings and moving some warriors round to attack the enemy from behind - and this is fine. Other times this is impossible though, depends on the luck of the randomly generated maps.While you can increase the stats of members of your gang by just getting experience, for some reason getting skills from experience also requires crazy amounts of gold that make giving characters skills not practical, which seems like a bad design choice too.The interface for equipping your warband members is strange and not intuitive in some ways - e.g to buy armour for a warband member from their equipment screen you need to click on the equipment slot . then on the shop, then the equipment slot that piece of armour or weapon goes in again.Probably even most of these problems would be ok at least for the single player campaign though, if it had a save game function you could use before a mission.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Turn-based squad strategy RPG in the Warhammer (not 40k!) universe. Very grimdark, lots of gruff voice actors trying super hard. If you've played any game in either Warhammer or 40k you know what I'm talking about.The game is very atmospheric, but extremely light on story. 90% of your missions will be randomly generated, and of those I never saw one that presented something new or interesting. Just a cobbled-together mash of buildings, hallways, and annoying dead ends. Randomization adds very little to the game, only changing the map and team spawn points. The mission is always to simply kill everyone on the other team, or deal enough morale damage to get them to rout.Typical for the genre, chance plays an enormous role in the outcome of your missions. Because this is so gritty and realistic (a "hardcore experience" as the game puts it) your guys will get knocked out, often, to things you could not possibly prevent. Party members who fall in combat have a chance to die instantly, or receive a permanent debilitating injury. To me, that's as good as them being dead. I'm not carting around some guy with -25% move speed who can't climb over walls for the rest of the game.So, obviously you don't want that. Any party member who's left alone can and will be killed in one turn if he encounters 2 enemies, or one powerful one. I found the most effective, and boring, strategy was to thus keep my whole team in arm's reach of each other at all times. The game has no time limit mechanics so there's really no reason to not play that way.Lots of little annoying things too. The tutorial system is♥♥♥♥♥♥ Information is vomited on the screen, literally dozens of statistics that no normal human could parse meaningful decisions out of. Enemy turns go by at a snail's pace, even with "Speed up enemy turns" checked. Eventually I just had my phone out for the inexplicable 45+ seconds of enemy turns that I couldn't even see because of fog of war. There's no *sell all* button for your resources. Traps litter the floor of the map but you can see them with the naked eye so they're pretty obnoxious "gotchas" more than anything deadly or interesting.Nothing I've ♥♥♥♥♥ed about here, by itself, makes Mordheim unplayable, but together, it's really unfun. I don't even mind the RNG sometimes screwing you over; I played XCOM on Ironman mode because I enjoy that thrill of not knowing what could happen. So a game that forces that upon you seems like it'd be right up my alley. I really wanted to like this game! That's why I stuck with it for as long as I did, despite the flaws. In the end, I just couldn't be bothered to bring my team of crippled lowbies into yet another randomly-generated massacre.

												The actual game is AWESOME!!! Like the mechanics. The world. The way they worked the tabletop movement to computer game.BUT!!The UI is so horrible that in the first 10 minutes I had cursed it 3 times, and instantly had better ways to do it. Simple ways.Good things:- Clear stats. What should affect what.-The way they made turn- and stat- based game in to this animated thing.- Mordheim. Well done.Not:- Tutorials. I spend 2 hours reading, playing and listening that. I'm vereran WH fantasy and Mordheim player... I got the idea... but because of the UI, I really struggled to understand the computer game mechanics. But 2h in tutorials... yeah not gona float in mainstream.- User Interface. UI for short. I don't even know where to begin! This is so failed.-- Every information piece is scattered to the sides. There is no focus to the relevant information. 2/3 of the screen is wasted on a little model that doesn't give you any information. I have no idea what is relevant.-- Any logical keybinding or hotspot does not exist. You keep pressing buttons and expecting certain result... but nothing happends. Feels like actual playtesting has been skipped, because only a masocist could play this.-- Deployment in scenarious is complete♥♥♥♥♥♥ In tactical mode (bird eye) you can see the spots that you can place your models, but you can't place your models in that view!! Makes sense right?! You can only place your models in the gameplay third person view. So you have to switch between, the gameplay view and the tactical view, about a 30 times when placing your troops. In the third person view you have no idea where you are ofcourse. And it doesn't help that even if know who/what model you are placing, because the UI doesn't really tell you in the beginning. I couln't figure out how to rename my troops so I could tell them apart. Again failure of the UI.Honestly. There has to be someone in their QA who had doubts? Someone who said this is quit hard to pickup??If you where in a position to change the keybindings, controls, and UI you had to be bonkers to not say something? I love the francise. Steam says that I have played 6 hours... 2 of those are from early access/beta. I still not have completed the first mission. That should say something.I want this game to succeed. I can see the problems and even how to fix them. What I can't see is, why didn't this♥♥♥♥♥♥get fixed before release?

								The idea is really great and hopefully when it's done being developed we'll realize a really fun game...However, most the time you don't see the player's actions that you control.There's nothing indicating where all your players are in reference to eachother.There's nothing showing you what the topography or area location has in it so you know where you want to go or hide or defend or setup ambush or anything - essentially cannot strategize at all.  Literally, at all... And there seems to be a glitch as to when your player gets to have turns because I just played a game where I didn't get to move one of my guys the entire match and he was just getting hit over and over even though I had parry enabled.No one plays it or is willing to wait for matchmaking (if it actually works I don't know) to come to fruition because I never found a human player to play against and ended up just playing AI.There's no tutorial of any sort or direction on how the GUI or skill tree works or anything like that so you just kinda figure it'll come after you gain experience somehow or something... no real way to know how to do anything until you hit buttons and try stuff out and decide that something did what you thought it was suppose to do.Plus one of my players was stuck in a building all by himself.  There was an invisible wall where the staircase was and a door behind that wouldn't open so one of my players was just sitting in a room by himself.  I don't know if the AI could engage by coming to him because I couldn't force myself to play after 15 minutes or so and I realized it was a fruitless endeavor.Don't buy it yet.  Make them develop it before handing them your cash.  It's definitely NOT worth it right now.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												Well, I went back and tried the game again to see if anything had been fixed.  It's still the same.  Unplayable.There is a lot to like about this game:  atmosphere and graphics being the best selling points.Unfortunately, there is an awful lot to dislike about this game:1) the RNG is a joke.  The 2nd time I quit it was after 16 consecutive to hit rolls of over 90.  That's 16 in a row, people.  One of the biggest mstakes the dev team made was putting the actual die results on the screen. It simply allowed me to see EXACTLY how awful the RNG truly is.   Over the course of 5 games I tracked every die result for each type of action.  I saw very little difference between action types such as "to hit" vs. "climbing."  But I wanted to track if there was a difference.  After averaging my "to hit" rolls, I found an average roll of over 80.  That's not even an attempt at randomicity.  IF you are the kind of person who enjoys constant failure at easy tasks...then this game is for you!2)  the variety of warbands is unacceptable.  I am a long time tabletop Mordheim player and loved the variety in the warbands. Here we get 4.  The Sisters have been solely relagated to a melee warband (they removed their sling option) and also removed perhaps the coolest aspect of the Sister...the steel chains.  Oh, well.    The Mercenary warband is one that wasn't even an actual warband in the original game, and here is just a watered down version of mish-mash of all of the other warbands that existed.  The possessed are unplayable becasue the mutations are random and one cannot actually plan/develop a warband because the random mutations ruin warband members so thoroughly that the only answer is to fire them and start over. 3)  skills are just a waste.  Pick a single attack and rank it.  Ranking more than one is a waste of time as you will never use it.  The passive skills are MUCH more useful.  Most skills are completely useless since you have limited slots for skills.  As a result, some skills that you may find quite useful ...such as helping you climb, will NEVER be taken becasue they are not worth the slot they use up.  A a result, at least half the skills could be removed from the game and it would have no significant effect on gameplay at all.4) the compensation for a good AI is simply the fact that every warband you face is better than yours.  Generally, a lot better.  More hits, better damage, faster; everything.  As many have said in other reviews, the game has a steep learning curve, but is not as impossible (in general) as many here seem to feel.  BUT, the huge advantage the AI has in strength, makes this game a series of gambles more than anything...pull the lever and hope you win and aren't ambushed.  Which leads me to the next thing...5) Ambush.  This breaks the game entirely.  When you are ambushed, the AI starts in range, usually goes first (due to the fact that they are simply better than your warband) and can take out 2-3 members of your warband before you even get to make an action.  This is essentially the game devs implementing a feature to knock the player down a few pegs by randomly killing some of their warband.  Such fun, let me tell you.   Spend hours upon hours building your warband only to be ambushed and  permanently lose 2-3 members of your warband before you even get to make an action.  Such awesomeness.    Which leads me to the SINGLE RNG factor that succeeds more than it fails...6)  When your Warband is being utterly destroyed, you have a MUCH greater chance of making your route check than ANY OTHER ROLL YOU EVER TRY.  You will miss attack roll after attack roll and fail all of your ALL ALONE checks, but when it comes time to make that 20% chance to NOT route...you make it.  Thus ensuring you get to hang around for at least one more round and risk losing even more warband members.  The ONLY way I can explain this is that it is a purposeful inclusion in the game to ensure the utter destruction of your warband.In conclusion, I think the devs are sadists.  I can only imagine them laughing themselves silly as players continually struggle against their plot to kill them at every turn.  They probably lay bets on how many players have launched their mouse against the wall in utter frustration. Additionally, I think they are lazy.  Dudes, just make a better AI...don't take the cheap way out and simply overpower the player with overpowered adversaries and rigged die rolls, that's such a chicken**** way out it makes me sick to my stomach.  You are expecting people to give you money for your product; have enough respect for your customer to put the work in that is needed to justify the money you are making.  If that's too much to ask, you should find a different line fo work.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game, but 12 hours is the most I can do.It's really clunky. Useless animation of your crew reloading and taking trap damage and looting stuff take way too long.In the end, I think you spend most of your time waiting to be able to play, which is even more frustrating when you're loosing.Then, It's supposed to be a hard game, whith no ability to reload saves. It could be fine, but there is still some awful stupid bugs that can make you lose, and it's hard to see your captain dying for a bug.My biggest concern is how hard it is to read the map and make precise positionning. It is supposed to be a tactical game, but it's nearly impossible to make the tactical part works. Sometimes it "feels" like your tank is blocking the door, but it is not. Some time it feels like there is a path, but it is not, and as you climbed a wall, you cannot get back. Sometime this house feel safe, but there is a "hidden" (hidden because you have to fully explore to see it, which can take 4 to 5 turns ) passage on the third flood after four stairs and bridges, and the IA kowns it, and use it.In short, you're often punished because the game isn't good enough to give you the information you need to play well, and I hate it.To conclude, after trying lots of differents things, and looking for advice on internet, it always end up with the same technique : make a bottleneck in a closed room and defeat all your opponent in a 3vs1 fight. Every map is only "how can I end up to this situation fast enough ?"Anything else is too dangerous, and you will get punished hard. Difficulty is fine when it force you to get better, but it's not the case here. It only force you to make a new game when you're not lucky enough.

												"Omg, the AI just ran a one armed rat carrying a small dagger into my Sister Superior and 2 experienced sisters"A few turns later..."Omg, that rat just took out two of them and is landing every blow onto my SS with 30% parry""Well, atleast my other team is doing well...."Two rats run into them, one drops a poison ball."Ok, they're tough heros, poison is no problem I have some healing! Sigma has my back!"80% circle of healing fail into a curse.75% Might of sigma fail into an area stun that hits all of my girls....in the poison cloud....Not to forget to mention the 75-80% consecutive misses being thrown left and rightThis game's RNG puts hearthstone to shame. I refuse to believe I am being shown correct numbers.And thats basically combat in a nutshell. If flanking works as a bonus, I sure as ♥♥♥♥ haven't figured out how to use it.Aside from the above being the game in a nutshell it feels extremely lacking in depth.  Only a handful of factions and not enough parts of the city mapped.  It can get very repetitive.The interface is terrible, tooltips and mouseovers do not exist.  It looks straight up like a console port to the PC.Some idiot decided it would be a great idea to immediately end the match as soon as the enemy team peaces out.....I had like 100lbs of wyrdstone in one spot, a huge pile of it.You'd think I'd be able to carry that back with me since I won and my girls are near it?  Nope.  Just stop what you are doing and gtfo because god forbid we get to grab items from things we are nearby....who needs a cart anyway, right?Its extremely painful to play, and this is coming from someone who has won every campaign battle so far and has lucked out quite a bit on recovering from injuries.Its not because its "unforgiving".....its just stupidly unforgiving and unreasonable for things that don't need to be.To top is all off? The fanboys are as hostile as it gets, the death of any game. Goodluck trying to give the game fair criticism without half a dozen people telling you to kill yourself.Great idea, terrible implementation, and god awful fanbase...and that's why its free this weekend.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game, but 12 hours is the most I can do.It's really clunky. Useless animation of your crew reloading and taking trap damage and looting stuff take way too long.In the end, I think you spend most of your time waiting to be able to play, which is even more frustrating when you're loosing.Then, It's supposed to be a hard game, whith no ability to reload saves. It could be fine, but there is still some awful stupid bugs that can make you lose, and it's hard to see your captain dying for a bug.My biggest concern is how hard it is to read the map and make precise positionning. It is supposed to be a tactical game, but it's nearly impossible to make the tactical part works. Sometimes it "feels" like your tank is blocking the door, but it is not. Some time it feels like there is a path, but it is not, and as you climbed a wall, you cannot get back. Sometime this house feel safe, but there is a "hidden" (hidden because you have to fully explore to see it, which can take 4 to 5 turns ) passage on the third flood after four stairs and bridges, and the IA kowns it, and use it.In short, you're often punished because the game isn't good enough to give you the information you need to play well, and I hate it.To conclude, after trying lots of differents things, and looking for advice on internet, it always end up with the same technique : make a bottleneck in a closed room and defeat all your opponent in a 3vs1 fight. Every map is only "how can I end up to this situation fast enough ?"Anything else is too dangerous, and you will get punished hard. Difficulty is fine when it force you to get better, but it's not the case here. It only force you to make a new game when you're not lucky enough.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												NOTE: My hours played should be far more than shows because I've mostly played this game offline.I REALLY wanted to like this game, and for periods I would have quite a bit of fun with it.  It mixes several things I really like: (1) Turn-based combat; (2) good graphics; and (3) a 3D Map.  But I'm about to uninstall.My primary issue is COMBAT:- You want victories to be as clean as possible, meaning that none of your troops get put out of action (lose all their HP).  That's fine, but the "strategy" required to avoid such ruins the game.- The RNG of whether you (or an enemy) hits or misses a swing is far too important.  I don't mind an unforgiving game (where its very possible to lose characters or die) but when the unforgiving element is tied heavily to RNG, that's a problem.- The enemy often has more (or stronger) troops that you do.  They will swarm on you really quickly once they find you.  So if you go out and try to collect loot on the map (fun) you expose your troops to getting pounced upon and dying (not fun).  The best tactic is often to ignore loot and set up a very defensive position and simply wait until the enemy finds you (not fun).- Some maps force your units to be split apart from each other, either randomly or by choice.  In any event, its quite frequent for some of your troops to be separated near an enemy.  Once they jump on you, you can't really effectively run away.I think those are enough points to give you my general impression.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												I really tried to like this, and I looked at forums and suggestions for play but I really cannot recommend this at all.  I know the frustration of RNG linked games, like for instance Blood Bowl; they can make you howl with rage, but as long as you can still have fun I don't mind that at all - so I love Blood Bowl despite the fact your best player can die trying to run in a score with a 80%+ chance of success without any opponents near them.  This game has that frustration but without any fun.  It is dull, frustrating and repetitive.  I gave up thinking of reasons I should give it another chance and just removed it.  Not worth wasting my time, and I would suggest yours.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												Mordheim is a merger between two of my favorite things, tactical strategy and warhammer fantasy.  Mordheim should be the game that I spend 100+ hours playing, and mucho dinero buying all the DLC. Instead it is infuriating beyond belief. My complaints first:Tactical game? -- has no functional top down view, no functional grid, nothing to help chart pathways, lay ambushes, plan charges, nothing. Ambushes often times do not trigger, for reasons unknown to me. Sometimes my warband can charge engaged opponents, sometimes not, seems completely random. I've found my warband stuck in poor situations too often, due to not being able to gauge distances, etc... Inventory-- is a total joke. Small items do not stack, WTF???? Bob loots 3 coins from a body. Bob gets 5 coins from a chest. Bob has 8 coins, right. No Bob has 3 inventory slots and two of them are occupied by 3 coins and 5 coins. Now Bob previously picked up a total of 27 coins. These 27 coins all fit in one inventory slot, but either Bob is too slow to put all his coins in one slot, or...Same thing with wyrdstones. Small fragments take the same space as clusters, which are 10 x the size? You also can't equip anything you pick up. The helmet you just picked up, which you have a place for, on your head, nope no putting it there, that'll have to wait till after the mission.  Gameplay-- is slow, with unnecessary animations. Opposing warbands are really aggressive, their only tactic is to swarm. Quest goals are sometimes vague and can take forever to figure out, or the quest will just randomly end, regardless of wether you are able to complete the objectives, or not. And your typical gather wyrdstone quest, goes like this. 3-5 rounds of exploring, looting, gathering. You get noticed by the other warband. They swarm your warband. One leader/hero or another falls. Morale check. Quest over. And this happens over and over again. RNG-- Game uses rng which can get stuck, causing your warband to suffer, sometimes permanent damage. I just finished a match where the roll was 90 for four consecutive attacks. I lost the objective, due to my hero falling to a zombie with 10 wounds left. Seriously, the zombie has time to destroy my hero, while two other henchmen miss all their attacks. Hero falls, zombie loots the token I took from the other warbands hero, I finally get a shot in on the zombie, morale check and quest over. No objective for you. My compliments:Warband develpoment -- Customization on every member of the warband. You can tweak each member of your warband to make them specific, dynami, and unique. There are almost too many customization choices available, which means you can really spend time and geak out. Landscape-- Mordheim is Warhammer fantasy to a T. It's brutal, trap filled, landscape in ruin. Basically Warhammer fantasy. Mechanics-- Not fully a plus in my book, but I do like that the warband can do maneuvers and attacks. Different maneuvers use movement points, attacks use offensive points, etc...I don't know if any of the issues I have with the game will ever be fixed, or if anyone with the ability to mod or fix some of this stuff will. I hope that happens. Like I said, Mordheim should be the game that occupies way too much of my life, except that it isn't.

												Very disappointing game. Expect to fail a 75% chance or above roll 6+ times in a row. Optional objectives are a joke as one of the war bands will be defeated before you are through looting even half of the objects on the map. content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												I want to like this game... I really do. I gave it a big chance, tried each warband, played it pretty hard.. But it's massively let down by terrible balancing and lack of saving... My game was ruined at Act 1 scene 4, after building a solid gang, I was progressing across the bridge when the Chaos Ogre on next to no health, Stunned the main story character then killed him in 2 blows from full health.. Mission over I lose? all my characters take wounds which ruins them, I lose all my magic equiptment... Seriously 3 BS Dice rolls in a row and may as well start over.. Why would you not give a save option? Seriously it's 2016.. you have an ok game with a terrible mechanic ruining it.Add to this... Terrible balancing means camping/Turtleing is by far the best option, kite an enemy, kill them, rinse and repeat.I await the downvotes from the insane hardcore lovers.. "oh you just don't get it" or some such nonsense.. Terrible mechanics don't equal hardcore they equal terrible design descions...Edit - It's not even difficult for the developers to fix. Offer a single player mode (so saving can't be exploited for multiplayer) disable the multiplayer for warbands created for singleplayer, and allow the player to save the game, it's clearly saved after every single characters move.  Just add saving/loading in camp. Then people can re fight bad fights.. Suddenly the game is less merciless and enjoyable. Balancing the battles however might take a bit more work. At present the AI seems ridiculously over powered in 1 on 1 situations.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
Product received for free
												Disclosure: Marking this review as if I got it for free since I got it on a freeplay weekend, which I guess would technically count.This doesn't really deserve a full review because frankly there's not enough good about it to warrant going into the finer points, nor is there a lot of potential here to want to discuss the game in greater detail. Instead, please see a list of Pros and Cons and determine for yourself if this is the game for you.Pros:*looks good (when the characters don't disappear, or aren't shown)*different from other games*not much elseCons:*Bad camera angles that don't show characters, they disappear, or are zoomed in on character's heads so you can't see the action.*Music sounds like someone beating a trash can with a baseball bat every other second.*Simple concept for gameplay is pushed beyond confusing and is completely counter-intuitive.*Endless tutorials*Slow gameplay with long waiting periods that typically makes one match last more than an hour (when it should be less than 30 mins)*Little to no variation with weapons, not enough variety in gear - literally clothes, light and heavy armor (no known subtypes).*Match conditions are "go get X crystals." Actual gameplay is enemy AI attacks you (is way OP) and then match ends with most of your guys wounded for 5 days which is a huge problem since you can only play one match per game day and you only have 3 slots (at the beginning) to rest injured characters.*If you win a match, you barely get a couple crystals, maybe one looted item that is the same as the crap you already have, and no gold. Thus making you unable to pay your groups upkeep nor upgrade them to be ready for the next match.*No strategy involved, literally guys are set up in seemingly random locations that almost always put you at a disadvantage.*Can barely figure out who's turn it is, what's in inventory, how strong enemies are, etc.*UI is unacceptably crowded with useless information while not providing useful information.*and it's incredibly boring. When I'm biased and a fan of these types of games, this is a very bad con.Watching this game develop from the ground up only to become a clunky mess is disappointing. There is a concept buried deep within this game that just never surfaces into a fun, playable experience. Well, for me anyways.

content:
Posted: February 16
												Was a really good game that had value both to more harcore players and to more casual players (although it required some kind of cheaty tactics) but they caved to the hardcore players and removed the ability to save scum. While I understand why people wouldn't want this in the game but I didn't see any reason they could have left the option in the game for those of us who wanted it. Haven't played the game since, waste of moneyedit: Went back to play this game again to see if it still was just as unfun as it was when I played it last and I confirm if you don't like games that just punish you for even booting them up then don't get this game. I played one mission and already regretted even the time I spent downloading it. If you just like the setting then I would grab Vermintide, it's a much better game and while challenging can be actually fun with a little investment (It has its own problems but they are not as severe, and the developers have worked to improvbe on them). If you want a warhammer tactical game grab Total War Warhammer (although I would suggest getting it on sale, it's not quite worth the full price). Maybe if you're a very particular kind of gamer than you can derive some kind of enjoyment from this game, but the developers made a "design decision" to alienate a majority of prospective customers and that's probably why this game barely gets a few hundred players a day. Sad but true

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
Product received for free
												I expected text. I expected numbers. I expected complexity and I even expected difficulty. I cannot recommend this game.The setting is good. The intro-cinematic sets the scene brilliantly and left me eager to dive into the mysterious city of the damned. The graphics are good and the atmosphere is created through them, even if the musical score is somewhat repetitive. Unfortunately, the illusion started to wear thin on the race-selection screen and, after several missions, the complete lack of any form of story was quite apparent. Without a story to speak of, all that remained was the strategy game-play itself and, sadly, it is awful.The strategy game-play is scuppered by the user interface which is abominable. Text flashes on the screen, containing vital feedback and numbers, and even though the game is a turn-based one, you still miss things because it disappears before you can read it - most noticeably when effects and spells trigger or during your opponent's turn! This is simply inexcusable - a scrollable text console of past dice-roll outcomes and effect numbers would have been more functional than the fleeting semi-transparent U.I. overlays that Mordheim relies upon.The controls are also pathetic. There are no mouse-and-keyboard controls at all – the left and right mouse buttons act only as pseudo-buttons, keyboard keys as more buttons and, together, these basically replicate a console controller. The mouse pointer, itself, is hardly utilised. Expect console-style inventory management and lists and lists and lists. To select a parry action, for example, you do not click a parry button or press a parry key. Instead, you use Q or E to scroll through all available actions until you get to "parry" and press the single action button. You have to scroll all the way, every time. To find out whether you have an "Aim" action available, you have to scroll through every available action, reading each one, to see if it is in the list. It's hopeless.Additionally, on the user-interaction side, the concept of a party-based strategy game with over-the-shoulder third-person movement is simply laughable. To see an overview of the situation - vital for any sort of strategic planning - you have to open a map view in which everything is represented symbolically, the height-levels of the terrain are inscrutable and no commands can be issued. To issue commands, you return to the over-the-shoulder perspective in which you can't see much at all and the game controls like a regular third-person game. This is extremely awkward to use, accurately. Why the developers thought this was preferable to a click-to-move, click-to-select scheme with a proper pannable and zoomable camera has only one possible explanation: can't click with a controller!Mordheim's penultimate failing is its complete lack of respect for the player's time and patience. I appreciate slow games and long games and games that reward a time-investment. I do not appreciate games that consist more of waiting than of playing and, in Mordheim, you spend well over 50% of your play-time staring at the message: "Waiting for opponent's turn." Why can't the opponent's turn be simulated near-instantly, as fast as my CPU can do so, when I can't even see the opponent-character that's acting? Time is also wasted by pointless animation for non-actions - for instance, the silly one that plays every time you select "Overwatch" - something that should be instant because it only has an effect in the next turn, if at all.Ultimately, however, Morheim fails to answer the most important question of all: "Why should I care?" After playing for a few hours, I realised that I simply didn't have any attachment to my warband or to the goals of the mission or to the gear I had scavenged or to the future of the game - the game simply neglected to make me care... certainly, it didn't make me care enough to see past the abominable U.I. and pathetic controls, or to invest the boredom-time waiting for my opponent's turn.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												This game is too hard.  The original Mordheim (and Necromunda etc like it) were tabletop games where both sides were humans and most importantly 'Used the same dice'.  Here the computer has one loaded set against yours.  Before people cry 'RNG' I have seen that in other games - even games based on other tabletop games by Games Workshop, and at least its generally fair even if you have a bad game sometimes.  But here when my character misses 3 '90% hits' in a row, and his one hits with 3 '60% hits' in a row - and it happens almost every game - I call that cheating not 'RNG'.  When this happens in 'every battle' then it goes beyond a joke, and so I have decided to uninstall this game today.  A shame really - I enjoyed the seeming difficulty to start with.  But there a difference between a difficult game (which I enjoy) and a cheating opponent (which I do not) - and there are better ways for a developer to make a game hard than loaded dice!  Not even remotely recommended - 2/10

								Very promising turn-based tactical battles.Visually looks good.More in-depth review when game is farther along, many things are marked "coming soon" at this point.Quick update: there is now single-player campaign system and it seems very interesting :)You recruit characters to warband between missions, equip them, level up, healing and so forth. number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Ok, this is my first review and it is worth my time to write about this game which is a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥in my opinion.For me this game is punishing me all the time without even slightly rewarding me for anything. It seems like the developers were thinking "oh look, our game is so hard and so challenging and most of the time we thought about ways to penalize you, so we must have a really great game, people like that!"Trust me dear developers, no they don't. I really liked games like Dark Souls which were challenging and hard, but also rewarding and you really had a pleasure to win after multiple deaths on the same boss. Dark Souls didn' t miss the one and most important thing that you did, you should have fun playing a game, afterall thats the only reason why you start to play a game, no?But let me start and say why. I'm sure I did something wrong on the first mission but god forbid. why shouln't I on my first day playing this game. What happend on the first story mission:1) I wasted 5 hours of my life without any progress or enjoyment2) Monsters started the first round and ganged my hero (2 x 48 hp hits) so he was almost dead (he is ok equiped, breast plate, helmet etc.. how am I supposed to finish the mission with one of my best players almost dead from the start of the mission??3) I had to play that mission two time to know how to place my party in the sewers for the Spinetaker rat there which is killing my people in one round4) I managed to kill all in the sewers with only loosing one player and placed 7/10 barrels there (really I have to place a frigging 10 barrels, why not make it 50???)5) So I thought ok, no problem I will go back and take another 3 barrels with me, but what happend? of course 2 more rats as reinforcements appeared.6) After killing those two rats, three more appeared. At the end I managed to kill a total of 9 rats.7) But of course they kept coming... why? I can't tell, I guess I would have to ask those genius developers of that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game8) Of course at some point all was over and my main character had a 5 day penalty, that means there is no reason to try the mission again for 5 days, resulting in failing the shipping request which will result in even more penaltiesSo, my first experience with this game was not only frustrating but I just felt messed with by the developers, thats really why I'm so mad about this♥♥♥♥♥♥here. Spending hours and loosing all at the end without any progress, with only frustration, please tell me why should I play your ♥♥♥♥ing game??Edit: Oh, and as I see all the weapons of my characters are gone also, rating my party useless. Hehe this is all so ridiculous, it really starts to get funny now for me.Edit: Ok, I played my warband a bit further. Recovered from the penalties, won some missions, was ably to fulfill the shipment penalty request of 167 weight. I stayed on the normal missions like suggested, actually my warband was in a good shape. Today I'm really done with this game after giving it really a looong chance that it didn't deserve from the start, and will finally uninstall it.Additional negatives:.) On many maps your party is spread all over the place making it impossible for you to plan tactically but just try to find the fastest path to group them together..) You have no idea how to navigate on this map. Is there really an exit in that building or will you find a magically closed door that you are for no reason unable to open..) It seems like the rats which I encouter often can walk over half the map in one turn giving them a tremendous advantage to form together and zerg single targets killing them in the first turn. I would say in those missions the advantage of the AI is 80:20 from the start. In addition self deploy just does not always work. No one knows why..) When the enemy is low you magically start to miss (I don't speak about dodge/parry). That is a proven fact for me. It is like that. Even when you have 88-93% hit chance, if an enemy is low on health you will start to miss a lot. If someone says otherwise, they need to go back to school. That is fact, it is cheating..) Some missions you will lose right from the first round and you can do nothing about it, just nothing. That is not how a tacticall game should work. This is making it look hard or unforgiving when it is just bad design and game mechanics..) You can not use the weapons or armour that you obtained after a mission. Really there is almost no loot in this game and when you find some, you are not allowed to use it because it is from a different warband. Really? You will not be able to use the poison swords from the rats or the hammer from the sisters, because the developers miss the animations? Give me a break, or some more for this game, please..) I could really go one but I'm losing interest....Who ever reads this, trust me, stay away from this game and take any other turn based game instead. Trust me, I'm not ranting or lying, just trust me.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Mordheim: City of the DamnedI’ve always loved table top games and played a little Warhammer 40k back in the day, and I’m a huge fan of 40k themed games, but I never really got into the classic Warhammer setting.  This was my first real experience both with the classic Warhammer setting and Mordheim, and I love it.The gameplay feels like how a tabletop conversion with great graphics should, and at first there isn’t a whole lot to fights – knock them out before they knock you out.  As the game picks up you gain levels, new units, items, skills, and enchantments and things start taking off.  Skills and items sets, along with unit placement and scavenging, becomes a huge part of every encounter.  If you get far enough, you can even unlock some units from another faction for more diversity and options.As many people have discussed, the game is brutally unforgiving.  Think XCOM on Ironman and one of the hardest settings – as much as I wish I had the option to turn off “Ironman” in this game, it’s built in.  The Random Number Generator (RNG) is more forgiving than it used to be, but people who are “perfectionists” will quickly find themselves stressed at all the things they cannot control.  You will miss with a 95% chance to hit, either because you rolled a “1” or because they dodged.  You will also get hit when your guy has “135%” chance to dodge incoming attacks.  And that’s the beauty of a true table top conversion.  Even gods have brain farts.The weakest aspects of the game, at this point, is balancing and AI – and they Venn diagram into one another where the weakness of the game is concerned (for me, at least).  While each faction does something a little better than the other, the units are mostly the same across the board with the only real exception being Impressives and the Chaos faction’s large number of Fear/Terror/Alone immunities.  The AI also leaves something to be desired.  I often find that 1 or 2 of the enemies in a fight get stuck on walls, in doorways, or on stairs – especially common for the larger Ogre, Rat Ogre, and Chaos Spawn Impressives.  This is great for the player because it means less to manage, but it is also frustrating – it makes victories feel cheap, keeps you from fulfilling optional bounty objectives (as it is often the bounty targets who get stuck!), and you never know when that guy is going to decide to stop derping into a wall and join the fight.  Another problem is the way the AI will often bee-line for you - which means that Heroes, Leaders, and Impressives (that don’t get stuck) are the first you run into, which also means they’re the first of the enemies to go down before the henchman can support them if you’re patient and set up proper ambush points.  The way the game “balances” the poor AI decision making and pathing is by simply making them stronger than you.  In a “normal” fight, the easiest on the map, enemies have more wounds (hit points) and hit harder.  It scales up with difficulty; the hardest missions simply have units with 40% more wounds and damage on top of their guys having more skills and better stats.  What this means is that you will never have an even match-up against the AI; you’re always expected to out play them as you’re never on equal terms.Despite the issues above, the developers are intent on polishing their game.  They are already working on improving the AI and making other adjustments as/when the community brings up issues.  The game has a lot of potential for growth as the Warhammer world is huge, with tons of units and factions that could be included, as well as more cosmetic options for people who are really into the customization aspect.  I look forward to seeing what the developers do and I hope to see more games like this, especially a Warhammer 40k type!

content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												This is a rough tough game and I love it. + It doesn't baby you like ♥♥♥♥♥ console games.  When you make mistakes you will be punished (sometimes severely) permanently.  BUT it has a decent set of tutorial missions to ease you in and get you and your warband on your way.+ If you are a  squad-level strategy fan you'll probably like it.  It's similar to XCOM, Blood Bowl, and Space Hulk Ascension if you've played any of those.+ It's original.  I love that the devs took risks on this and I think it paid off.+ The graphics are certainly not AAA, but they did a good job of making you feel like you're roaming the twisted streets of the city of the damned.There are some downsides for sure:- Currently loading screens are almost 1 min, and I suspect it has quite a few memory leaks.  Hopefully this will improve with patches.- The 3rd person persepective really detracts from the strategy nature of the game.  It's very difficult to navigate your team around the multi-level streets without constantly flicking over to the map.  I wish they'd built the game more around top-down perspective.  Having said this I can see why they chose to get you down into the streets where the action is.- Alot of the bonuses are marginal.  I find this frustrating.  2% here, some other useless skill there.  When your men get 'killed', often they either suffer some marginal penalty, or get one so severe they are finished.- The AI is pretty good compared to many games, but has some pretty serious flaws.  Hopefully this will improve with time.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												A good TBS game!   You move a Warhammer-style squad through the ruins of a city in search of comet fragments.  4 different factions with 4 somewhat different play-styles give it decent variety.  AI is generally predictable, prioritizing loot over tactical advantage, but will react quickly if you make a mis-step, and also makes a point of prioritizing & hunting down near beaten warriors of your squad if you leave them exposed.MP is much more of a nail-biter challenge, as each player scouts for the other and tries to bring more force of arms to the point of conflict before the other player.  One-on-one duels between squad units tend to be RNG affairs, which make a lot of the strategy about tactically manuevering your opponent into an ambush where you can bring the hammer of sigmar down on them with the full weight of your squad.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												I really want to enjoy this game, and I'll probably keep playing it now and then, but it's very, very hard to recommend, especially at full price. On sale it's much, much safer for your wallet, though not on your blood pressure, it will suffer and if you're anything like me you'll break a keyboard or two while realizing that.It is an excellent strategy game. As a warband within the walls of Mordheim you are tasked by superiors to retrieve a substance froma meteor that's all over the city, while combating rival bands and improving your troops.It's strategy, so you'll move units around a battlefield and combat and pick up items and resources, pay tribute to your benifactor, and upgrade your team. However, given my complaints, it might be better to call it a rouge-like strategy.Your higher ups will demand some wyrdstone, you will go out to complete the order, and get paid for it. RNG will kill your team. You will try to hire more people. You will run out of money. You will be stuck without money and without units and your superior will still demand more until game over. Over and over and over again. Plan to fail in the face of an awful system of routine pain and suffering if you want to get to the delicious center where all the excellent strategy and gameplay lie.An auto save system keeps you from save scumming, which would be a mode in another game, allowing for a variety of people to enjoy the game any way they want. As it stands, it serves only to frusterate as men you pay to fight fail and fall over while trying to complete basic plans. A 90% chance to hit is closer to a 50 in the eyes of the RNG gods. Watch people you've put hours of work and skill into die because they were randomly put next to an ogre. Observe nights of effort put to the flame by lucky crit.Some people are into that, and that's cool, this game will cater to you, and I can reccomend it. The rest of us are left kind of disappointed we spent money on this.

												     A poorly executed attempt at bringing the original Mordheim game to PC. If you enjoy dumping hours into building a team, only to have 30 minutes of gameplay destroy your effort, you'll enjoy this. If you like getting your teeth pulled, it'll be a great experience. If you enjoy being roughly ♥♥♥♥ed in the♥♥♥♥♥ this is the game for you.      The sad thing is there's a great game hidden somewhere in here, but the glitchy AI (that does things like speed through your overwatch and into your face without having suffered any consequences on a turn-by-turn basis) kinda ruins any hope of greatness this game may have had. I want to like this game, but I also don't want to stick my leg in an open door and smash it closed as hard as I can repeatedly.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												Only recommended for a die hard Warhammer fan. If you are looking for a strategic game is better to find an alternative. The campaign & warband management it's generally well done, with upkeep costs for your soldiers, wound system (both mental and physical) that can permanently change the warrior attitude and stats, equipment choices and so on, but the actual strategic gameplay is a joke. Movements and attacks are performed in a 3d person view camera, you can't pan around and you can only use a crappy 2d map to actually plan your moves. Movements are clunky at best. UI it's terrible.  Actions takes way too much time to process (especially the enemies ones), many useless animations are in the way. Stats checks for stupid stuff like climbing a wall that frankly i don't understand what purpose should serve in terms of actual gameplay. Lastly, most of the skills/spells you can teach to a warrior are useless or way too marginal to actually make a difference. It's just feels weak as a turn-based strategic game. Overall a sleep inducing gameplay, with a boring soundtrack and low quality sound effects that unfortunately didn't help in keeping me engaged.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												AVOID THIS GAME. YOU WILL BE WASTING YOUR MONEY.I so wanted to like this game, but as it stands I cannot recommend the game. The graphics are good, as is the combat system.I did make a negative review after 18 hours play, but decided to delete that and give the game a second chance as it is quite addictive. However I wish that I hadn't bothered deleting the review.Over 200 hours played and almost as many warbands formed and deleted within first few rounds due to being routed and made useless by way over powered AI warbands.All that you read about the broken and biased RNG is true and then some.Warband characters who have 80%+ chance to hit miss 80%+ of the time. Whilst AI characters hit your characters 80%+ of the time and a high percentage of these hits are critical kills or stuns. Your hits do minimal damage, with very few criticals.The vast bias toward AI characters can in no way be attributed to stats and buffs or debuffs. The obvious imbalance is too great for this.If this were anything to do with gambling the developers would be guilty of cheating by using loaded dice.In the 92 hours I played so far I have formed and deleted over 100 warbands, most of them during the first or second mission, because they were put out of action so easily by the AI warband, with resultant loss of items, and treatment costs and cost of replacing items and characters which were out of action or died.If you meet the Sisters warband near the beginning you might as well abandon mission immediately and delete your own warband. They are so OP, and have far greater movement han other warbands. Chances of beating them latter in the game increase, but only slightly. They have high level spells, and multiple high damage hits with weapons.Out of action characters get wounds which need treatment. This treatment is expensive and far out weighs any loot or gold gained from a mission. It quickly comes to the point that you can nolonger continue as you can't treat out of action characters and you can't replace them. If your leader is out of action you cannot continue untill treatment is finished or they are replaced by another leader. With obvious loss of already scarce funds. If you have insufficient funds that's end game.On the subject of costs, the costs of training a character are prohibitive. On the one occasion where I did get a warband to a decent level I had characters with 6 skill points which could not be used as the costs were unaffordable. Most charcters had got to their maximum stats too as it took so many missions to get anywhere.In the end this warband was deleted at the library mission still in the first chapter, as charaters were either so badly injured, lost limbs or died that continuing was not possible.At high levels the costs of replacing characters who die is so expensive as to be pretty much impossible. This means you can only get low level replacemants who are put out of action the first mission they enter.The mercenary warlock is a waist of time and money. His single spell, blinding light, is ineffectual. He is easily killed and not worth the expense of treatment. I soon fired the one I had.The same goes for the wolf priest of ulric. Crap spell to start with, misses most of his hits if he gets into melee, only 10% dodge chance even without armour so easily killed. Also can easily be  killed or seriously wounded just casting his one crap spell.Game load times are appaling. Go make a drink, finish it and go make another. If you are lucky the mission may have loaded. Deployment and AI movemnt also gets increasingly lengthy as the warband members increase in numbers.I will probably continue playing in the hope that the RNG issues are fixed, but I won't hold my breath on that score having seen the number of comments on this area without improvemnts being made.I cannot recomend the game until the RNG issues are fixed.Edit:- 18/01/16I forgot to mention the constant freezes and crashes. Usually when any sort of action is initiated. Climbing, jumping down, attacking and triggering traps. I have plenty of games which are far more graphic intensive and I do not have issues with them.The crashes are particularly anoying because of the lengthy load times.Edit 8/2/16Gave it another chance.Appalingly bad game balance. It seems that not only is the game heavily balanced towords AI warband strength, and hit abilities and defence abilities, the AI warband does not have a limit on the nuimber of characters in the warband or the distance each character can move.Just deleted yet another warbdand after 33 games getting nowhere. Hadn't even got as far as the temple mission (second main mission). Warband at full compliment with most characters max'd out on ability points, was overwelmingly outnumbered by characters who could move from one side of the map to the other in one move, and had multiple hits per character. I did have the disadvantage of 3 one eyed characters, 2 of them being archers. The ability to gain gold is so limited, and the expenses involved replacing higher level characters so excessive, as to make replacing even one of these 3 impossible.All my characters were put out of action and belongings removed. This left me with all characters needing days of recovery with no weapons, and no money to replace lost weapons.I have now deleted this pile of garbage from my pc, as it's obvious balance issues are not going to be fixed. It has become far to tedious spending hours getting absolutely nowhere, because the game is so heavily biased in favour of the AI warband. Unfortunately a refund is even less likely than a balance fix.Edit: After a very long break I decided to give this game another chance. Big misstake.Hoping updates would have improved the obvious imbalance to the overpowered AI characters how sad I was to find that the AI charcters are now even more overpowered. Now it is impossible to get anywhere without being obliterated.Out of over a dozen warbands started, well over 60% were deleted after the first round having been whipped out by overpowered AI with greater numbers in warbands, having much higher damage output and multiple attacks. Edit - after spending over 100 hours getting mercs to level 9, most of them level 10 I had to abandon act 2 scene 2 because the game froze on pulling the lever to the heirloom cart. Had to control, alt del to get out of game, and then would not load past 98%. Tried various fixes from checking game cash and deleting local files and reloading, but did not work. Even deletd save files once I found it, and cut connection to steam cloud for this game, and it still managed to try and load from same broken save file only to get as far as 98% and no further. Abandoning resulted in most mercs being killed and those left were incapacitated including the captain so could not continue with game. Deleted warband. This is a known issue that still has not been fixed!Unfortunately I cannot get a refund so I will no doubt continue to bang my head against a wall playing this occasionally since I have wasted my money on the game.
