												While I can't recomend this game I have to give props to Rogue Factorfor their revolutionary, yet simple, game engine! It couldn't have been easy to come up with something so sadistic yet seemingly random. I don't know if 'screw the player whenever possible' can be written in game code but thats what this game feels like.I read on a post that easy mode for this game came at lvl 5 when you could get your epic (or whatever) hero. Well as soon as you get one, your enemys have them too (on single player). I did this on three of the 4 factions. It sure was fun playing round after round on two of these factions, with my big ol' ogre dude failing inteligence tests over and over and never doing anything. Keep in mind, to field these guys you have to get rid of 2 hero types that would have actually done something. The AI never really seemed to have this issue, their big ol' ogre dudes always seemed to show up to roll over my band. The whole game is like this. I have never been so frustrated, or dissapointed, by a game. Sad, the concept was awesome.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												     A poorly executed attempt at bringing the original Mordheim game to PC. If you enjoy dumping hours into building a team, only to have 30 minutes of gameplay destroy your effort, you'll enjoy this. If you like getting your teeth pulled, it'll be a great experience. If you enjoy being roughly ♥♥♥♥ed in the♥♥♥♥♥ this is the game for you.      The sad thing is there's a great game hidden somewhere in here, but the glitchy AI (that does things like speed through your overwatch and into your face without having suffered any consequences on a turn-by-turn basis) kinda ruins any hope of greatness this game may have had. I want to like this game, but I also don't want to stick my leg in an open door and smash it closed as hard as I can repeatedly.

Posted: March 2, 2016
												A game that I have invested many hours into that has ultimately given me minor streaks of enjoyment with a heavy dose of pure, gut wrenching frustration, due to largely the games broken, or non-existant RNG engine (Random Number Generator). The game maker has "addressed" their broke RNG engine in the last patch, but for the life of me, I see no difference. I have yet to play this game against other humans, but against the AI, no matter the hit chance, the AI wont miss and no matter what I do, I seem to be unable to hit consistantly. if they ever fix the RNG engine in this game, I'll change my review to thumbs up, but until then, its nothing but frustration and hate for this game that has so much potential.  A game that is not fun due to what seems like weak AI that is propped up with a loaded RNG engine is not worth your money.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												I have NEVER, in the history of Steam, used the Steam Refund system. I refused. Even in games I have that I could only touch once. I left them in my library out of respect for the game developers, or just because it padded out my collection a little. Either way, that changed when I got this game.I am a huge fan of Games Workshop. I love the lore that they craft. I even played through their horrible first rendition of Space Hulk because I enjoyed the original tabletop game. But this game just broke me a little. My friend watched as I struggled through just over an hour of gameplay. It was horrendous. He died of laughter. I went and got a refund.I want to like this game. I do. The concept behind it is full of potential. But this delivery is just poor. I would wholeheartedly come back if they completely revamped it instead of pushing out a DLC warband or two. At least Space Hulk learned a little from the past in the sequel; I hope this game can eventualy do the same.

												I found this game to be frustrating in the extreme. The Loot system if difficult to use and limited in capacity as to make it impossible to collect the required items to complete missions. The control system is also very clumsy so that you can often end a characters turn or preform the wrong action by accident . Overall i am very uhappy with this game and feel that it was waste of my money and time.

content:
Posted: February 17
												RNG: The game. Simple as that.Its not really about planning, about strategy or whatever. Its all about dice rolls.You might plan ahead, trying to setup ambushes but in the end all that matters is if you will get proper rolls. 85% chance to hit or 95% doesnt mean anything, you will miss all attacks because this time RNG decided to have bad day. That enemy you flanked and outnumbered will kill half of your people, because RNG will favors him this time. And said half of people will die for good or get absolutely useless due to permanent injures because of RNG. Half of your troops wont even get a chance to attack against that vampire from DLC warband because they will fail all rolls. All your precious weapons will get stolen because your guys will fail their dodge rolls and die. Your units will lose half their hp from charging enemies, because when both you and AI have same range, AI gets advantage, because. And so on...Of course, veteran players wont agree with that. They will tell you that game is fair and "high level warband gets advantage over AI". Maybe - chances are that you wont reach that high level at all. They will defend system, where enemy warband have same composition and same levels as your own team - except that they wont be restricted by gold and have all those skills you cant learn because you lack money. They will tell you that AI is actually in worse position for picking skills at random - while your own team wont have ANY. They might even just tell you to "get good".Some say that all the fun in this game comes from losing. If you like being wiped on the floor, then go ahead - you will probably enjoy this. If you want fair game - go play something else.

												This game has an excellent premise, it has the perfect setting, it is punishing if you make a mistake and intend you to not get attached to warbands as they fall by the wayside in the city of the damned.It is also incredibly unfair at times, and I personally will never put the game down with a smile on my face as I generally feel cheated by the RNG or the AI's ability to rush half a football field over to you and then ruin your day in a turn. content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Mordheim has a nice idea, coming from the old tabletop game.  However, the idea that your warband automatically deploys every time in random areas with no idea where the rest of the warband is, is just flat out rediculous.  You have no way of knowing where they are unless you accidentally see them in passing, when the enemy is moving and you see at least 2 warband members.  Then finding any loot, forget it.  You have no way of knowing where that is either.  You will wind up deleting and creating new warbands constantly because you have so many injured, that you cannot adventure to make money, and when you do, you are scattered and wiped out.  And your opponents are not scattered.  They are grouped together and always know exactly where your warband is.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												I really wanted to recommend this game.  Let's start with the good: it looks amazing, and does a strong job of capturing the feel of despair that permeates the Warhammer universe.  I approached the game assuming it would be a rogue-like, and on my first playthrough everything clicked well for 8-9 battles and I had a great time.  I won most, I lost a couple.  Eventually, my warband lost a fight badly, my Leader and my Hero both suffered perma-death, so I rolled-up a new warband.I've rolled up four new warbands since then, and never made it past the second mission.Because the AI is so bad, the Devs game it a huge number of advantages.  Some are blatant, others I'm inferring based on AI behavior.1) In anything that should be an even match-up, it takes twice as many hits for a PC to defeat an AI than it does an AI to defeat a PC.  If the enemy leader runs up out of nowhere and smacks your leader, you will lose about 1/3 of your health in one shot.  When you counterattack, you'll do about 1/6 of his health in total damage.  Also, archers are incredibly underpowered, and only do about 10-15% damage to an enemy.  It's pretty much the same for minions.  This means that in a one-on-one fight, you are generally guaranteed to lose.  The only way to defeat the enemy is to mass combat power on an isolated enemy.  Which brings us to point 2...2) It's often impossible to mass combat power, because the game frequently scatters your characters' starting positions all over the map.  You will often start with at least one character alone and surrounded by enemies.  Even if you have all your characters make a beeline for a central location, it will take a minimum of 2-3 rounds to consolidate.  In that time period, at least one or two of your characters will probably be dead, because the AI never seems to have a problem bringing 2-3 characters into contact with an isolated character by round 2.3) The AI always seems to know the shortest path through level geometry.  If I have archers stationed at a high point raining down arrows, the AI can always find a path to get a melee character into close combat in one round.  Meanwhile , a human player without perfect knowledge of the geometry may spend several rounds trying to find a path up to an enemy archer.4) The only real source of money in the game is Wyrdstone, and you must collect it constantly to please your patron to keep the game from ending.  However, the enemy generally seems to have no interest in Wyrdstone, and makes a beeline for your characters, forcing you to spend all your efforts fighting until one side routs.  If your rout, you receive no Wyrdstone.  If you win, you receive a very small fraction of the total Wyrdstone remaining on the map.The one time the enemy IS interested in Wyrdstone is when one of your characters has collected some and is running it back to your wagon.  The AI seems to know which character has Wyrdstone and focuses all effort on bringing down that character to prevent you from collecting any.5) There is no difficulty setting.  I understand it's supposed to be hardcore, but even after paying for scouts, my difficulty options for battle on Day 2 are frequently a combination of Brutal and Deadly.  In order to make your required payments to your patron, you need to win the overwhelming majority of battles.  Because of the low Wyrdstone collection rate, even the battles you win provide very little Wyrdstone.  Check out the achievements on who has even gotten as far as completing Chapter 1 for each of the factions.  The highest is currently the Mercenaries with 3%.  It's one thing if your game demands intelligent play and well-thought tactics.  But this game is frequently over before you take your first turn.Verdict: This could be a great game if they smooth the learning curve a bit, stop the deployment stupidity, and reduce the AI's stat advantage.  There's a great game hiding in there.  The people who praise the game in its current form generally talk about how easy it is to exploit the AI.  If the only way to win is through AI exploitation, this is a poorly designed game.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												This is my first review.Mordheim is absolutely my very most favorite tabletop game of all time.  I love just about everything it has.  I love the feeling of scarcity.  I love the brutal, unforgiving nature of that terrible broken city.  I love how your heroes grow and develop only to eventualy succumb to wounds, madness or death.  It is dark, and it is amazing.This rendition of it did get some things right, a lot when I truly consider it.  However, I can not recommend it.  It simply has no soul...  It is immediately a grind from the very beginning and nothing else.  Yes, you will get some new units unlocked and some slightly better gear.  Yes, your units will level up, get skills and improve.  Yay!The game made it feel as if none of that really mattered.  You will never encounter the same warband you fought before.  They are all random.  You will never enter an engagement against anything other than a superior foe.  I like hard games, but I also like a game to make me feel something other than annoyance.Here's what happened to me.  I made a whole bunch of different warbands.  I tried 'em all.   Started with the Skaven, but couldn't get them to work.  They were really fast and could kind of use that to determine where the battles took place but they just seemed too fragile to keep up with constantly superior foes. Chaos way too random.  Really liked Sisters of Sigmar, but seemed to get the furthest the Empire.  Had everybody in really heavy armor.  Ended up in a fight with the Sisters of Sigmar.  Did freaking great/  Didn't lose a single guy and filled up with a lot of wyrdstone.  Awesome!  Wait...  where is this last enemy? The leader?  I creaped around through a few buildings ready to fend off an ambush but nothing emerged.  The computer was thinking every turn, so I thhought the matriarch must be moving.I found here in an attic right in front of the only ladder, too stupid to come down.  Because I had found them largely useless, none of my guys were packing ranged weapons and the only archer who could do something a little bit useful sometimes was wounded.That left me with three choices:1.  Accept every single one of my units as a casualty because I had not lost enough units to voluntarily rout.2.  Start a new warband as the game does not allow for loading previous games.  I am totally fine with this concept.3.  Quit the game because I didn't like the first two options.I chose number three, and that is why I cannot recommend this game.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								First up I love Warhammer and Mordheim and I think this could well be a fantastic game and hope it will be when finally released.I was planning to wait for the full release but it was on sale so I thought I would pick it up nowbut I always wanted to see how it runs and how its coming along.Well firstly the load times are as many others have pointed out, pretty bloody long but its not the end of the worldits likely the kind of game ill play with a podcast or something in the background,and while I can certainly see how it would not be a major priority a the momentit is something I hope they are able to reduce for full releaseSimilarly it doesn't run great on my laptop, granted my lappy is no beast but when I have fairly modern RTS games running at much better frame rates than turn based games, I think something needs to be said(It's my biggest problem with XCOM a game which I love but god damn does it run like♥♥♥♥♥♥Seriously why is a turn based stratedgy game running at sub 10 fps on the lowest settingsthat isn't something that needs a lil polish at the end, that is something that needs to get optimized pronto.So onto my experience playing the first tutorial, well I finished the tutorial part but you are allowed to finish the battle and kill the remaining enemies, so I set to it...for one turn and then My Rat ogre got stuck and I was forced to quit.Yeah that is a pretty big problem, game ending bug within minutes.What happened was one of my lil skaven ran up a walkway leading to a higher area and ran out of movement on the edge of the other side I then tried to run my Rat ogre up past him as he was closer I was fairly sure I could make it(It was not very easy to tell how far I was gonna be able to move, maybe there is an easier way to see that I didn't notice) so he goes up this ramp and though he is a big guy it looks like I should be able to pass by my other skavenbut alas he got stuck and floated off the floor slightly, unable to move in any directionand due to not being able to end a turn close to an ally (within their field of control)I was forced to quit.I really hope I can at some point change this to a reccomended and say that all this is fixed and the game is greatbut first I needed to do this so that these issues can be fixed, because quite honestly a game breaking in its first tutorial is embarrassing.I hope the devs see this and are able to fiz these issues as best they canI will be back, I bought to support and I am leaving this review to hopefully make this game better.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Mostly the design of the game is solid. Fundamentals like the Stragey and Offence Point systems combined with the various actions are clever and I assume lifted straight from the tabletop. I especially enjoy the ambush mechanic and they are generally well balanced against each other.The maps look nice and are interesting but they need to open some buildings up a bit, it is too easy to turtle up inside a fortress of a ruined tudor building.Customization sucks though I would expect it to be a lesser priority.Collision meshes are too big and frustrating on characters making them silly road blocks for your following characters and making it difficult to navigate.However the biggest problem is that inspite of the level of tactical play offered your ploys will too often become undone by the rng. Your strategy may be sound, you may get the drop on the enemy and be able to focus your strengths, but then you will get ♥♥♥♥ed over by the rng.That is this game in a nutshell, the rng ♥♥♥♥ing you over, again and again. You will do little or even nothing wrong but a set of ridiculously bad rolls (or lucky for the enemy) will see you fail and punished hard. This game and world is meant to be harsh but somewhere someone forgot the game part of that equation, and it's implications. This is less a game and more an exercise in random-fueled frustration.For example I just had my entire warband of 7 take on the enemy commander of a weaker warband, and 2 whole rounds of my team missing, he pummeled my leader and gave him a skull fracture causing him to be stupid for the rest of the campaign. I could not have weighted it more in my favour but all that invested expense, time and effort is now wasted on a useless leader.Maybe if they introduce say three warband fate points I will give this game another shot, until then, ♥♥♥♥ this game.

												I rarely write reviews on games I play here on steam, but this game definitely deserved one.  I got into the game during the early days of playtesting.  Even though I knew that the game was far from finished, it was very difficult to play back then.  Characters would get stuck on stairsor other platforms, or else a in game bug would force you to quit.  Needless to say these all got fixed and the game is one of the best "digital" adaptions of a Tabletop game to date, if not the best.This doesn't mean that the game is perfect, however, knowing what it took to make the game and what went into the development and playtesting mode I will eagerly await DLC for new factions or for the opportunity to play more than two warband on a single map.I am really looking forward to seeing more in the future.

content:
Posted: January 3
												This feels like it would be a game from the late 90s / early-aughts.It's trying to be a 3rd-person turn-based tactical strategy game that incorporates some good ideas, but it needs so much more polish, the end result is just plain disappointing.You will constantly be fighting the camera if there are any walls nearby.Movement will be slightly more restrictive than you expect.The maybe dozen or so mission objectives will be ignored and it will just become a RNG slugfest to see who can kill the other teams leader and heroes first.I'm usually not one to harp on graphics, but the character models are somewhat bland.  Admittedly, I have not played around with the customiation options, but meh.Overall, I can't recommend the game.  It's interesting for maybe an hour, but as the flaws stack and wear on you, you will likely have trouble giving it your attention much longer than that.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
Pros: Faithfully replicates a lot of the Mordheim wargaming experienceCons: Faithfully replicates a lot of the Mordheim wargaming experienceJokes aside, I really wanted to like this game. I'm a big fan of Warhammer in general, so anything in that setting deserves a look in my book. This game fails to deliver on quality, tho, and I'm a bit salty that I spent cash on it at this point. I kept playing, hoping it would "loosen up" and get better as I learned the systems more, but that didn't happen.I played Mercenaries, so your experience may vary depending on your warband preference.Main problemThe main problem this game has is usability. Information I crave isn't provided when I desire it. For example when an enemy is in ambush stance, and I see them, why can I not see how far their ambush range extends? This is vital information for planning my approach, but the information isn't there! This problem is confounded by the fact that ambush ranges vary depending on the movement range of the unit doing the ambush, so you can't learn an approximate distance through experience either.The same applies to traps of all kinds. When I have perceived a trap to be there, why can I not see the trigger area? For a game that wants to be tactical, it makes it very hard to make tactical decisions. The game would be a lot more rewarding if it gave me enough information.Outside a certain distance from my active unit, I can't see traversal-nodes anymore (leap, jump down, etc.) This is tactically important information, but I have to awkwardly run my unit closer just to see this info. Bogs down the game with unnecessary busywork.Secondary problemAdding to the usability problems is the fact that units block a larger area around them than their model indicates. This fact interplays with the level design, which is rife with small corridors, walkways, stairs and bridges to make it a horrible experience trying to maneuver your units around. If you get an archer out on a walkway, you can't be certain you'll be able to funnel any other units past him even though it visually looks completely possible. It's extremely frustrating when your entire plan of attack is foiled by visual misinformation like that. After being hurt by this issue a few times, I started playing extremely conservatively. This bogs down the entire game, as you can't assume based on visual clues what's possible, and have to take the safe bet at every juncture.OtherThe game soaks in randomness. Sure, Mordheim the wargame does, too, but the encounter layouts that aim to provide variation are frightening because of it. When there's a large probability of my units permanently dying, it's infuriating when one is dropped in the middle of three Sisters of Sigmar that proceed to bash him to death in unison with no recourse possible. I have no control over this. If I was given the chance to stack up my forces in a manner I wanted, I could at least take the blame for the misstep myself.The strategy/offense point system feels sub-par. Moving a huge distance and not moving at all has no bearing on how many attacks the unit gets to do. This feels awkward, and makes strategy points less valuable once engaged in melee. Please create a way to revert any movements made on a unit to the starting to position. This is unnecessarily awkward, as I have to retrace my steps to get back the strategy points used. Sometimes, moving in a certain way around corners and through doors will make it impossible to retrace my steps, too.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
TL,DRPros]/b] Visually the world looks good. Captures the style of the classic Mordheim table top game and adds to it. The warbands carry some of their flavor from the original game well. Combat is simple and easy to learn early on, but can be expanded on with skills. The maps are great and intuitive. They are both easy and difficult to navigate at the same time. Unlike most Turn based games your moves aren't locked in.  Room to grow. Theres plenty of source material to develop more warbands and hopefully a better story mode.Cons RNG in this game is almost too painful. The maps could be more diverse.  The warbands only carry a very limited amount of their inspiration over from the table top. leading to ... The warbands are too similar. Very low amount of customization.  Lack of a regular Story to play.  RNG      I truly do like this game so far. It has a lot to offer, to anyone who enjoys turn based strategy (TBS) games and/or Gamesworkshop. The warband all fit their flavors aestheticly. There is RPG elements mixed into the characters; It is deceptively deep if you can keep your characters alive long enough. But thats not to say this game doesnt have it's downfalls. Repetitive maps generic feeling warbands and rage-inducing RNG all scream for some serious future updates. Here I will cover some of the pros and cons I encountered along the way.       P6) The most refreshing part of the TBS side of the game is the ability to move your character throughout the world and then back to explore a different avenue, before coming to the point that you want to stop. Being able to freely explore the buildings and streets is a HUGE boon. P5) There are traps and enemies along the way that can stop your exploration though. The maps are built like city streets and inner city mansions, making them easy to navigate. The catch is all the traps along the way that will stop your movement along the way. Also, many of the buildings are in ruins so you might enter one side hoping to cut through to find that the other side is blocked off. C2) After playing for awhile however, the maps start feeling too similar the buildings all the same. It's like if you were walking through a forest. "Sure, this clearing is different than the last. But it's still really similar."      Being a longtime Gamesworkshop fan since WH40k: Chaos Gate and an avid player of the Mordheim table top game, I was really looking forward to this game. Getting into the game the aesthetics were spot-on. Dark gritty dirty broken. Exactly what longtime fans expect. The look and feel of the warbands is also on point. Where it fails is customization. You can change a few bits of clothing here and there. You can have some different colors but nothing more. That limited customization bleeds over into the gameplay of the warband themselves. Each warband plays in a very similar manner. You have x ammount of little dudes with x amount of heroes. Each warband has the same numbers. Each warband can use most of the same weapons. The flavors of the original game are there for all the warbands except skaven. Chaos guys mutate. Sisters gals are vendictive nuns with divine magic. Merc are well Mercs but they have access to the largest array of wepapons. Skaven are supposed to be an endless horde of assassin rat-men. Because the limited number of henchmen they are not endless. Skaven barely hold onto the idea of being assassins by having a few poison skills. More to come later im tired time for bed

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												What an experience! So unforgiving and brutal, yet tactically challenging and rewarding on good days. Just don't begin to build up an affection for your warband as some bad days will follow unavoidably ... or really bad days.Normally Roguelikes aren't my thing, but this game is so fun and the lore and the factions are just great. The combatsystem is quite similar to the Valkyria Chronicles series (excluiding the direct aiming and in-turn suppression fire) and, in my opinion, is the best possible choice for this kind of game.Mordheim features a global progression that will make new attempts easier over time, but do not expect the game to hold your hand or to provide you with an alternative difficulty. Depending from various factors that you do not know before attempting combat the fight might turn from "under control" to "last ditch effort to avoid getting pummeled" rather quickly.  This is not a game about you nurturing your party through grind. This game is about improving yourself, trying out new things and always taking risks you might wish you would have avoided afterwards.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												Mostly reviewing this to counter all the free weekend people who didnt seem to understand the game. I also started playing during the last free weekend, and it was an easy decision to buy it after i got used to the game mechanics.At first i was annoyed by the limited inventory space, and being unable to loot everything on the map, but the game is balanced around this and if you got all the wyrdstone/loot after winning the game would be too easy and would become boring because of it. I think there is a good risk/reward system in the missions. You can go with the hardest missions and split up your guys to gather more loot of complete the optional objectives, but you risk getting someone isolated and taken out of action. Alternatively, if you only do easy missions and focus only on routing the enemy warband, you risk failing wyrdstone shipments.The only problems i have with the game now is that the AI is very basic and often gets stuck on terrain, and some of the optional objectives are pretty much impossible to complete.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
												Mordheim is essentially a  turn based action strategy game that tries to reduce the feeling of turn based action, and by that I mean that the game removes more traditional elements like grids square moves etc, your movement, for example, is just like you would move in an action game save the distance and actions you take are limited and create almost a checkpoint system where you can back track your movement...so long as nothing happens during that movement.It is set in a city that is basically hell on earth, where demons roam and everything is trying to kill you while you collect little green rocks called wyrdstone that serve as your main currency generator, which incidentally is also trying its best to make sure you die by debuffing you with magic radiation. The fish on the walls spray junk on you to debuff you, traps are everywhere and any corner could have a very angry woman with a hammer or a giant rat with big claws to maim, kill or eat you and then loot your corpse. Surviving Mordheim is like surviving the game of thrones… don’t get too attached to any one character as it will die, lose a leg, arm or eye when you least expect it. There is no save scumming and you get what you get. Which is thematically accurate and well Mordheim.There are moments in this game that are brilliantly funny, like seeing the enemy caster blow him or herself up… it's not so funny when it happens to you. The luck gods are fickle creatures and they do not like you. And that is the core of this game, managing and minimizing luck and risk.  If you can manage your risks well and understand what and why things happen, you will do fine.. ish. However, there are times when you will out right get bent over and torn to shreds, and you will pay for your mistakes. Which to me is part of the challenge of the gameThe AI is not brilliant and sometimes the enemy will sit their licking the walls if it gets stuck on something..like their wagon, though overall the AI acts in a more or less intelligent fashion with the scripted missions being better about it, the AI is exploitable. I once trapped half the enemy force on my own wagon due to its inability to “see” or register some objects and I threw bombs on them until they died..or switched to range and got out of its hole to shoot me. However, this level of ridiculous exploitation is a bit rare and normally one or two enemy AI will get stuck like this every few missions..so don’t count on it. The AI also tends to “prey on the weak” meaning your new hero is going to be target number 1 more often then not..so be aware. Common complaint: other then the AI is regarding impressive..personally I don’t use them all that often as they cost me 2 hero slots and I lose versatility for raw power but here is the thing, as others point out when you 1st get your impressions as you will always be facing an impressive that out levels you own until late game “ie L7-10”. This is true and often frustrates people who play, fair enough, but the trick is until you impressive beefs up, don’t ever have it go head to head with other impressive instead treat him like any other new member, protect it have it beat on weaker opponents and use it as a tool to support the warband, don’t think “raaahg kill!” and send it running off on its own…its just going to die. This game can be a great deal of fun and for me it is…likewise it can be an exercise in frustration as it will punish you, but the sense of reward when you do manage to complete a few chapters is that much more worth it, because unlike other games that just kinda had you victory with a simple reload, you haved, to earn it here..through a mix of strategy, luck and occasionally balls. For some people that is an awesome thing for others not so much

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												Mordheim: City of the Damned is overall a fun game but it requires a very patient and forgiving player sometimes to enjoy it. Originally you have to build up your numbers slowly from 5 members in your warband (which I supported when first playing the game but by the time I made my 20th Warband it felt very restrictive and tedious) to a maximum of 9. The game can become rather repetetive after completing all the story missions with a Warband but before then it is varied and interesting for the most part. There are amusing visual and technical glitches which are relatively harmless (such as being unable to go down a set of normal stairs etc.) but there are also rare glitches which cause warbands at rank 10 to all suffer injuries due to a forced game shutdown (this having occured to a friend of mine's Skavens and he was not very happy to say the least). Never did I feel that one of my casualties was unavoidable and was caused rather by my poor decision making and replacing the units is not that hard in general so I feel the game is usually fair and not that difficult. Learning unit's strategies and combos is a thoroughly enjoyable part of the game that gives it some replayability. However one problem I have with the game is the number of warbands. There are originally 4 to choose from (with an additional one that can be bought as DLC to bring it to 5) and even though their styles are different I would obviously enjoy more Warbands

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												I really tried to like this one. The opening words of dissapointment.I'm a big fan of the Warhammer Fantasy setting and love the warband combat where there is potentiol to get attached to each unit and on paper this game has many games I like. The cruel fight against all odds while just holding on, permanent scaring and wounds that influence gamplay, customizable units etc.I can get over things like medicore animations, the lack of variety character faces or limitations to the aforementioned armor custimization, the bafflingly bad menu design and the fact that said menus work better with mouse controls while the actual gameplay is more fit for gamepad.I do understand the limitations of a budget and in the end they did a very solid job in many areasBut holy ♥♥♥♥ the RNG (Random Number Generation) in this game is just infuriatingly bad to a point where I don't feel challenged or mad, just frustrated. I gave the game several goes with different parties. Some getting obliterated in their second battle beyond repair, others doing allright for a while until half of the team gets crippled and where things can only go downhill from there.RNG is really the core of everything in this game. Even before getting into the turn based combat, RNG decides which units are available, what stuff the shop has in store for your warband and what missions are available to play.In battles you have RNG to decide not only your positioning, but also any movement, attack or defensive actions you take.After the battles you have RNG that decides if an injured characters bears a permanent injury, thus decreasing their stats and further decreasing their chances of success...But surely it cant be just the virtual dice-rolling in the background that's so bothersome. X-Com or FTL for example work just fine for me.So I tried to understand why I feel that the RNG in this game is so bad and I think i managed to figure it out. The combat is very deadly, where a single attack can chip away huge chunks of a healthbar with most units at the beginning of a campaign going down in 3-4 hits. This leaves us with a combat system where technically every hit matters but the game excludes you from having major influence on the outcome.In the end, this lack of control is what just kills it for me and makes me feel like this game doesn't respect my time at all.No matter how well I play, how carefull I plan my movements, set traps and try to outflank my enemies... Win or loose, in the end it just all comes down to a random dice-roll and that just isn't fun to me.So sadly, not a recommendation for me.

												Some things that happened to me in a few hours of play.Leader died on second mission, i had no money to pay the upkeep or medical bills, had to sell my wyrdstones just to get by but i also needed to fulfill a shipment request in three days. After hiring a new leader and patching up my guys i had one day remaining for delivery, took a mission crushed my enemies got the stones, somehow it all worked out and all was fine for a bit.Some time later my leader died yet again this time along with one of my henchmen and several others were wounded pretty bad, the loss hurt even more this time as both dead characters had spent skill points 200 gold down the drain. After recovering things were going pretty smoothly, i was making shipments on time doing well on missions and even picking up a few upgrades for my warband, it was looking good...Next day i do a campaign(story) mission, get horribly recked by demons and fail it, leader died again and my hero also died, my impressive unit got a leg sliced off and now can barly move around on a peg leg.Basicly playing this game is like riding a rollercoaster, sometimes you hit the high point and feel untouchable, then suddenly you get plunged into dispair and desperation.10/10 would get leader killed and units horribly maimed again.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												It is turn-based tactical fighting, squad management game in the warhammer world.  If that sounds good to you than pick it up!  You will not be disapointed.  This game keeps all the stategy element of any other tactical game but instead of moving big clunky squads around you move individual warriors around.  Each warrior levels up, you can pick customizable skills and customize their gear.  As you go you unlock more troops/heroes and troop/heroes types.  Which can be a lot of planning if you OCD about your character builds like me.  You start to get attached to your troops but they can get injured or die which adds a true sense of risk to the game.   The factions are interesting and I love that they put skaven as a playable faction.  The maps are designed well and the control work well.  To maintain your warband you have to be constantly farming warpstone around the field which makes you split your troop into fighters and gathers most of the time.  The layout is a bit hard to see for the map.  It is hard to tell if an area is raise or if you can climb something until you run your character there but that might be intended.

Posted: December 13, 2015
												im going out on a limb with this, and sharing my experiance with my own skaven warband, in essence-ive been lucky as crap due to the horror stories ive heard, mostly i just get minions/henchmen with bad mental conditions or internal injuries that i can just shrug off, so far ive been getting good missions-my advice to people, dont take anything harder then normal for the frist few runs untill you get your warbands size up to snuff with good equipment and your henchmen able to carry at least 3 objects apeice, your heavier units around 4-5. This should give those warpstone runs an easy time or just looting the crap out of people.Also surround surround surround is the key, break enemy units moral and they cant attack! Unless its stinkin chaos, then they dont ever break-personal experiance. Also if you can and have grabbed secondary objectives go for the enemy cart and loot their idol and if you can their chest, you can get some good stuff somtimes from that!The game is susposed to be unforgiving due to mordheims nature as the boardgame and the fact its a gaint imperial city turned into a hell-hole of untold horrors of chaos, skaven, and undead (shame no undead faction...YET!) So those like X-com or the likes will enjoy this game, if your a casual gamer beware, as♥♥♥♥♥♥goes down the drain faster then a dice roll can when you get double 1's.The random roll dynamic fits it, sure you can have a guy with 90% chance to rip the other guy to shreds, but somtime sooner or later hes going to hit that 10% chance to miss, or the enemy dodge or parry is to great to beat. *continued*

content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
												I'd like to recommend this game as I do believe it is fun but I also found alot of people were put off and I was somewhat inclined to agree with them.  I bought the game because I personally enjoyed it and can live with its flaws but since this is a recommendation I personally wouldn't recommend it to someone else.With that being said, here are my views overall:The pros:1. It's a very indepth game, plenty to do and alot to learn.2. Clearly based on Warhammer rules including stats and skills which I love!3. Skaven! I mean c'mon!! Though I would personally prefer Lizardmen.4. Graphics are pretty decent.5. Gameplay is pretty fun and interesting and can keep me going for hours.The cons:1. Lack of content. I mean seriously.. alot of the maps are used too many times and only 2 acts per warband? meh2. Lack of races to choose from. Only 3 and only 4 if you buy the DLC.3. Having to buy DLC for extra units, no new races.4. Gameplay is rather difficult and the hit/miss ratio is rediculous!If you can tolerate an unbalanced hit/miss ratio similar to that of XCOM, or perhaps even worse, and enjoy Warhammer then this is for you but honestly if you can't cope with the frustration and don't like hardcore mode on games like XCOM where every loss counts then I honestly can't recommend this game. Also imo the price tag for this game is a bit steap due to lack on content, I'd recommend waiting for a discount if you're serious about buying it, which is pretty much what I did.Also, I wouldn't bother checking the forums, it's full of newbie haters who'd rather flame you than accept the fact that this game has flaws, they are worse than fanboys around WoW and that to me is pretty sad.  However, don't let the community decide your judgement of the game, fortunately they don't speak for that part, they just merely like attacking others, I guess it gives them a cheap thrill or something.  No doubt I'll get flamed for my comment here but haters will hate, infact if they do it merely proves my point.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												What an experience! So unforgiving and brutal, yet tactically challenging and rewarding on good days. Just don't begin to build up an affection for your warband as some bad days will follow unavoidably ... or really bad days.Normally Roguelikes aren't my thing, but this game is so fun and the lore and the factions are just great. The combatsystem is quite similar to the Valkyria Chronicles series (excluiding the direct aiming and in-turn suppression fire) and, in my opinion, is the best possible choice for this kind of game.Mordheim features a global progression that will make new attempts easier over time, but do not expect the game to hold your hand or to provide you with an alternative difficulty. Depending from various factors that you do not know before attempting combat the fight might turn from "under control" to "last ditch effort to avoid getting pummeled" rather quickly.  This is not a game about you nurturing your party through grind. This game is about improving yourself, trying out new things and always taking risks you might wish you would have avoided afterwards.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Overall still love the game. However, a few issues.1. Stances. Percent to dodge and block should be automatic. Stance should increase the chance. Do no make my shield useless against an attack if I happen to not be in block stance.2. Charge VS Ambush. Make the Ambush range reasonable, or the charge range reasonable, or for god's sake put indicators on the ground. I cannot count the number of times I've been approaching an enemy in "Ambush" stance, setting up for a charge, only to get ambushed, when I CAN CLEARLY SEE THEM! On the other hand, I can count the one hundred million times I've been in "Ambush" stance only to be charged by a computer player. Make it fair or f*ck right off.3. Make the percentage the actual percentage. I wish I knew enough about programming to be able to read whatever code is going on in the background, but I seem to miss a lot more 70%, 80%, or even 95% chance to hit than I should. 7 misses in a f*cking row at 85% to hit isn't fair, and it isn't fun. This doesn't make the game more enjoyable when you do this, it just makes it unplayable. I've already disbanded several games and deleted the saves because while progressive damage and even losing is fun, it's fun to lose when it's fair. If I go into a "difficult" or "punishing" mission, I expect to lose, or for it to be hard. If I go into an encounter and make multiple mistakes, I expect to lose. If I go into an "Average" mission and miss multiple attacks in the 80% hit chance, only to have the enemy counter, and fail to dodge/parry multiple attacks, and then get my whole warband wiped out because the enemy got 3 criticals and 2 of my guys fail their "all alone" saves, that's not expected, that's not fair, and that's not fun. Why do you guys do this with your games?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												As someone who has played the actual tabletop game, and still keeps several Warbands on hand (y'know, just in case)... I can very much reccomend this game to anyone that is a fan of the tabletop version. It has it's flaws, and there are bugs, but please keep in mind that this is an Early Access game. They are barely in alpha and aren't even finished making all the warbands.  I admit that the limitations of the program now do make it something that would be hard to play often, but as more features are released to people that have already bought it, the game will get much better. There are currently four warbands to choose from (June 2015) and they are Humans, Skaven, Sisters of Sigmar, and The Cult of the Possessed. The units included are all quite faithful to the source game, and the equipment loadouts are fairly self explainatory to anyone familiar with Mordheim, and easy enough to figure out for new players. Lack of leveling system is disappointing, but that will come in future updates. When the game is more complete it will have a lot more appeal to newer players, or people unfamiliar with the source material. Gameplay is fairly easy to figure out.  Move your character, perform action, etc. Combat animations look decent, the city has some nice detail and the maps look pretty good. Fun overall to play, though definately more fun with other players than against bots. The bots are fine if you just need a quick game, but for the best experience, play with friends.  All the best multiplayer games are ones that can end friendships. lol.TL:DR VERSION:   Good game. Currently would rate 6/10, only for limitations of early access version, but well worth investment. Great game, faithful to the source material, and fun to play with friends. 10/10 would buy again.UPDATE - Full Release Patch 2 -  Having played the campaign and had a chance to genuinely enjoy the game a bit now that it has hit full release, I can say that I still do not regret my decision to purchase this game. It remains a very playable, faithful adaptation of the classic tabletop game that still gets played in my house. Looking forward to the addition of more warbands and expanded content in the times to come.  10/10 would descend into the City of the Damned again.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												I made my mind up to give this a negative review pretty early in playing, but thought I'd give it a bit of an extra chance. Unfortunately, it's not really improved a great deal.I've played a lot of the Games Workshop games and I've enjoyed the vast majority of them. I liked the idea of Mordheim as something which has more of an inherent story built in as your warband develops and takes on progressively harder missions (unlike e.g. Dawn of War I which had very little natural storyline and Dawn of War II which moved away a fair bit from Warhammer 40,000). Unfortunately I felt they missed the opportunity to put in some sort of story campaign, or at least a heavier story element in to the pick your own adventure style campaign that is included.I'm not a huge fan of hardcore games (i.e. no saving and going back), but I appreciate that this is a conscious design decision by the makers. However, I feel that combining that hardcore element with a very steep learning curve decreases the chance that you'll actually keep playing long enough to hit an enjoyable point. I found myself repeatedly restarting as my warband increasingly reached the point where I couldn't do anything (e.g. everyone injured and no gold left). Perhaps it reaches a cruising point later on, but I've still never hit that and I feel like I've given it a fair crack.The warband tutorial is very dry and basically just gives you a slideshow of what all the buttons do. It doesn't give you worked examples which means you either have to remember it all, keep going back to the tutorials or just guess. They've tried to compensate for this by having guidance stuff at the beginning of every campaign you do, which gets pretty annoying if you've done it before. I think they could have combined the combat tutorials with a properly interactive warband tutorial to make a mini-campaign which would have been much more engaging.My main beef, however, with this game is the probabilities. Over my time playing it, I would say that 70-80% hit chances come off less than half the time. Perhaps I've been incredibly unlucky, but that's my experience. At best it makes the combat laborious as you wait for the whole turn cycle to go around again before you can attempt another hit. At worst, it screws you over as the opposition then piles a load of extra soldiers in to the combat and you lose all advantage that you had.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												A hesistant recommendation from me. It is a lot of fun and is mostly successful in translating both the mechanics and feel of the old tabletop game. However the RNG leaves me feeling so frustrated. Too many times do my 95% chances to hit work out as a miss. I know I shouldn't be taking probability personally but it just feels like extremely safe bets end up with failure due to consistent bad rolls. The percentage chances also don't square with reality - I have regularly had small percentage chances to hit large targets that were very near and in the open. The AI is also puzzling - I had a Skaven henchman run past 6 of my warband only to get the last hit on a wounded warlock at the back only to be cut down seconds later by his vengeful comrades. Skaven do not do that. Nobody rational does that - the AI was clearly programmed to prioritise him above everything else just to get the kill. The loading times are also long which doesn't really bother me but it might be frustrating for other users.It's a good game but in short frustrates me in a way the original never did.p.s. The Skaven need a nerf as of writing I have played ten games in a Skaven campaign and have won them all.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												I really like this game, it's addictive and is fun to play up to a point. But it is so demanding constantly, needing to earn gold to pay your warband, collect wyrdstones to send shipments and being constantly aware that one battle could be the end of your warband perminantly, even a technical win could result in a overall loss if some of your key members get poor RNG results at the end and end up loosing an arm or other injuries. While I do like the demanding nature of the campaign it makes the game something you can't really play when you're not paying full attention and it makes it feel not so much like fun to me. If they were able to introduce a way you could have duel profiles, one you could play seriously and was as it is now brutal, and one where things were more relaxed but not easy I think I would start recommending my friends to get this game rather than steer clear for now.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								While I've only just started the game, I can say for sure that of the warhammer video game adaptations I've played, this is by far the best. Playing it on max graphics definitely lives up to the videos and screen shots that I've seen. The animations are still a little glitchy, but understandable for a very early release game. The movement could use some fine tuning as well. It can get annoying when you disengage from one enemy, try to walk around another and get pulled right back into combat. Overall despite the lack of players on at the moment, this is an absolute buy for any strategy game player. It takes all best tactical elements of xcom and brings it to the next level with a warhammer twist. But do not let the comparison fool you, this game brings much of it's own to the table compared to any other stategy. I can't wait to see upcoming patches and the full release.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												Mordheim: City of the Damned .An awesome game that simply needs polishing or at least modding....A hardcore game , 300% hardcore . I love it and it reminds me of X-Com: Enemy Unknown.There are several thing i LOVE . 1:NO♥♥♥♥♥♥♥SAVING .2:It`s Warhammer Age of Sigmar.3:Factions ( Skaven (LOVE EM ) , Adepts of Chaos (Disappoting) , Sisters of Sigmar (never heard of em) , Mercs and Witch Hunters (OP if you ask me))4:Customization is cool but could be better.5:The city is♥♥♥♥♥♥♥amazing ! Traps , shady pathways , destroyed buildings and mutation starting to take over the city . But there are thing that could be some much better in this game like:1:Skills are kinda lame ... Some skills seem to even harm you if you learn em. I would preffer X-Com like skill system or Faction exclusive skills with neutral skills mixed in or something like that ....2:Objectives : Poorly executed. Why? Cause to win you need to do a Primary objective and it`s simple . Route or kill all enemies , easy peasy lemon in your eyes squeeze ( Gives you 2xp) . Secondary objective kill and loot marked enemies(easy) , collect warpstones(easy-hard) , steal opponents flag and bring it back(Brutal) . (Gives you 3XP) Last one is total BS .... Primary 2xp secondary 3xp .... Just meh....3: Battle difficulty  : What is difficulty level does in battles ? It buffes your enemies with more health and damage that`s it ... lame as hell ((( It is rewarding though but there is no point in getting stronger because your enemies will ALWAYS be as strong as you are and have the same unit setup. So as i said lame as hell... GIve enemies more units or allow enemies to have reinforcements like in campaign missions...4: Units death : You would think that if your unit died ... well he died. Nope not here , we have KO`s here with an axe or a greatsword to the head . LOL . But here is a thing your unit that was KOed has a random chance of dying , you won a battle but your leader got KOed and BANG he is dead FUN!!! Otherwise there is an injury system that is really cool but at the same time I just hate it .... It just doesnt make sense to me ... 5: Ai turns : are SLOW as hell when you dont see their units ... All in all a fun game, soooooo .... BUY IT ! Me want MORE games like this =^_^=PS: I WANT ORCS AND MORE UNITS !!!

Do no make my shield useless against an attack if I happen to not be in block stance.2. Charge VS Ambush. Make the Ambush range reasonable, or the charge range reasonable, or for god's sake put indicators on the ground. I cannot count the number of times I've been approaching an enemy in "Ambush" stance, setting up for a charge, only to get ambushed, when I CAN CLEARLY SEE THEM! On the other hand, I can count the one hundred million times I've been in "Ambush" stance only to be charged by a computer player. Make it fair or f*ck right off.3. Make the percentage the actual percentage. I wish I knew enough about programming to be able to read whatever code is going on in the background, but I seem to miss a lot more 70%, 80%, or even 95% chance to hit than I should. 7 misses in a f*cking row at 85% to hit isn't fair, and it isn't fun. This doesn't make the game more enjoyable when you do this, it just makes it unplayable. I've already disbanded several games and deleted the saves because while progressive damage and even losing is fun, it's fun to lose when it's fair. If I go into a "difficult" or "punishing" mission, I expect to lose, or for it to be hard. If I go into an encounter and make multiple mistakes, I expect to lose. If I go into an "Average" mission and miss multiple attacks in the 80% hit chance, only to have the enemy counter, and fail to dodge/parry multiple attacks, and then get my whole warband wiped out because the enemy got 3 criticals and 2 of my guys fail their "all alone" saves, that's not expected, that's not fair, and that's not fun. Why do you guys do this with your games?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												Personally, I dislike this game. Now don't let that get you down, because there's really nothing wrong with the game itself.If anything, if you're like me and you expect gameplay somewhat like turn-based dragon age, welp, you're looking in the wrong place. I think the best way to describe this game would be to compare it to darkest dungeon, but with better graphics and more confusion. And 3D. But of course, still the same amount of micromanagement, perma-death of characters, stress, and the game simply hating you. Another way to describe this game would be.... say... "turn-based dark souls". I think that should say enough.But hey, if you /are/ interested in a hardcore turn-based 3D game, then here's some stuff. This game allows you to choose between like, 6 factions, (two of which are dlc only but it won't tell you until you try to choose them), and build a warband with the units from that faction. With your warband, you go on missions, which are basically "matches", where characters take turns doing actions (order is determined by stats n' stuff) and you need to eliminate all enemies; there are also some side-objectives. This game has the kind of combat where you left click twice to attack, yet it is one of the most complicated combat systems I've seen, you know? Chances and stats and stuff? And targeting stuff? Ye. But don't expect to just go from mission to mission, left clicking enemies in a strategic way, no no no. You gotta assign stats n' stuff. You gotta equip yo units with stuff. You gotta let yo bois heal. You gotta hire new bois. You gotta manage "wyrdstones". And even in combat you gotta manage like 4 different resources per character every turn, like, no matter what. Basically it's hardcore af is what I'm saying.So ye. If you're up for a game that will take a while to get used to but then, like, you'll be used to it so you'll be like, liking it and stuff, and then you git gud n' stuff, and start understanding all the complicated stuff and... stuff... then ye. This is the 3D dark hardcore darkest dragon age dungeon board game for you. TLDR; It's complicated af, so only buy it if you know what it's like and want to get invested into it. Like, real deep n' stuff.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												If you like turned based strategy games you should pick this one up.  At over 100 hours I'm still on my first race.  The graphics are fine (nothing mind blowing), gameplay is fun.  I enjoy being able to use my movement points (SP) to wander around, then backtrack if I decide to take a different approach.  Real injuries that will have different effects on the party.  You can lose arms, legs, eyes, suffer brain injuries.  All of which will change the way the warrior plays the next time you play him.  Oh, and there is permanent death which really makes you want to make sure you plan out your attack the best way possible.Worth the price, but it seems to go on sale quite a bit if you want to wait.Pros-Fun-Challenging-Dark, depressing atmosphere really makes things menacing-Hits and missed attacks are critical     They can literally spell the difference between your warrior living or dying-Can be hardCons-Depressing losing trained warriors!     You spend a lot of time building up your army.  Losing your favorite warrior or having him/her suffer a gruesome injury      SUCKS-Injuries     These can wreck your party and force you to pick up a new warrior and start from rank 0-Predictable AI     After awhile you figure out the best (and only necessary) strategy is keeping everyone together, because your enemy      won't

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												I absolutely love the old warhammer lore, so I bought this game just to support that; I've wanted it ever since the MMO servers went down. That said, in 2015, strategy games do not have to be turn based to be tactical, and I feel like playing this leaves something to be desired. I feel like they have a very limited budget or something, which is a shame because the world itself is awesome.Edit: Updating my review since playing more with updates since early access. If someone were to put everything they've added to this game, instead to Vermintide, the result would be one of the best multiplayer fantasy slashers ever made, with a massive fanbase of active players. As it stands, the core game mechanics are turn based and dice rolls. The warhammer board game I played in the 80s had similar mechanics. I'm switching my review to positive because they really did add great content and Fatshark should take note. But in 2016 I can't go from playing Witcher 3, to rolling dice to see whether or not I can jump off a ledge for my turn.

												Purchased this during sale and havent stopped playing, was hesatent with the bad reviews.  But glad i got the game.  The gripes I saw were not enough factions, i'm sure it took alot just to do the current factions more in expansions maybe.  The perma death, wounds, and skill checks - heard alot of gripes on these, IT MAKES the Game to me.  You want to hit every time go play an RTS, a percentage is a percentage, yeah you can even miss on a 99% chance it's not rocket science.  I for one like the percentage ratios, Yeah it sucks for your favorite character getting a bad wound, but that's the breaks, protect it more, don't be a kamikaze.  I like the game for those reasons, it really gets my heart pumping when my favs are in a tough spot, im on the edge of my seat and if they die, then I just have to groom another character into my favorite.  So for me all the negatives other people seem to no like,  are extreme positives to me, it's what makes the game in my opinion.  I hope they make lots of Expansions for this game because i intend to play and play and do every warband faction, so it will be a while haha!!  MY only gripe is I have lots of people I can upgrade but can't because of money, maybe i'm doing something wrong, but i play lots of missions but somehow am always broke, maybe I need to open more chests, i used to not untill i started finding gold in them, now i try to get them.  So will see if my poverty stays.  BUT for anyone who loves Turn Based Tactics like I do and doesn't like a boring walk in the park,  THEN like me this Game is a Must have.  Wussies need not apply though haha, because it is not easy. it is a genuine Challenge...

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												First I'll state that I DO recommend this game if you like tactical games, however I'd like to point out that when you first start the game its extreamly hard due to how bad off the very first team will start, but the game is designed be like this as I'll explain.You start off with nothing, and the first few fights will likely see most of the starting warband (squad) wounded or dead, however all is not lost. As you complete fights win/lose, you gain Veteran points that improve the next warband for the next play through. I'll not say anymore in fear of spoiling the entire system set in place, but the game gets better the longer you play.If you are a person who resets a game at the first defeat or are always reloading from saves, than this game will frustrate you because there is no going back once a fight has started and no checkpoints to restore from. You have to learn to roll with the damage and carry on. After 24+ hours spent in straight fights I'm really loving the game and I'm still only on my first warband. Love the game, only downside I've really seen is the enmey AI will most the time simply shoot to kill and ignore any other objective.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												A hesistant recommendation from me. It is a lot of fun and is mostly successful in translating both the mechanics and feel of the old tabletop game. However the RNG leaves me feeling so frustrated. Too many times do my 95% chances to hit work out as a miss. I know I shouldn't be taking probability personally but it just feels like extremely safe bets end up with failure due to consistent bad rolls. The percentage chances also don't square with reality - I have regularly had small percentage chances to hit large targets that were very near and in the open. The AI is also puzzling - I had a Skaven henchman run past 6 of my warband only to get the last hit on a wounded warlock at the back only to be cut down seconds later by his vengeful comrades. Skaven do not do that. Nobody rational does that - the AI was clearly programmed to prioritise him above everything else just to get the kill. The loading times are also long which doesn't really bother me but it might be frustrating for other users.It's a good game but in short frustrates me in a way the original never did.p.s. The Skaven need a nerf as of writing I have played ten games in a Skaven campaign and have won them all.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												I like Mordheim.  If you have the system to run it.  It's an asynchronous adaptation of the original that's very pretty with a collection of neat tactical environments.The developers were quite good during Pre-Release in terms of responsiveness, and I think overall they pushed out a good product, unfortunately they no longer support 32-bit systems.  Early on when they updated there was a brief time when Mordheim would not work on 32-bit systems but it was soon corrected.  So I'm a little surprised now that despite the last words being "We're dedicated to our 32-bit fans and are working diligently to get it up and running on 32-bit systems" (a paraphrase rather than a quote), there's been no update to fix the issue or any further communication on the issue since October 2015?  You'd think that they could give us an update "We're still working on it" or "Yeah, we tried, but we can't get it done, sorry y'all."It happens that system requirements change, I can't be bitter about that, but this behavior strongly implies that the money has run out and that future patches/fixes are simply not forthcoming.  Since I can no longer play, I'm not sure if it's worth $40.  Get it on sale.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
Product received for free
												Note: My review is only based off of the experience that I've had during the free weekend trial that recently occurred.Mordheim: City of the Damned is a very good game.  It consists primarily of two parts, the first being warband management where you hire/fire/manage your mercenaries, deal with their items/skills, and fufill your wyrdstone delivery.  The second, is the primary part of the game, which is the turn based tactical strategy where your warband squares off against another warband in the ruinous city of Mordheim.  The graphics are decent but feel slightly dated if you zoom in a lot (a High-Res texture pack would be nice but definitely not necessary) and the sound and music are very fitting for the game.  However, graphics and sound aren't as important; The strategy is where the game truly shines as there can be a lot of depth, planning, and positioning involved to come out victorious on the battlefield.  Unfortunately, as good as the game is, I can only recommend it to people who are okay with the following points. Early game difficulty - The game can be extremely brutal to players early on in the game if not played properly.  As you progress through the game, you'll gain access to better gear, enchantments, etc that increases your troops' effectiveness and reliability to the point where you'll consistently win if you don't make terrible decisions/mistakes. RNG screwing you over - The RNG can screw you over.  Now, to make it clear, there are a lot of reviews out there that claim that they miss consistently with 80% chance to hit.  I would just like to point out that most of these people are missing the fact that the enemies tend to be in a defensive stance at the end of their turn.  You need to pass the chance to hit roll AND the enemy has to fail their dodge/parry roll in order to hit.  But back to the point of RNG, early game is where RNG is the most volatile and 60% chance to hit feels like 20% and 80% feels like 50%.  I've had times where I failed a climb up with 82% and then failed the proceeding one at 92%.  Or times when you attack one single enemy with 4 of your units and they all miss.  There were some runs where most of enemy team spawned closer to my cart than my own team did.  It's RNG, the only thing you can do is learn how to improve your chances or how to handle it.   The game is extremely TEDIOUS -  Some of it is due to bad design (I'll expand more on that later), and progressing through the game can be very slow at the beginning since the battles can be VERY time consuming, especially since you want to minimize risk at the beginning.  And if you want to complete the side objectives for additional Exp and items, you'll usually have to do it after a good majority of the enemy team is dead but before they rout meaning you'll have to keep several of them alive on purpose and tank them in order to do the side objectives.  You can spend hours on a character only to have him/her fall in combat once and all of a sudden, he/she is missing a body part and is now suffering from brain damage and now has to pass stupidity rolls every turn (It IS possible to get a full recovery after falling in combat but is very unlikely without using an item).  Or he/she is dead.  Hours of work down the drain from one mistake.  But that's life.The AI is decent but isn't always consistent.  There are times that they'll see you, hide out of line of sight, and then flank your archer out of nowhere but there are also plenty of times where they'll run into your band one or two at a time and you can basically overpower them if you've kept your band together.  There are also pathing issues that are very apparent when they run into an invisible wall such as a long wooden ramp leading up into a broken mansion and they get stuck there, allowing you to slowly whittle them down with your ranged units.  The AI also seems to have more health and deal more damage than you do.  I suppose it's to compensate for their lack of human ingenuity, but I've never liked artificially inflated difficulty that's achieved by throwing in more health and damage.There are also a lot of design choices that don't make any sense to me.  For example - Jump up in place a couple feet (if you can).  When you land, do you feel like it hurts more than jumping off the third floor? Put your hand on your keyboard.  Now move your body over to the left or right about an inch.  Are you suddenly unable to touch your keyboard anymore? Are you often unable to put any textbooks into a schoolbag because you've already put 4 pencils in that bag? Do you often go to work and at the end of the work day, leave work immediately without your belongings or your paycheck because the work day is over and you must leave exactly on the dot?If you've answered yes to these questions, then you are probably existing in Mordheim!  OR you're an out of shape Tyrannosaurus Rex with huge pencils and a possible developmental disorder and you should probably go to a doctor to get it checked out (the out of shape and huge pencils part that is, being a T-Rex sounds awesome).If you fail a climb up, you not only fail to climb up (duh) but you also take damage, up to 13 for jumping up a couple feet (Skavens do land on their back, I'll admit, they deserve that damage).  Most of the time, I've been seeing 9+ damage for failing climbs...  Meanwhile, failing a roll for jumping off the floor is...  6-16. And this is entirely unaffected by the armor class you're wearing.  So it's very VERY possible for you to be wearing cloth armor, jump up a couple feet and take MORE damage than you would if you were wearing heavy armor and jumping off the third floor.The next couple design choices make the game extremely tedious.  You get action prompts for certain things in the right positioning, such as picking up wyrdstone.  Unfortunately, move a pixel and poof, all of a sudden you lose the prompt for it.  I can't recall how many times I've gotten the prompt to do something, double clicked but apparently shifted a bit, and boom, I'm in dodge stance.  It's even worse when you do it in front of your wagon chest, as not only are you unable to deposit your items with that character that turn, you also block the your other characters from depositing items because no matter how close they are to the chest, they have to stand on THAT particular spot in order to open the chest.  Another time this gets tedious is when you're picking up Wyrdstones and they're all in a group.  You'd think you can pick them all up in one go if they're that right next to each other but NOPE, you have to pick them up ONE AT A TIME.  And sometimes, you're not in range for a particular wyrdstone EVEN THOUGH YOU'RE PRACTICALLY ON TOP OF IT.  Which means you'd have to move and that costs a strategy point because you'll perform an action.  And items (other than gold) don't stack either meaning a wyrdstone fragment takes up the same amount of space as a piece of armor.  This makes ferrying items to your wagon chest extremely tedious.  And the worst offender in this game?  The battle ends as soon as the enemy warband routs or their last member dies.  You immediately leave the map without being able to pick up any items.  Yes, a small portion of whatever is left on the map is picked up when you win but you have no control over it so it could be (and usually is) the most worthless stuff in the map while you ended the match in front of a whole bunch of wyrdstone clusters.  All these design choices make the game THAT much more tedious and difficult in a bad way.I also found myself constantly opening the map to check my positions (that map also needs a car mirror/camera disclaimer that objects on the map are closer than they appear) so a mini map would make that part of the game that much less tedious.Overall: Recommend but not for everyone.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												I thorougly enjoy this game. It offers the tactical gameplay I have been craving. I entered during the early-access period and while for awhile it was dissapointing, the developers have certainly delivered on their promises. Mordheim offers a rogue like flavor with the ability of your warband members to become severly injured, both physically and mentally, and even die during the campaign. The ability for you to play against other people and have the same consequences of playing the campaigns is a big draw. Don't fret however if your warband becomes crippled. Your profile maintains passive advancements for being a warband leader, such as lower cost hiring of new warriors, or training old ones. So if you need to dismiss either a few people or your entire warband you still maintain some key forward momentum.The few complaints I have include the extensive load times, and a bit of lack of explanation in some abilities. The self cast abilities and some spells don't quite have enough explanation for what they actually do. So unless you can remember rather well you either have to test it once during the mission or write it down. This is balanced by the fact that the advancement is paced well enough, that you use the abilities with such a high occurence to become familiar with them until you purchase and train in your new ones.I Recommend this game to anyone who enjoys brutal, competitive, and tactical gameplay with a grim and dark fantasy setting. 8/10
