content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												A nice suprise.Never played Morhiem table top, but love the WH world, so figured why not give it a try.Good:-Its different than other strat games. Its not Xcom with WH skins, its not Jagged Allaince with WH skins. Its a different type all in its own.-The models are amazing. I am in love with playing with my little Skaven warband. All the models look great.-Lots of options to customize your warband. From tanky to quick, from range to melee, etc. etc. So far it seems like you can make 2 warbands of the SAME faction and play them totally different.-The premise of "Mordhiem" is awesome. Looting a city to fulfill an order while competing with other warbands...very neat.Bad:-I know...I know...Mordheim is hardcore. At the same time its a GAME than needs to make MONEY. Appealing to more people (i.e. difficulty levels, saves, etc) would get more people that are dont play PC games to stroke their e-peen.-Wish there were more factions. Just 4? Yes they are done well, but dang...would love to see at least 2 more.-Performance. Its not bad, and load times are MUCH better, but still odd to get some slow downs now and then. -As a single player only, it would be cool to see some 1v1v1 fights, not just 1v1. All in all if you like Warhammer, and if you want something different you cant go wrong. If you are turned off by upper difficutly (although I hear its gets easier) watch some lets plays.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												If Xcom & Warhammer were put in a blender, mixed up a bit, you would end up with Mordheim City of the Damned.The game is good; but; can come over brutally unfair. I've only played 6 hours, and already had to restart a couple times either due to failing a mission putting me in a downward spiral of debt or just not understanding the mechanics of the game (in my first play thou').There is a bewilding array of stats and options available, my advice is to just dive in and start playing. Give the tutorial missions a whirl first to get a grips of the game then go for it. As you play you will grasp the stats and what is going on, I guess one small gripe with the game is a lot of things are not explained. A glossary or some way to look up terms would help;  over a few games I realised pressing B shows Buffs, press it again will show the debuffs.Another feature I'd like to see added is a small map in the bottom right corner of the screen (UI). When starting any mission I spend a good few minutes switching between the map just to make sure I am heading in the direction I thought I was.Games can be tense, maybe feel unfair, especially if one of your warband get caught out. I done a quick video let's play video if you want to see more, I've playing as Skaven. :)

content:
Posted: January 7
												Another great game for masochists, are you a good strategist? Too Bad!  Feel the hateful touch of RNG-sus!  nearly every action has a percent chance to succeed which you can pretty much ignore because of how often a chance over 90% will still fail.  You would think the point of the game is the combat, but no.  You lose the game if you don't collect enough green junk off the map and keep your squishy losers alive to deliver the junk to your loan agent.  That's a bigger pain than it sounds like since you essentially have to gather crap before any of the enemies show up.  Once any enemies appear they make a beeline for the first of your characters they see and Jack them up.  If you want any of your team to survive you have to give up on everything but fighting and hope you nabbed enough greenies to pay off your warband loan for the week.       I can't imagine using a caster enough to train one up to being good, especially considering most of the magic seems to punish you to varying severities just for using it.  How does a spell that curses the caster with random ailments in order to give a character +10% chance to hit but they also receives 10-20 damage whenever they attack sound?  Laugh or rage whenever your agile rat archer fails to climb a brick wall and busts their♥♥♥♥♥  Start off your campaign by having your mushy fresh characters get wrecked by the automatically superior forces in the first few levels.  It's pretty tricky to feel confident in your warbands' future when most of your troopers are permanently crippled or dead from the first few missions.    This game can be summed up in two activities.  Desperately push your plodding troopers to loot a map for meteor boogers then engage your oponent in frustrating match of miss me dodge you while holding your lucky rabbits foot and four leaf clovers to pray for a lucky win.  This game can produce some really intense frustration when your characters suck and die through countless horrible rolls of the dice.  10/10- I must be lucky! I missed that attack with a 95% chance to hit!

content:
Posted: January 15
												It's good, my favorite of the X-COM-alikes. I played Skaven, Empire, and Undead and progressed until I had a level 10-ish warband in each. A few pros and cons:Pros:1. Races feel distinct and none feels too strong or too weak. Weapons and armor feel balanced.2. The game does a good job in making you use tactics and the environment to win over an enemy that will almost always be stronger than you are. As Empire, I had a clump of ranged that moved around and focused individual stragglers or used chokepoints while my tanks took damage. As Skaven, I was mobile enough to converge first in the missions where you start out in separate packs. As Undead, i'd have zombies distract and occupy enemies while my crypt horror and vampires focused the rest down. 3. RNG is just right for me. Part of tactical games is to have a backup for your tactic; if my 85% chance to hit guy misses...what do I do? I've never had those one in a million streaks some of these other commenters have. One in a thousand? Sure. But not one in a million.Cons:1. Campaign missions aren't very good. Endless waves of reinforcements while you try to get that last objective. 2. AI will get stuck on stuff. The large creatures especially will get stuck on stuff. That ends up giving a lot of variance to the difficulty. 3. Many of the skills are almost never worth using. Overall pretty good and worth buying (maybe on 50% sale, those come around fairly often).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												Third mission - A Rat Ogre tears off my best archers right arm.  Not willing to pay for his recovery, the man suffers for a few days and dies alone in the ruins of Mordheim.  The city is both capricious and cruel. Not only does it make you fear the consequences of every misstep, it gleefully punishes you for each one.  There is no "save-and-quit, try again".  There is no mercy in Mordheim; expect none and give none.  The true god of the setting, the RNG (or Tzeentch for the knowledgeable), is fickle and treacherous.  Trust not in the 95% chance hit, for it is a lie.  All is a lie - there is only Warpstone, and gold.  Glory, truth, honor, chivalry - leave these at home, for the city will drink your tears if strive for them.  There is only survival.This game is really fun.  I've never quite played a game with this degree of difficulty.  It's the Dark Souls of tactical RPGs, but at least Dark Souls has save points,  This might sound like its not for you, but trust me.  Every victory is all the sweeter when it came at the cost of one of your henchmen's eyes and a harrowing, intense battle amidst the insanity of Mordheim.

content:
Posted: January 12
												All in all, the game is fun, with a high replayability. You can quickly get attached to your warband characters and will feel woefully sorry if one of your highlevel soldiers looses an arm or a leg or gets killed on a mission. The six warband all have their distinctive features and play differently enough to use them all. Levelling options give you a great number of choices - better than XCOM2. Character customization is o.k. but  might be improved (more head or at least hat types) and a little less varied than in XCOM2. The game itself is fair enough, you can choose between "Normal", "Hard", "Brutal" and "Deadly" mission types. So far I have only attempted "Normal" missions, as - depending on your starting position and your opponents - even these may be challenging at times. Story missions so far are o.k. as long as you can avoid mistakes like not keeping your warband together. Beware that the game runs always in "Ironman mode", there is no savescumming and when your characters die or get maimed, they stay dead or crippled. Perhaps the introduction of some exit points on the maps would be a good idea. At the moment you can only "abandon" a mission  at the cost of injuries to all party members or end the mission by failing a party morale check - difficult if you have high leadership stats, as that means you will have to have almost all your high ranking characters out of action before party morale falls below the critical value.There could be more maps though. However the existing maps are big and as starting positions and weather conditions (day, night, fog) vary it doesn't get too boring. But two or three more maps would be nice. Hopefully the devs keep adding content to this game. It's much better than "Darkest Dungeon" and almost on par with XCOM2.

content:
Posted: January 8
												Well having played Warhammer... and its cousin Warhammer 40K in the Tabletop game mode.... you could say I was pretty prepared for how brutal this game can be. You absolutely need tactical play or it will grind you to dust. Always have a backup plan, you are playing Chess, where each piece and its move matters. And even if you do everything right... bad luck can bring you down. Yes, I admit its incredibly atmospheric, strategic, and tactical. I love this game... but yeah I can easily see how it could make you rage quit at times. BUT... yes... even when things look their bleakest... you can still win.... just when you least expected to. I recommend this to anyone who likes a challenge, and a tactical one at that.

												If Xcom & Warhammer were put in a blender, mixed up a bit, you would end up with Mordheim City of the Damned.The game is good; but; can come over brutally unfair. I've only played 6 hours, and already had to restart a couple times either due to failing a mission putting me in a downward spiral of debt or just not understanding the mechanics of the game (in my first play thou').There is a bewilding array of stats and options available, my advice is to just dive in and start playing. Give the tutorial missions a whirl first to get a grips of the game then go for it. As you play you will grasp the stats and what is going on, I guess one small gripe with the game is a lot of things are not explained. A glossary or some way to look up terms would help;  over a few games I realised pressing B shows Buffs, press it again will show the debuffs.Another feature I'd like to see added is a small map in the bottom right corner of the screen (UI). When starting any mission I spend a good few minutes switching between the map just to make sure I am heading in the direction I thought I was.Games can be tense, maybe feel unfair, especially if one of your warband get caught out. I done a quick video let's play video if you want to see more, I've playing as Skaven. :)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
Product received for free
												Note: My review is only based off of the experience that I've had during the free weekend trial that recently occurred.Mordheim: City of the Damned is a very good game.  It consists primarily of two parts, the first being warband management where you hire/fire/manage your mercenaries, deal with their items/skills, and fufill your wyrdstone delivery.  The second, is the primary part of the game, which is the turn based tactical strategy where your warband squares off against another warband in the ruinous city of Mordheim.  The graphics are decent but feel slightly dated if you zoom in a lot (a High-Res texture pack would be nice but definitely not necessary) and the sound and music are very fitting for the game.  However, graphics and sound aren't as important; The strategy is where the game truly shines as there can be a lot of depth, planning, and positioning involved to come out victorious on the battlefield.  Unfortunately, as good as the game is, I can only recommend it to people who are okay with the following points. Early game difficulty - The game can be extremely brutal to players early on in the game if not played properly.  As you progress through the game, you'll gain access to better gear, enchantments, etc that increases your troops' effectiveness and reliability to the point where you'll consistently win if you don't make terrible decisions/mistakes. RNG screwing you over - The RNG can screw you over.  Now, to make it clear, there are a lot of reviews out there that claim that they miss consistently with 80% chance to hit.  I would just like to point out that most of these people are missing the fact that the enemies tend to be in a defensive stance at the end of their turn.  You need to pass the chance to hit roll AND the enemy has to fail their dodge/parry roll in order to hit.  But back to the point of RNG, early game is where RNG is the most volatile and 60% chance to hit feels like 20% and 80% feels like 50%.  I've had times where I failed a climb up with 82% and then failed the proceeding one at 92%.  Or times when you attack one single enemy with 4 of your units and they all miss.  There were some runs where most of enemy team spawned closer to my cart than my own team did.  It's RNG, the only thing you can do is learn how to improve your chances or how to handle it.   The game is extremely TEDIOUS -  Some of it is due to bad design (I'll expand more on that later), and progressing through the game can be very slow at the beginning since the battles can be VERY time consuming, especially since you want to minimize risk at the beginning.  And if you want to complete the side objectives for additional Exp and items, you'll usually have to do it after a good majority of the enemy team is dead but before they rout meaning you'll have to keep several of them alive on purpose and tank them in order to do the side objectives.  You can spend hours on a character only to have him/her fall in combat once and all of a sudden, he/she is missing a body part and is now suffering from brain damage and now has to pass stupidity rolls every turn (It IS possible to get a full recovery after falling in combat but is very unlikely without using an item).  Or he/she is dead.  Hours of work down the drain from one mistake.  But that's life.The AI is decent but isn't always consistent.  There are times that they'll see you, hide out of line of sight, and then flank your archer out of nowhere but there are also plenty of times where they'll run into your band one or two at a time and you can basically overpower them if you've kept your band together.  There are also pathing issues that are very apparent when they run into an invisible wall such as a long wooden ramp leading up into a broken mansion and they get stuck there, allowing you to slowly whittle them down with your ranged units.  The AI also seems to have more health and deal more damage than you do.  I suppose it's to compensate for their lack of human ingenuity, but I've never liked artificially inflated difficulty that's achieved by throwing in more health and damage.There are also a lot of design choices that don't make any sense to me.  For example - Jump up in place a couple feet (if you can).  When you land, do you feel like it hurts more than jumping off the third floor? Put your hand on your keyboard.  Now move your body over to the left or right about an inch.  Are you suddenly unable to touch your keyboard anymore? Are you often unable to put any textbooks into a schoolbag because you've already put 4 pencils in that bag? Do you often go to work and at the end of the work day, leave work immediately without your belongings or your paycheck because the work day is over and you must leave exactly on the dot?If you've answered yes to these questions, then you are probably existing in Mordheim!  OR you're an out of shape Tyrannosaurus Rex with huge pencils and a possible developmental disorder and you should probably go to a doctor to get it checked out (the out of shape and huge pencils part that is, being a T-Rex sounds awesome).If you fail a climb up, you not only fail to climb up (duh) but you also take damage, up to 13 for jumping up a couple feet (Skavens do land on their back, I'll admit, they deserve that damage).  Most of the time, I've been seeing 9+ damage for failing climbs...  Meanwhile, failing a roll for jumping off the floor is...  6-16. And this is entirely unaffected by the armor class you're wearing.  So it's very VERY possible for you to be wearing cloth armor, jump up a couple feet and take MORE damage than you would if you were wearing heavy armor and jumping off the third floor.The next couple design choices make the game extremely tedious.  You get action prompts for certain things in the right positioning, such as picking up wyrdstone.  Unfortunately, move a pixel and poof, all of a sudden you lose the prompt for it.  I can't recall how many times I've gotten the prompt to do something, double clicked but apparently shifted a bit, and boom, I'm in dodge stance.  It's even worse when you do it in front of your wagon chest, as not only are you unable to deposit your items with that character that turn, you also block the your other characters from depositing items because no matter how close they are to the chest, they have to stand on THAT particular spot in order to open the chest.  Another time this gets tedious is when you're picking up Wyrdstones and they're all in a group.  You'd think you can pick them all up in one go if they're that right next to each other but NOPE, you have to pick them up ONE AT A TIME.  And sometimes, you're not in range for a particular wyrdstone EVEN THOUGH YOU'RE PRACTICALLY ON TOP OF IT.  Which means you'd have to move and that costs a strategy point because you'll perform an action.  And items (other than gold) don't stack either meaning a wyrdstone fragment takes up the same amount of space as a piece of armor.  This makes ferrying items to your wagon chest extremely tedious.  And the worst offender in this game?  The battle ends as soon as the enemy warband routs or their last member dies.  You immediately leave the map without being able to pick up any items.  Yes, a small portion of whatever is left on the map is picked up when you win but you have no control over it so it could be (and usually is) the most worthless stuff in the map while you ended the match in front of a whole bunch of wyrdstone clusters.  All these design choices make the game THAT much more tedious and difficult in a bad way.I also found myself constantly opening the map to check my positions (that map also needs a car mirror/camera disclaimer that objects on the map are closer than they appear) so a mini map would make that part of the game that much less tedious.Overall: Recommend but not for everyone.

content:
Posted: March 4
												This game is adictive and somewhat fun when things go right or at least half right. Being set in the realy Warhammer Fantasy world helps a lot, think GW was wrong in killing it off, but that is different. Character development is interesting and allows you to do what you want. Combat is quick and feirce. And I have to say the challenge is there.Problems are, I can't make it to warband level 5, nor really ever get a character to level 5. Difficulty is high, even when fighting an "normal" battle. The AI seems to always have more luck then you, particularly when you have a 95% chance to hit, and sit there missing two or more times in a row. I never seem to find any usefull blue or purple gear. I find my self nearing warband level 5 and all the enemies are on steroids, not sure if their equipment is blue/purple but they always hit, and always seem to get the drop on my guys. At this point I typically lose 2 games in a row hard, and don't have any fit warriors left to fight. I get loseing guys is part of the game, but 3 in a game is rough, twice in a row, and now you have level 0 guys fighting full upgraded level 3 and 4s, just makes things go south fast. So yea, while challenging, it is far more frustrating then pure enjoyment.

								I was very disappointed when the first Warhammer games were RTS. Warhammer is all about Turn Base Strategies and Mordheim puts the tabletop at your control. Creating your own warband and then placing them on the map seeing an actual battle take place from their point of view one move at a time. I feel they had captured the spirit of the tabletop game and I cannot reccomend it anymore than I do. Big thumbs up from me for finally bringing turn based to Warhammer since that was what it's meant to be. Now the hardest part of the game is trying to figure out which faction I want to play.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's pretty good considering that it's still in development, I hope they'll add an RTS style strategy view at some point. It's playable right now and I haven't really found any bugs other than occasional AI pathing errors that result in the AI being unable to complete their turn, as well as the game not realizing whose turn it is and being stuck at "Waiting for opponent" but I'm certain the devs have already acknowledged the existence of these bugs and are going to fix them in the future.Currently, the game is quite bare bones (that is certain to change). You can play as 3 factions (though they'll be adding the carnival of chaos soon) and are currently unable to customize your heroes and henchmen very much at the moment, other than in equipment. Classes, stats and abilities remain unchangeable at the moment. Also, currently the only visual differences between units of the same class are in weapons, but I'm sure they'll be adding visual differences between heavy armor, light armor and clothing in the future. Can't wait until they add progression, I want to see my inexperienced skaven thugs turn into true clan Eshin assassins. I do hope you'll be able to customize the name of your heroes, henchmen, and warband in the future, for the sake of other players, anyways (assuming you can't do that now, and I'm just clueless). I'm perfectly happy with my (hopefully) randomly generated warband, "The Murderous Murderers of the Murderlord".Graphics are great too, but I am unfortunately unable to experience graphics without lag (i still lag on lowest settings) because I have a weaksauce non-gaming graphics card.Overall, there's a lot of content that hasn't been added yet, but there's a lot of awesome sounding stuff listed as coming soon. I hope the developers deliver. Seems like it'll make a fun game.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												If you were expecting a faithful interpretation of the original tabletop game then prepare for disappointment for this is not the game you're looking for. The only similarities between this game and the original are that you're playing a warband management and battle game that has character progression, random loot tables and is set in GW universe's Mordheim. Deeper inspection, however, reveals that even these shared attributes are more dissimilar than they are similar.I'll start with my number one grievance with the game that is also the main thing you'll spend your time on: combat.The combat in the tabletop Mordheim is about odds calculation, risk assessment and careful positioning that aims to maximize the risks your opponent must take while minimizing your own. There's strategic beauty and elegance to this general concept that reveals itself to you when you start to comprehend the multitude of variables and see the matrix open before your eyes.In the PC game, however, you have no easy way of assessing how far you can move and you have no idea about the ranges of attacks and abilities. The camera is set behind the character whose turn it is, and despite the function that lets you see the entire map from above, you generally struggle to get an idea where you are and how to get where you want. Often you waste several turns just trying to navigate out of a multi-level house because there are only couple of set points you can jump down from and you can't openly inspect the map to find them. Sufficient information is simply not provided to you, which forces you to adapt a trial and error approach, which erodes any strategic merits the game might have otherwise had.The game also uses its own way of calculating hit chance, damage, armor saves, stats and even health that differ entirely from the tabletop game, making the game less accessible for us experienced with tabletop Mordheim.  Fair enough, the tabletop version is by no means perfect, byt why would you replace that system with something alien, more complex, and arguably, even worse?As if all of this wasn't enough the developers also added a horrible UI that makes even the simple task of charging an enemy a fiddly process that requires you to move your character back and forth to find the right distance from the enemy to enable the action. Each character also has their own 'bubble' that stops you from taking actions if you enter them, making positioning a constant nightmare, especially since, as mentioned above, you have no sense of ranges.And then we have the A.I... I really don't get it why the devs get this so wrong so often. No, you can't make up for bad A.I. by giving it an artificial advantage over the player in form of better stats and gear. That's the cheap way of doing it and ends up with A.I. that is is incredibly unrewarding and frustrating to face but at the same time easily abuseable. I'd go so far as to say that even if all the other issues were ignored the terrible state of the A.I. alone makes the campaign mode unplayable.The final insult to us who now prefer PC versions over the tabletop games because the real life version takes too much time, is make us wait for the A.I. to finish all its moves, slowly, one character at a time, even when the movement is not visible to the player... Why would you make your players wait and stare at the screen for nothing?The thing I personally enjoy the most in these type of games is the leveling and character management system. I just love seeing my guys advance, get new skill and stats, better gear etc. Unfortunately, this was also ruined by a stat restricted system that forces you to spend vast amounts of gold and several campaign turns to learn a new skill. You can't exactly go fight without your leader, and each wasted turn makes it harder for you to complete the time based objectives the game gives you.If I sound needlessly harsh it's because I am tired. Tired of seeing developers time and time again waste golden opportunities by taking something with good concept and great theme and then, rather than improving on the original games while staying as faithful as possible, proceed to s*it all over it and give birth to an abomination only Clan Moulder packlords could appreciate.

content:
Posted: March 24
												**********RECIEVED ON HUMBLE MONTHLY*******************Fantastic underrated game! I wish there were more people to play against in multiplayer it really is a lot of fun. Single player is a great time and I have been waiting for a game like this for awhile. You have your persistent warband that stays with you in multiplayer and you really get attached to them so when they get injured you have to change your strategy.My first warband I made when I was first trying out the game was terrible and I just threw a bunch of guys together. It was awesome. I knew it was gonna be great fun when my leader lost his arm and his leg and it really shows it in the character model and changes his stats! He had a cute peg leg and could dodge REALLY well. Could only hold a dagger but it didnt matter it was ♥♥♥♥n hilarious. Throughout my playthrough many of my warband lost limbs and I think that I just got really bad luck. But it also made me invest in agility and changed how I played. It was LIT.Get this game! It has amazingly deep gameplay and customization, you could spend hours figuring out how you're going to outfit your group. GET IT it's lit fam

												I actually had no problems whatsoever from the performance side, except for one thing that kills this game completely for me and i don't see myself playing it any further. The waiting times while the AI moves drive me crazy. I started to Alt Tab out of the game because i was getting sick waiting. (i AM an impatient person). Waiting for hidden movement to be done while they loot, jump, and whatever the f*** they do is not fun.I was looking forward to a hardcore game, everything looks great from what i've seen but the waiting, i can't take it, let me speed this up and i might reconsider it, huge design failure in my book. (Apartently technical difficulties)

content:
Posted: January 30
												I wanted to like this game. Honestly I did. I Uninstalled and reinstalled at least 3 times before i left it for good, if that tells you how conflicted i was. I'll throw down some pros and cons then elaborate on specifics.Pros: +visually pleasing considering the time+elaborate and complex combat/level up system+loot system: special weapons and items can be found at random on quests+customizable teams: decently customizable. Each individual can have their color and costume changed as well as be given unique items and weapons to improve combat capabilities+3 playable factions(more with dlc)+Perma-death and permanent consequences(pro for hardcore game lovers)Cons:-Failure Countdown: you are expected to ship a certain number of 'crystals' to your faction leader every few weeks and the number is always ridiculously high at lower levels. you are allowed a few failures on this, but but the game only lasts as long as you can keep sending these 'crystals'.-No gameplay variance: the only, ONLY way to play this game successfully is with the element of surprise. Stick to shadows and pray to god you aren't spotted first. This style of play can be fun, but it gets old. There needs to be more options than the whole cloak and dagger routine. -the dlc are in the game already, but you can't use them. They show up when you first select your faction and you think "oh cool, i'm gonna be these undead guys cause that sounds cool" but nope, you gotta buy dlc for that♥♥♥♥♥♥ That's them just flagrantly slapping you in the face with the "you just payed for our game, so we'll try milking you for more money by showing you what you're missing out on by not buying the dlc" card. Real douchey move. Especially for a full priced game. When all said and done, all of these sins are forgivable. This however, is not. The A.I. is complete BS. They know. They just KNOW. They know where every item on the map is,they know the map layout, they know what to do and exactly when to do it, the only thing they don't know is your position before you are discovered(it's like they're oblivious morons to your whereabouts beforehand), but once you're found, there's no way to escape their pursuit. The most BS thing about their A.I. though, their turn time. Never, not once, did a turn of mine last even remotely close tothe time of one of theirs. Even my longest most thought out turns against their most simplistic, theirs is longer. Too much time is spent watching your troops stand around looking stupid. Seriously, half my time spent in this game was waiting for the bot to finish its turn. And that is an unforgivable, unredeamable flaw. If that were fixed, this would be a highly enjoyable and challenging game. but alas, the developers couldn't figure out how to make their A.I. think its moves a little quicker even though they already know all the details about the map and where they need to go. Good day gentlemen and ladies.
